paragraphCards.markdown: It takes a lot of guts to write a book about one of your most embarrassing moments in life –but the boldness sure paid off!
This book is perfect for any meditation-skeptics, because Harris was one too. ![giphy.com/nightline/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1BTwZS5q3EhvpKbo0/giphy.gif)

10% Happier explains meditation techniques and focuses on the benefits, both of which are much more important for beginners.

insights.title: Your ego gets in the way of your happiness by constantly wanting more

actions.title: Stop comparing yourself to others.
actions.markdown: In our social media age, it’s easy to identify others who are seemingly smarter, more successful, or better looking than ourselves. But remember there’s much more to social media than meets the eye--and no one does YOU like you do. Celebrate that!

paragraphCards.markdown: The friction between acting in the present, but constantly thinking about the future and past, is what gives our ego its insatiable appetite.
Our ego constantly assesses our worth by looking at our wealth, looks and social status, and then finding the next best person with more of it to compare it against.
Therefore, our ego's default setting is always more. ![https://giphy.com/mushisca/](https://media.giphy.com/media/YQ5TIv9sGI7T2O0D3y/giphy.gif)
The minute we feed our ego a new achievement, toy or compliment, the baseline for desire is reset, and it starts hunting for its next goal.
Our egos thrive on drama and worry, and will instantly look for the next bigger achievement to compare yourself to.
If none is there, it'll dig up some ancient problem or crisis, and pester us with it instead...

That's why the ego is never happy, and it's up to us to take charge of that, because no matter which new heights we reach, it'll never be enough. Time to reign it in! ![giphy.com/lucasscanto](https://media.giphy.com/media/McbLbWpEdwxTXnmax1/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Be simple, not a simpleton -- why letting go of your ego won’t make you a pushover

actions.title: Practice mediation to bring yourself back in balance.
actions.markdown: Throughout your day, pay close attention to the things that get you down. Beating ourselves up over things we can’t control--like something embarrassing things we said at a party, for example--is not useful to us. Keep moving forward!

paragraphCards.markdown: Now, we might say: "If my ego is my drive to achieve greater things, won't I lose my edge if I completely let go of it?"
Nope! That doesn't have to be the case at all. Quite the contrary. ![giphy.com/originals/](https://media.giphy.com/media/X7hRO9V7SAwaeCf9vb/giphy.gif)

Often people overdo it with the Buddhist attitude of letting go, and in some cases even end up letting other people order for them at restaurants in order not to express personal preference. ![giphy.com/lerabling/](https://media.giphy.com/media/UD2vKWlBBjtCjVB6OU/giphy.gif)
Indian meditation teacher Munindra taught his students to keep things simple and easy.
When one of them approached him during his fierce negotiation over the price of a bag of peanuts at the local market, they asked how this matched his earlier lesson.
Munindra replied: "I said be simple, not a simpleton!"
Mindfulness should make us more creative and productive, but not a pushover.
Meditation removes the need for competition, fuelling our drive by removing wrong assumptions and bad thoughts. ![giphy.com/lerabling/](https://media.giphy.com/media/cJ53VLbM1eEo4s1toi/giphy.gif)
Instead of the usual stress, we'll approach things more clearly, because we're not giving in to aggressive temptations.

Author Dan Harris found himself filling pages upon pages with notes during a meditation retreat, because his mind was less cluttered and chaotic, and his creativity flowed freely. ![giphy.com/nightline/](https://media.giphy.com/media/21LLW7sxQBbFKmyGl7/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Meditation makes you more mindful and compassionate by giving us a fourth habitual response

actions.title: Reflect on painful emotions before acting on them.
actions.markdown: Negative feelings, whether it be jealousy, anger, or anxiety, are human emotions. We all experience them. But don’t let them control you. Understand that these feelings are temporary--take a moment to cool down before acting rashly.

paragraphCards.markdown: So, what is it that meditation can help us do to tame the ego and fuel our drive? ![giphy.com/acosyreader](https://media.giphy.com/media/HnEAk9WH9oAI5ci1sD/giphy.gif)
Meditation makes us more mindful. It helps us live in the moment, as well as act more compassionately towards others.
Its method of achieving this is by giving us a fourth habitual response.
According to ancient Buddhist wisdom, we usually exhibit three characteristic habitual responses to all of our experiences:
We want it. Ever passed by a hamburger place when hungry? Yeah. That. ![giphy.com/FeliVillarreal/](https://media.giphy.com/media/60rUE5e0SYRPRl3vcS/giphy.gif)
We reject it. Ever had a spider land on your hand? Our instinct is normally to instantly throw it off. ![/giphy.com/donatellostudio/](https://media.giphy.com/media/erYRc7cubyPfK5hfIB/giphy.gif)

We zone out. Because we always listen to the flight attendant's safety instructions all the way to the end, right?...Yeah. Exactly. ![giphy.com/Harrrumph/](https://media.giphy.com/media/61TfdMnEQupbuWNJTH/giphy.gif)
Once we start meditating, though, we'll be able to choose a fourth alternative: Observing without judging.
It usually starts with physical pain. Our legs will become sore, or our nose itches, but we should (and can) resist the urge to scratch it, and just let it be.
After a while, this can-do attitude towards pain transfers to our emotions and thoughts as well. ![giphy.com/gaiama/](https://media.giphy.com/media/I1DjUddBdgy3rOS11m/giphy.gif)
We start to catch ourselves while gossiping, acting out on a bad habit, or thinking negative thoughts. ![giphy.com/yipan/](https://media.giphy.com/media/5Y9yzaDoGw6p3Iuvw2/giphy.gif)
The important thing to know is that we can just observe your feelings until they pass by, without reacting to them.
It's this little pause between thinking and acting that makes us realize that, often, no action is necessary, thus helps us to make better choices altogether.
"There's no point in being unhappy about things you can't change, and no point being unhappy about things you can." \[Dan Harris\]

Life as an ABC News correspondent must feel pretty good, right? The pay is great, millions of people know your face and name. ![giphy.com/GoodMorningAmerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/jt301Jk3iV2hd99274/giphy.gif)
But for some, the pressure can become too much – and they crack. ![giphy.com/FridayTV](https://media.giphy.com/media/TdGCK3hp5DFJdn84fx/giphy.gif)
This happened to author Dan Harris 12 years ago, when his voice broke in a live, on-air panic attack on national television. [youtube.com/c/ABCNews](https://youtu.be/_qo4uPxhUzU?t=54.32&e=95.24)
Embarrassed and humiliated, Harris was driven into self-reflection.
There began his long journey into the science of stress, which in turn introduced him to mindfulness.

Although originally a skeptic himself, Harris eventually learned to tame his ego with the power of meditation. In his 2014 bestseller, he shares those lessons with us. ![giphy.com/lillamraz](https://media.giphy.com/media/W2WLGDytcJ4cAUPRJi/giphy.gif)
10% Happier gives skeptics an easy 'in' to meditation, taking a very non-fluffy approach to the science behind this mindfulness practice.

Letting go of your ego is critical for living a stress-free life, and this handy guide pinpoints how and why we should do it. ![giphy.com/MindfulVibing](https://media.giphy.com/media/T6qTipNlmgXt0qAGSw/giphy.gif)

13 Things Mentally Strong Parents Don't Do is a valuable tool for parents of kids at any age. By following Morin's practical advice and learning to be mentally strong ourselves, we raise kids that will be able to handle challenges in adulthood.
The book has countless useful tactics and real-life that will help you empower your child.

insights.title: Help your child be responsible and persevere rather than be a victim

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The best way we can teach our kids is by example.
So if you want a child that's mentally strong, you need to start showing them what this looks like.
One way you can do this is by not encouraging a victim mentality.
It's natural for us to want to shield our children from things and defend them when they've been wronged.
But it's important to make sure you show them how to deal with life's challenges instead of viewing themself as a victim of circumstance.

An example Morin shares is a 14-year-old patient named Cody who was on medication for his ADHD. His teachers said the medication helped him pay attention and be calmer, but his grades weren't improving.
His parents responded by demanding he be given less work than the other students. But the problem wasn't in his workload - it was actually the result of learned helplessness.
His parents enforced the idea that his ADHD made him incapable, so he believed there was nothing he could do about it.
When they recognized the problem and helped him feel like he was able to handle these responsibilities, he started trying and turned his grades around.
When parents are mentally strong, they don't let kids shy away from assuming responsibility.
Hold your child accountable instead of letting them blame others for their problems.
Rather than just intervening and allowing them to blame others, encourage them to resolve conflict on their own.

insights.title: Don’t expect perfection or step in to help every time they mess up

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: A lot of parents view their kids as an extension of themselves.
Many secretly hope that if they push them to succeed in the things they didn't, they can help mend old wounds.
But pushing your kid to perfection is bad for their mental health.
When you expect perfection, they start to believe your love is conditional and you won't love them if they make a mistake.
If you want to make sure mistakes don't destroy their sense of self-worth, help them try for excellence rather than perfection.
Make sure you don't criticize too much. Morin says you can offer what she calls a praise-criticism-praise sandwich.
This can be like, "Great job cleaning up the playroom! I noticed you missed a few blocks, but you did great at cleaning up your markers."
When we expect perfection we also tend to micromanage and overstep, which leads kids to not learn how to bounce back when they make a mistake.
Helicopter parenting leads to kids not knowing how to make decisions in adulthood and struggling with taking care of their own needs.
These kids are more likely to have mental health problems, physical health problems, and do recreational drugs.
Instead of doing this, help them learn when they slip up that what's most important is how they overcome problems.
Talk with your child about times you recovered from setbacks so they can see nobody is perfect, and it's okay.

insights.title: Mentally strong parents only do things that match the values they teach

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: As parents, we get caught up in the day to day problems we face. But how often do we step back and wonder if we are teaching them the right life lessons?
Morin shares the story of a 15-year-old student named Kyle who got kicked out of his advanced school program when he was caught cheating.

His parents couldn't understand where things went wrong. Kyle's parents seemed to prize his academic performance above everything else, and they often bragged to friends and family about his achievements.

Kyle believed that their reputation and his grades were more important than character or honesty. In therapy, they realized they had indeed sent the message that he should avoid failure no matter what.

This example demonstrates the lesson that it's important to emphasize the values you want to instill, and you can do this more with what you do than what you say. A 2014 survey found 80% of teens believed their parents prioritized achievement over kindness.
One way you can make sure kids know what values are important is to make a family mission statement.
Have values you want to include beforehand, and with everyone's input, make a short statement about what's most important to your family. Post it somewhere they will see it.
You can also instill values early in life by explaining why you do good things when they are young.
You can explain that you are making dinner for a sick neighbor because it's important to do kind things for people.
Through your example, your child will learn through this that we use what we have to try to make the world around us a better place.
"Learning how to manage emotions and endure unpleasant feelings are skills that can be taught." \[Amy Morin\]

Everyone wants the best for their children. These days, parenting is more a problem of doing too much than too little. We all know parents who monitor their child's every move and swoop in to protect them at any sign of conflict or difficulty.
This type of parenting results in adults who are incapable of handling life's challenges on their own. So how can we avoid it?

There's no shortage of "how-to" books about parenting. But Amy Morin, psychotherapist and author of 13 Things Mentally Strong People Don't Do, argues it's just as vital that we know what habits we shouldn't teach our kids.
If we want children that are mentally strong we need to look first at our own detrimental behaviors.
In 13 Things Mentally Strong Parents Don't Do, Morin shares the common parenting practices that are holding your child back and teaches what you should do instead.

13 Things Mentally Strong Parents Don't Do teaches parents how to stop being a roadblock to their kids academic, behavioral, and emotional success by outlining ways to develop the right thinking habits.

paragraphCards.markdown: With this book, you know about everything important that's going on and can decide how to act on which information. Some topics, you won't think further about, others might even change how you raise your kids.
With 21 Lessons For The 21st Century, Yuval Noah Harari once again captures interesting aspects of humanity in enlightening stories.

insights.title: Data has become the most valuable asset, which is why technology disrupts all our systems

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Different ideologies have always shaped how humans see and steer the world. Whichever one grabs the most people tends to determine our history for decades.
In the 20th century, fascism, communism, and liberalism fought for that privilege. Liberalism ended up being the clear winner.
Depending on which ideology dominates, different assets grow in value.
Whatever's most valuable is the thing politicians and nations will fight for, thus deciding what future the world progresses towards.
So far, in the 21st century, technology seems to have all competitors beat. It's the thing we most believe in.
With technology being our prime ideology, data becomes the most valuable asset.
That's why politicians struggle for their nations to win the giant tech race. The problem is that this time around, no one fully understands the implications of our ideology.
Just look at the financial markets, where algorithms already do most of the work with very few traders grasping what's actually happening.
For politicians, this lack of understanding quickly becomes a threat. People are frustrated, feel ignored, and realize the representatives they elected don't deal with the most important topics.
And yet, we know just as little about technology as they do.

insights.title: We believe we have a lot of knowledge, but we don’t and that’s dangerous

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: In Germany, it's common for the minister of economics to suddenly become the minister of health. Highly specialized offices are swapped like Christmas presents, which makes no sense. How could someone be an expert in both medicine and military defense?
In reality, this problem befalls all of us, however. That's why we talk so much about cognitive biases - to help us think a little better.
One of them is what Yuval Noah Harari calls 'the knowledge illusion'.
Basically, we think we know a lot more than our ancestors when, actually, we know less in many regards.
For example, we all rely on many experts to live our everyday lives. We can't hunt our own food, build our own shelter, or make our own clothes.
We think we're smart, but just because we can access all the world's knowledge doesn't mean it's already in our head.
Instead, we should stay humble, be thankful, and do our best to never stop learning.

insights.title: School needs to start teaching us how to think, not what to think

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Neil deGrasse Tyson once gave a great speech on the value of knowing how to think vs. just knowing what to think. Sadly, our schools only teach us the latter.
Even higher education still very much centers around cramming as many facts into your head as you can, only to spit them out once on a piece of paper, then forget them again. That's a problem.
A basic understanding of history, biology, math, and other subjects is important, no doubt. But beyond that, it's more important that we learn how to navigate the modern sea of information.
We need to learn how to filter out the important, and how to determine what's downright false, instead of just remembering more facts.
With more data being created now in a single year than the past few millennia combined, future workers won't need to know as much as possible, but how to find out what they really need to know.
For our kids to have a thriving future, that's what we must teach them how to do.
"In a world deluged by irrelevant information, clarity is power." \[Yuval Noah Harari\]
How do you prepare your children for the year 2050? Or even the year 2100? It's a great question, especially because nowadays, no one knows what the world will even look like then.
Historically, humans could make at least decent assumptions about where the world was headed. But in today's fast-paced, technology-fueled civilization? Forget it!
However, that doesn't mean it's not worth giving our best to prepare for an uncertain future. In 21 Lessons For The 21st Century, Yuval Noah Harari helps us do just that.

After his previous bestsellers Sapiens, which explored the human past, and Homo Deus, which focused on our distant future, his latest book is about our biggest challenges in the here and now and how we can deal with them.
21 Lessons For The 21st Century highlights today's most pressing political, cultural, and economic challenges created by technology while helping us prepare for an uncertain future.
It's wise to challenge the way things have always been, and doing so for capitalism is enlightening.
It's especially interesting to consider the book's conclusion – that capitalism itself isn't the issue, but rather the way we implement it.

insights.title: Your financial choices aren’t rational and businesses take advantage of that, but governmental economic planning can help fix that

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: In the late 90s, two economists named Robert Merton and Myron Scholes received the Nobel Prize for their work.
Centering around the idea that people always make rational financial choices, they began applying their theories in the real world.
Rather than making it big, however, these two ended up broke.
While we want to think we act rationally when it comes to finances, the truth is most of us cannot.
The fatal flaw in their ideas is similar and foundational to many of the assumptions of free-market economics.
In reality, making completely rational choices requires having every possible detail and taking it into account.
Our best actions come when we look at all scenarios and alternative routes.
Unfortunately, there's no way that any of us can get that kind of vast information for every money decision we have to make.
Thus, our choices aren't rational but instead are limited to bounded rationality, which we'll explain further in a moment.
If the government were to step in and limit economic choices, we could make better selections.
Given only options we can understand, our ability to thrive economically would improve.
It's not such a wild idea to do this, either.
The government already limits drugs and unsafe cars to help keep us safe.

insights.title: Despite fears of governmental economic planning, implementing it the right way can be wildly beneficial

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The big question on everyone's minds with this issue is whether or not the government should interfere with the economy.
While a free-market economist might tell you no, they'd likely cite the failure of this pattern in the Soviet Bloc.
You might hear that because it failed there, it will fail everywhere else, too. But that's not the case.
A government can do a great job of guiding the economy if given the right amount of control.
The problem in the Soviet Bloc was that they had too much authority.
A little guidance from the state, who often knows more about the whole economy than individual companies, can go a long way.
Take the experience of LG in South Korea, for example.
The company originally wanted to go into the textile business, but the government saw a better opportunity.
Carefully guiding LG to move into the electronic market, they paved the way for the well-known and successful enterprise that the company is today.
Even in the United States, the government has already guided the market in the past.
If it weren't for their helping hand, aircraft, biotech, and internet industries might not be as successful.

insights.title: Capitalism isn’t such a bad thing – it’s how we apply it to our world that causes problems

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: There are good and bad things about the current way we view the economy.
Capitalism certainly has its benefits. The profit motive, or people's desire to make money, drives people to innovate and create new inventions that make society better.
Additionally, capitalism helps regulate the economy by making sure we have enough plumbers and not too many rock stars.
Think of capitalism like a car. Without seat belts or brakes, the vehicle is likely to crash, causing damage and injury.
But given proper safety standards, cars provide many opportunities otherwise unavailable to the owner.
The same is true of economics.
If we let the market run rampant, like free-market capitalism does, it could be dangerous.
With some small amount of governmental control, however, we get the opportunity for a safer, fairer, and better system.
This is where we come back to the idea of bounded rationality, which says that humans are better at making decisions when options are limited.
With a little more power, our politicians could help us have a better economic system.
For example, leaders could guide banks to not make risky investment choices.
Improving our system in these small ways could provide big opportunities for making our world a better place.
"Markets weed out inefficient practices, but only when no one has sufficient power to manipulate them." \[Ha-Joon Chang\]
If you listen to economic experts in newspapers or on TV, they talk as if there's only one theory to follow: free-market economics.
This method centers around letting supply and demand govern reign supreme.
Free-market economics prizes little government involvement in the financial world.
Although it sounds appealing, there is a lot wrong with this view.
Other than not being very scientific, it's based on many false ideas about the way society and the economy work.
The good news is that there are other options, but unfortunately, these are ignored by the media and we never hear about them.
In Ha-Joon Chang's 23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism, you'll learn all about the problems with free-market economics.
More importantly, though, you will get a picture of how we can solve these issues and the better world they may offer everybody.

23 Things They Don't Tell You About Capitalism helps us think more clearly about our current economic state by uncovering the hidden consequences of free-market capitalism and offering solutions that could give us all a fairer world.

insights.title: Bring purpose into your life and your business

actions.title: Develop your empathy.
actions.markdown: Make empathy a top priority in your life. Try to become more intentional and learn how to look for solutions to people’s problems. This is a big asset when it comes to creating and designing products and services.

paragraphCards.markdown: Purpose is about intention. It's about the why.
When you do things with purpose, you have a direction and a guideline you abide by. Purpose is the answer to feeling lost.
When you get a new idea for a business, you can't think of the brand or the product as an end in itself. The product should be the means to an end.
Why do you want to create it? What does it offer?
Bring generosity back into the business vocabulary. You're creating something that'll bring value to the lives of those who choose to purchase or use it.
Creating, when it comes to business, is about giving rather than taking.
Focus on your purpose so you can create something that truly makes a difference in people's lives.
Turn to people in your life - friends, family, colleagues, even people you don't know very well - and ask them for their opinion.
This is my idea, what do you think about it? What does it mean to you? Would you benefit from it? Does the price seem fair?
It's easy to get carried away by the financial aspect of business and forget that a transaction had to happen between two human beings as they exchanged goods, money, and energy.

insights.title: As the world changes every day, you need to adapt to keep up

actions.title: Research the workings of the mind.
actions.markdown: If you’re creating something, pay attention to people’s habits - what they’re doing and how they’re doing it. Attention span has never been as low as it is now, so take that into account and craft something that appeals to your audience.

paragraphCards.markdown: In this competitive, highly-connected, fast-paced world, we need to be able to move and change with our surroundings to avoid becoming obsolete.
Think about how cellphones keep evolving every year. All the products we sell adapt to the world around them - otherwise they'd disappear.
Whatever your product or service, make sure it fits the context in which you're trying to sell it.
Your business's purpose gives you a guideline to follow and an end goal to be inspired by and aspire to reach.
Your product needs to be unique and make sense to you, but you need to find the target customer for it that's relevant today. It's about following trends without losing sight of your main goal.
If you're developing an app, become aware of the others already in the market. Why do they succeed? What makes them appealing? Who uses them and why?
All successful businesses stay modern and change as fast as the world does - so make that your priority as well.

insights.title: Always be on the lookout for opportunity

actions.title: Find inspiration outside your field.
actions.markdown: The best inspiration often comes from unexpected places. Embrace curiosity and follow your interests. The more you learn and discover, the more likely you are to find inspiration for your business.

paragraphCards.markdown: Opportunity is abundant. It's all around us through the people that we meet, the books we read, and the movies we watch.
Ideas are opportunities. Growth is an opportunity.
Even crises can help build a better business model and focus on what truly matters, like improving efficiency and communication.
When you design your business model, you need to become aware of the fact that, in order to function and thrive, your company needs to be curious and open to change.
When an object is too rigid, it breaks instead of bending. You need to bend.
You need to welcome opportunities and welcome changes of direction when needed.
We often set off in a certain direction without really knowing why.
In times of loss, it's important to seek inspiration within other creators who are thriving. What are they doing right? How could you implement that in your own company?
Ask for help or advice. Welcome feedback. Let the world in so that it might let you in too.

insights.title: Create a morning routine that works for you

actions.title: Journal when you wake up.
actions.markdown: Journaling is about awareness. Each morning, sit with your own feelings so you can experience them fully and recognize them for what they are.

actions.title: Eat nutritious foods.
actions.markdown: Food is a great way to show gratefulness to your body and to your life. Pick foods that bring you energy but that you also love. Thank them for their taste and the health they’re gifting you.

paragraphCards.markdown: Waking up in the morning is like jumping into consciousness. The first few things you do set the tone for the rest of the day.
When you wake up and automatically check your phone, or stub your toe on some furniture, you're inviting more of that energy into your day.
By becoming intentional about the way you enter your life and the world each morning, you'll begin to create a new reality, one that fulfills you and looks like you.
Consciousness is at the core of a healthy lifestyle.
People who feel disconnected from their emotions tend to be more dissatisfied with their lives and less likely to take part in a creative endeavour \- even just as a hobby.
Bringing consciousness into your mornings can be as simple as thinking of three positive goals you have for the day ahead, or three things you feel grateful for.
More than just thought, consciousness is about action. We become conscious by taking intentional action.
Welcoming the day with a few minutes of meditation helps you get into your body by focusing on the life energy that enters you through your breath, and inviting more intention into your day.

insights.title: Connecting to your dreams helps you connect to your sense of self

actions.title: Write down your dreams.
actions.markdown: The closer you’re connected to your own consciousness, the more you’ll be able to understand your dreams and relate to them. Each morning, before you get out of bed, write down if you had a dream and what it was about. See if you can start to see what your brain is telling you.

paragraphCards.markdown: Our dreams are full of hidden messages.
Like Freud and his disciples, you can try and analyze your dreams to understand the deeper parts of yourself. After all, they're an expression of your unconscious trying to come out.
Dreams are like water trying to slide down cracks on a dry soil. It soaks up the water to bring the earth back to good health.
If you let the dreams in, you'll refill your consciousness with the good stuff.
A good way to assess whether you're disconnected from your consciousness or not is simply to look at your dreams.
Do you remember most of them? Conscious people tend to have memorable, vivid dreams.
Do you understand them or do they seem to escape your own logic? Do you relate to them emotionally?
The more disconnected and foreign your dreams seem to you, the more you need to work on becoming more conscious and intentional.
One of the reasons why children talk about their dreams more than adults do is because they tend to be more connected to their inner desires and needs.
Children naturally listen to their impulses and feel things as they come.
As adults, we learn how to quieten our emotions - but focusing on our dreams can help bring them back!

insights.title: Trust your intuition, never just dismiss it

actions.title: Distinguish between should and must.
actions.markdown: ‘Should’ corresponds to others’ expectations, and ‘must’ is who we are and what we know to be true. Become conscious of those two components when making a decision. If you always pick should, you might be ignoring your own needs to focus on others’.

actions.title: Step into your emotions.
actions.markdown: If you feel creatively stuck, ask yourself which emotions are blocking you. Allow them to be. Sit with them for a while. They’ll likely pass, like thoughts in meditation, and you’ll be free.

paragraphCards.markdown: Being highly connected to your intuition is a strong sign of consciousness.
Conscious individuals tend to make better decisions, not only based on logic but on their gut feelings.
Part primal instinct, part strange whisper of truth, our intuition is a very mysterious thing.
But when we look back at our experiences, most of us can relate to these moments of, "I could sense it was going to go wrong from the start. Why didn't I listen to my gut?"
Sometimes, the answer to that question is simple.
We don't always recognize our intuition for what it is. We confuse it for fear or laziness, or dismiss it completely as 'illogical'.
But most of the time, logical or not, the initial feeling we have about something makes sense - we just don't trust ourselves enough to shut up and listen.
Without being extreme or dismissing logic in return, welcome your intuition.
Acknowledge it by questioning it. Why do you feel this way? What does it mean? Have you ever felt that way before?
Intuition is quiet and calm. It whispers, and it feels like truth. Learn how to recognize it to be able to use it.
"When you stop doing the wrong thing, the right thing will do itself." \[Elle Luna\]
Are you a creative individual looking to free yourself and live a better, more inspired life?
Do you feel torn between the expectations others have for your life, and the inner desires that inhabit you?

In this insightful interview, writer and designer Elle Luna speaks out on her own struggles with creativity, and the ways she's found to welcome her artistic flow and give it the space it needs to flourish.

In this course, you'll learn how to create an efficient morning routine, and how to make your dreams a part of your consciousness journey, by embracing your intuition to become the best version of yourself - today, tomorrow, and for years to come.

In this episode of 30 Days of Genius, Chase Jarvis sits down with famous designer and writer Elle Luna to open up about awareness, motivation, and solutions to find and follow your own calling - and change your life for the better.

Self-improvement click-bait makes for so many bad blog posts ("10 Confidence Hacks To Make Yourself Look Better In Front Of Your Boss"), but when the topic is well-explored and properly argued, it can provide some intriguing food for thought.
By not rushing this book out-the-door, Richard Wiseman has done the self-improvement community a great service.

insights.title: Think about your own eulogy to align your actions with your long-term goals

actions.title: Plan your own eulogy.
actions.markdown: Write down what’s most important to you in life (your career, your relationships, your dreams of a healthier, happier planet), and then be specific about your goals.

paragraphCards.markdown: One of the most popular techniques in self-improvement is visualizing your goals.
You sit down, close your eyes, and imagine yourself achieving your dreams, as well as doing the things necessary to get there.
However, there's also some opposing evidence to this with some studies finding people tend to work less for their goals if they visualize them.
One thing that's timelessly been proven to work is this: having a step-by-step plan.
When Richard Wiseman examined the New Year's resolutions of 5,000 people, he found that planning and breaking down goals made all the difference.
But to do that, you first have to know what your high-level goals even are.
A great 59-second exercise to get clarity on that is to just think about your own eulogy.
What do you want the speaker to say about you at your funeral? If you want to be thorough, you can even write it down.
Similar to the funeral test, this'll show you what's really important to you and help you align your daily actions with your biggest dreams.

insights.title: Skip the brainstorming and go right from eureka to execution

actions.title: Try a hypnagogic nap.
actions.markdown: As you’re feeling sleepy, sit in a chair, hold something small and heavy (ideally metal), and place a metal dish below it. When you nod off and the noise wakes you up, chances are you’ll have had some new creative thoughts.

actions.title: Don’t be afraid to daydream.
actions.markdown: If you’re struggling for inspiration, just stare into space and let your mind wander. Then the moment something comes to you, get straight to work – write it down and start to develop it.

paragraphCards.markdown: You know what ruins a great idea? Thinking about how to implement it.
Brainstorming is supposedly this creative process, but it really suppresses ideas because it creates delay and friction between having an idea and getting to work.
This is especially true for groups, where people often refrain from even voicing their ideas because they fear the judgment of their peers.
But don't lie to yourself, you can just as well spend forever in "brainstorming hell" all by yourself.
Instead of procrastinating by deliberating, what if you went immediately from distracted to doing, from eureka to execution?
Salvador Dalí had the perfect technique for doing so: he sat in a chair, holding a heavy key right above an upside down plate on the floor, waiting until he dozed off.

The second he did, the key'd slip out of his hands, hit the plate and wake him up with a loud noise. Right on the verge between sleep and consciousness, he'd instantly start sketching the images in his mind.
This is called a hypnagogic nap, and the same principles apply any time you're distracted and let your subconscious go to work.
Right when you have a brilliant insight, drop everything and start executing it.
This'll save you plenty of planning time and make you loads more productive, keeping the ideas flowing as you need them.

insights.title: Use “but” every time you point out something negative in another person

actions.title: Balance the bad with the good.
actions.markdown: If you feel you need to criticize your loved one, try to compliment them at the same time. Gently address the insult, then use that magical ‘but’ to make it better.

paragraphCards.markdown: When following couples around for a year to determine what makes some relationships successful while others break, researchers Sandra Murray and John Holmes found one word to be particularly useful: "but."
Imagine you make your sweetie dinner, she twists her mouth upon first bite, grins and says: "You're such a horrible cook!" Supposedly cute, but still stings, right?
Now, imagine instead, she'd say: "You're such a horrible cook…but at least you're funny!" Feels entirely different, doesn't it?
That's because using "but" after any negative statement allows you to smooth out the minus with a plus, get the other person to focus on the upside and view your relationship in a different light.

However, it's probably a good idea to extend this practice beyond your significant other and adopt it in any relationship, as this greatly improves your communication with co-workers, family and friends.
"Happiness doesn't just flow from success; it actually causes it." \[Richard Wiseman\]
Richard Wiseman isn't your average researcher. The British psychologist is the only professor of Public Understanding of Psychology in the world.
Wiseman also has a Youtube channel with over 2 million subscribers, and it's all about magic.

Wiseman loves to debunk paranormal phenomenons and has published over ten books. He's also one of the few sources where you can learn something in under 5 minutes, thanks to his 59 Seconds concept, which also gave name to this book.
Most self-improvement books lay out big plans and long journeys of transformation. Wiseman thinks there's no need for that, when there's so much you can do that takes less than a minute.
59 Seconds offers several self-improvement hacks grounded in the science of psychology, which you can use to improve your mindset, happiness, and life in less than a minute.
The advice in 60 Seconds & You're Hired! is golden. It should be your go-to for preparation to land the perfect job. It really gets you confident, so that if you want to, you can ace any interview.

insights.title: Help your interviewer remember that you are a good fit by consistently mentioning your top 5 skills throughout the interview

actions.title: Focus on your traits that best match the company’s values.
actions.markdown: Have a look at the company’s website, press releases, and employee reviews to figure out values the company holds in high regard. They’ll look for these values in their employees, too.

paragraphCards.markdown: We've already made it clear why we need to stand out from the crowd. But how do we do that?
It starts with helping the interviewer remember us, and focusing their attention on your strengths.
With so many candidates to consider, we need to help the interviewer remember us. This is where the 5 Point Agenda comes in.
To begin, we should make a list of our top five most marketable skills.

Don't just list what first comes to mind, though. Focus on the strengths that are specific to the job. (A graphic designer, for example, would want to focus on their portfolio and experience building websites.)
Keep in mind that the list may be different for each role.
The primary objective is to focus on what we can do to best match the goals of the company.
It's a good idea to look at your potential new employer on LinkedIn and Glassdoor, and find out what their values are.
Once the list is ready, practice until it's easy to highlight all five in less than 60 seconds.
Make sure to mention each of these strengths somewhere in the interview, so that the interviewer remembers them.

insights.title: Eradicate fear and boost your confidence to answer questions concisely by preparing beforehand

actions.title: Prepare, practice, and practice some more.
actions.markdown: Simply taking the time to prepare will instantly calm our nerves. Practice your answers out loud, in the mirror, or even record yourself doing them. You’ll familiarize yourself with the material but also help you realize that you’ve got this!

paragraphCards.markdown: Preparation kills fear.
The reason this works is because it limits the potential for surprises.
Nothing can catch us off guard if we've put in the work and prepared.
First, research some of the most commonly asked questions in interviews, and practice answering them.
Role-playing isn't always fun, but it does make a big difference in your confidence levels every time we do it.
We can also use our research to think of specific questions the company might ask about their products or services.
Next, remember the details of best performances at previous workplaces.
Again, focus on those that highlight the company's values.
The main goal of the employer is to determine if we're a good fit, and being more specific will help them do that.
Last, we must get ready to market our specific personality as an ideal worker persona.
We might not think it, but interviewers go in with biases that we have to fight.
Millennials, for example, may be thought of as dealing with entitlement and technology addiction.
Older candidates might be seen as less innovative.
Highlighting our learning, communication skills and successful attitude will combat these disadvantages.

insights.title: “Do you have any questions?” is your chance to let your true motivations and preparation shine

actions.title: Prepare smart questions for the end of the interview.
actions.markdown: Your prepared questions are your chance to shine – so use it as an opportunity to show off your research. Practically, it’s also your chance to determine if the job will fit your personal goals. Your questions will mark the final note of the interview, so end on a good impression!

paragraphCards.markdown: We may have been told before to take advantage every time an interviewer asks if we have any questions.
Many of us brush off this last interview question as non-important. But employers use it as a chance to gain valuable information about your character, so be ready for it.
To prepare for this opportunity, write a list of 10 to 15 questions for when this fated moment comes.

Doing this shows the interviewer our diligence in researching the company, and that we're thinking about how we can help it succeed. If the interviewer answered any of your questions during the interview, be sure to say so.
Last tip on questions is to never ask about benefits or salary during an interview.
Employers use our questions to gauge our intentions – when we ask about money, it shows that we're more concerned about pay than the actual job. Not the impression you want to give off!
"You'll never know what you can achieve until you try. Just never, ever give up." \[Robin Ryan\]
Remember your last job interview? Did it make you nervous knowing that you were about to be grilled by a total stranger?
Interviews are uncomfortable for everyone – evaluating potential candidates can even make employers nervous!
After all, they're under pressure to make the right decision. Choosing the wrong person for a position costs the company.
It's hard for interviewers to sift through so many candidates, though, and after meeting multiple applicants, the specifics start to blur together.
This is why we have to be quick in our interview responses – ideally, in less than a minute.
Ryan's how-to guide has all the answers for how to do so, providing little-known hacks to acing our interviews, and securing that dream job.
Feel confident in every interview with 60 Seconds & You're Hired!, the go-to guide to getting your dream job by Robin Ryan, dubbed "America's Top Career Expert" by the LA Times.
A Beautiful Mind is a wonderful story. For those that enjoy math, it's fascinating to learn more about Nash's contributions to the field, and the struggles with mental illness he faced along the way.

insights.title: John Nash started making mathematical breakthroughs while still in graduate school

paragraphCards.markdown: Like many geniuses, John Nash had some eccentric and reclusive tendencies. ![John\_f\_nash\_20061102\_3.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/91/John_f_nash_20061102_3.jpg)
While his parents worried about him socially, he had a gift for thinking about math problems in new and unorthodox ways. [youtube.com/user/cunytv75](https://youtu.be/xu7UxpKcYC0?t=1114.56&e=1137.00)

Surprisingly, Nash didn't show glowing grades in high school math, because he would neglect to show his work and just write an answer that he had solved in his head. [youtube.com/user/cunytv75](https://youtu.be/xu7UxpKcYC0?t=1090.21&e=1103.90)
But in college, his professors were astounded by his methods for solving difficult math problems with ease, and he was accepted to graduate school at Princeton University.
Graduate students formed cliques under different mentoring professors, but Nash preferred to stay a loner, making him not particularly well-liked.
He finally found his place working under John Neumann, who fathered game theory. ![JohnvonNeumann-LosAlamos.gif](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/JohnvonNeumann-LosAlamos.gif)

Game theory is a way to explain human decision making among competing players through mathematical models. ![Game\_Theory\_An\_extensive\_form\_game.png](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/Game_Theory_An_extensive_form_game.png)
Nash expanded Neumann's theory in his thesis to include games involving more than two players and allowing for cooperation.
This crucial step in the development of the theory allowed it to be relevant in real-world situations, particularly in economics.

Most importantly, his additions to the theory allowed the possibility of mathematically determining human behavior with the possibility of mutual gain. ![John\_Forbes\_Nash\_(2).jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/John_Forbes_Nash_%282%29.jpg/800px-John_Forbes_Nash_%282%29.jpg)

This became known as the 'Nash equilibrium', which would win him the Nobel Prize half a century later. ![Nash\_graph\_equilibrium.png](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Nash_graph_equilibrium.png)
His thesis gave him huge recognition in the mathematics field, and landed him a job at MIT."

insights.title: Nash’s diagnosis of schizophrenia came after a stressful time in his career and life

paragraphCards.markdown: When math genius John Nash approached the age of 30, he began to be increasingly anxious about not yet receiving tenure and a lack of new mathematical breakthroughs.

His anxieties led him to decide to take on Reimann's hypothesis, a famously hard unsolved math problem. ![RiemannCriticalLine.svg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/RiemannCriticalLine.svg/1920px-RiemannCriticalLine.svg.png)
It was just when Nash was putting all of his energy into this that he found out his wife was pregnant.
This was when people noticed his increasingly strange behavior. Nash accused his colleagues of looking through his trash to see his work on the hypothesis.
He began to believe aliens were trying to ruin his career, sending him secret messages through the paper. [youtube.com/user/cunytv75](https://youtu.be/xu7UxpKcYC0?t=832.47&e=859.70)
Turning down a professorship at the University of Chicago because he was "Emperor of Antarctica," it was obvious that Nash was in deep.
The tipping point for Nash's wife, Alicia, came when he went to Washington, D.C. in the middle of the night to give letters to embassies explaining there was an imminent world government.
Nash's wife had him committed to a psychiatric hospital, where he was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia.

Nash was treated and given the clear, but it was soon apparent he fabricated this to leave. ![John\_Forbes\_Nash,\_Jr..jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/John_Forbes_Nash%2C_Jr..jpg/1280px-John_Forbes_Nash%2C_Jr..jpg)
He wandered to Europe to convince the embassies of his world government, but was eventually deported.
Nash saw things get worse with his income source gone and Alicia filing for divorce.
Living with his family for only a short time, he soon went back to an institution.

insights.title: Genius John Nash made a seemingly unbelievable recovery, and finally found success

paragraphCards.markdown: After John Nash's time in a psychiatric hospital, those around him feared his great genius was lost for good.
But in a miraculous turn of events, he began to recover. [youtube.com/user/cunytv75](https://youtu.be/xu7UxpKcYC0?t=725.90&e=738.44)
The process happened slowly, but Nash's schizophrenia slowly began to subside. By the late 1980s, people at Princeton saw his research was real math rather than incomprehensible equations.
Nash himself said that he began to realize that though his paranoid thoughts were still tormenting him, he could reject them now.

More wonderful for Nash still, he was finally getting recognition for his contribution to game theory by receiving the Nobel Prize in Economics. ![GTM2008\_19.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/29/GTM2008_19.jpg)

After around 30 years away from academia, the invitation came for him to be a professor at Princeton. ![Nassau Hall in Princeton University, USA](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_366267023.jpg)

Nash spent his remaining years reconnecting with family and friends he had estranged, and even reacquainted himself with his wife, Alicia. They remarried in 2001, and they lived out their lives together.
"I've made the most important discovery of my life. It's only in the mysterious equation of love that any logic or reasons can be found." \[John Nash\]

A lot of us have seen the movie, A Beautiful Mind, but the story itself is just as compelling. ![Russell\_Crowe,\_Auckland\_(1997).\_by\_Jane\_Ussher.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Russell_Crowe%2C_Auckland_%281997%29._by_Jane_Ussher.jpg)
John Nash was a brilliant man, but his antisocial behavior was off-putting to some.
Even the colleagues who found him annoying couldn't deny he was going to make a name for himself, though. [.youtube.com/c/DefilmblogBe](https://youtu.be/9wZM7CQY130?t=0.00&e=28.76)

Tragically, just as his career was taking off, his behavior became more erratic and obsessive. His world came crashing down after his diagnosis with paranoid schizophrenia. ![https://giphy.com/antoniovicentini](https://media.giphy.com/media/S52usGav8ivv8pzPHQ/giphy.gif)
The novel A Beautiful Mind chronicles John Nash's decade-long battle with disease and his recovery.

Author Sylvia Nasar brings us into the mind of a brilliant man tortured by his inability to distinguish paranoia from reality. ![Sylvia\_Nasar\_-\_Flickr\_-\_Knight\_Foundation.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Sylvia_Nasar_-_Flickr_-_Knight_Foundation.jpg/800px-Sylvia_Nasar_-_Flickr_-_Knight_Foundation.jpg)

A Beautiful Mind tells the fascinating story of the mathematical genius, mental illness, and miraculous recovery and success of John Nash Jr. ![John\_Forbes\_Nash,\_Jr.\_by\_Peter\_Badge.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/John_Forbes_Nash%2C_Jr._by_Peter_Badge.jpg)
A Return to Love preaches that we really need less egoism and selfishness in our world and more kindness and selflessness. It's a really good reminder that nice people don't finish last.

insights.title: Fear is the root of everything that causes us to be unhappy

actions.title: Find the courage to leave your comfort zone.
actions.markdown: Opening ourselves up is key for our growth. Whether it’s saying “hello” to new people in the elevator, speaking up in meetings, or asking someone on a date, the more we incorporate boldness into our everyday life, the more comfortable we’ll be with it.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you're a normal human being, chances are you've had your fair share of misery in life.
Whether it's losing your job, the death of a loved one, or getting sick, we all have crummy times in life.
But whatever it is you're going through, the feeling of unhappiness is because you're afraid.
Don't worry though, it's not your fault that your upbringing makes you fear suffering. The odds are stacked against us when it comes to this truth.
From a young age you were taught to focus on getting good grades in school instead of being kind to others.
Learning to compete with your peers taught you the feelings of fear and contempt as a child, and you've known them too well ever since.
Even once we graduate from college and go out into the workplace, our economic stability centers around fear.
We're afraid to lose out on the best job and the home and security that it brings.
Not only is the workplace full of negativity, but the world in general teaches us to fear strangers. Our news seems to only air the dreariest stories.
It's as if we've got everything working against us to keep us in a habit of fear.
The barriers we set up to try to keep ourselves safe make it really hard to open our hearts to any kind of love.

insights.title: Being happier at work and making the world a better place come from turning your career path over to a higher power

actions.title: Find purpose in your everyday life.
actions.markdown: Whether it’s through helpful customer service, building a useful new product, or just being kind to your colleagues, altruism is our most powerful tool. Know that the world becomes a little better every day because of you and your kindness.

paragraphCards.markdown: Unfortunately, too many people only listen to their ego when it comes to their career and financial life.
When we focus only on our own preservation and survival, we separate ourselves from others who are the true key to our success.
Only by opening our hearts and minds to the higher power of love and kindness can we tap into our full potential.
Author Marianne Williamson writes that God put each of us here to make the world a better place. That's the purpose of your career: to help other people – but the way you fulfill it might be unique.

Discovering this meaning in your work could require you to go through a few different jobs. If you let a higher power guide you, though, the lessons you learn in each position will become vital to your success.
No matter what you do, you can find purpose, a way to make the world a better place.
When Williamson was working as a cocktail waitress, she found it difficult to see the difference she made. Then she thought about how it was just a matter of perspective.
Looking for the meaning in her work, she made a quick discovery that her job gave her an opportunity to bring joy to her customers each day.
Regardless of your work, it's better to focus on kindness and love than just looking out for yourself.
Most employers would rather hire the nice guy than the self-centered one with an impressive resume.

insights.title: Try to understand the people who are mean to you, most likely all they need is a little empathy for what they’ve been through to open their hearts

actions.title: Live with compassion.
actions.markdown: When someone takes issue with you or is rude, it’s important to understand that their problems come from something inside _them_, rather than something inside you. Often, others’ rudeness is a cry for help, not an attack on you.

paragraphCards.markdown: It's hard to accept that someone who hurt you may only be having a hard time dealing with past trauma.
But remember that you don't know what the people around you have been through.
And you especially can't tell if you'd act any better had you been given the same lot in life as they have.
Instead of passing on their suffering, we need to become more empathetic and understanding of those around us.

Consider an experience Marianne Williamson once had while at a salon. While getting her hair done, a cold and mean customer walked into the room. Worrying that she may get stuck next to this icy personality, Williamson prayed for some guidance.
At the same moment, she heard the woman who'd walked in open up and talk about her abusive father to the hairdresser.
So the next time you see someone angry, just stop to think about the shield they're putting up because of their trauma.
Showing them a little love will go a long way to making the world a better place.
"It takes courage to endure the sharp pains of self discovery rather than choose to take the dull pain of unconsciousness that would last the rest of our lives." \[Marianne Williamson\]
In this world we live in, there is far too much pain and suffering. A lot of the reason for this is that individualism is rampant. People care only for themselves and satisfying their ego.
What is the key to overcoming this plague of selfishness that is sweeping over us? The answer, according to Marianne Williamson, is love.
She believes strongly in its power and teaches all about it in her book A Return to Love: Reflections on the Principles of "A Course in Miracles."
Williamson teaches that to find true happiness and relief from the pain that life brings, we must turn ourselves over to the higher power of love, also known as God.
This message isn't one from or to any specific religion. Anyone can receive, practice and benefit from it regardless of their beliefs.
A Return To Love will help you let go of resentment, fear, and anger to have happier and healthier jobs and relationships by teaching you how to embrace the power of love.
A Short History Of Nearly Everything is a brilliant book to learn a little about all the core pillars that make up our existence, and the universe we live in.
![CC BY 2.0](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/35/Neil_MacGregor%2C_Bill_Bryson%2C_Claire_Walker%2C_Huw_Edwards_%2828449155987%29_%28Bryson_cropped%29.jpg)

insights.title: All it took to create most of the universe as we know it was a single, three-minute moment

paragraphCards.markdown: A singularity is defined as a moment in which nothing is defined and everything is unpredictable.

It's a massive inflection point. When scientists talk about the "initial" singularity, they refer to the moment the universe was created. ![giphy.com/mcgillu](https://media.giphy.com/media/3pZhyDpeZRy46gsO9i/giphy.gif)
It's hard to imagine, but think of a little, compact point, that is infinitely dense – it contains everything that's in the universe now, but is compressed into a tiny, tiny dot.
All of a sudden, it explodes, splattering all of its contents into the void. This moment is known as the Big Bang.
When it happened, the entire universe was created in the time it takes you to prepare a sandwich.
Immediately after the blow, the universe doubled in size every 10-34 seconds – that's FAST. Within three minutes, 98% of all matter in the universe we know today was created.
With all this expanding, how wide is the universe today? ![giphy.com/hidrogenesse](https://media.giphy.com/media/j3POomBxMU6ZCFlMyr/giphy.gif)
About 100 billion light years – that's the distance light can travel in a year times 100 BILLION. And light is fast.
It travels 300,000 km (or 186,000 miles) per second. That's this much in a year: 9,460,800,000,000 or about 9.5 trillion.
So 9.5 trillion times 100 billion, that's the diameter of the universe. ![giphy.com/cbc](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7btPCcdNniyf0ArS/giphy.gif)
In numbers (whatever that means), that's the span in kilometers: 946,800,000,000,000,000,000,000.

insights.title: The odds of a planet supporting life are so low that our presence on earth comes close to a miracle

paragraphCards.markdown: If you think about how easy it is to die, it becomes clear how frail human life actually is. ![giphy.com/bbc](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0MYxcBlCIytbB768/giphy.gif)
You fall down a couple stairs, hit your head, and that's it. You dive too deep in the sea, climb too high on a mountain or get stung by the wrong plant or insect, and you're done.
But an even bigger surprise than us managing to maneuver the dangerous world we live in every day is the fact that we're here at all.
99.5% of earth's habitable space is not suited for humans – because it's either water or doesn't have enough oxygen.

We need land to move and live, and even on land we're limited: only 12% of the total land mass of our planet can host humans. ![giphy.com/technoir](https://media.giphy.com/media/kW7memdfRgRB6/giphy.gif)
It's pretty rare for a planet to be livable in general, because several things have to come together…
1.  The distance to a star must be perfect. If it's too close, the surface burns; if it's too far away, the planet will be iced over.
2.  The planet has to keep out cosmic radiation by building the right atmosphere.
3.  A moon has to keep the planet's gravity in check, so that it can spin at the right speed and angle. ![giphy.com/peacocktv](https://media.giphy.com/media/XFpCAWSfTwXh2uSEk2/giphy.gif)
All of these events have to line up in the right order and timeline. Talk about once-in-a-lifetime chances!

insights.title: There’s a lot that could go wrong for our planet, which makes every new day a gift

paragraphCards.markdown: Humans not falling prey to all the dangers in the world pales into insignificance in comparison to all the dangers that threaten earth's existence from the outside.
There are around 1,000,000,000 asteroids flying around space close to the earth, and about 10% of them that regularly intersect with earth's orbit are larger than 10 meters in diameter.
That's 100 million 10m-sized rocks potentially hitting earth at tremendous speeds! ![giphy.com/historyuk](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1J9HHnpVLEJiMepW/giphy.gif)
In fact, 2,000 of those are so large that upon collision, we might get wiped out completely.
According to scientists' calculations, those deadly asteroids could fly by and nearly miss around 2-3 times a week – without us even noticing.
As if that wasn't enough, there are earthquakes, tornadoes and volcano eruptions, all of which can have devastating consequences.
So no, it's totally not normal that the sun rises every morning. ![giphy.com/ufc](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0Iy85WxKpavDsF2M/giphy.gif)
Every single day is yet another miracle, waiting for you to appreciate it and take advantage of it. Live like it!

"If you were to pick yourself apart with tweezers, one atom at a time, you would produce a mound of fine atomic dust, none of which had ever been alive but all of which had once been you." \[Bill Bryson\]
What's the most fascinating thing about our world to you? Is it space, other planets, galaxies far far away? ![giphy.com/joshhilldesign](https://media.giphy.com/media/llCMePepHIqmv1ZYoN/giphy.gif)
The depth of the ocean and the mysterious, alien-like creatures that live down there? The genetic makeup of all of the species around us?

Even people who don't show a particular interest in science and history have one or two things they're absolutely smitten by – and it's not surprising. There's so much incredible stuff going on around us, it's hard to not be starstruck, if you think about it.

A Short History Of Nearly Everything tries to explain (almost) all of it. At least as much as we know. Bill Bryson has done a tremendous job at it. ![CC BY-SA 3.0](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b1/BillBryson02.JPG)

A Short History Of Nearly Everything explains everything we've learned about our world and the universe so far, including how they formed, how we learned to make sense of time, space and gravity, and how much of our planet is still a complete mystery to us.
