paragraphCards.markdown: Business Model Generation highlights the importance of planning when creating a business. Perhaps it's some of the least fun of being an entrepreneur, but doing them is the difference between success and failure.

insights.title: Market channels, value propositions, and customer groups are the basis for a good business model

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Take a look around where you are right now. On public transport? On the phone? Sitting in a cafe? Wherever we are, whatever we're doing, we are surrounded by businesses.
Although they all have different purposes, these business all have one thing in common: they creates value for their customers.
The beginning of this is a business model that outlines a company's product and what type of people it creates value for.
The heart of the best business plans is customers.
Without anyone to buy our product, we don't have a company.
We can get into a mass market, which covers a large audience of customers with similar needs.
Or, our business can cater to a niche market that is made up of smaller groups of people with certain interests.
Once we know our market, we've got to figure out our value proposition, or what problem we're going to solve for people.
Identify the need our product or service fulfills and what makes it better for customers to choose over other similar products.
The value you provide can be connected with design, reducing risk, or top performance.
The next step is to figure out how to reach our audience.
This is also known as market channels.
Will you have a storefront? Or maybe a sales team is what you prefer. In many cases, a website is a good option.
New channels can even be made by partnering with others, like a wholesaler.

insights.title: We need to know our customer’s relationship with us, how money is coming in, and what physical things that we need to run your company

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: When running a business, we need to understand who we're serving, how we're meeting their needs, and the ways we'll reach them.
Then, we need to identify the relationship we want to have with our customers.
This step is vital, because it's the foundation for how much value customers find in your company.
If we have a personalized way of relating, we might personally assist your patrons with their needs. An IT company that helps people with specific computer needs is a good example of this.
If this same business has regular customers, then they might try a more automated approach with their email marketing.
Next, it's time to look at revenue streams.
We should think of our business like a body, with the customers being the heart. This would make revenue like the arteries and veins that make sure things run correctly.
We can get money coming in with a few different models.
One option is transactions, which includes three one-time payments, like when we buy a new computer.
There are also subscriptions, like Netflix.
We can also have usage fees, which differ depending on how much a customer uses the service, like mobile data.
The next step is to determine the ways we will secure the resources our company needs to stay in business.
Think of these like food and water that keep a body running.
Materials, buildings, and equipment are all examples of physical resources you need.
It also takes human resources, or your staff, to keep things running smoothly. There are also intellectual resources, which include copyrights and patents over your products.

insights.title: Plan out what an average day looks like, who to work with, and what the cost structure will be

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Just like we have to exercise if we want to keep your body healthy, we need to know the activities that will make our business healthy.
This includes platform or network hosting, problem-solving, and production.
Examples of production activities include manufacturing a laptop or making a pizza. Being a consultant for an engineering firm is an example of problem-solving.
When we put up a product or service for sale on eBay or Airbnb, this is platform and network hosting.
Next, it's time to figure out who we're working with.
Most of the time, we need a team to keep things running. It's a good idea to plan who will be on it beforehand, because it can make some of our other activities possible and limit risk.
The last step of all this planning is to outline the cost structure.
The choice is to be either value-driven or cost-driven.
If we work hard to keep expenses low, maybe by reducing our service level, then we are cost-driven. (Cheap airlines are a good example of this.)
In contrast, value-driven companies brush aside how expensive it is to take care of their customers.
They focus mostly on offering top-quality services that justify a higher price. Private airlines that cater to high-end customers are a good example of what it means to be value-driven.
"Companies should focus on one of three disciplines: operational excellence, product leadership, or customer intimacy." \[Alexander Osterwalder, Yves Pigneur\]
So you've got a great idea, but you don't know how to turn it into a business.
What do you do about it? Are you going to just let it sit there and fizzle away like most people do? Or will you get up and make a plan to help you take action?
Entrepreneurship is fun, but most of us underestimate the difficulties along the way.
Money problems, arguments with partners, not knowing our customers, and many more troubles await us.
But this doesn't have to be a problem: the key is to plan wisely.

Business Model Generation: A Handbook for Visionaries, Game Changers, and Challengers is here to help prepare each step of starting a new company. With these tips, the chances of us becoming a successful entrepreneur will skyrocket.

Business Model Generation teaches us how to start our own company, by explaining the details of matching our customer's needs with our product's capabilities, managing finances, and everything else involved in the planning stages of entrepreneurship.
With the iconic metaphor in the film's title, Bruce Lee embraced a philosophy of both fluid flexibility and rock-hard determination.
Blending social history with poetic inspiration, Be Water is a reminder of everything that made Bruce Lee more than just another movie star.

insights.title: After a troubled childhood, Bruce Lee found his calling in America but faced discrimination

paragraphCards.markdown: Bruce Lee was born in 1940 in San Francisco's Chinatown while his father, a Hong Kong opera star, was on tour. ![SFO-Chinatown.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/SFO-Chinatown.jpg)

As a child in Hong Kong, Lee was raised amidst his father's entertainment career, appearing in multiple films and studying Wing Chun martial arts under the renowned Yip Man. ![https://giphy.com/karatecombat/](https://media.giphy.com/media/dYqzzPQ2wZe7aHrSNj/giphy.gif)
However, Bruce was a rebellious youth, often getting into fights. Fearing he would become involved in gangs, his parents sent him to live with relatives in the US, with only $100 in his pocket.

""Who am I? That is the age-old question asked by every man at one time or another. Though he looks into a mirror and recognizes his own face; though he knows his own name and age and history, still he wonders, deep down: who am I?"" \[Bruce Lee \]

While working at a restaurant to support himself and attending the University of Washington in Seattle, Bruce Lee began teaching martial arts and met his future wife, Linda. ![Linda\_Lee\_Cadwell\_portrait.JPG](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fd/Linda_Lee_Cadwell_portrait.JPG)
At the time, many US states still banned interracial marriage.
Bruce Lee's son Brandon was born in 1965 and his father died soon after. Bruce was deeply affected; he knew that being sent away to America had taught him independence and responsibility.

As one of the first to teach Chinese martial arts to Americans, Lee faced disapproval from the Chinese community, but remained undaunted. ![https://giphy.com/teamcoco/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l378p1ZIWdbDNYUiQ/giphy.gif)
""As a martial artist, one of the most important concepts is the notion of bridging the gap. Bridging the gap between me and my opponent, bridging the gap between me and my dreams."" \[Bruce Lee\]
Bruce Lee's Hollywood acting career began when he was contacted by a producer after a martial arts exhibition. However, he found few roles as a Chinese-American.
Asian characters were either played by white actors in 'yellowface' or portrayed as blatantly racist stereotypes - dastardly villains or subservient automatons.

Lee's first major role was as the hero's sidekick Kato in the series The Green Hornet, where he fought for extra lines and a more active role, as well as pay equity. ![https://giphy.com/boomunderground](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4KigVC0Ox2TjDB1m/giphy.gif)
Lee decided to make it his mission to represent his heritage and prove that a Chinese man could be a leading hero in Hollywood.

""As Asian-Americans, as people of color, we get affirmation from the culture around us, right? Being able to see another person on screen who looks like you is galvanizing. It makes you feel like you're supposed to be here."" \[Jeff Chang, cultural critic\]

insights.title: Bruce Lee remained true to his heritage while melding diverse influences to bridge cultures

paragraphCards.markdown: After The Green Hornet was cancelled, Bruce Lee worked as a stunt coordinator and focused on writing.
While Lee continued to act, he refused parts he considered demeaning to Chinese people, and got little work as a result.

Despite financial struggles, it was a happy time for Bruce Lee's family, and in 1969, his daughter Shannon was born. [https://www.youtube.com/c/barnesandnoble](https://youtu.be/n--jaWgi2Hc?t=0.00&e=21.09)

"The 1960s influenced Bruce Lee greatly - an age of experimentation, disillusionment. Existential angst was way high. There was a very conscious attempt to challenge the established Western way."" \[Sam Ho, film critic\]

Bruce taught martial arts to Hollywood actors, developing friendships with Chuck Norris and Kareem Abdul Jabar. He was interested in sports and studied many influences, unbound by tradition. ![https://giphy.com/grittv](https://media.giphy.com/media/d2jfPv6CUzpopfLa/giphy.gif)

Jeet Kune Do, or Way of the Intercepting Fist, was a hybrid form of martial arts created by Bruce Lee himself. ![:JeetKuneDo.svg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/JeetKuneDo.svg/800px-JeetKuneDo.svg.png)
""I personally do not believe in the word 'style'. Because of style, people are separate. They are not united together, because styles become law."" \[Bruce Lee\]

Bruce Lee conceived the idea for the Kung Fu television series, but was denied the lead role because studios believed his race and accent would not be popular with viewers. ![https://giphy.com/grittv](https://media.giphy.com/media/UVRoPsDJRrO0uJnqah/giphy.gif)
Frustrated with Hollywood, Lee returned to Hong Kong, where he found an eager audience. ![https://giphy.com/rotomangler/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41YsliaHNoSvAau4/giphy.gif)
Hong Kong in the 1970s was a vibrant center of entertainment and culture, as well as growing protests against British rule.

The success of 1971's Big Boss gave Bruce Lee more control over his next film. Set in Japanese-occupied Shanghai, Fist of Fury resonated with Hong Kong's growing anti-colonial sentiment. [https://www.youtube.com/c/miramax](https://youtu.be/qOi56V-HOM4?t=190.55&e=211.30)
"Bruce Lee was very much a nationalist in that sense, that he wanted the Chinese people to be free and independent."" \[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, former NBA star\]

insights.title: Bruce Lee’s life was tragically cut short just as his dream was being fulfilled

paragraphCards.markdown: Bruce Lee found himself a star in Hong Kong, mobbed by fans while also facing resentment as a foreign-educated man married to a white woman.
Lee's newfound fame made him feel lonely and unsure who his real friends were.

He still longed to prove himself in America. Hong Kong producer Raymond Chow was reluctant to lose his star, but was convinced to partner with Warner Brothers for Bruce Lee's first Hollywood leading role.

During production of Enter the Dragon, Lee fought with producers, insisting on inserting more of his philosophy into the script to give the film substance. ![https://giphy.com/SportsManias/](https://media.giphy.com/media/jTkbYjIbs02XioSbi6/giphy.gif)

In July 1973, Bruce complained of a headache during a meeting and laid down for a nap after taking a painkiller. When his friends were unable to wake him up, he was taken to the hospital and pronounced dead on arrival.

Lee's death was determined to be a cerebral edema caused by a reaction to the medication Equagesic, but rumors and speculation abounded. ![Bruce\_Lee\_1.JPG](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/59/Bruce_Lee_1.JPG)

""I think that people wonder about his death so much because they can't believe that this 32-year-old, very strong, very virile man is just gone. So yes, they keep questioning and coming up with theories and all of that. But it doesn't matter. He's gone."" \[Linda Lee Cadwell, Bruce Lee's widow\]
Bruce Lee's funeral was chaotic for the family, with press cameras and large crowds.
Six days after its star's death, Enter the Dragon was released to massive success, grossing $91 million, the equivalent of $521 million today.
Bruce Lee may not have lived to see his vision realized, but his legacy lives on. ![https://giphy.com/digg](https://media.giphy.com/media/tSJWa6k0jgSis/giphy.gif)

""Even though I, Bruce Lee, may die someday without fulfilling all my ambitions, I feel no sorrow. I did what I wanted to do. What I've done, I've done with sincerity and to the best of my ability. You can't expect much more from life."" \[Bruce Lee\]

""Empty your mind, be formless, shapeless, like water. If you put water into a cup, it becomes the cup. You put water into a bottle and it becomes the bottle. You put it in a teapot, it becomes the teapot. Now water can flow, or it can crash. Be water, my friend."" \[Bruce Lee\]
With his sudden and untimely death at the peak of his stardom, Bruce Lee was immortalized as a larger-than-life figure in the history of cinema and martial arts.
Now, we're given a close-up look at this extraordinary, yet relatably human icon. ![https://giphy.com/brownsugarapp/](https://media.giphy.com/media/26gR1iYzSqtzcta4E/giphy.gif)
30 for 30 is a series of ESPN documentaries highlighting pivotal moments and figures in sports history. ![https://giphy.com/espn/](https://media.giphy.com/media/kdXjY8InWX0iUsyFvd/giphy.gif)

In this installment, director Bao Nguyen, previously known for commercial campaigns, crafts a masterful and nuanced examination of a remarkable life cut short in its prime. [https://www.youtube.com/c/TalkingPicturesTVShow](https://youtu.be/J_01-V35x2Y?t=12.68&e=30.26)
Featuring interviews with Bruce Lee's friends and family, cultural critics, and his own writings, Be Water traces the star's journey from Hong Kong to Hollywood and back again.
From his struggles with racism and his own mixed identity to his personal philosophy and creativity, this is a multifaceted look at the making of a legend.

Be Water is an intimate and poignant look at the life and philosophy of Bruce Lee, as well as the struggles that shaped his career. ![Bruce\_Lee\_1973.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ca/Bruce_Lee_1973.jpg)

Because Internet provides a deep insight into the way we communicate with each other, and how quickly this continues to change. [giphy.com/zambonato](https://media.giphy.com/media/9SJaONs482vvfqp3z9/giphy.mp4)

As more and more aspects of our lives move online, it's important that we learn to communicate with all the different generations - even the ones that may not be familiar with the latest reel on Tiktok.

insights.title: The rise of the internet means that we’re speaking to more people than ever

paragraphCards.markdown: 100 years ago, most human interaction took place either at home, work, or out and about in cafes or the dentist. [giphy.com/anchorpoint](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oKIPtwX904KOvjCEw/giphy.mp4)
Whilst you might occasionally speak to your hairdresser or the person behind you in a queue, most conversations would come from within certain networks of people you knew.
These days, however, that list just grew a lot wider with one single introduction: the internet.

Think of it this way - imagine walking into a restaurant with a group of friends, but instead of just interacting amongst yourselves, you also sit and listen to every conversation that's taking place at every table, as well as joining in on a chat between the chef, waiters and manager.
No longer are you only exposed to the people you know and spend a lot of time around, who often come from the same background or work in the same field.
You're now engaging with every single person from around the world. [giphy.com/robindavey](https://media.giphy.com/media/BcpGNCJ6A1j44/giphy.mp4)
It is this exposure that has exponentially affected the way that we use language.
By reading posts, watching gifs, and most recently scrolling through Tiktok video reels, we are constantly being bombarded with different people's ways of speaking.
Teenagers and the younger generations in particular are spending more time online, opting to send their friends Snapchats rather than meet to have a drink or go bowling.
This in turn has allowed them to spend longer browsing the infinite content the internet has to offer. [giphy.com/juliakotowski](https://media.giphy.com/media/YXH4C2beou9N22sx0q/giphy.mp4)
Whilst time on Facebook is usually spent reading updates from people we went to school with, Twitter has had the greater impact as it encourages us to follow and hear from people we don't know.
Once a new turn of phrase catches on, it can spread like wildfire.

insights.title: The internet’s influence over the way we speak has come a long way since LOL

paragraphCards.markdown: "Internet writing is a distinct genre with its own goals, and to accomplish those goals successfully requires a subtly tuned awareness of the full spectrum of the language." \[Gretchen McCulloch\]
Since the turn of the digital age, not only are we changing what we say, but we are just writing more often. [giphy.com/robindavey](https://media.giphy.com/media/aMat5ZC75j5JK/giphy.mp4)
Email and WhatsApp have replaced phone calls, and so whilst communication was predominantly based upon how you spoke and interacted personally, the written word has taken on a whole new dominance.
No longer do you associate it with school essays or formal editorials. Nowadays, we spend our days writing to everyone - our friends, parents, bosses, and even total strangers.
It's this that has instated the widespread understanding of 'informal writing'. [giphy.com/zambonato](https://media.giphy.com/media/1Sylk43T3fTSB3pGd0/giphy.mp4)
Whilst a period merely used to indicate the end of a sentence, it now comes with a feeling of passive-aggression or annoyance. You never end a message, period, right? You just go onto the next line.
Similarly, CAPITAL LETTERS have come to imply yelling, an exclamation mark means you're excited, and extra letters tacked on the end add some emphasis - 'yayyy', 'nooo'.
We're all aware of various acronyms that speed up our messaging process - OMG, BRB, BTW… Even your mom probably throws them around from time to time.
LOL started out just to confirm that you were laughing from behind your screen, but even that has developed over time. [giphy.com/hoppip](https://media.giphy.com/media/hnsu0K78O7hJK/giphy.mp4)
It can now be used as a form of irony or to diffuse a tense situation.
Our language online is a wheel that never stops turning.
[youtube.com/c/LingThusiasm](https://youtu.be/pGFmYiIzSnc?t=72.00&e=93.00)
One key foundation for these shifts is that we lose many of our tools for communication in text. [giphy.com/diegofarao](https://media.giphy.com/media/U7MbmX2RrLaruoPR44/giphy.mp4)
We aren't able to use volume or tone of voice to articulate ourselves and produce organic conversations.
This similarly links to the emergence of emoticon smileys in the 1980s :-) The internet was growing in popularity, and users needed a way to convey a virtual grin response.
These days, smileys go beyond just being happy or sad, but are actually even used for irony - something that can be easily mistranslated over text.

"I hate you" can be a pretty intense thing to say to someone, but stick a smiley on the end and it's fine - "I'm just kidding." [giphy.com/xuetongwang](https://media.giphy.com/media/5UvnjA9W69ZrEP3tWk/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: The emoji is a powerful form of self-expression

paragraphCards.markdown: Over the years, we've come to realize that it takes more than words and LOLs to express ourselves when writing a message.
Here enters the emoji. ![giphy.com/jamesthacher](https://media.giphy.com/media/d3mlGIM8WBQbQfVC/giphy.gif)
"Rather than try to compete with words on their own turf, emoji added a whole new system to represent a whole other layer of meaning." \[Gretchen McCulloch\]
Emojis are small symbols designed to represent a whole host of human gestures, emotions and activities.
Although they've been around a while, once Apple added them to its dataset in 2011 and Android in 2013, they exploded in popularity.
Now, all major phone manufacturers offer over 2,800 of them to choose from. [giphy.com/laurynsiegel](https://media.giphy.com/media/xTiTnoieCQLmBcZbvq/giphy.mp4)
An emoji allows the user to show they're nodding, thinking or laughing, and make the conversation more personal without having to bother with words.
And it's not just faces either. It's become common practice to add a cake when wishing someone Happy Birthday, a heart for sending love, or an eggplant for...well, you know.
Emojis add a whole new level of personality to a chat, providing not only color but an insight into the world around us.
Another thing that's brought a visual element into our communication is the use of memes. [giphy.com/yonialter](https://media.giphy.com/media/5xtDarvCddLSNySfI5O/giphy.mp4)
They took off in the early 2000s as sites started to pop up allowing users to add text to an image, offering the opportunity to get creative and design something online to share with your friends.
If a simple emoji won't cut it, maybe a meme can better express what you're trying to say.
After all, why tell someone how you feel on a Monday morning when a cat can do it for you? [giphy.com/samconcklin](https://media.giphy.com/media/MEcmrnpshJzYzsH4et/giphy.mp4)
"Language is a network, a web. Language is the ultimate participatory democracy. To put it in technological terms, language is humanity's most spectacular open source project." \[Gretchen McCulloch\]
We are all aware of the presence that the internet has in our lives. [giphy.com/tunadunn](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0K3YqS3Xv8vBAGiI/giphy.mp4)

We check social media multiple times a day, instantly turn to Google when we can't answer a question, and especially in 2020 when a lot of us suddenly found ourselves working from home, even our entire business systems can be found on the ever mysterious 'cloud'.
Being online has changed the way we socialize, date, work and relax at the weekends - but have you ever stopped to consider how it's affected the way you communicate?

Language is forever changing, and will always naturally develop with society. Looking back to Shakespeare 400 years ago, most of us can just about keep up. But go back a further 200 years to Chaucer, and you're going to struggle unless you have a degree in the subject.

Now, with our growing, instant access to different people all around the globe, these developments are happening faster than ever. [giphy.com/annasalmi](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IgMebNBaqnxe22Y/giphy.mp4)

Gretchen McCulloch is a linguist with her own podcast, Lingthusiasm, devoted entirely to the subject. In her book, Because Internet, she explores the impact that the internet has had on our language and the way that we use it.
It looks into the history of the internet and the different types of users that gradually got on board, before delving into how it's changed the way we interact with friends and strangers alike.

Analyzing our typography and vocabulary, Gretchen McCulloch shows us how we chat - and why emojis are actually key to our friendships. [giphy.com/dennismoore](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7aDd4hAEcciOzcVW/giphy.mp4)
[youtube.com/c/LingThusiasm](https://youtu.be/pGFmYiIzSnc?t=15.50&e=36.70)
Because Internet looks at the way in which we communicate today since the arrival of the internet, and how our language has developed to keep up with the ever-changing trends online.

Becoming the Boss is an excellent book for everybody, not just managers. It focuses on looking inward at how you can improve as a leader, and as so much of being a boss these days is about having a commanding presence with no humility, we need leaders that can see their faults too.

insights.title: The best leaders are the best at leading themselves

paragraphCards.markdown: Being a great leader isn't just about how you manage other people's lives, but how you manage your own.
It might sound daunting, especially if you're new to your position, but there is hope for you.
The first rule you want to follow is: don't panic.
Things change fast in the business world. Technology throws ideas at us at lightning speeds, and it's completely normal to be afraid occasionally. You can learn to handle it.
One helpful way is to ask yourself if you want what's in front of you is worth it - do you want it more than you're afraid of it?
If you can answer 'yes', then push through your fears and go for it.
Nowadays, it's essential to learn to be creative. It used to be that you could become an expert in your field and that would be enough, but not anymore.
If you want to stand apart, learn the ropes of other fields.
Always be looking to learn, and work harder. Assess your current knowledge. Pay attention to the skills you need to work on and make a plan.
If you need inspiration, check the LinkedIn profiles of people you admire to see what they're good at and work on those things.

insights.title: To have a positive influence, focus on others and make your communication skills top-notch

actions.title: Lead with communication.
actions.markdown: Have an open door policy with your team. Keep them updated on what’s going on within the company, and always encourage them to come and talk to you. Listen carefully to what they need, and try to help whenever possible.

paragraphCards.markdown: Some of the best leadership and life advice you'll ever receive is: It's not about you.
Research from the University of Texas confirms this, too. It identified that leaders don't use the word "I" as much as non-leaders.
If you want to be excellent, stop thinking and talking so much about yourself.
It doesn't do any good to just try to avoid doing something bad, you want to fill the gap with what's good - and that's thinking about your employees.
You need to focus on the needs of your people, and not your own. If you're lost in yourself and what you need to improve all the time, you won't be receptive to other people.
Under-communication is another must-avoid when working with others.
One survey by Accountemps identified that not communicating often or openly enough hurts morale more than anything else a manager can do wrong, so it's better to do it too much than not enough.

insights.title: Use people’s names when talking with them, avoid gossip at all times, and know how to deal with difficult questions

paragraphCards.markdown: Not all are born with excellent communication skills, but you can always learn them.
Even some of the most basic ones can be applied, and you'll see the results in just a few minutes.
One of the first is to remember people's names, and use them when you're speaking.
It's an excellent persuasion tool and can make people feel special and valued - but always be sure that you're using the right name.
We often overlook the power of eye-contact, but building this habit when conversing with employees expresses confidence.
Sometimes an unexpected question comes up that you don't know the answer to. Don't just try and guess. Instead, maintain confidence by using one of these three techniques…

1.  Refer the person to another who might have the answer.
2.  Defer the question by telling them you'll get back to them.
3.  Ask them to be more specific.
You also want to avoid gossip at all times. It's always negative, and often influences others to think you're not trustworthy.
Have you ever been around someone that only likes to talk about other people? If they're talking about another person behind their back, then what's to stop them from talking about you behind yours?
Don't lose your employees' trust. Never talk about other people when they're not around.
"How well you are capable of leading other people begins, first and foremost, with how well you lead yourself." \[Lindsey Pollack\]
There are a few common threads in books, and one of the biggest is how fast our world is changing.
We all have to work pretty hard to keep up, and leaders are no exception to this rule.

What worked well for the greats of the past, like Bill Gates and Steve Jobs, doesn't always apply today. Technology is changing the way we communicate and learn so fast that it's a wonder any of us can keep up - let alone those at the top.

In Lindsey Pollak's Becoming the Boss: New Rules for the Next Generation of Leaders, you'll learn what you need to succeed as a leader, and how to remain malleable enough to change and improve according to the modern world.
Becoming the Boss shows leaders of all kinds, whether new or experienced, how to identify the pitfalls that stand in the way of influencing others for the better and overcome them.

Getting enough quality sleep is paramount for human health, but in the modern world of artificial lighting and multiple screens, it has been pushed into jeopardy. Using the tips outlined in Better Sleep, you can take the first steps towards better sleep.

insights.title: Some of us really are just ‘morning people’

actions.title: Embrace your chronotype.
actions.markdown: Learn to understand your genetic chronotype, and assess if you’re a morning lark, night owl, or a bit of both. Make changes in your routine to better suit your body.

actions.title: Keep your sleep regular.
actions.markdown: Avoid social jetlag. Even a two-hour difference in your sleep timing can have devastating effects. Keep it regular, even after nights out, and notice a positive difference in your sleep.

paragraphCards.markdown: "You can think of deep sleep almost like the very best health insurance policy that you could ever wish for." \[Matthew Walker\]

Human sleep falls into two subtypes: rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and non-rapid eye movement sleep (NREM). These battle each other every 90 minutes, all night. ![:Normal\_EEG\_of\_mouse.png](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/58/Normal_EEG_of_mouse.png)
NREM helps to consolidate information learned during the day, transfers short-term memories to the long-term memory store, and improves our immune system.
So, we need sleep to cement new memories and to help us solve problems.
REM sleep is the dream state. ![giphy.com/carawrrr/](https://media.giphy.com/media/efiJu4wfuirdwmT57D/giphy.gif)
"Think of REM sleep almost like group therapy for memories, taking information, and seeking out, and connecting these pieces of information." \[Matthew Walker\]

From the moment you wake up, a chemical called 'adenosine' builds – this is sleep pressure. ![Adenosintriphosphat\_protoniert.svg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Adenosintriphosphat_protoniert.svg/2880px-Adenosintriphosphat_protoniert.svg.png)
The more adenosine builds up, the sleepier you feel. When you sleep, your brain removes it all.
Working alongside adenosine is your circadian rhythm, a cycle that monitors the time of day through a 24 hour cycle.
Your circadian activity will peak before midday and extend through the afternoon, before dialing down through the evening and hitting its lowest point 3-4 hours into sleep.

Circadian rhythms use a hormone called melatonin, which can be disrupted by light - which is why they tell you to stay off your bright phone screen before bed. ![giphy.com/alessiamoreno](https://media.giphy.com/media/SUzqTGCOdOwi6xSIXm/giphy.gif)

Our genetic chronotype determines whether we're a morning lark, a night owl, or somewhere in between. This shifts throughout our childhood and later stages of life. ![giphy.com/BENTMOB](https://media.giphy.com/media/ZY3UyE6u6XNt2n0I7i/giphy.gif)
Everyone has a 24-hour circadian rhythm, but it's your chronotype that determines where your peak rhythm sits.
Remember - it's impossible to 'catch up' on lost sleep. ![giphy.com/popandsicle/](https://media.giphy.com/media/lMC94UjrRyLs1UvDnT/giphy.gif)

"When you are mismatched with your chronotype, especially if you're trying to sleep during the day, the quantity and the quality of that sleep isn't as good. And as a consequence, you become immunocompromised." \[Matthew Walker\]

insights.title: Sleep deprivation has a catalytic effect on certain illnesses

actions.title: Sleep well to lose weight.
actions.markdown: If you want to lose a few pounds or go on a diet, get your sleep pattern in check first. Make sure you’re getting at least seven hours a night, as sleep deprivation will result in a loss of muscle rather than fat.

actions.title: Speak to your doctor.
actions.markdown: If you think you might have a fully-fledged sleep disorder, get treatment from a health professional for better long-term physical and mental health.

paragraphCards.markdown: "There is a very intimate association between your sleep health and your immune health." \[Matthew Walker\]

We think of sleep, diet, and exercise as the three pillars of good health, but sleep is the foundation on which those two other pillars sit. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/106zCmbMKYY?t=33.82&e=49.01)

Those who report sleeping fewer than seven hours a night are more likely to catch the common cold, or even pneumonia. ![giphy.com/jagyasini](https://media.giphy.com/media/JQFxBKv9u2Kf2EAaIa/giphy.gif)

Lack of sleep can disrupt testosterone production and the menstrual cycle, and significant relationships have been discovered between sleep disorders and depression, anxiety, PTSD, schizophrenia, and suicide.

The quality of our sleep will begin to decline with age. As our brains deteriorate, they can't generate the sleep that they need. ![giphy.com/Comicada/](https://media.giphy.com/media/h5KucFQG3rl8bZPsj9/giphy.gif)
There's significant evidence of a relationship between sleep and Alzheimer's disease.
The brain has its own cleansing tool known as the 'glymphatic system', which clears away a lot of the waste products developing during the day. A lack of sleep hinders this process.
Sleep deprivation also results in a shift in the immune system that can lead cancers to grow more aggressively. ![giphy.com/harvard](https://media.giphy.com/media/1rO2oRHQxqETgyUryr/giphy.gif)
"Short sleep duration has been associated with a doubling of your risk for the development of things such as lung cancer, ovarian cancer, as well as thyroid cancer, even myeloma." \[Matthew Walker\]
A lack of sleep can change the balance of your appetite-regulating hormones. This often results in weight gain, and impairs will power and impulse control.

Sleep deprivation disrupts both the release of insulin, triggered by high blood sugar, and the cells' ability to respond to insulin signals. Chronically high levels of blood sugar can go on to result in type 2 diabetes.

insights.title: Healthy habits and a bedtime routine can help improve sleep

actions.title: Wind down before sleep.
actions.markdown: Turn off all screens at least an hour before bed, and find a relaxing evening routine to suit you, whether that’s light stretching, reading, meditating, or having a hot shower or bath.

actions.title: Expose yourself to less light.
actions.markdown: Open your eyes to natural light in the morning to feel more awake. Seek out more darkness in the evenings. Even artificial light at night will encourage wakefulness.

actions.title: Get up if you can’t sleep.
actions.markdown: If you wake up in the night and after 30 minutes can’t get back to sleep, move into a different space. Read or listen to music in very dim lighting. Stop your brain associating your bed with wakefulness.

paragraphCards.markdown: The best way to start sleeping better is to go to bed and get up at the same time every day, aiming for between seven and nine hours of sleep. ![giphy.com/olehenriksen/](https://media.giphy.com/media/55vOys8brQlzq6Wc3O/giphy.gif)

Sleep isn't as simple as flicking a switch – take the time to wind down. A hot bath and writing down any worries before bed can help. ![giphy.com/beautybay/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ofRHW71femyc8kW0Q/giphy.gif)
Avoid screens and dim the lighting in the hour before bed. Keep your bedroom cool, at around 18°C.
Don't use alcohol as a nightcap, as it sedates rather than encourages sleep. If you're going to drink, avoid going to bed tipsy. Same goes for nicotine.
Limit your caffeine intake after 12pm, as it has a quarter-life of around 10-12 hours after consumption, meaning you will still have 25% of that initial hit in your system.
Don't go to bed too full or too hungry, and avoid sugary foods in the evenings. Try to stop eating around 2-3 hours before bed.
Limit the bed to solely sleeping and intimacy – don't watch TV or do work. ![giphy.com/beautybay](https://media.giphy.com/media/OvQE7HXPukMUP0BDmR/giphy.gif)
If you're going to take naps, take them before 3pm and keep them to less than 20 minutes.
"Sleep may be the greatest legal performance-enhancing drug that too few athletes are abusing enough in this modern day and age." \[Matthew Walker\]

Those who exercise regularly sleep better and for longer. In turn, sleep improves your quality of exercise by helping the body to recover overnight. ![giphy.com/rysetcomic/](https://media.giphy.com/media/25OC7fR4bg6lvxGrjI/giphy.gif)
The lower your quantity and quality of sleep, the higher your injury risk.
However, avoid exercising right before bed, and make sure to hydrate after your workout. ![giphy.com/slizzabella](https://media.giphy.com/media/5hwo8oJtV4zUYqC0Ix/giphy.gif)
"Sleep will actually prime back the levels of energy such as the glucose and the glycogen stores within our muscles." \[Matthew Walker\]
"Sleep is the elixir of life. It is the Swiss army knife of health, and it is mother nature's best effort yet at immortality." \[Matthew Walker\]
Why do we sleep and why is it becoming a more challenging task for people all over the world? ![giphy.com/lonbali](https://media.giphy.com/media/gijLs0MZlIinEJTVQq/giphy.gif)

Whether you're struggling with sleep or are simply curious about the mechanics and impacts behind it, this is the MasterClass for you. ![giphy.com/Tiffaaanyyy](https://media.giphy.com/media/h5hoo98qX5Pr9EbpM5/giphy.gif)

Neuroscience professor Matthew Walker, author of Why We Sleep, has studied sleep for more than 20 years and had more than 100 scientific papers published on the topic of sleep. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/106zCmbMKYY?t=0.00&e=20.35)

In this MasterClass, Walker shares extraordinary insight into why sleep is so important, how a lack of sleep will affect your wellbeing, the importance of chronotypes, and what tips you can bring to the bedroom for a better night's sleep.

This MasterClass from neuroscientist Matthew Walker is loaded with facts about how sleep impacts our health. Backed up by numerous studies, it can provide us with a wealth of advice, and a better understanding of our own sleep.

Through revealing interviews with Nye, his closest friends and family, and fellow scientists, Bill Nye: Science Guy is a personal look at the man behind the character from television that weaves together poignant moments and professional accomplishments.
By stressing the importance of scientific thinking, we are invited to join Nye on his quest to save the world.

insights.title: Scientists are alarmed at the increasing rejection of scientific thought in the United States

actions.title: Be curious about science.
actions.markdown: You don’t have to become a scientist; a documentary or an evening class at your local community college might be enough to spark your intellectual fire.

paragraphCards.markdown: "We have this increasing anti-science movement in the United States. It's worse than ever. The anti-science movement is more powerful than it's ever been." \[Bill Nye, science educator\]
In the past few decades, science teachers have noticed a decline in the number of young people who want to have science careers.
The amplification of science deniers through the internet and social media has created an immense challenge for educators and researchers.
The resurgence of religious beliefs held up as 'scientific', such as creationism, has been particularly troubling.
People who deny scientific consensus from evolution to climate change have been given platforms to spread disinformation to people of all ages, but especially to children.
Though a minority, science deniers can have an outsized impact through social media.
And politicians further amplify the message on a national scale by repeating false and inaccurate information.

"It does not always seem as if science is in the room when it needs to be. And so gifted teachers of science, with a lot of credibility, a sense of humor and ability to convey complex information are needed more than ever." \[Francis Collins, director of the National Institutes of Health\]
The struggle to keep pseudo-science out of science class has galvanized scientists and educators.

"These people who are denying science … and especially denying human-caused climate change, we can't have this. We've got to fight this fight. I've got to fight this fight." \[Bill Nye, science educator\]

insights.title: It might be uncomfortable, but we must keep engaging climate change deniers

actions.title: Challenge misinformation and ask questions.
actions.markdown: Don’t let misinformation go uncorrected, but engage the people with empathy and curiosity. Ask questions about their beliefs rather than making it a one-sided conversation of facts and figures.

paragraphCards.markdown: It's a recurring question among the scientific research community as well as the public: Do we argue with anti-science stances and climate change deniers? And if so, to what extent?
"Debates between scientists and science deniers could be a trap that scientists probably should not get involved in." \[Eugenie Scott, physical anthropologist\]
Professional researchers caution against giving a platform to deniers.
While formal debates with large audiences can backfire on high-profile scientists, Nye still encourages everyday people to have hard conversations with those who deny human-caused climate change.
After all, many of us know someone who still expresses doubt about the validity of scientific findings.
And keep in mind that, often, a deeply held philosophical belief that contradicts science is an ingrained part of someone's identity.

"So what I say is just keep talking to people. Why do you believe that? What makes you think that climate change isn't happening? What makes you disagree with all the world's scientists? What is it?" \[Bill Nye, science educator\]

insights.title: A child’s environment is important for developing the capacity for scientific thinking

paragraphCards.markdown: We all know that our parents have a profound effect on our development, views, and attitudes and that extends to our relationship to science.
Bill Nye's mother was an Enigma code breaker during World War II, and her intellectual influence as well as her feminism deeply affected her children.
Both of Nye's parents encouraged his intellectual curiosity growing up.
As a child, Bill Nye had space of his own in the family home to conduct experiments. He credits much of his success to this freedom to explore and the values instilled in him by his parents.
Nye's father always told him to 'leave the world better than you found it.'
The messages a child receives from their parents stick with them, whether it's the idea that girls aren't good at math or skepticism about the validity of scientific information.
Even if these messages are subtle, they can have a deep and lasting impact.
On the other hand, positive messages can set children on a trajectory for unimaginable success.
"My parents made me who I am \[...\] I try to be worthy of them. I try to leave a legacy." \[Bill Nye, science educator\]
"He's the science teacher we all wish we had in elementary school, or middle school, high school, even college." \[Neil deGrasse Tyson, astrophysicist\]
For Americans of a certain age, few things bring to mind science lessons faster than the name Bill Nye.
The kooky host of the 1990s children's science television show introduced millions of kids to scientific theory and thinking.

In this documentary, filmmakers David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg gained exclusive access to Nye and his personal life, interviewing friends and family as well as heavy-hitting colleagues in the science world.
Throughout the film, Nye keeps a laser focus on climate change and space exploration and lays out his approach for combating science denialists in a civil manner.

The film presents the vulnerable, sometimes fallible, side of the science star, such as when he accepts a high-profile debate with an anti-science creationist and unintentionally amplifies the man's message.
Directors Alvarado and Sussberg portray the human behind one of the country's best-loved bow-tied educational characters.
Bill Nye: Science Guy is an intimate behind-the-scenes look at one of America's favorite science educators and his ongoing battle to stop the proliferation of anti-scientific thinking.
Brain Rules has advice that has been said before, but the repetition adds to its validity. It boosts our productivity through brain power in a way we can enjoy.

insights.title: Our brain and body will work better if we exercise more

actions.title: Incorporate exercise into your routine.
actions.markdown: You don’t have to go for three hour runs to feel the benefits of exercise on your mental health. Break up your long working day with regular stretches and walks, even just up and down the stairs. Consider walking or cycling to close-by destinations instead of driving.

paragraphCards.markdown: It's interesting to look at our brain's development from the perspective of our early ancestors.
After all, their daily activities had an impact on the way their brains evolved into what we've got today.
Each day the average _Homo sapien_ would walk or run 10-20 kilometers.
What does that mean for neural development? It had to happen during exercise, which means our brains today do best when we move more.
Our minds need fuel from the food you eat to run properly.
When we exercise, all parts of our body, including our head, get better at taking in nutrients from eating.
This healthy habit also improves blood flow around the body, which helps create new blood vessels. Vitamins and minerals can then move around more easily, and waste is easier to discard.
Think of this like early civilization's road systems.

At first, the pathways were bumpy and difficult to travel. But when one engineer saw the need to smooth them out, the movement of goods became more efficient. With this came better access to all sorts of supplies.
The same happens to our bodies when we exercise, as our blood flows more smoothly as well!
Another huge benefit of exercise is that it stimulates the creation of hormones, many of which improve our body's tissues.
One of these is the brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), which helps in the creation of new cells. It also keeps neurons and the connections between them healthy.

insights.title: We all have a unique sleep pattern that we need to discover, and stick to, for optimal mental performance

actions.title: Establish a sleep pattern, and stick to it.
actions.markdown: Set your ‘night time’ settings on your phone, to encourage yourself to stick to this schedule. Try to put your phone away at least an hour before you go to bed, so you don’t keep your brain “awake”. Leave it in another room if you have to. Try to find something to read instead.

paragraphCards.markdown: For our early ancestors, sleeping was dangerous. You could easily be eaten by a predator if you dozed off at the wrong time!
So the fact that our ancestors took the effort to make it possible, and that we still do it today, is telling: it means that it's vital to our health.
In the simplest terms, sleep rejuvenates our body and brain.
Without sleep, we begin to suffer. Not getting enough rest has such an impact that doing it one week will give you a "sleep debt" the next.
And if we only get six hours or less of sleep a night for five days, we're just as cognitively impaired as if we'd gone 48-hours straight without sleeping!

While you might be thinking, "I know I need to get to bed earlier," you actually might have a sleep cycle that's just later. Understanding this, and adhering to it, is vital for good mental and physical health.
According to research, people that know their schedule and follow it generally are intellectually stronger.
About 10% of people are night owls that like to stay up late. People who like to get up early are larks, and make up another 10% of the population.
Everyone else is a hummingbird, changing between staying up late and rising early.
If you really want to discover yours, try searching Google for a quiz that will tell you. Once you know your type, stick to it for better mental performance!

insights.title: It’s easier to learn when we try to get information in both visual and auditory formats

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Our mind's integrative instincts began when the earliest _Homo sapiens_ were still drawing on cave walls.
What does that mean? Because they experienced multiple senses at once, their brains evolved to take in knowledge when all senses are engaged.
We can still do this today, and should, if we want to learn efficiently.
Another way to think of this is that the more senses we involve when we're learning something, the better the information will stick.
In one study, scientists had participants view a video of someone speaking that had no sound. Their auditory cortexes, the part of the brain responsible for picking up noise, were still active.
Interestingly, this same area was inactive when the same people saw a silent video of someone only making faces.
In other words, learning isn't as efficient when only one sense is involved because fewer parts of the brain are active.
Research by Richard Mayer confirms this. He conducted an experiment that separated participants into three groups that were given information by different means:
When it was time to remember the material they had all been shown, the group that could see AND hear it performed the best by far.
It seems illogical that the more senses that participate would help us remember things. Shouldn't our brains get overloaded from this?

If we're multitasking, then yes, that may be the case. But as the science confirms, if we really want a specific thing to stick in our mind, try to get as many senses involved as possible in the experience!
"One of the greatest predictors of successful aging, they found, is the presence or absence of a sedentary lifestyle."
Put your hands into fists and put them together. This is about the size of that gray matter in your skull that's letting you control everything you're doing right now.
It seems small when we think of it like this, but our brain holds a whole lot of potential. The big question is, can you improve it?
Maybe you still think that you can't teach an old dog new tricks. But the truth is that our minds can grow and improve no matter how old we are.

That's what we'll learn from Brain Rules: 12 Principles for Surviving and Thriving at Work, Home, and School. After this book, we'll know just what habits we need to have a happier and healthier mind.
Brain Rules teaches us how to become more productive at work and life, with proven facts about how much our mind improves with good sleep, exercise, and learning with all five senses.

Change Your Questions, Change Your Life is full of lessons you'll want to share with anyone willing to listen. Its ideas and questions are functional tools that can help you shift away from conflict and into progress.
So now, when you find yourself asking judgmental questions, you'll be able to turn and look for a switching question, and change the direction of the conversation.

insights.title: The questions we ask will either open doors for learning, or lead us into a pit

actions.title: Cut yourself some slack.
actions.markdown: Bad things happen, but that doesn’t always make it your fault. Instead of fretting or getting angry at yourself, stop and ask objectively, “What are my options? What am I going to choose as my next step?”

paragraphCards.markdown: Thoughts, feelings, and circumstances fill every waking moment of our days and spill over into our dreams.
Our first opportunity for change presents itself when we observe our thoughts and recognize their nature.

Questions like: "What am I responsible for?" and, "What are they thinking, feeling, and wanting?" steer us toward rational choices, solutions, and win-win relations. ![giphy.com/mila\_neus](https://media.giphy.com/media/UwnjJySmxczzrAQpbc/giphy.gif)
In contrast, when we ask, "Why are they so stupid?" or, "Why bother?" we find ourselves stuck in a pit of judgment. ![giphy.com/mila\_neus](https://media.giphy.com/media/9wLJtpJalOPe7Yiigq/giphy.gif)

Imagine receiving an email from a boss highlighting every benchmark not hit over the last quarter, or receiving summons for jury duty that's scheduled for the same week as a much-anticipated vacation.
Both of those scenarios elicit thoughts and feelings, so how should we deal with them? ![giphy.com/oceanicglobal/](https://media.giphy.com/media/LwISXPUr9bA0MH4vD9/giphy.gif)
Do we ask, "Why am I so careless? Why am I a failure? Why bother?" Or, instead, "What's happened? What choices do I have? What's best to do now?"
Asking learner questions keeps us moving forward.
Events, good and bad, flow through our lives like a river. When we mindfully paddle, we master the ability to skirt rocks, and find less turbulent waters within the rapids.

insights.title: Switching questions have the power to move us from judgment to learning

actions.title: Be a learner, not a judger.
actions.markdown: When you start to feel yourself rolling your eyes at someone, stop. Think about how you could potentially help them feel better and less negative. Learn something about them, and allow yourself to grow as a positive person.

paragraphCards.markdown: Imagine sitting at a long, rectangular conference table waiting for a meeting to begin. ![giphy.com/XING\_DACH/](https://media.giphy.com/media/U4pTjbmK3GyqWujKlz/giphy.gif)
For ten minutes, the woman to your right has been rapid-firing opinions about your child's primary school, which her children previously attended.
You endure her complaints about the teachers, the lunch program, and the new math curriculum. Running through your mind are questions like, "How did I get seated here? Who does she think she is?"

If you think about it, you're asking yourself judgemental questions about a judgmental person. Two judgers don't lead to possibility. ![giphy.com/CartoonNetworkLatam/](https://media.giphy.com/media/LS8dIaRdiTEFVBSxDF/giphy.gif)

Feelings of anger and frustration alert us that we're shifting to a more judgmental state of mind. So instead, seize the opportunity to shift into questions that will keep you out of the judger pit. ![/giphy.com/Michael\_on\_the\_Moon/](https://media.giphy.com/media/1dNMDv15NeGDvY3iGz/giphy.gif)
A 'switching question' gives you the freedom to explore options like, "What does she need?" and "How else can I think about her?"
When you feel yourself slipping into more judgemental thought patterns, you can flip the switch to learner mode, and turn the conversation around for both parties.
Practice asking questions like, "What assumptions am I making?" and "How can I be more objective and honest?"

One switching question has the potential to free you and your companion from unhelpful conversational territory. Before you know it, you'll be paddling alongside each other on calm water. ![giphy.com/ShastaPools/](https://media.giphy.com/media/M9TbsVzWI8YAEEJJ5u/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Asking yourself a few questions can shift individuals and groups toward comprehensive and creative possibilities

paragraphCards.markdown: When we encounter situations in which we feel frustrated, stuck, or want something to change, you can ask yourself certain questions to help shift your perspective. ![giphy.com/Affectiva/](https://media.giphy.com/media/hR6g5ZQZfwav8gMctA/giphy.gif)

*   What do I want?
*   What are my choices?
*   Which assumptions am I making?
*   What am I responsible for?

*   How else can I think about this?
*   What is the other person thinking, feeling, and wanting?
*   Is there something I am missing or avoiding?
*   What can I learn from this person/situation/failure/success?

*   Which action steps make the most sense?
*   What questions should I ask?
*   How can I turn this into a win-win?
*   What's possible?
There's no need to ask them in a specific order, and not every question fits every situation.
The goal is to incorporate learner questions into our daily thinking patterns. ![giphy.com/leeamerica/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1J9CNGWbBdfaDfz2/giphy.gif)
As we regularly reference and ask queries from the list, we will find ourselves opening up to possibility.
Make a copy of the list and keep it handy!
""I have a vision of workplaces and a society - of individuals, families, institutions, and communities - that are vibrant with the spirit of inquiry."" \[Marilee Adams\]

Through a vivid cast of characters, author Marilee Adams invites us into a workplace fable from which we'll learn how to revolutionize our personal and professional relationships. [youtube.com/c/InquiryInstitute](https://youtu.be/AbloxyQpr2A?t=0.85&e=22.68)

We're all prone to judging others, but we're also quick to judge ourselves. Each of us operates from a mix of learner and judger mindsets. [youtube.com/c/InquiryInstitute](https://youtu.be/sLmhoOiZ0L8?t=74.17&e=98.10)

With effort, we can cultivate the seeds of connection by watering and fertilizing rich beds of acceptance, curiosity, dialogue, and creativity, while pulling out the weeds of blame, rigidity, assumptions, and fear.

Additionally, we can learn to implement the ABCC Choice Process. First, ask yourself if you are judging. Next, take a breath, and get curious about your circumstances. Finally, choose to ask learner questions. ![giphy.com/noguenogue](https://media.giphy.com/media/StFXOevytfSohl7cUC/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Even if we’re the underdog, we can win against big competitors by relying on our unique skills

actions.title: Focus on your strengths.
actions.markdown: Don’t dwell on your opponent’s strengths or your own weaknesses. Instead, think about what you’re good at and work out how you can use that to your advantage.

paragraphCards.markdown: Interesting statistic: If an underdog army uses guerrilla tactics in battle, it wins 63% of the time. If it doesn't and tries to fight fire with fire, it wins in only 29% of battles.
What does that mean? If you're the underdog, don't fight your biggest competitor in their domain.
Instead, focus on how you can outsmart them with your own individual strengths. ![giphy.com/teamtumult](https://media.giphy.com/media/j0SrVwV9e95qWm7Gs2/giphy.gif)
If you've ever been to Trafalgar Square, you'll see a statue of Lord Horatio Nelson at the very top of a huge column.
In 1805 at the Battle of Trafalgar, the English navy was clearly outnumbered with 33 ships facing 41 of the French and Spanish.
The reason they engaged in such a dangerous battle was that they knew, once the French made it to the English homeland, they'd lose.
The French army was a lot stronger than the British. But at sea, the English could beat them. ![giphy.com/blacksails](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0ExkIaOPEOBOB9Be/giphy.gif)
Thanks to uncommon tactics, like approaching the enemy head-on and circling off parts of the fleet, the British sunk one French ship and captured 21 others – without losing a single one themselves.

If you're facing a Goliath, and feel like David, don't compare yourself in physical strength. Think about what you can do that your enemy can't. ![giphy.com/teamtumult](https://media.giphy.com/media/iIGKHgWCKPt7OJgGzZ/giphy.gif)
Then, you'll actually have a decent chance of winning.
"Courage is what you earn when you've been through the tough times and you discover they aren't so tough after all." \[Malcolm Gladwell\]

Malcolm Gladwell draws on historic events and the psychology of highly successful human beings to illustrate that underdogs have advantages. ![Malcolm\_Gladwell.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f6/Malcolm_Gladwell_2014_%28cropped%29_-2.jpg)

Just like David beat Goliath despite being smaller, weaker and less skilled in battle, he shows how we can battle the odds and come out on top. [youtube.com/c/audiblecouk](https://youtu.be/nw26Kfx2s1A?t=111.50&e=129.40)

David and Goliath explains why underdogs win in situations where the odds are stacked unfavorably against them, and how we can do the same.![giphy.com/boomunderground](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0MYL0jA0InII1F1C/giphy.gif)

Delegation Mastery: Increase Productivity & Hit Your Goals! makes the process of developing a delegation strategy quite simple, and shows all the opportunities available when we actively plan before delegating.

insights.title: Delegation can help to develop team members.

actions.title: Pick a team member with just enough skills to do the job.
actions.markdown: When looking for a team member to give a task, consider who has just enough skills to complete the task and can stand to gain the most growth from the experience.

paragraphCards.markdown: Besides the more commonly known benefits of delegating such as achieving personal and organizational goals, delegation can also be a powerful tool for skills development for individual team members.
By giving a team member more responsibility we are giving them a challenge and an opportunity to grow their skills.
So where we are faced with an opportunity to pick one team member over the other for a particular task it might help to pick the team member with just enough skills to see the task through.
Instead of giving the opportunity to a team member that can easily do the job, we can give the opportunity to a team member who can be challenged by the experience.
Everything must be done in moderation however.
If we delegate to the wrong person or give the wrong team member too much responsibility we risk failing to accomplish the task.
It's equally important to consider the particular team member's workload before assigning them even more tasks, as we might mistakenly assign more work to a team member who is already overwhelmed.

insights.title: The secret to effective delegation is planning.

actions.title: Define the task.
actions.markdown: Think about all the questions that someone would want to know about the task before taking it on, and try to address them in detail during the planning phase.

actions.title: Make sure the person and the task are a good fit.
actions.markdown: When choosing a person to complete the task, consider if the person has the right skills and is competent enough to complete the task.

actions.title: Set clear boundaries.
actions.markdown: Clearly set out parameters and limits by clearly stating expectations, level of authority and even access to resources when delegating.

paragraphCards.markdown: When it comes to delegating there should be no surprises, everything has to be according to a plan.
That is the only way of reducing some of the risks associated with delegating.
When we delegate we cede control of the task in one way or the other and the only way to ensure that goals will still be met is setting out a plan and ensuring compliance to that plan.

There are quite a few steps to establishing a delegation plan but they are all focused on defining the task, setting performance indicators and achieving mutual understanding of the roles and responsibilities of everyone involved.
Just as importantly it has to be clear what resources are going to be available to complete the task.
Everyone has to understand what is expected of them and even repeat it a couple of times if possible.
Also, parameters and limits have to be clearly established, especially on higher risk projects where creative license may pose too big a risk.
Failure to establish or maintain parameters can also lead to unnecessary conflict, unexpected demands and overstepping of boundaries that are not clearly defined.

insights.title: Delegation is not limited to subordinates; it can also extend to bosses, peers and so many other groups.

actions.title: Delegate to a boss.
actions.markdown: There are cases where getting a boss involved might help us achieve our goals faster, and where there are shared goals, bosses may be more willing to help than we might think.

actions.title: Sign a NDA when delegating a task to an external partner.
actions.markdown: Delegating work to external partners exposes us to privacy breaches, so it is important to make sure that we sign a non-disclosure agreement with the partner to protect ourselves from the possible exposure

paragraphCards.markdown: When people think about delegation in most cases they think about their subordinates.
However, when we open our minds up to the skills, resources and opportunities we can access by expanding the groups of people we can reach, we can get even more done.
Depending on the nature of relationships we have with people there are groups of people within and outside our organization we can delegate responsibilities too.
It's interesting to know that there are cases where delegating tasks to our bosses is possible.
There are times where we might spend days trying to get things done when we could ask a boss to do it on our behalf and have it done in a couple of minutes.
We must also be willing to let our subordinates delegate work to us when it serves our shared goals.
The key is to promote a culture of collaboration where we can even delegate work to our peers and vise-versa.

Sometimes we may not be able to find the skills or resources we might need to meet our goals internally. In those cases it's a good idea to call on external partners such as virtual assistants, consultants, vendors and any other partners that may be within our reach for help.
It is important to note however, that when we engage external partners we don't expose our own organization to breaches in privacy as well as any kind of liability.
"If it can be delegated, it must be delegated." \[Steve Ballinger\]

With 25 years of experience in various leadership and management positions, Delegation Mastery: Increase Productivity & Hit Your Goals!' instructor Steve Ballinger has real workplace experience developing delegation systems that work.
That is why his courses are so practical; they are not only developed from empirical research, but from practical hands on experience.
So when Ballinger says it works, he knows what he is talking about.

In this course he focuses on demonstrating how delegating can make it easier to achieve personal and organizational goals, empower colleagues and even clear up more time to focus on the bigger picture.
Ballinger provides a detailed systems approach to delegating, allowing us to use the course as an easy to follow step by step guide to delegating when we need to.

Ballinger acknowledges that people often have bad experiences with delegating when tasks are botched, but he also provides an alternative approach to conducting the process that reduces the risk associated with delegating.
Through the practical principles introduced in this course, we can begin to reach for all the benefits of delegating, with little of the risks.
In Delegation Mastery: Increase Productivity & Hit Your Goals!, Steve Ballinger demystifies delegating by showing how effective a tool it is when used well.
