paragraphCards.markdown: The beloved princess remains a topic of intrigue for many ![Diana, Princess of Wales 1997 (2).jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/Diana%2C_Princess_of_Wales_1997_%282%29.jpg)
There has always been much speculation not only on her fraught private and public life, but the circumstances surrounding her death and the role of the media in the tragedy.
This portrait is an intimate account of the intricacies of Diana's upbringing and life with Charles, and the discrepancies between the media's portrayal and the truth - in her own words.

insights.title: Diana felt estranged even as a child, and was not prepared for a royal marriage

paragraphCards.markdown: Over a montage of scenes from early life, Diana describes her childhood as unhappy and her younger self as detached and unstable. ![giphy.com/bbc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/lzQYVFyCmFPkj200Aw/giphy.gif)

Born into a noble family, the princess felt estranged from her peers as a teenager. ![Althorp. The home of the Spencer Family and Princess Diana (England)](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_13088878.jpg)
Despite not having had a boyfriend she intuited that she would eventually "marry someone in the public eye."
At 19, Diana met Prince Charles. Their brief courtship culminated in a marriage proposal in 1981, her immaturity and lack of experience considered an asset by the press and the royal family.

Diana was not ready for the extent of press hounding she received. Paparazzi trailed her with binocular lenses and photographed through her windows, but the royal family was no help. [giphy.com/GodfatherMovie/](https://media.giphy.com/media/gIIw2mdmILeXRlQqpb/giphy.mp4)
She didn't get any support from Charles, and was left to fend for herself.
Both during their proposal and in public statements afterward, Charles downplayed the importance of love, and focused instead on the fact that Diana would one day be queen.
"People seem to forget in western society we marry for love, but in royalty that never seems to enter it." \[Diana, Princess of Wales\]

From the very beginning of Diana's marriage to Charles, his ongoing contact with his former lover Camilla Parker-Bowles cast a shadow over their lives. ![giphy.com/bbc](https://media.giphy.com/media/LZ51fz3Le21Sv4RFF3/giphy.gif)

A famous photograph of Diana standing in tears as Charles boarded a plane was revealed to be the aftermath of an argument over his extramarital relationship. [youtube.com/c/NetflixFilmClub/videos](https://youtu.be/6aCjsEP_R7s?t=177.37&e=204.67)
Charles refused to discuss his relationship with Camila, and Diana's cousins told her it was too late to back out of the marriage.

insights.title: Despite being held up as a media and style icon, Diana’s life was one of inner torment

paragraphCards.markdown: Diana's private battle with bulimia began the week after their engagement.
She describes herself as having 'shrunk into nothing' before the wedding. ![1981 Royal Wedding Stamp.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/1981_Royal_Wedding_Stamp.jpg)
Triggered by an offhand remark from Charles, the princess struggled with an eating disorder for years, her drastic weight loss well-covered by the media.
Diana describes the day of her wedding as "the worst day of my life." [giphy.com/bbc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/9P8V2tfblPBWN8MD1Q/giphy.mp4)
After a disastrous honeymoon where Diana saw Charles wearing cufflinks gifted by Camilla, she finally realized the depth of what she'd entered into.
Diana's increasingly severe bulimia, exhaustion from her public duties, and constant fighting with Charles all contributed to her declining mental state, and she was prescribed valium.
Despite feeling the increasing disapproval of the royal family and the emotional unavailability of her husband, Diana recalls the birth of her first child William as a wonderful occasion.
"I learned how to be royal in one week. Nobody helped me at all. They'd be there to criticize but never to say 'well done'." \[Diana, Princess of Wales\]

The first few years of marriage was a rotation of public appearances and expectations that contributed to her depression, anxiety, and eating disorder. ![Diana\_visits\_Halifax.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Diana_visits_Halifax.jpg/640px-Diana_visits_Halifax.jpg)
The princess revealed that she had tried to take her own life by throwing herself down the stairs, which the press labelled a 'fall'.

Simultaneously glamorized and demonized by the press, Diana lived a life that was outwardly glamorous, but inwardly haunted and self-loathing. ![Sandro\_Pertini\_con\_i\_Principi\_di\_Galles.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/84/Sandro_Pertini_con_i_Principi_di_Galles.jpg)

insights.title: Diana found a way to embrace her public role, but did not live long to enjoy her efforts

paragraphCards.markdown: In 1987, Diana decided to adapt to the life in which she found herself, and began the first of her charity excursions, beginning with her devotion to the AIDS crisis of the time. ![Princess diana bristol 1987 02.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Princess_diana_bristol_1987_02.jpg)

Rumors of the marriage ending were widely circulated - a humiliating scandal for the royal couple - and the pair increasingly lived separate lives. ![Modena-italy-diana-spencer.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/53/Modena-italy-diana-spencer.jpg)
With the life-changing help of her psychiatrist, Diana experienced transformative changes, overcoming her bulimia and confronting Camilla with her knowledge of the affair.
"I cried and cried, didn't sleep that night, and the next morning I woke up different - I'd said how I felt." \[Diana, Princess of Wales\]
[youtube.com/c/NetflixFilmClub/videos](https://youtu.be/6aCjsEP_R7s?t=168.26&e=190.71)

In 1991 Diana approached journalist Andrew Morton to write her biography through a series of secret interviews. ![Andrew\_Morton\_appearing\_on\_"After\_Dark"%2C\_21\_October\_1989.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cc/Andrew_Morton_appearing_on_%22After_Dark%22%2C_21_October_1989.jpg)
In the interviews, Diana discussed her journey from victim to victor, and her desire to alter the structure of the monarchy when her son William assumed the throne.
"I know one day if I play the game of life I will have those things I've always pined for, and they'll be that much more special because I'll be older and able to appreciate them that much more."
As gossip of her declining marriage escalated, casting her as the "1980s Marilyn Monroe,"  Diana delivered an unexpected speech rebuking the paparazzi and the media.

Continuing to be a devoted mother as well as a beloved global humanitarian, Diana divorced Charles in 1996 and began dating Egyptian film producer Dodi Fayed. ![112407-Harrods-DiannaDodiMemorial2.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Diana_and_Dodi_Memorial_at_Harrods.jpg/576px-Diana_and_Dodi_Memorial_at_Harrods.jpg)
When the new couple was suddenly killed in a 1997 car crash, the world mourned the loss of 'the people's princess' and blamed it on paparazzi who'd relentlessly followed her.

At her funeral, Diana's brother bequeathed a devastating eulogy where he described her as "the most hunted woman" and "the essence of compassion." ![Flowers for Princess Diana's Funeral.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/df/Flowers_for_Princess_Diana%27s_Funeral.jpg)
"I always felt very different from everyone else, I always felt detached from everyone else, knew I was going somewhere different - had no idea where." \[Diana, Princess of Wales\]
In 1991, Diana, Princess of Wales orchestrated a series of secret interviews at Kensington Palace, recorded by a close friend. [youtube.com/c/NatGeo/](https://youtu.be/UfaTLTo3250?t=11.86&e=22.84)
These interviews would form the basis of a renowned, tell-all biography of her life, published in 1992 by journalist Andrew Morton, and sanctioned by the princess.
As the title implies, this is a detailed portrait of the fraught life of the Princess, spoken by the subject herself.
The public saw Diana as a somewhat divisive figure.

To some the princess was an adored 'people's princess' shaking up the stuffiness of the monarchy with her glamor and humanitarian work. ![giphy.com/rodekruisvlaanderen/](https://media.giphy.com/media/LPBx8LyMaJIPRVc2KR/giphy.gif)
To others, she was a rebellious, reticent young woman who was a drain on her husband Charles and threatened the stability of the British royal family.

Despite the relentless hounding of Diana by the press, the public at this time were unaware that her marriage of ten years was already in ruins. [youtube.com/c/NetflixFilmClub/](https://youtu.be/V18ZM9rYlhM?t=7.06&e=31.69)
The documentary opens in 1977 and narrates an illuminating overview of Diana's youth, her courtship with Charles, and her tragic fate.

Highlighting the discrepancy between Diana's glamorous public-facing life and her inner torments marked by severe bulimia, depression, and suicide attempts, the film is an eloquent document of the late princess.

Through archival and personal footage, this documentary illuminates the inner life of the adored Princess of Wales, as told by Diana herself. ![Princess\_Diana\_1985.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/47/Princess_Diana_1985.jpg)

Jon Acuff tries to bring out the best in others, without sounding preachy or like he knows it all. The phrases and formulas he coins make his work more memorable, and it's easy to recall the concepts later on.
If you're just not feeling it at whatever work you're doing right now, Do Over will help you discover what you need to do next.

insights.title: Look at what’s in your Career Savings Account

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Just like a filled bank account helps you through a financial slump, a filled Career Savings Account helps you through a career slump - and it happens quite often.
According to the 2014 Gallup poll, around 70% of Americans are either not 'engaged' (ie. enthusiastic) in their jobs, or downright hate them.
But changing your career and rebuilding it requires courage.
The way you build that courage is by making sure you have the abilities to handle whatever comes next.

The following formula will help you calculate what's in your Career Savings Account so far:

Relationships + Skills + Character x Hustle = CSA
Knowing you have a good network, solid technical skills, and a strong character, plus being prepared to do what it takes, are the foundation of a strong CSA.

insights.title: Break through any career ceiling with new skills

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Sometimes everything looks to be going just fine, but it feels like something's wrong.

You can't really put your finger on what it is, because technically, everything is going well at your job. You're paid well, you routinely handle all your tasks, and are in good standing with all your colleagues.

However, even though you're doing great, you just can't get to the next level. No promotion, no head hunters contacting you, and no promising side projects on the horizon. You've hit a career ceiling.
In that case, your Do Over requires an objective assessment of your skills.
What are you good at? What are you missing? Which skills do you need to take your career to the next level?
Dig deep. A lot of our skills are often invisible, hiding beneath the surface.
For example, if you're the one managing the company Christmas party every year, that's probably a good sign you're very organized in general.
Once you see that, you'll probably also notice that another skill you don't have would go quite well with it.
For example, if you're good at organizing, how about actively creating and marketing events too? Set yourself a new challenge with new opportunities.
By going out and acquiring exactly those skills that complement the ones you already have, you round out your skill set which is just what you need to smash through that career ceiling, and rise up.

insights.title: Take a career jump by investing in your own character

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Maybe you don't want to break through a career ceiling. Maybe you want to leave that building altogether, take a career jump, and start your own thing.

In that case, the most crucial aspect you need to develop first is your character. Once you take the leap, a lot of responsibility will rest on your shoulders and you'll have to be a leader - first leading yourself, and then your eventual co-workers later on.
The strongest business is built on the strongest you.
The three most important character traits are generosity, empathy and presence.
Generosity is simple: give more than you receive.
Empathy can be trained by asking one simple question, over and over again, when you talk to others: "How would I feel if I was in his/her shoes?"
Just mentally stepping into someone else's perspective will help you understand them so much better, and judge them a lot less.
Presence is about being in the moment and paying attention.
The next time a friend tells you a story, put down your phone, look at her, and really listen to her problems.
Invest in your character whenever you get a chance. All it takes is time, and you can never know when the next career jump opportunity presents itself, at which you'll be glad you did.
"Want a better job right this second? Choose your attitude and adjust your expectations." \[Jon Acuff\]
Jon Acuff's Quitter was about quitting your job, and Start was about starting your own. Do Over is what happens before, after, and sometimes in-between those two.
It shows you how to intentionally build your career by focusing on developing four skills, each of which is particularly helpful in a certain stage of your career.

Do Over shines a light on the four core skills you need to build an amazing career: relationships, skills, character, and hustle, and shows you how to develop each one and use them in different stages of your career.

It's also worth watching Dan's great TED talk on the subject. If you feel like you're chasing rewards, which somehow don't end up making you happier, then motivation often becomes a huge question mark.
If you happen to work in a carrot and stick model, and find yourself not happy with where you are, then give Drive a go.

insights.title: Both the carrot and the stick are dead – why extrinsic motivators don’t work

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: When the industrial age started, external rewards were all you needed to motivate workers.
There was so much money to make and such a great life to be lived, if only you had a little extra cash to pay for new conveniences, like TV, a radio, or pre-cooked dinners.
But as we're shifting from the industrial age to the information age, slapping on a bonus for fast delivery doesn't work any more – most people simply don't care.
Expenses to cover our basic needs, like rent and food, have never been cheaper. What we really value now is time.
But that's not the only problem with external rewards and punishments.
If a car mechanic is promised a 50% salary bonus when he completes 200 repairs in 3 months, guess what he does? He tells more of his customers that their car needs repairs.
The money becomes the driving force, and will lead him to do repairs where none are needed, and maybe even do a sloppy job, just to meet the quota.
Instead of leading to better and faster work, this creates dissatisfied customers and stressed workers.
Even more intriguing, for tasks that require creative thinking, adding financial incentives puts so much pressure on workers, that they become incapable of performing the task.

For example when given the task to fix a candle on the wall with a few tools, participants who were told to be given money for a fast solution performed a lot worse than those who weren't offered any money.
The more money is on the line, the worse it gets.
Participants of a study tasked with hitting targets with tennis balls completely cracked under the pressure of potentially earning 5 months worth of pay.

insights.title: Over time, extrinsic rewards destroy our inner drive

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Wait a minute…aren't almost ALL jobs nowadays somewhat creative? Exactly!

Of course this applies to developed countries more than to emerging ones, but eventually, we'll all end up with jobs that require us to only work with information, people and creatively solve problems.
Daniel Pink says that to succeed at this kind of work, what we really need is intrinsic motivation.
You know, doing something for the sheer enjoyment of doing it. Either because we're passionate about it, have a ton of fun, or are just plain curious, like we were as kids.

But if you're like most adults, those days of strange curiosity are long gone. You gradually lost your intrinsic motivation, as the world taught you to rely on extrinsic motivation over and over again.

When kids are being asked to draw, once just to have fun and once for a small reward, if you tweak their reward system, you will find that the first group is happy to draw just for fun later as well, while the second refuses to draw without the incentive.
We live in an "if-you-do-this-then-you-get-that" world, and it's ruining our motivation.

insights.title: Find a way to get into the zone at work, and you’ll be a lot happier

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: 70% of Americans either hate or don't feel fulfilled at their job. But what to do about it?
This is where motivation 3.0, as Dan calls it, comes in.
We must relight our inner desire to strive for perfection.
If we're given a task that challenges our skills, without being overwhelming or boring, and are then allowed to autonomously work on it, we love to give our best.
Imagine playing a video game for hours, or noticing that time flies while you paint, read, or plan your honeymoon. This state is called flow.
While it can't last forever, it is important that you periodically end up in it while working.
Keep that in mind while looking for the next job, talking to your boss about work, or figuring out the next task.
Don't settle for a boss who doesn't understand this or a job who doesn't require you to live up to your potential.
Promise yourself that until you're excited to go to work, because you can't wait to perfect what you're working on, you'll keep looking.
"Control leads to compliance; autonomy leads to engagement" - Daniel Pink
In Drive, Daniel Pink, lawyer-turned-economist and government employee, takes us through the history of human motivation.

Al Gore's former speechwriter explains how we've gone from being mostly intrinsically motivated (to survive) to jumping through hoops for carrots, while trying to avoid the sticks being dangled over our heads by bosses and employers.
Dan argues that it's time to go back, give workers autonomy, a purpose, and the freedom to master their craft, so we can go back to being as intrinsically motivated as we were as kids.
An approach he calls motivation 3.0.
Drive explores what has motivated humans throughout history and explains how we shifted from mere survival to the carrot and stick approach that's still practiced today – and why it's outdated.

Eat, Move, Sleep is all about small, incremental changes. Even if you just make one small change each month, that'll be 12 each year, and within four years, you'll have accumulated almost 50 positive habits.
This stuff compounds big time, so never underestimate the power of marginal gains.

insights.title: Limit inactivity instead of trying to work out more

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: If you're like most people, you'll not exercise for a while, then feel bad and start setting really ambitious goals like going to the gym 5 times a week.
Even if you're one of those rare types, who can pull off these kinds of sudden habit changes, there's still a chance it's the wrong thing to do.
Here's why: If you sit for six hours a day, even working out for two hours afterwards won't reverse the health damage you've done.
The consequences are similar to those from smoking.
Exercise isn't about the total amount of sweat you produce each week, your body only cares about not being inactive for a long stretch of time.
The National Institutes of Health looked at 240,000 people's movement behavior, finding out sitting for most of your time increases your mortality rate by 50%.
The solution is wonderfully simple: Don't sit for longer than an hour. That's it.
Don't pile 6-8 hours of sitting around on top of watching TV, eating your meals and sitting in the bus, train or your car (we do sit a lot, don't we?).
Walk to the house five blocks away, take the stairs, not the elevator and just get up a few times at work to move around.
Note: If you can, go get a Garmin, FitBit or Apple activity tracker  – sit for too long and it'll vibrate and tell you to move!

insights.title: Treat sugar like it’s a drug

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: There are illegal drugs, like cocaine and heroin, legal (and socially accepted) drugs, like tobacco and alcohol, and then there's sugar, which, according to Tom, is the worst one.
Not only because it's not even considered a drug, but because it's part of everyone's daily food intake.
How much sugar do you think you eat each year? Remembering it is actually quite simple…
It's your own weight in pure, white, refined sugar. Imagine building a statue of yourself, purely made from sugar, and then eating that, one bite a day – every year.

There are 3 reasons why added sugar is the devil in disguise...

1.  Eating it releases dopamine, which gives you a "high" feeling and makes it addictive.
2.  The more you eat, the more you want.
3.  You build a tolerance, meaning you have to eat more each time in order to get that dopamine hit again.
What should you do? Treat sugar like it's an actual, illegal drug.
Avoid added sugar wherever you can, don't even buy unnecessary sweets and snacks and use it very carefully when cooking.

insights.title: Stop hitting the snooze button and get up right when your alarm rings

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: There's sleep and there's efficient sleep.
You know, one is physically being in bed, the other is actually getting some quality shut-eye during which you're actually recovering.
However, and most of my friends do this, you can ruin a perfectly good night of sleep with one tiny mistake in the morning: hitting the snooze button.
The reason is that if you hit snooze and go back to sleep, your alarm wakes you up right at the point where you're about to enter a deep sleep phase again – which makes you groggy and tired.
The more you repeat this, the worse it gets – so even if you've just slept 7 hours before, getting up would've been better than snoozing for another 45 minutes.
Why would you rather spend up to an hour in a constant state of semi-wakefulness, instead of just sleeping an hour longer in the first place? But it's a habit deeply ingrained in lots of people.
If you're one of them, make this your mission for tomorrow: don't hit the snooze button. Set your alarm at the latest, possible time, and force yourself to get up instantly.
"Every hour you spend on your rear end saps your energy and ruins your health." \[Tom Rath\]
Tom Rath knows a thing or two about business – maybe you've heard of his most popular book already, it's called Strengthsfinder 2.0.
However, in order to even become one of the world's leading business thinkers, he first had to learn a lot about something else: health.

Tom was diagnosed with a rare disease called VHL at a very young age, which basically promotes random tumor growth all over your body. Instead of throwing in the towel, he decided to focus on what he could control.
The little changes he made ended up amounting to a pretty healthy lifestyle and have allowed him to live a long and happy life (he's 40 now and thriving!).
But if these little changes helped him go from cancer patient to the healthy, bestselling author of Eat, Move, Sleep, they sure must be good enough to help you and me live to be 90 and beyond.

Eat, Move, Sleep shows you that living a long and healthy life is not the result of massive lifestyle changes, but of lots of small habits which improve the way you sleep, eat and exercise and, if combined, add a whole lot to your health.
You are the key to your success as a communicator. Be honest, share your vulnerability and take interest in the people around you.

With authenticity and respect for others as your base, you can use the tools from this MasterClass to build up your skills as a communicator, giving you the confidence to share the stories of others with the world.

insights.title: Make an authentic connection

actions.title: Make your mess your message.
actions.markdown:
Take a look at your own life to discover what your own message to the world should be. Share your experiences to be in service of others.

Live life with optimism.

Work that optimism muscle and do it often. Optimism will help you see the best in people and share stories more effectively, and joyfully.

paragraphCards.markdown: What is it that you can share with others? The role of a communicator is to share stories, so you have to figure out how you can be of service to others through whatever it is that life has thrown at you.
By sharing your vulnerability with others, you can make a more human connection. ![https://giphy.com/erickoh](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7qE0DKA57n1L3ck0/giphy.gif)
However, remember that it is your decision if and when you share these things.
"Vulnerability is being strong, not weak. When you allow yourself to be vulnerable, you're showing a strength, not a weakness." \[Robin Roberts\]
Start with a genuine interest in the lives of others – when you engage people, they will reciprocate. ![https://giphy.com/oscars](https://media.giphy.com/media/xTiN0h8rOOiku7ljUs/giphy.gif)

Don't rely solely on technology to contact people – it is very helpful and beneficial, but nothing replaces a genuine human connection. ![https://giphy.com/dennismoore](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7aDd4hAEcciOzcVW/giphy.gif)
Be sincere and respectful too – good manners will serve you well in life.
"Don't fake it. Have a genuine interest in listening to those people." \[Robin Roberts\]
Make a habit out of practicing optimism to live a more fulfilled life. ![https://giphy.com/goodmorningamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/ZFFV8zWDIzfvl424dI/giphy.gif)
By changing the way you think about challenges ahead, you can change the way you feel about them. ![https://giphy.com/rebeccahendin](https://media.giphy.com/media/322Wdbh6wg2He5agZb/giphy.gif)
"Optimism is a muscle that gets stronger with use." \[Robin Roberts\]
Acknowledge and learn from the mountains you've already climbed and be mindful to enjoy the process. If you don't enjoy the journey, you're robbing yourself of something special.
Remember too, that nobody else can be you, so make sure you're the lead character in your own life story. [https://www.youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/6-GK5drjjyw?t=56.98&e=72.78)

insights.title: Find ways to stand out in the workplace.

actions.title: Come with your homework done and your best ideas ready.
actions.markdown: Do your research and come prepared, no matter what the scenario. Feeling prepared with relevant knowledge and fresh ideas will make you feel more confident.

actions.title: Know your worth and do more than what’s on the job description.
actions.markdown: Know your worth and what you’re bringing to the table. Remember that your company doesn’t owe you anything. You earn it because you’re the right person for the job, and you’ll go above and beyond what’s asked of you.

paragraphCards.markdown: When interviewing for a job, do your homework and enter that room with knowledge of the company and of the interviewer. ![https://giphy.com/cplu](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41lPShqazpN7SVrO/giphy.gif)
Bring a comprehensive proposal and your most creative ideas to stand out from the crowd. ![https://giphy.com/andrewillustration](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0ExgMFxtvmHgD3r2/giphy.gif)
"Dress the part. Go in with confidence. Don't be cocky, but be confident." \[Robin Roberts\]
What you do after the interview is important. Wait an appropriate amount of time, then follow up with the interviewer.
Be sincere, as people can tell when you're trying to butter them up.
To get yourself in front of the right people at a company, first ask for advice, not a job. ![https://giphy.com/juliayellow](https://media.giphy.com/media/l3mZsXph9EywxtxAs/giphy.gif)
"There is a fine line between being persistent and being a pest." \[Robin Roberts\]
When communicating your value in the workplace, make sure you are always grateful, but never content.

Go above and beyond where possible and check that your personal career goals are aligned with the goals of your company. ![https://giphy.com/centralcoasthondadealers](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1BgRAz5LLh01tdRe/giphy.gif)

Seek out allies in the workplace. If you're authentic with people, more often than not, they will want to help you. ![https://giphy.com/goodmorningamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/Q5AL5ipNxtnPjLIxBf/giphy.gif)
"Good people want to lower that ladder and help you climb up to join them." \[Robin Roberts\]
There is no 'I' in team, so remember to choose people over the process.
There are many unsung heroes in every company – respect and support them. ![https://giphy.com/warnerarchive](https://media.giphy.com/media/l3nW8NRAtkvB30zxC/giphy.gif)
Maintain all of the skills you had to acquire in the early days of your career – you never know when they will come in handy.

Communicating is about storytelling and a genuine human connection, so remember who it is that you're trying to reach and connect with. Don't try to be perfect, or anything other than exactly who you are.

insights.title: Be present, listen and have fun.

actions.title: Listen to those you are trying to connect with.
actions.markdown: You need to be able to think on your feet, so pay attention to the direction the interview is taking. Your job is to help your interviewee share their story.

actions.title: Take the time to get to know your audience.
actions.markdown: Do some thorough research and take the time to care about whatever it is that they care about. You don’t necessarily have to have walked the same path as people for you to treat them with empathy - but never pity.

paragraphCards.markdown: Whether you're interviewing one person or speaking to a thousand, get to know your audience. What do they want from you, and what are you going to give them? ![https://giphy.com/teamtumult](https://media.giphy.com/media/7JprzxLVDJRzXuhgkj/giphy.gif)
You need to genuinely care about people and to let them know you care. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/6-GK5drjjyw?t=27.05&e=41.12)

Do your research and use that information to help you think about why you're there, your story, and what you have to offer. ![https://giphy.com/ailadi](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT1XGGXpfKQz9AW3bW/giphy.gif)
Don't go in too fact-heavy – share your message via a personal story that people can connect with.
When speaking publicly, don't rely on a script. ![https://giphy.com/soulpancake](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IgvCv8a57oACtdm/giphy.gif)
If you're staring at your speech instead of your audience, you're memorizing, not connecting, and the audience will notice. Write down a few key bullet points and be prepared beforehand.

Don't put too much pressure on yourself – have fun with it! Stay in the moment so you can feel the room. ![https://giphy.com/rachaelrayshow](https://media.giphy.com/media/3kywqcgH3V13uzRelE/giphy.gif)

Accept that you're not going to connect with an audience 100% of the time, but keep your sentences concise and your message simple. ![https://giphy.com/oliversin](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oEduJmTLJlAxYqN7W/giphy.gif)
If you're feeling nervous, look just above the audience instead of directly at individuals. Take your time, speak with purpose and enunciate.

When interviewing an individual, have a gameplan of the points you want to cover, but stay present and listen to your interviewee. ![https://giphy.com/primerstories](https://media.giphy.com/media/xTdAjhDiiZZl2srgXe/giphy.gif)
You are a partner with your interviewee in sharing whatever it is that they want to share. Be compassionate, but don't shy away from the hard questions.

Speak to your interlocutor before the camera rolls or going on stage. Reassure them that you're going to be fair and unbiased, and make sure they feel welcome and comfortable. Think of your interviews as a conversation.
"The art of the follow up is listening." \[Robin Roberts\]
"Nothing replaces a human connection, and nothing is going to get you farther along than to be able to communicate and to be able to connect with people." \[Robin Roberts\]
When we get down to basics, it's easy to see that we all have more in common than not.

Through harnessing genuine interest in the people around you, showing them compassion and being authentic with your character, you can connect and find common ground. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/6-GK5drjjyw?t=41.14&e=72.82)

Robin Roberts has been working as a successful broadcaster since 1983, starting out as a sports anchor after having wanted to be an athlete in her youth. ![Robin Roberts at Heart Truth 2010 cropped.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Robin_Roberts_at_Heart_Truth_2010_cropped.jpg/301px-Robin_Roberts_at_Heart_Truth_2010_cropped.jpg)
In 2005, she was made co-anchor on Good Morning America. ![giphy.com/goodmorningamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/Q5jJ89rag6NbtFumL4/giphy.gif)
Roberts is a breast cancer survivor and was later diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome, for which she needed a bone marrow transplant.
Her openness regarding her illnesses and the campaign work she did around that inspired new donors to register and earned her the Arthur Ashe Courage Award and the Sager Strong Award.

Effective communication is an area that many struggle with, but through this MasterClass, you'll learn the techniques required to create that vital connection with others. ![https://giphy.com/goodmorningamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/J26sJt2rGDder04lLC/giphy.gif)
Roberts gives permission for you to be yourself, to be honest, and to be optimistic. Through taking a genuine interest in people's lives and stories, you can become a successful communicator.

In the MasterClass, broadcaster and Good Morning America anchor Robin Roberts shares her most important secrets of communication and connection, guiding you towards your career goals with authenticity and compassion.

Author Ashlee Vance interviewed the entrepreneur for over 30 hours to compile this biography, so it gives a thorough insight into one of the most interesting characters of our time. We can all learn something from the invaluable lessons of Elon Musk.

insights.title: Spend most of your time figuring out what questions to ask, rather than just answering them

actions.title: Ask the right questions.
actions.markdown: If you have a problem you can’t solve, take a step back. Look to the root of the problem instead. Instead of analyzing the symptom, look for the cause.

paragraphCards.markdown: Elon Musk didn't have a particularly easy childhood. ![Charles\_Bolden\_congratulates\_SpaceX\_CEO\_and\_Chief\_Designer\_Elon\_Musk\_in\_front\_of\_the\_historic\_Dragon\_capsule.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0a/Charles_Bolden_congratulates_SpaceX_CEO_and_Chief_Designer_Elon_Musk_in_front_of_the_historic_Dragon_capsule.jpg)
His relationship with his parents wasn't simple to begin with and when they separated, this didn't get any better.
Musk decided to live with his dad, but to add pain to injury, he was also bullied in school. [giphy.com/sherchle/](https://media.giphy.com/media/1gQwMNJ9z1mqABgQd3/giphy.mp4)
Both of these circumstances led Musk to retreat and turn inward, spending most of his time reading and studying. [giphy.com/Skrzat/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1J9HWBKLp20YfNAY/giphy.mp4)
At one point, Musk read 60 books a month. Thanks to his photographic memory, he managed to memorize two entire encyclopedias!
One of his biggest inflection points was reading The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, which would not only greatly influence his humor, but also his way of approaching problems.
This book showed him that answering questions is easy – the hard part is asking the right questions.
Most of the time when we're stuck, we're simply answering and executing answers to the wrong questions, a problem we wouldn't have if we'd asked the right question in the first place.
A simple example is this: if you're trying to find out how to sustain your energy to keep working a high-stress, high-income job, instead first ask why you think you need the income or the job?
What is it for? Is there a better way to live, that maybe doesn't even require increasing your energy? [giphy.com/juliaveldmanc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l378aiPPFAGEsetIk/giphy.mp4)

This kind of thinking led Musk to ponder topics like solar power, space exploration and rockets and paperless banking even before entering high school. [giphy.com/producthunt/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT39Div8FqzcSnf5hm/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: Accomplish your goals with a success-through-determination approach

paragraphCards.markdown: "Success-through-determination" is ambiguous.
Determination means to stick with things long enough until they work out.
But it also means to determine what your next step should be and spend a good deal of time thinking about what you'll do. [giphy.com/sharpie/](https://media.giphy.com/media/121cS334yDC0Hm/giphy.mp4)
Elon Musk did just that when he won over his first wife, Justine Wilson. Her interest in him was zero when she met him, so he had to hustle to get her attention.

She stood him up on their first date at an ice cream parlor. Not a big whiner, he determined that if she wouldn't come to eat ice cream with him, but still liked ice cream, he'd just bring it to her instead.

He asked a friend of hers what Justine's favorite flavor was, and where she studied. Then he showed up with two cheap chocolate ice cream cones.[giphy.com/huffpost/](https://media.giphy.com/media/1LutagTLHDQAw/giphy.mp4)

This approach comes back to asking the right questions. "Does she like me enough to show up to eat ice cream with me? – No. Does she like ice cream in general? Most likely. Will she like me more if I bring her ice cream? Probably."
It was worth the shot. The two had six children together.

If what you're trying to do is important to you, stick with it and take a scientist's approach in how you determine the next step. [giphy.com/Fermilab/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3JNGvAym5kKzQrD4xt/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: Align all of your work and projects with one giant goal to ensure you leave a lasting impact

actions.title: Get into business to serve your purpose.
actions.markdown: Decide on what’s most important to you, and align your work with it. Join a company in the relevant field. Create a product that will help make it happen. However loose it may seem at first, if it fits the brief, then give it a go.

paragraphCards.markdown: Having a lot of goals in various fields of life is important. It's the spice of life, and it makes living fun.
But if you think of the variety of your goals in levels of a pyramid, you can see how they influence your focus. [giphy.com/banco\_itau](https://media.giphy.com/media/QszJQ3spkAzcDQgQ70/giphy.mp4)

Imagine you're living at the bottom of a pyramid where everything is wide. You'll spend some of your time chasing a career in sales, working on a book on the side, and maybe become a real estate investor a few years later.
Now go to the top of the pyramid, where everything is narrow: there's only space for one goal. [giphy.com/adventuresoncehad/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4FGHqrRZNPkfoLCw/giphy.mp4)
If you can unite all the goals on the lower levels to somehow serve that one mega goal at the top, your life as a whole will become a lot more focused.
In Elon Musk's case, Tesla produces batteries, which SolarCity can sell, and SolarCity makes solar panels for Tesla charging stations.
All of his companies work together to serve his grand mission: saving the future of humanity. [giphy.com/soulpancake/](https://media.giphy.com/media/JmJVnDL6COI4VBBwfu/giphy.mp4)
"If the rules are such that you can't make progress, then you have to fight the rules." \[Elon Musk\]
Elon Musk is a truly fascinating character. [youtube.com/user/businessinside](https://youtu.be/SEuxbFRYXJk?t=20.00&e=143.00.54)

When thinking about how he should live his life, he concluded early on that the best goal he could pursue was to ensure the future of humanity – something we all know is surely not guaranteed, looking at some of our behavior over the last 100 years.

How he then decided to tackle this goal is the biggest lesson in reverse engineering you'll ever see, and after this, you may try to think in a more Musk-like way. [giphy.com/thinklumi/](https://media.giphy.com/media/ls9xCyaVCP6ntJdfBg/giphy.mp4)

This is the first official biography of Elon Musk, the creator of SolarCity, SpaceX and Tesla, highlighting his complicated childhood, the way he makes decisions and navigates the world, and how he managed to disrupt multiple industries.

Enchantment is for anyone who wants to learn the art of communicating a purpose. Whether as a personal skill when meeting new people, or on a larger scale when starting a business, Guy Kawasaki can help you realize your values, and gain new followers who value them too.

insights.title: Enchantment isn’t manipulation - it’s about inspiring people to be as excited about your dreams as you are

actions.title: Make a good first impression.
actions.markdown: Even before you open your mouth, it helps if you make a good visual. Smile with genuity, dress appropriately, stand tall, and offer a firm handshake. Then, let your communication skills come into play.

actions.title: Hold your core values close.
actions.markdown: Going into business purely for the money will probably only get you so far. Instead, look to yourself as a person. Ask who you are, what you stand for, and what you want to create for the world. Then, lead with that when creating your product.

paragraphCards.markdown: Most people think that success in business comes from creating a really great product and doing a good job of marketing it at the right price - but there's more to it than that.
Real success comes when a business has a strong ethos. They hold meaningful values, and stick to them. ![giphy.com/itsjustcavan/](https://media.giphy.com/media/jrhpLcf9hbKoyvpFRU/giphy.gif)
When other people share these same values, that's when they truly buy into the idea of something. In other words, they're enchanted.
Enchantment triggers emotions and surpasses logic. It influences decisions and inspires action. ![giphy.com/gocaseoficial/](https://media.giphy.com/media/L2rAl9kIUK4Kjg198R/giphy.gif)
Chances are you've never felt captivated by somebody you weren't sure you could trust - well, enchantment works the same way.

If you can get people to not only like but trust you, you can start to persuade them towards your way of thinking. ![giphy.com/easyvote/](https://media.giphy.com/media/Wt6D3Q81DKywhMIViB/giphy-downsized.gif)
And this isn't just in business, but in any social interaction that you find yourself.
If you're open and accepting towards other people, and can speak animatedly about your hopes and dreams, chances are they'll get a positive vibe from you.

Be enchanting by being open, honest, and authentic about who you are as a person - or, as Kawasaki calls it, a 'Mensch'. ![giphy.com/xtvsocial/](https://media.giphy.com/media/J4hB4AZuk1YflNaQxU/giphy.gif)
Enchantment shouldn't be confused with manipulation, however.
The word may prompt you to visualize a witch with a shiny apple, but it's actually about inspiration. ![giphy.com/illustrationlisa](https://media.giphy.com/media/J1R6LF0c9df6XyKkaU/giphy.gif)
Rather than scheming for money or some form of personal gain, you're taking the opportunity to share your dream with other people, and get them excited too.
Speak vibrantly about your passion, and allow that infectious emotion to warm people towards you. ![giphy.com/clapforcrap/](https://media.giphy.com/media/fnJYmEbzCJnlAMH4H3/giphy.gif)
If people can't buy into you as a person, they probably won't rush to buy your product.
"In a perfect world, you are so enchanting that your cause doesn't matter, and your cause is so enchanting that you don't matter." \[Guy Kawasaki\]

insights.title: Your product should be enchanting, and have a launch to match your message

actions.title: Make your product DICEE ready.
actions.markdown: Enchant people with your product. Make it Deep, Intelligent, Complete, Empowering, and Elegant. Let it sell itself.

actions.title: Make your launch enchanting.
actions.markdown: Don’t create an amazing product but make the launch a flop. Instead, ensure that the buying process is easy, efficient, and inexpensive, with evident results and ideally a good returns policy - just in case.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The goal of enchantment is long-lasting change. You want enchantment to endure and, even better, to blossom." \[Guy Kawasaki\]

Having an idea for a business is just the first step. Next, you have to make it enchanting so that people actually buy it. ![giphy.com/brickmakers/](https://media.giphy.com/media/WOfDnVlunIYDL6CJv7/giphy.gif)
It's all well and good if a company or salesperson is captivating, but the product also has to sell itself.
To ensure this, the product must have five qualities: DICEE.
1.  **Deep:** This shows value. It offers multiple layers so that it can help now, and will continue to do so in the future, with different features for different purposes.
2.  **Intelligent:** A product that's worth having should solve the customer's problems efficiently, and in a way perhaps others haven't thought of.
3.  **Complete:** A company's product life-cycle is important. It's not just about owning the product - it's about the sale process, and the customer support afterwards.
4.  **Empowering:** A really great product should make the user feel stronger, smarter, or more capable. It should come with a sense of achievement after use.
5.  **Elegant:** The product's design is important. It should be created with the user's experience in mind and contain features people didn't know they needed.
Once the product is ready, the next thing to prepare for is its launch - and it needs to be good. ![giphy.com/PragmaSchool/](https://media.giphy.com/media/GeW1s972sctto4Mpnu/giphy.gif)
Half-hearted statistics and scraps of information will get you nowhere. It's the 21st century, people are drowning in data already.
Instead, you need to focus on what lies behind the product. You need a good story. [giphy.com/benjybrooke/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2SpXaJA67JaSqSxq/giphy.mp4)
Tell people why you wanted to create your product in the first place, and how it's going to help them in their lives.
Sell your dream, and explain why it's important. Have a simple message, and be authentic and genuine.

insights.title: First, persuade your customers to try the product; then, give them a reason to stay

actions.title: Write the perfect email.
actions.markdown: When constructing an email, write an individual subject heading and keep the content personal. Be concise and avoid paragraphing. Ideally, stick to fewer than six sentences. If you’re asking for something, be open and honest, but don’t overdo it.

actions.title: Mix up your marketing.
actions.markdown: Make sure your posts or emails don’t all look the same. Use a variety of pictures and videos as well as text. Create variety, all whilst aligning the content to match your branding - whether that be educational or entertaining.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Enchantment is a powerful skill, and with power comes responsibility. It's your duty to use these skills in a manner that benefits all the parties involved, if not the world." \[Guy Kawasaki\]
With everything moving online and bricks-and-mortar stores almost a thing of the past, finding new customers has become easier and harder than ever.

Sure, we now have access to everything at the click of a button - but there's a lot of competition out there and technology is advancing every day. ![giphy.com/tiateam/](https://media.giphy.com/media/18kO7fNLgNQNbXhUk9/giphy.gif)
Once you start creating yourself a bit of a fanbase, it's important to take care of your customers from day one.
For starters, communication is key if you're to keep them interested.
Your customer service must be quick to respond, keen to help, and personable. [giphy.com/teamtumult/](https://media.giphy.com/media/j0SrVwV9e95qWm7Gs2/giphy.mp4)
Always request feedback and be open to criticism - it's only then that you can learn how to improve, after all.
Then, it's onto the marketing strategy. The simple days of billboards are gone.

With social media leading the way, you have to know which online platform suits what, and integrate both Push and Pull technology. ![giphy.com/Ontag/](https://media.giphy.com/media/kBZfvX7e5Ma9q8GWqH/giphy-downsized.gif)
Keep it in line with your brand, and allow it to enhance your core message.

1.  Push implies sending out your message to others, and sharing news or updates - via Twitter or email. Something short, concise, and clear (perhaps even personalized or with images) that reaches as many people as possible.
2.  Pull is about shouting to the masses and seeing who talks back - via a website, Facebook, LinkedIn, or YouTube. Create exciting new content for both existing customers and potential new ones.
"If Facebook were a country, it would rank third in the world in population – behind China and India." \[Guy Kawasaki\]
Marketing a new product used to be about reaching the 'somebodies' and letting them approve it, before getting it to the rest of the world.
However nowadays, capturing as many people as possible has become the more effective approach. ![giphy.com/ontag](https://media.giphy.com/media/fUAjdHaENNcI5KuuFy/giphy-downsized.gif)
Online 'experts' are no longer trusted, so let people tell their friends and share your posts.
Once they enjoy the product, and don't feel manipulated to do so, they'll take pleasure in getting other people on-board.
Then, they'll be successfully enchanted to stay.
"Enchantment transforms situations and relationships. It converts hostility into civility. It reshapes civility into affinity. It changes skeptics and cynics into believers." \[Guy Kawasaki\]

Since the explosion of technology, with more and more people moving online everyday, it's become harder than ever to reach new customers. ![giphy.com/maximilliannyc](https://media2.giphy.com/media/l0HU5pC1CuCl8NFqU/200.gif)
Yes, constant connectivity allows us to send emails and posts to millions at once - but when every company is doing the same, that can only account for so much.

Customers have access to data, statistics, reviews, and comparison sites at the click of a button, so proving your product is better than all the competitors' out there is no mean feat. ![giphy.com/zacitarna](https://media.giphy.com/media/MA16qmyGu2jzRykx4J/giphy.gif)

That's where Enchantment comes in. Guy Kawasaki is a venture capitalist, entrepreneur, and author, and this book - his tenth, in fact - looks into how you can stand out from the crowd by producing something meaningful.

By creating a business that's founded upon fulfilling your dreams and striving for a greater cause, rather than a shallow desire to make money, you can persuade customers to share the same desires and join your mission. You can enchant them.
Enchantment will teach you not only how to make a product and get it sold, but to turn your customers into avid believers of your purpose, and loyal followers of your cause.
Even the Six Pillars won't prevent you from escaping future challenges or failures altogether.
Gemma Leigh Roberts uses her expertise to teach us that, although problems are inevitable, our response to these challenges is completely within our control.
The next time you find yourself hitting a wall, keep the Six Pillars of Resilience in mind.
Remember to always find the positive in each of the setbacks you face, by identifying the valuable lesson that can be learned from each experience. This is what you need to keep you moving forward!

insights.title: Resilience is a skill, and anyone can learn it

actions.title: Build Your Confidence.
actions.markdown: Don’t underestimate the power of good energy. Start believing that you can face any obstacle that comes your way, and you will. Be in control of the situation and use your physical and mental power to withstand the difficulties.

actions.title: Surround Yourself with Positive Energy.
actions.markdown: Stay focused on resolving the problem and various factors that make you feel optimistic, like your loving friends and family, rather than obstacles that can throw you off course.

paragraphCards.markdown: Despite what you may think, resilience is not an innate personality trait. All of us can develop inner strength through proper coaching and training.
As life goes on, no matter how many hardships we face, we need to maintain resilience in order to better cope with any difficulties we might face in the future.
The only way to do this is to focus on nurturing each factor contributing to our resilience development.
The frustrating part of building resilience is that there is no shortcut. You have to experience the worst to bring out the best in you.
Consider it this way: the hardships and frustrations you have gone through in the past, no matter what they be, are exactly the materials you need to build up your present strength.

"Do you have a resilience-boosting strategy? What's your support system like? And have you created a structure that can support your development? All of these factors are essential parts of enhancing your resilience." \[Gemma Leigh Roberts\]
Now, in a moment of calm, take a moment to think of all the ways you are already resilient.

Do you have a solid support network of friends, a naturally positive mindset, or a strong sense of self-belief? Remind yourself of these in tough times: these factors are what you need to deal with whatever life might throw at you.
If nothing else, remember that with each difficulty you face, you are preparing to become a better version of yourself in the future.

insights.title: Use the Six Pillars of Resilience to build your own mental strength

actions.title: Deal with your problems head-on.
actions.markdown: Stop putting off dealing with that difficult problem. Burying your head in the sand won’t make them go away. Learning to face up to difficult situations (as soon as you can) will build your courage, confidence, and productivity.

actions.title: Learn from past setbacks.
actions.markdown: Practice finding the ‘lesson’ in each challenge you face. This mindset will help you put a positive spin on otherwise difficult moments.

paragraphCards.markdown: Do you know why successful businessmen and sports professionals are so adept at what they do?
It's because they have psychological resilience-- the ability to learn from mistakes, and use those lessons to bounce back stronger than ever.
Successful individuals have the mental strength to look at the problem differently. They see the good side that other people don't see.
This strength in character doesn't develop overnight- they first have to undergo the complicated process of learning each of the Six Pillars of Resilience.
Master each of these yourself, and you'll have all the tools you need to face your next challenge.

These six pillars are:

1.  Confidence
2.  Adaptability
3.  Positivity
4.  Perspective
5.  Mastery
6.  Stamina
'Mastery' means learning to 'master' your challenges, by understanding that they're what help you grow.
'Stamina' is about building a support network of friends and family to help you come back during the times you're down.
Harnessing all of these pillars is crucial in developing the strength to withstand any challenge you may face.

"You may be familiar with the idea that resilience relates to bouncing back from adversity, learning from experiences, and turning challenges into opportunities to grow and develop." \[Gemma Leigh Roberts\]

insights.title: Identify which Pillar of Resilience needs your immediate attention

actions.title: Look at your ratings, and focus on your worst three.
actions.markdown: Consider the top three areas that need enhancement. Remember that you can't make all improvements at once, so you have to select your priorities.

actions.title: Create a learning opportunity.
actions.markdown: Reflect on previous challenges you’ve encountered and determine what lessons you have learned from them. Consider how you will respond if similar problems arise in the future.

paragraphCards.markdown: Want to improve your mental strength? First, you must identify your current resilience 'rating'.
After all, you can't move forward if you don't know where you currently stand.
But how do you do this?
A key part of determining your 'resilience rating' is to rate yourself against each Pillar of Resilience, and working out which areas you're lacking in.
Find a piece of paper, and quickly rate yourself (honestly!) out of 10 in the following areas…

1.  Confidence
2.  Adaptability
3.  Positivity
4.  Perspective
5.  Mastery
6.  Stamina
Which three are your lowest areas? Focus on building up these first.
Don't scatter your attention: you must identify a few key areas to work on.
By doing this self-assessment, you will know which areas you need to improve on, and which pillars only need small adjustments.
For example, if you believe your Confidence is low, try practicing repeating mantras like "I am enough" and "I believe I can" to yourself every day in the mirror.
It will feel strange at first, but with daily practice, the effects are striking!

"Learning how to enhance your resilience will help you to overcome challenges and deal with difficult situations effectively, helping you to get through tricky periods of time." \[Gemma Leigh Roberts\]
Life is full of challenges. It's near-impossible to avoid running into a few problems here and there.
In fact, the various setbacks we face are a part of life, whether they concern our emotions and mental wellness, our relationships, our career, or our studies. The list goes on!
Sometimes, these roadblocks can feel like they're too much for anyone to bear.
If you're currently feeling overwhelmed, miserable, or stressed, it's important you know that there's an easy way for you to get out of your predicament.

In Enhancing Resilience, executive coach and author Gemma Leigh Roberts shares her expertise on building resilience not only for the toughest of times, but for the trivial day-to-day difficulties we face too.
Instead of trying to avoid your problems, this course will teach you how to face issues with confidence, and use the lessons you learned to solve similar situations in the future.
Most of all, Roberts highlights the importance of turning the tides around to see the positive side of daily struggles.
The course also provides an easy step-by-step process to understanding the core of emotional strength: the Six Pillars of Resilience.
These pillars will help you understand that you are on top of every situation, and that you have the power to turn struggles into positive energy.

In Enhancing Resilience, Gemma Leigh Roberts teaches the importance of emotional resilience and provides easy steps in which to build it, so that we can cope with future setbacks with positivity and strength.
According to Michael Chernow, being a great entrepreneur is all about relationships.
Yes, a business plan is important, but in a people management business like restaurants, the relationships that you have with your staff and your customers is what will set you apart.

insights.title: Create an informative business plan for your idea

actions.title: Perfect your executive summary.
actions.markdown: Dedicate the first page of your business plan to clearly, concisely, and thoroughly explain exactly what your business is.

actions.title: Hire someone if you need to.
actions.markdown: Some things are difficult to determine on your own, like the financial section of the business plan. If that’s the case, don’t hesitate to hire someone that can help you create realistic figures and projections.

actions.title: Find multiple investors.
actions.markdown: Tap into your friends, family, and closest networking circles to find several small investors for your idea. Go through your contacts and practice your pitch before meeting up with them.

paragraphCards.markdown: "In order to be competitive today, you have to come up with something that's appealing." \[Michael Chernow\]
For your idea to become a reality, it must fill a need and a space in the market that has not been addressed in the way you want it to be.
Around your idea, you create your business plan outlining various aspects of how your idea would look like as a business.
Your business plan "is essentially your ticket. It is a guide map" which you create.
This simple document is usually around 10-pages and lays out the law of the land, from your concept idea and market research findings to your corporate structure and financial projections.
Keep the business plan concise, realistic, and to the point.
"You don't want to hand somebody a Bible." \[Michael Chernow\]

The most common parts of a business plan are: the executive summary, your anticipated sales and profit, a list of your management and division of labor, the concept description (design, aesthetics, the product).
There's also the corporate structure, the market research (including your target demographic and your competitors), and the financials.
When looking through the business plan, investors start with the executive summary, which captures everything in a single page.
If they are interested they are likely to go directly to the financial section which outlines the projected finances and your five-year projected plan.

insights.title: Create a strong team and company culture

actions.title: Build a brand.
actions.markdown: Create a mood board with 20-30 images that represent your brand and implement them into your design branding and physical space or aesthetic.

actions.title: Invest in your company culture.
actions.markdown: Create traditions within your company that align with your core values as a business. Have weekly meetings and monthly outings. Create a sports day or a barbecue event.

paragraphCards.markdown: For a business idea to actuate and a business to survive, a strong team must be supporting the business core values and the correct processes and systems must be in place.
A good team is made up of people who "work as hard as they could possibly work." [Michael Chernow]
It is also important to partner up with people who make up for your weaknesses and have their own perspective on things.
Chernow also believes in genuineness and says that while you can teach someone technical skills, it is almost impossible to "teach somebody to be genuine."
"A strong brand is a physical, almost tangible thing and culture is who you are." [Michael Chernow]
A business needs a passionate team, but also a solid brand and its own company culture.
A brand describes the look and feel of your business or restaurant, the mood, the ambience, the music playing in the background.
Culture is implemented through staff training and meetings.
You can provide a training packet to employees that clearly outlines the company's mission and core values.
Overtime, through practice and iteration, the company culture will form. Together, your brand and company culture interact and create a unique environment for your staff and clients to experience.

insights.title: Smile and be friendly

paragraphCards.markdown: “Smiling and being friendly is the number one secret.” [Michael Chernow]
Your attitude is an important part of success because investors are “actually investing in you, they’re not necessarily investing in the business and the concepts” only.
Therefore, even though your business plan is an important part of making your concept a reality, so is your attitude and behavior towards others.
While speaking with others like someone you just met, you never know who is on the other end of the conversation. Your best bet is to always “err on the side of fairness and kindness.”
Your smile and genuine positivity will not only improve the connections you make but will also motivate your staff to do well which, in turn, leaves a good impression on your clientele.

“Any manager that walks through the door, before they do anything, they walk through the restaurant and they greet and say hi, high-five or a hug to every single person that works there.” [Michael Chernow]

actions.title: Show your pearly whites.
actions.markdown: When you meet someone new or are talking to someone you know, show your pearly whites and remember to smile! Be presentable and carry yourself well.

actions.title: Be engaged in conversation.
actions.markdown: In a conversation, be focused and ask questions to show that you are engaged. Truly listen to what the other person has to say and maintain eye contact throughout the exchange.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Smiling and being friendly  is the number one secret." \[Michael Chernow\]
Let's face it, many people imagine opening a small-business at some point in their lives. But more often than not, this remains just an idea, an unfulfilled dream.
One of the best ways to learn how to succeed in the business world is by learning from people who have already been through that journey.

In Michael Chernow's Entrepreneurship Hustle: From Business Plan to Real Success, you will learn valuable lessons and secrets about how to set up and run the successful small business you've always dreamed of having.
