paragraphCards.markdown: You may already know the term big data and have an idea what it is, but you may not have imagined how useful it is. Everybody Lies is a real eye-opener that can help us all understand our true natures a little better and hopefully make us want to improve ourselves.

insights.title: People aren’t as good at identifying patterns as big data is because they don’t consider large enough sample sizes

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The term big data refers to amounts of information so big that we need massive computational power to understand it.
We might, for example, use Google searches to determine popular foods in a region. It's actually rather intuitive, at least in some regards.
With this understanding, we can all see that in some ways we're all data scientists.
We like to rely on our intuition but it's not really scientific. We're right to gather information and try to make sense of it to make predictions, but we need to do it correctly.
When we have the right data, we get facts to back up our ideas so that our understanding of how the world works is correct.
One experience Seth Stephens-Davidowitz had with his grandmother is a good example of this.
She once began giving him relationship advice, suggesting all the traits to look for in a companion. His potential partner needed to be funny, clever, and pretty, just to name a few.
Looking at this from a data science perspective, she was simply using her 88 years of experience, and the information it had given her, to come to these conclusions.

Over the years she'd seen the traits of successful relationships and was simply passing that down.

But not all of her conclusions were accurate.
She firmly believed that for a long-lasting relationship couples should have a lot of mutual friends. However, she wasn't taking information from enough people's experiences.
In 2014, with a large enough sample size from big data, a study identified that more mutual friends on Facebook made a couple more likely to eventually split up.

insights.title: Big data tells us the deep dark secrets that people won’t share

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: One university recently asked students in a poll to share their GPA.
Just 2% of the participants mentioned their 2.5 or lower GPA. But when the school checked the official records, the actual number was over five times that amount at 11%!
It's pretty obvious from this that people lie on surveys. We do this because we want to look good, even in the face of someone that we don't know.
This is also known as social desirability bias.
And people don't just lie to become liked, either. They'll also try to impress whoever is asking the survey questions.
Regardless of how well we know someone, this psychological bias takes over and we try to make a good impression.
Just think if someone that looked similar to your dad was asking you about your drug use in college. You probably wouldn't be very willing to share the truth!
This is why surveys are unreliable, but where big data comes in to save the day.
What we do online seems anonymous to us, but the information collected can tell when we're lying.
Some surveys that asked about sexual acts, for example, showcases this perfectly.
A far smaller number of people were willing to try certain things in surveys compared to the actual amount that showed based on search data from websites!

insights.title: Society will be better off if the government uses big data to look at helping society as a whole rather than specific individuals

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Whenever you use Google to search for something, you're giving your information to big data.
This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but there are implications we should think about.
For example, what if the government decided to take over this information? If people search for suicide-related phrases, for example, then it might be a good idea to notify local police, right?
The numbers show that this isn't smart.

About 3.5 million searches for suicide-related words happen each month, but only 4,000 actual suicides. Following-up with each search would be an incredible waste of time and money. Let alone the ethical implications.
If we instead look at how we can use regional data to influence people's lives for the better, we get much more promising results.

For example, research indicates that actual suicides do correlate with Google searches on the state level. A local police department could then determine whether the search rates for these terms are higher in their state.
Using that information they could then implement measures to reduce the number of suicides with prevention programs.
So the next time you're worried about Google having your information and the government getting it, stop and think.
Your use of the internet and allowing big data to collect your information could help save someone's life someday, at least in a small way.
"Never compare your Google searches to everyone else's social media posts." \[Seth Stephens-Davidowitz\]
How do you feel about Google having the information that it has about you?
Some people are convinced that it's a big problem; they won't use Google search or even consider having a Gmail account.
While everybody has a right to choose what they will and won't use, some information collection on the internet is a good thing. It helps sites know how to better market to our needs, for one.
And we can learn a lot about human nature from looking at the data and use it to improve society.
Big data, as this collected online information is called, is an important part of our digital world.
Understanding it is important to our future, and Seth Stephens-Davidowitz's Everybody Lies: What the Internet Can Tell Us About Who We Really Are explains it all in great detail.
Everybody Lies will expand your mind about the true nature of human beings by explaining what big data is, how it came to be, and how we can use it to understand ourselves better.

Paul Jarvis takes a philosophical approach in his work, leaving room for you to align what you learn with what you already know about yourself. Everything I know will help you to look inside yourself and find what's most important, before you can get creative and turn it into something great.

insights.title: Let your most important guide in life be your own inner values

actions.title: Find your values and stand by them.
actions.markdown: Sit down and write down what is most important to you in life. Family, relationships, career, environmentalism… Then, assess what you’re doing to make each one happen. Think what more you could do.

paragraphCards.markdown: Here are some of the external yardsticks the world gives us to measure our worth by, which we usually happily take and compare ourselves with…

1.  Money
2.  Grades
3.  Sales
4.  Revenue
5.  Diplomas
6.  Number of shoes
7.  Twitter followers
First, forget all of those. Instead, answer this simple question: What is important to you? What do you think matters?
Whatever answer pops up in your head, it's the first step towards finding your own inner values.
Chances are your internal worth is totally separate from any of the ways the world measures how valuable you are, and that's great.
Now you have your own yardstick, with an incredibly simple way to measure your sense of worth, ask yourself, "How well do I live up to my own values?"
Ironically, this is also the basis of worldly success because it allows you to start doing things your way, and to create something unique that's different and irreplaceable.

insights.title: Make time to create the work the world needs right now

actions.title: Free up your free time.
actions.markdown: There are more hours in the day than you realize. For one week, at the end of each day, write down what time you spent on what. Then, at the end of the week, look where you can free up some time to focus on something bigger and better.

paragraphCards.markdown: Whether you're trying to plan your finances or start a business, you can't predict the future.
It's impossible to control any eventual outcomes, which makes setting too specific goals a futile effort.
However, you can control the work you're doing right here, right now.

The magic trick is to just get started. The moment you start focusing on what work the world needs today, that matches your own values, you can get cracking on a side project that'll deliver just that.
But know that making an effort to deliver such meaningful work will come at a price: the sacrifice of consumption.
You can't just do everything you did before and slap more hours on top. Instead, you'll need to shift your mindset from consumption to creation.
For example, if you watch less TV or listen to fewer podcasts, you can now take that time to shoot your own Youtube show, write a blog, or build a business.
In order to maintain balance, ask yourself: What can I do without if it means I get to create something great?
Take time, start now, don't fret about the future, and keep following your values to reach an outcome – any outcome. It'll be worth it either way.

insights.title: Don’t be afraid to steal, mix, match, and adapt other people’s ideas

actions.title: Look to others for inspiration.
actions.markdown: Don’t think your new idea has to be entirely new. Look to other experts, artists, and innovative thinkers for inspiration. Then, borrow a few of their ideas and twist them into your own.

paragraphCards.markdown: Ideas aren't the result of thinking inside a vacuum. Every thought you ever have is the result of your accumulated experiences.
Ideas are the entirety of what you've ever felt, seen, heard, read and learned. This means that we innovate by letting others inspire us, and then infusing our own unique values into it.

Therefore, you can start by 'stealing' initial ideas to start working with - for example, by meshing three different website designs into your own, or mixing a travel writer's style with one of a scientific research paper.
The more you iterate and integrate what you stand for into the work, the less it'll look like the original. Eventually, you'll arrive at something totally unique to you.
Imagine the idea you start with as a piece of clay which you shape until it's in line with your values, so it'll eventually tell your own story.
"The first draft of anything is shit." \[Ernest Hemingway\]
Paul Jarvis suggests you focus on creating, not what the final result looks like. Let your creativity flow unfiltered in the beginning - just go and make something happen.
"What if instead of reading, you wrote? Instead of watching TV, you made videos? Instead of listening to music, you learned how to play guitar?" \[Paul Jarvis\]
Paul Jarvis is not your average freelancer, writer, podcaster, or programmer.
He's just Paul Jarvis: a tattooed, rat-loving guy, who works incredibly hard to help you create cool stuff, mostly digital products.
After working for himself for the past 18 years, he's pretty much unemployable now - and that's a good thing, because it leaves him with more time to help you and me.
He writes weekly articles which he exclusively sends out to his mailing list.
In 2013, he published Everything I Know to share some of the lessons he's learned along his way. Now you can move past your fears and act out your plans – wherever your adventures may lead you.

Everything I Know ditches all the rules, and gives you a guide to living a fulfilled and adventurous life that can be infinitely updated, stretched, expanded, and customized. Instead of another "do-this-to-get-rich-fast" scheme that doesn't work for everyone, this is based on who you are.

Everything Is Figureoutable will fill you with motivation to do whatever it is that you've always wanted to do. It will make you realize how much you're holding yourself back, and instead to make a change to make your dreams come true.

insights.title: “Everything is figureoutable” is a mantra that will help you beat your own mind games

actions.title: Figure it out.
actions.markdown: Telling yourself something is impossible is a sure way to make sure it is. Instead, get creative and look for solutions. Consider it a challenge - how can you make this tricky thing happen?

paragraphCards.markdown: Every day, you make excuses with self-limiting beliefs. So how do you overcome them?
You could examine your dysfunctional thinking patterns one by one all day if you want - but there's an even simpler way.
Adopt the mantra that "everything is figureoutable," and you'll begin to see that there really are solutions for every problem you set up in your mind as unsolvable.
That's really what each limiting belief comes down to. It's the idea that we think that we cannot solve our problems.
Contrast this with the idea that you can find a solution for every problem, and the entire situation changes.
When you assume from the get-go that the problem is solvable, you set yourself up for success.
Marie Forleo once almost missed a flight because she was late for baggage check-in, but this philosophy saved her trip.
She got thinking, bought some carry-on bags, and was able to get on the flight without checking in any cases.

insights.title: Every time you say “I can’t” you really only mean “I won’t” or “I don’t want to”

actions.title: Stop saying, “I can’t.”
actions.markdown: We don’t always realize the power of such a small phrase. Instead of saying, “I can’t,” consider, “How can I?” Look to find a way around your problem.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you dig deep within yourself, you can see that self-limiting beliefs are simply you justifying yourself, and hiding how much you don't want to do something.
Put more simply, it's just an excuse. The truth is, you won't do whatever it is that you're thinking you "can't" for whatever reason.
Many of us had our parents tell us, "Where there's a will, there's a way."
If you truly wanted something that you think you can't do, you'd figure out how to make it happen - no matter what obstacles are in the way.
Consider a time when you had a goal that seemed impossible, but that you wanted to accomplish more than anything. Your desire made you look, reach and work to find a way.

Marie Forleo experienced this when she wanted to go to a retreat in South America, but didn't have the money for it. It would have been easy for her to think it was impossible to afford, and just quit trying.
But with a strong will to make it happen, she worked hard, and found three additional side jobs and a special payment option with the organizers of the retreat.
Catch yourself the next time you're saying "I can't," and recognize the hidden "I won't figure out a way," that's behind it. Then, adjust your expectations and go to work to make it happen.

insights.title: Clarity, motivation, and desire come only after you start, not before

actions.title: Take the plunge.
actions.markdown: Instead of writing a pros and cons list of giving something a go, just do it. You’re more likely to regret not doing it than doing it. Step out of your comfort zone, be brave, and give it your all.

paragraphCards.markdown: Indecision too often paralyzes even the best go-getters. It's one of the biggest stumbling blocks in our way toward success.
Sitting there and wondering whether or not you can or should do something is a complete waste of time though.
Marie Forleo even spent years trying to decide if she should go after her dream of being a dancer before actually doing it.
Sometimes, the paralysis of indecision can last as long as years, and even that turns into a life of wasted time that you could have been working on your dreams.
The reality is that the only way to know whether an idea is good or not is to take action.
You think that you have to have a perfect idea of what it's going to be like and how to accomplish your end goal, but it doesn't work that way.
It's not even possible to have much clarity at the beginning of a project. You only get that by starting.
All it takes is a small step forward, and you'll immediately begin to see the right path.
"The most powerful words in the universe are the words you say to yourself." \[Marie Forleo\]
Marie Forleo has many childhood memories of her mother fixing things around the house.
It didn't matter if the roof leaked or the radio didn't work. Because of limited money, she needed to do it herself.
And all this was back in the 1980s, before the time of Google and smartphones.
Forleo became confused at how her mom always seemed to know how to fix things, so she asked her. Her mother's answer is something that would change Forleo's life - and today, it can change yours too.
Everything is Figureoutable is the phrase Marie learned from her mother that day.
It's also the title of her book that teaches you how to beat the excuses that get in the way of you living your dreams.
You can find a solution to any problem with a willingness to work at it, and you're about to learn how.

Everything Is Figureoutable will help you annihilate the limiting beliefs that are holding you back. By identifying the thinking patterns that get you stuck and learning how to use self-empowerment principles to become free, it will allow you to finally pursue your dreams.
Factfulness is only one of many books in a long, recent line of works that help us fight our biases.
It delivers its research in a way that's easy to understand and uses great examples to help us see clearly. If Bill Gates can learn something from it, we're sure we can too.

insights.title: There is no such thing as “the East and the West.” We only have one world

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: There are two kinds of people in the world: those who divide the world into two kinds of people, and those who don't.
What we hope to be a clever Quora answer of mine is also one of the first points Hans Rosling makes. He calls it 'the gap instinct.'
It's our tendency to want to see things as black and white. The example he uses to illustrate it is the classic division of the world into East and West.
We have grown up in a time where schools would teach Westerners that their countries are developed, while Asian ones are currently developing, trying to catch up.
This instilled an us-vs-them mentality early on.
But the truth is, whatever gap there was has almost completely disappeared over the past 20 years.
How do we even define 'developing' and 'developed?'
If we use child mortality, for example, only 13 countries could be considered 'developing' today.
One thing's for sure: dividing the world geographically to determine its economic, demographic, or psychological state is useless.

insights.title: Population growth will eventually level off, despite our perception of increasing numbers

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: A second mega misconception, as Hans Rosling calls ideas that are rooted deeply but are incredibly wrong, is that of our impending doom due to exponential population growth.
Books like The World Without Us elaborate on the idea that one day, nature will conceive devastating diseases and catastrophes to rid itself of the growing damage from humans.
But while our growing numbers are sure a cause for concern, they might never hit apocalypse-worthy levels.
The UN's projections for population growth see us hit 9.8 billion in 2050, and 11.2 billion in 2100.
That'd be a double-up from 6.1 billion in 2000.
But in 1900, there were only 1.6 billion humans, which means that in the last century, we grew fourfold, showing the growth rate is already declining.
That's because as countries get out of poverty, people tend to have fewer children. In countries like Germany, populations are even declining!

There are three biases that prevent our feelings from matching the numbers: the straight-line instinct, the fear instinct, and the size instinct. We misplace our primal fears, think trends continue in a straight line, and overestimate their size.
That's why population growth might feel like a huge threat, when actually, it'll likely not be a big deal.

insights.title: To see the world accurately, you always need multiple perspectives

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Democracy is one of the 21st century's most popular ideas, because in it, Western countries have thrived.
But right now, most of the fastest-growing countries aren't democratic, indicating it's not the only political system that works.
And yet, we tend to see it as the ultimate end goal for any 'developing' nation.
Using only a single perspective to shape our opinions might be our biggest flaw.
Sometimes, you come across other viewpoints by accident, but mostly, it's a matter of actively seeking them out.
If you don't do it, you're once again stuck in black-and-white land.
One of the best remedies, Hans Rosling says, is travel.
By exposing yourself to other cultures, you'll naturally get access to many different points of view.
Also, when getting your information online, it's always best to read multiple sources, not just one. It's the equivalent of traveling around the world.
Only when we surf the globe can we learn to see it as it really is, so that we may form our opinions based on facts, not feelings.
And that's what factfulness is all about.
"There's no room for facts when our minds are occupied by fear." Hans Rosling
When we first got into reading blogs, learning about self-improvement, and exploring the startup scene, we were delusional optimists.
We read and read, thinking that would somehow make us entrepreneurs. But that was just blind faith. We never actually did anything.
Over the years, we've learned to become more of a realist-optimist.
We still focus on the positive, but we try not to sugarcoat things.
As it turns out, with fake news and advertising-driven media becoming more and more extreme, this was a good move.
Usually, life is better than news outlets make us believe, so focusing on the facts, but staying positive, will help you form clearer opinions.
That's why Bill Gates is such a big fan of books like Enlightenment Now, which bring us up to speed with data about the world.
It's no wonder, then, that Factfulness is another one of his 2018 favorites.
Written by the Swedish, late professor, sword swallower, and public speaker Hans Rosling, it's a book about the current state of the world.
But beyond giving us the facts, it helps us see them for ourselves by diving into ten mental biases that obstruct our thinking.

Factfulness explains how our worldview has been distorted with the rise of new media, which ten human instincts cause erroneous thinking, and how we can learn to separate fact from fiction when forming our opinions.

You might decide to massively cut down on McDonald's and Burger King after reading this. Read Fast Food Nation. Get educated. Choose better food. ![giphy.com/anchorpoint](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4FGtLo1mvRrl0cxy/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Fast food companies target children in their marketing because they’re impressionable

paragraphCards.markdown: When you think about who to market a product to, one of the first questions that comes up is usually: "Who has the money to buy this?"
But the fast food industry found a group of customers that helped them go around this question: children. [youtube.com/user/RealFoodMediaProject/](https://youtu.be/PWOcP-bXuO8?t=145.70&e=162.70)

Children are responsive, easy to impress and can be convinced with very simple incentives. You show them a bunch of toys and funny characters plus a savory burger and they're sold. ![giphy.com/notflipper](https://media.giphy.com/media/jVTdzFpzaJDdKcnxhB/giphy.gif)
Speaking of sold, how do they come up with the money to pay for the food?
They don't. They simply annoy their parents until they buy it for them. There's hardly anything more convincing for a parent than a child's plea.

The tendency of parents to compensate for a lack of attention with spending more money on their kids has gone up since the 80s, and so this kind of advertising made for the perfect combination of desire and guilt.
For example, consider how food companies use exploitive marketing tactics to manipulate the mind of children. [youtube.com/user/RealFoodMediaProject](https://youtu.be/PWOcP-bXuO8?t=162.90&e=176.70)
Just think of all the colors at a McDonald's. The playground outside. The naming of "Happy Meals." They're a children's paradise.
Adding the toys alone can double or triple sales in any given week. ![giphy.com/slimjimstudios](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7bu2PfKPFoCpvaz6/giphy.gif)
A shocking result of their deliberate marketing to children is that 90% of all children in the US between the ages of three and nine go to McDonald's at least once a month.
Of course, today people use the apps to order in.
Oh and the food has long snuck into schools too. Fast food chains like Subway are often the main suppliers of cafeteria food.

insights.title: Wherever big meat packaging companies go, crime and poverty are on the rise

actions.title: Avoid fast food.
actions.markdown: Yes, it tastes great - but don’t pretend to distance yourself from its negative effects. Instead, find a local delivery service that makes real homemade burgers from scratch. Support small shops instead of chains. Eat real food with real ingredients - and happy, healthy workers.

paragraphCards.markdown: How is it even possible for one cheeseburger to cost $1? ![giphy.com/slimjimstudios](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6Zt9IcOM8guyG03S/giphy.gif)
Think about how much of the work that goes into one burger - could you do it if I gave you $1? And that's not even thinking about profit!
Of course mass production is the main driver behind these prices, but even with that in mind the race for cheaper could hardly be any closer to the bottom, could it?

The meat processing industry has long adopted the same assembly line and highly standardized process that the fast food industry uses to make the food. ![giphy.com/marcrodriguez](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6nURRboKQJrBGVC8/giphy.gif)
This has made skilled workers unnecessary. Instead, they hire cheap, replaceable employees, often illegal migrants, homeless people or refugees, and pay them next to nothing.
[youtube.com/c/bigthink](https://youtu.be/9TIfBlieuOg?t=0.50&e=12.02)
For example, since an employer must only offer paid holidays and health insurance after at least six months of work time, many meat companies fire their workers shortly before passing this mark.
Another thing meat packagers love about hiring illegal immigrants (like the 25% of workers in this industry in Iowa and Nebraska are) is that they can't form unions.
The natural result of these practices is not just a cheap burger, but also a downfall of the cities these companies move to.
Because poor and desperate people make up the workforce of meat packaging firms, the cities they move to see a drastic spike in crime and the need for medical care.

Lexington, Nebraska, for example, doubled both its crime rate and state-subsidized medical care incidents within ten years of a big slaughterhouse moving there in 1990. Gangs controlled the streets and turned the city into a drug hub.
Everything comes at a price. Even if it's just $1. Especially if it's just $1.
[youtube.com/c/bigthink](https://youtu.be/9TIfBlieuOg?t=120.80&e=137.02)

insights.title: There’s a worse health issue than obesity that the fast food industry creates, and it affects 130,000 people a DAY

actions.title: Choose your meat wisely.
actions.markdown: The cheapest beef mince in the supermarket is the cheapest for a reason. Read the packaging, find out where it came from. Was the cow fed organic food or grass? Was it kept free-range? Make sure it was reared correctly and to the appropriate health standards.

paragraphCards.markdown: You're probably aware of the big obesity problem in the US, and you're right to suspect that fast food is largely at fault here. ![giphy.com/slimjimstudios](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0MYQkHMx4FzOoypG/giphy.gif)
However, there's an even bigger health issue, one that affects still more people, that you probably have no idea about.

A type of bacteria called E-coli sometimes pops up in the news for bringing someone into the hospital or even causing their death. ![giphy.com/rob\_gif](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUOxfeHOtSheFIdRks/giphy.gif)
E-coli is a pathogen that mostly grows within feces (that's poop). But sometimes, somehow, it ends up in the food people eat, which then gets them infected.
[youtube.com/c/RETROREPORT](https://youtu.be/_1_slAWLFfw?t=0.00&e=20.00)
Now you might say, "Wait a minute. If the bacteria grow in feces, and end up in food, then…" – and you're right.
It means some of your fast food is shit. Literally. [youtube.com/c/BuzzFeedNews/](https://youtu.be/12JpOFiO1to?t=67.10&e=86.00)
Because in both the meat packaging and fast food industry, the work is done fast by unskilled people and in unsanitary conditions, it's not uncommon for crap to somehow come in contact with the meat.

But that doesn't even have to be the case. By illegally feeding the cattle (which naturally eats grass) the wrong (like corn) and sometimes downright atrocious food (like dead horses, pigs or chicken poop), they're increasing the chances of E. coli even further.
Since so few companies (there are just four big meat packagers) supply all of the US with meat, just one contaminated batch can affect millions of people.
As a result, 130,000 Americans get sick from food poisoning – EVERY DAY. ![giphy.com/Elisetta](https://media.giphy.com/media/3htASEphfpyEFg9ATi/giphy.gif)
"The twenty-first century will no doubt be marked by a struggle to curtail excessive corporate power." \[Eric Schlosser\]
The most serious thing about Fast Food Nation is that it was written 15 years ago and not much has changed.![giphy.com/bad\_arithmetic](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9Igx3rVzdPHoi78A/giphy.gif)

Many books have taken on the topic of fast food, and while they all emphasize different aspects, they share one unanimous message: fast food is bad for everybody, regardless of whether you eat it or not.
Even if you don't eat fast food, you'll still be negatively affected by some of the consequences.

Crime rates may have risen where you live because a big supplier moved there recently, and now employs illegal migrant workers who are poor and desperate. And if you think that's bad, wait till you read the other lessons from Eric Schlosser's book.
Chances are, you'll take a break from eating at McDonald's for a while. ![giphy.com/molehill](https://media.giphy.com/media/1APg5zJR0PbtGKbuqs/giphy.gif)
Fast Food Nation describes how the fast food industry has reduced the overall food quality worldwide, created poor working conditions for millions of people and ruined public health.
Fear is pretty compelling but not surprising, given the huge ego that drives the man(iac).

Whether you are in Trump's camp or not, this book is authoritative and well-honed. It is the result of hundreds of hours of interviews with first-hand sources, meeting notes, personal diaries, files, and documentation.
If it weren't true, this book might make a pretty solid horror story.

insights.title: Trump’s advisors can’t get him to see the advantages in maintaining a good relationship with South Korea

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: After Trump moved into the White House and needed a national security advisor, he hired a military veteran, Lieutenant General H.R. McMaster.
Bob Woodward says he did this on impulse and without going through proper channels for removing an active-duty army officer from his military position.
For Trump, this is typical behavior – no concern for protocol or how things should be done.
It was the same attitude when it came to the relationship between the U.S. and South Korea.

Trump didn't attempt to understand why the country was spending ten-billion dollars on a missile defense system, only to have it located on some, "piece-of-shit land" in South Korea, as Trump referred to it.
Trump couldn't understand why the U.S. had an eighteen-million-dollar trade deficit with South Korea. To him, the United States was being "screwed over" by the people that he was paying to protect.

At least three advisors attempted to explain the importance of the United States maintaining a good relationship with Korea. Particularly when North Korea was flexing its military muscles with aggressive nuclear testing.
And then Trump walks away from a meeting after suggesting that all military personnel in South Korea be brought home.
Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson was heard muttering, "He's a f\*cking moron."

insights.title: Though Trump’s economic advisor, Gary Cohn, shared countless pages of data proving that free trade was good for the U.S., Trump refused to look at it

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Trump is of the opinion that politicians who favor "globalism over Americanism" are responsible for the decline in good factory jobs in the US.
Not only did Trump's economic advisor, Gary Cohn, not believe this, but ninety-nine percent of U.S. economists didn't buy it either.

Even when Cohn had reams of data printed out to support his position, proving that free trade was good for the country and that the nation had moved from manufacturing to a service-based economy, Trump refused to look at any of it.
Once Trump has his mind set it's almost impossible for him to see any other side.
It's part of the Trump philosophy – never show weakness, apologize, or admit when you're wrong.
This same philosophy applies to Trump's relationships.
He once advised a colleague that real power comes from never backing down, remaining strong, and always pushing forward. Always deny and never admit you were wrong.
No matter how many people told him that his views on free trade were wrong, he would respond with, "I don't want to hear it!"
He was relentless in getting out of NAFTA, the North American Free Trade Agreement. This agreement reflects a one trillion dollar trade deal between Mexico and Canada.
Trump only felt like the deal was "screwing" the country.

insights.title: Trump likes to refer to his Twitter account as his “megaphone” for speaking to the public directly and unfiltered

"The reality was that the United States in 2017 was tethered to the words and actions of an emotionally overwrought, mercurial and unpredictable leader" Bob Woodward

paragraphCards.markdown: There are myriad routes toward becoming a writer, but not without discipline. [youtube.com/c/masterclass/](https://youtu.be/ZoAYmnRX2gY?t=96.78&e=107.78)

Through Walter Mosley's course, we come to see the necessary relationship between a dedicated writing routine and writing what we know, telling our truth and opening ourselves up to being changed by the process.

If you maintain a schedule of daily writing, within a year you'll have a draft novel ready to begin its journey toward publication. ![giphy.com/gifitup](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oz8xDBz9ZMP9RWACs/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Don’t be afraid

actions.title: Devote yourself to daily writing, three hours a day.
actions.markdown: Most people generate their best work first thing in the morning; if this doesn’t work, try the evening—but you must write daily. If the words don’t come, warm up with a writing exercise as simple as describing the room around you.

actions.title: Edit as you go.
actions.markdown: Each day, look over what you have and make small edits. Notice what strengths and problems you encounter and make a note of these to attend to later, rather than applying heavy edits at this point.

paragraphCards.markdown: Follow your heart in writing, and write your truth. Ask yourself what kind of book you want to write, not what you think you should write. ![giphy.com/willherring](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4hLAnH7GC9XaQkAo/giphy.gif)
When you begin to write what you're genuinely trying to examine, feel, and address, you will begin to figure out who you are and what you believe—and what comes out on the page is often surprising.
Perhaps you've never written before, or you're coming to it late in life, or you think you need to get through the top 100 novels of the past century before you begin.
What you need is confidence in your voice and your story.
"The hardest thing you're ever going to face in writing a novel is believing in something that has come from seemingly nothing." \[Walter Mosley\]

Narrative storytelling is as simple as writing the beginning, middle, and end of a tale, and finding the discipline to do so. ![giphy.com/artukdotorg](https://media.giphy.com/media/jOnj3L7KVi2GfYWg2u/giphy.gif)
Rejection is inevitable - Mosley's novel was rejected 17 times - but we must push past fear of rejection and develop a committed practice of daily writing: "no holidays, no vacations - every day".
Each morning, for the past 30 years, Mosley wakes early and writes 1000 words over three hours, reading over and making light edits on the previous days' work before he begins.

"You will find, if you write every day, that the next day ideas have bubbled up from someplace that you had no idea were there." \[Walter Mosley\] ![giphy.com/thokamaer](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41lRVmlnknDV3n9u/giphy.gif)

If you're sitting at your desk staring at a blank page and the words don't come, write anything that's on your mind, and the words will arrive, even when you feel stuck, even when you feel that you're failing.
It's often an emotional process, but as we write and read over our work we begin to find the inner storyteller self.
And if we write for three hours each day, we'll have a completed draft of a novel within a year. ![giphy.com/nationalmuseet](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ov9jMptZ7rrpvxHu8/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Increase your knowledge of the craft

actions.title: Track your progress.
actions.markdown: Keep previous drafts in a folder so you can see how much your knowledge and skill has improved, which will motivate you to continue writing and further refine your skills.

actions.title: Sound it out.
actions.markdown: Practice reading your work aloud, either to yourself, a tape recorder, or a trusted friend who will provide honest feedback. It makes a significant difference, and you’ll often find that what reads on the page translates as clumsy when read out loud.

actions.title: Learn the fundamentals.
actions.markdown: Read up on the definitions and foundational elements of writing. This will give you confidence to more clearly articulate the intention and synopsis of your novel to yourself, your peers, and future publishers.

paragraphCards.markdown: Once you're in the practice of daily writing, it's important to incorporate other routines into your schedule. ![giphy.com/okkultmotionpictures](https://media.giphy.com/media/xkmQfH1TB0dLW/giphy.gif)
Editing and rewriting is as crucial as the initial writing itself. In fact, Mosley doesn't think about 'writing' per se; there's "pre-writing and there's rewriting."
Pre-writing is the first draft; rewriting means combing through the text, restructuring and revising, noticing what works and what needs clarifying.
Another good pointer is to read your work aloud, to hear where dialogue and plot are successful and seamless, and where you stumble over the story, because there, the reader will also.

Once you have a work of decent enough length where you could use some input, find a few writer peers to share your work with, or a low-cost writers' workshop. ![giphy.com/boomerangtoons](https://media.giphy.com/media/69jvP3VXUYhr3YUYu9/giphy.gif)

From these relationships, it's easier to gain perspective and ideas, critique and advice, and learn what works and what doesn't in your peers' work, and find the same strengths and weaknesses in your own.

Your draft will not be perfect and may not be published, but to get to publishing you must first finish a draft—harder than it sounds! And then, another draft. ![giphy.com/gifitup](https://media.giphy.com/media/wbY6dFxpJ4jzXq9FLf/giphy.gif)

Mosley writes around 20 drafts before he decides it's finished; and as he approaches his final draft he reads it aloud into a tape recorder. ![https://giphy.com/millmotion](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oKGzvg3gGxSS3O38A/giphy.gif)
Accompanying the actual writing is a necessarily sound grasp on the fundamentals of storytelling. ![giphy.com/pavelaslaptevas](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUoqaN8IaedGH0sr3h/giphy.gif)

Knowledge of the technical terminology and processes of writing will aid in both developing a rigorous routine and improving your work. ![giphy.com/johnmellencamp](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o84sqlBujhGoXvTyM/giphy.gif)

Once you have a strong understanding of the structural building blocks of writing - plot, story, genre, character, character development, narrative voice, dialogue, poetry, and metaphor - you'll find writing comes easier.
For example, Mosley describes 'story' as what's happening, and 'plot' as the reasoning that's revealed to the reader.
Learning the distinctions of literary terms will help us make sense of what we're writing. ![giphy.com/franciscab](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oEjHGjKmtrGhDqchO/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Read, find, and listen to stories, and start with pedestrian topics in your own work

actions.title: Never too late to start reading.
actions.markdown: If you’re not sure where to begin, check out lists of the most-loved books over history. Read up on those writer’s lives and influence on literature. You’ll then be able to follow threads to similar writers.

actions.title: Broaden your horizons.
actions.markdown: Read widely and test your assumptions to increase your knowledge. If you haven’t read poetry, give it a try. Look up writing exercises online, and experiment with form.

actions.title: Find your inner storyteller.
actions.markdown: If you want to write a novel, chances are you’re already a storyteller at heart, so don’t underestimate what you already know. Everything is material, and experiential knowledge is often richer and more unique than intellectual understanding.

paragraphCards.markdown: When writing a narrative, begin with the commonplace, drawing out characters who undertake menial, everyday actions, then introduce larger events and themes. ![giphy.com/blendfilmsinc](https://media.giphy.com/media/FVOGnebMJHKFy/giphy.gif)
One way of learning how to believably transition from the small to the broad is to read plenty of books, and study the thematic and technical aspects of narrative as you read.

The more you read, the more you begin to thoughtfully observe what we recognize, and receive stylistic and structural instructions from established writers.![giphy.com/benjybrooke](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2SpXaJA67JaSqSxq/giphy.gif)

Although it's not necessary to read the entire canon, you ought to read classic books within the same genre in which you're working. ![https://giphy.com/warnerarchive](https://media.giphy.com/media/DMvOJX5R6UvUQ/giphy.gif)
Poetry is one of the oldest and most expressive modes of human language.
If we train our ear and eye to poetry, and study how it relays expansive, dense, and image-rich stories with brevity, even our prose writing will improve.

From there, look at the history of literature and the canon. What's missing? Who is missing? Don't write to correct history, but do observe gaps and prejudices. What stories do we contain that are unique, underrepresented, or invisible?
"If you want to exist in cultural history, then you need to be present in literature." \[Walter Mosley\] [youtube.com/c/masterclass/](https://youtu.be/ZoAYmnRX2gY?t=34.88&e=53.28)

Ultimately the most important skill for a writer is to be able to tell a good story. Reading is one of the most important things we can do, but it won't turn us into writers. ![giphy.com/alcrego](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o85xonfOvQzN3eCNG/giphy.gif)
People who can crack a joke and hang out on street corners chatting are the real story-tellers.
Jokes are 'tiny little novels' and if you can riff a series of jokes you're probably a writer at heart, regardless of your education or number of books read.

"Don't mistake the fact that you're reading books with the issue of you becoming a good writer or a person who can write a beginning, middle, and end. Reading and writing are two different things." \[Walter Mosley\]
"Fiction is one of the few things that we can do in the modern world in which you make something from nothing." \[Walter Mosley\]
Mosley began his writing career at the ripe age of 34 and believes the longer you wait, the better - to a point. [youtube.com/c/masterclass/](https://youtu.be/ZoAYmnRX2gY?t=9.28&e=24.88)

When he began writing he was, in his words, a failure at life, lacking conventional training, institutional support and, he felt, on the older side. ![giphy.com/sociality2](https://media.giphy.com/media/w8N49ojv4AgZfxPfPr/giphy.gif)

However, Mosley came to see his 'failure' as being advantageous, observing that his years of accumulated life experiences and natural ear for storytelling were skills that can't necessarily be taught through a writer's program.

He came to see that what he lacked afforded a freedom to break rules, and so, he developed his craft as an attempt to understand the world through the mode of the novel. ![giphy.com/polyvinylrecords](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohhwnXMCVPWD3IOSQ/giphy.gif)

This class offers not only a set of process-oriented and practical tools necessary to complete a novel from inception to completion, but a revelatory exploration of self-discovery through the act of writing to more fully understand ourselves.

This MasterClass by prolific crime fiction novelist Walter Mosley offers an illuminating and motivational crash course in the art of story and maintaining a disciplined writing practice with the aim of completing a draft novel within a year.
Find a Job in the Hidden Job Market teaches that the real secret to job hunting is networking.

Determination, politeness, and good people skills are the skills you'll need, and this course could help you to find the courage to chase after your dream position. ![Excited happy american woman](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1361068394.jpg)

insights.title: Finding the right job is about being as specific as you can

actions.title: Set clear expectations.
actions.markdown: If you are looking for a job, write down a list of what you want from a company, and what you can provide in return. Be specific to help narrow down your options.

actions.title: Set clear goals.
actions.markdown: Ensure that you have clear, actionable goals for your job hunt. Then, monitor your progress and hold yourself accountable. Make it happen for yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Before you write your resumé, reach out to your former acquaintances and colleagues, and tell them that you're job searching. You really need to get clear on who you are, and the value that you bring to an organization." \[Sarah Johnston\]

The act of beginning your job search with a specific intention and direction in mind will ensure you're using your time wisely. [giphy.com/netflix/](https://media.giphy.com/media/ViIN80tf1dy1pKpdFa/giphy.mp4)

Take a piece of paper and write down a few words about yourself. What are your best qualities that can be used in a professional setting? [giphy.com/paramountnetwork/](https://media.giphy.com/media/SXCiEOdH8YIGMQoCgH/giphy.mp4)
Are you a team worker, or do you crave alone time at work? Do you consider yourself to be a leader, or do you need a bit more direction?
Being specific is not only about picking the right job; it's about getting to know yourself on a deeper level. [giphy.com/netflix/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUA7bdYDx2nrFTHPRC/giphy.mp4)
The only way you'll find your match in a job is by getting clear on who you are, what you want, and what you can bring to the table.

Put yourself in the shoes of the company that will interview you. Why should they hire you? ![Job Search Qualification Resume](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_267933893.jpg)
If you don't know why you should be hired, the company will have a much harder time working it out too.

insights.title: Use informational interviews to your advantage

actions.title: Get to know the company.
actions.markdown: If you know where you’d like to work, do some research. Learning about a company will allow you to develop an interest in its mission and values. Remember to be genuine in your approach.

actions.title: Ask for the company’s story, not the job.
actions.markdown: Ask questions about the company’s culture and their goals for the future, but don’t push them - remember that it’s still just an informational interview.

paragraphCards.markdown: An informational interview is like any informal meeting you'd have with a friend: you shouldn't make it all about you. [youtube.com/c/SelfMadeMillennial/](https://youtu.be/_BP7RE7TmtA?t=92.86&e=107.20)

A successful informational interview should feel like a human conversation more than a business venture. Try to get to know the person in front of you. ![Friendly female colleagues](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1246077505.jpg)
If you're stuck for conversational points, ask questions about the interviewer's career, their accomplishments, and why they enjoy working for their company.

"People can sense when you're being insincere. Show genuine interest in the work that they're doing, where the company's headed, and what the other person cares about and is passionate about. It leads to a more authentic and genuine connection." \[Sarah Johnston\]
But how do you get an informational interview in the first place? [giphy.com/tvland/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oEdv2lXxLYHjuafMQ/giphy.mp4)
You should start with cold-emailing, a technique that has an average response rate of 20-25%. Job board applications, on the other hand, only give you a 3% chance of getting a reply.

Find a decision maker at a company that interests you, and send them an email inquiring about the company. ![Closeup Woman hand using Laptop](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1715370262.jpg)

Make sure that the person you're talking to knows how much you appreciate their time. A compliment or two (genuine, of course) will go a long way. [giphy.com/nbcsunnyside/](https://media.giphy.com/media/VgNGBOjaYLq5vu79FA/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: Broaden the scope of your job search, and you’ll find the hidden job market

actions.title: Send out LinkedIn connection invites.
actions.markdown: When you find a company you’d like to work for, get into the habit of taking a chance and always reaching out to company employees for job opportunities or informational interviews. Be proactive, and see what comes of it.

paragraphCards.markdown: Networking is the golden ticket to discovering jobs that aren't advertised online. ![Diverse business people at a dinner party](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1379347964.jpg)
Networking is about being bold and proactive, taking the initiative to seek job offers out for yourself, instead of waiting for them to magically appear.

Have you ever volunteered? Charity work in a sector that inspires you is a good start to getting to know people in your target industry. [giphy.com/closershow/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT0xeAHbxtwb3OASUU/giphy.mp4)
If you'd like to, say, sell pet supplies, volunteering at an animal shelter could be a way of getting your foot in the door, and meeting suppliers that you could work with in the future.
Meeting people in person always trumps talking to someone online. ![Cheerful millenial woman](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1389384308.jpg)
Leverage conferences and trade association meetings where you can meet people face to face, and show them your motivation and interest in their specific field.

Face to face meetings make people more likely to remember you, and they might even offer you an interview for a position that has just opened up. [giphy.com/NAHREP/](https://media.giphy.com/media/WtTsazRdL1GZQWTdE3/giphy.mp4)

To optimize your time at a conference, research before you go, and find out what the schedule is. This way, you can consciously seek out conversations with people that work in your sector. Always come prepared.

"Now is the time to take a bold step for your career. Get out a sticky note and a pen, and jot down two or three ideas of things that you want to do differently. Stick it in your calendar as a reminder. Take a bold step in your job search." \[Sarah Johnston\]
"The hidden job market is all about talking to the right person, at the right time, about the right opportunity." \[Sarah Johnston\]
Looking for a job is exciting, but it's stressful too. [giphy.com/c8tv/](https://media.giphy.com/media/ulLuKKwo9GuaI1gbjR/giphy.mp4)
It often involves hours spent in front of a computer, sending out emails that don't always receive an answer.
Many of us know all too well that most applications we send out do not get a reply or an interview.
That's not because we're not good enough - it's because these company websites and job boards are often saturated.
If we solely rely on job sites, we might end up disappointed.
Fortunately, there are ways around this, like getting to know and use the hidden job market. [giphy.com/clioawards/](https://media.giphy.com/media/fe7rvYvwBZH42lj6ie/giphy.mp4)

After a successful career in recruitment, Sarah Johnston became a career strategist, or a job search guru, if you will. [youtube.com/c/SelfMadeMillennial/](https://youtu.be/_BP7RE7TmtA?t=210.11&e=233.83)
In this course, Johnston's expertise will lift you out the rabbit hole of fruitless job applications, and help you target, aim, and shoot your shot.

Through active job seeking, better understanding the psychology and the expectations of recruiters, and listening to your professional desires and abilities, you can unleash your potential and secure the career path you deserve.
Are you ready to put in the work, and get the job you're after?

In Find a Job in the Hidden Job Market, career strategist Sarah Johnston gives you practical tips on how to hack your job search, by looking where other candidates don't - so you can snatch your dream position.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you liked Simon's last book, Find Your Why is a good addendum. It's practical, so if you liked the message but felt stuck in applying it to your own life, this may be the solution.
Besides outlining the process for individuals, the book also includes ideas for team workshops and businesses, which rounds it all out nicely.

insights.title: Recount stories from your past to find your WHY

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Once, Simon Sinek sat next to a man on a plane who had been living his WHY for over 20 years. Guess what that man's company did? They produced steel.
Super boring, right? How could someone be passionate about cold metal?
Well, as it turned out, the man's business was focused on low carbon emissions and making products that were easy to recycle.
His WHY was to keep the environment clean for future generations.
That's pretty powerful and it doesn't matter whether you apply it to steel tubing, cool apps or knitting socks – if your business becomes large enough, the impact will be big!
After Simon first found his own WHY – to help others wake up inspired to go to work in the morning – he sat down with others to walk them through the process.
The most important part of that process was always for the person to recount old stories.
Most of us can point back to childhood and find lots of buried passions, but even recent stories matter a lot, as long as they had a big impact on us.
If you want to do this for yourself, go through 10-12 stories with a friend or someone who asks you lots of questions along the way, and you should get a lot closer to your purpose.

insights.title: Use your HOWs to be efficient in implementing your WHY

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: We all have a WHY, and while finding it isn't always easy, it's only the first step.
After all, you want to live your WHY, not just know it. This is where your HOWs come into play.
They are the attitudes and behaviors that enable you to do your best work.
Your HOWs include both very specific habits and more general points of view.
Whether you're a night owl or an early riser belongs into the first category, for example, while being good at marketing goes into the second.
Knowing the former helps you move towards a job or style of work that supports those habits. The latter helps you make important decisions.
For example, if it's easy for you to market things, get traction on new projects, and capture some early sales, what you should work on next needn't always be what's most profitable.
Instead, you can focus more on ethics and selling what you really want, because you can generate word of mouth quickly with a lot of different products.
But how do you identify your HOWs?
Just like past stories help you identify your purpose, past behavior can give you a good idea of how you should best go about living it.
Take some time to think about how you work, write down the daily routines that allowed you to perform best in the past and which high-level skills you've accumulated so far.
With your HOWs in hand, living your WHY becomes a lot easier.

insights.title: Once you have your WHY, practice sharing it as much as possible

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: If you know your WHY and do a good job at keeping it front and center in your life, you're already ahead of most people in life on your journey towards happiness.
That's why part of your responsibility once you have it is to share your WHY as much as you can.
There are several good reasons to do so…

1.  It will inspire others to start searching for their own WHY.
2.  It might turn a lame conversation into a fascinating experience.
3.  It's the perfect answer to "What do you do?"
4.  It'll help you refine your mission statement constantly.

What's more, if your WHY is a bold claim or something that makes people roll their eyes, like "I want to help humans fly like birds," this is a chance to double down on your commitment and back up your words with actions.
Lastly, it'll help you work better with others and pinpoint when something doesn't feel right.
So, craft a short, one-sentence WHY and write it down somewhere!
"Fulfilment is a right and not a privilege" Simon Sinek
In 2017, Simon Sinek did it again. After giving one of the world's most popular TED talks in 2009, he once more held a speech that rocked the world.
Talking to Tom Bilyeu, he broke down 'the millennial question' and addressed four reasons why young generations struggle so much with building a satisfying life.
The result? 35 million views and, probably, a new book for him to write.
The book we're looking at today, Find Your Why, acts more as a practical follow-up, a workbook, if you will, to his previous bestseller, Start With Why.
It adds more context and actionable exercises to help individuals and businesses find their WHY and ensure they implement it at work.
Find Your Why is an actionable guide to discover your mission in life, figure out how you can live it on a daily basis and share it with the world.

You can't do enough critical thinking and questioning about the educational system these days. It's falling apart at the seams, with degrees becoming less and less valuable and thousands of new options of making a living emerging by the day.
Finding Your Element is a highly important book about a highly important topic.

insights.title: Stop for a second to appreciate your own, unique experience called life

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Has someone ever told you "you really are one-of-a-kind?" to express they think you're special? It's a really nice thing to happen, isn't it?
But have you ever stopped to consider how profoundly right they were, when they paid you that compliment? Because they literally were.
Stop for a second and really think about this. No human person in the history of the world has had the same biology and psychology as you do.
Throughout human evolution, genes have been combined, changed, tweaked and permuted countless billions, trillions of times even.
Yet you are the first and only instance of your exact combination of genes. No one will ever have the same genetic code, ever again (even if you have an identical twin).
Of course this includes your brain, which is responsible for the second, absolutely unique thing about you: your experience.

You were born at a certain place (which will never be the same it was that day) at a certain time (which will never come again) into a certain set of circumstances (which will never be the same again).
Nobody can ever have the same experiences with the same people in the same moment as you. No do-overs.
Your life can and never will be recreated as you've lived it – so far and until you die. One time.
Take a second to appreciate this. It really is one-of-a-kind. Just like you.

insights.title: Don’t be afraid of the unknown, because everything is

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Logically following this uniqueness, you'd have to think that no human life plays out in the same way, which should hold true for our work too, right?
How come then that millions of people end up doing the same thing and making the same career choices?
This is where one of the most basic yet strongest human fears kicks in: the fear of the unknown.
Our brains scream for certainty and reassurance, and society is happy to offer both of those to us.
"Follow the plan," it whispers "you know, the well-established path, the one where you know how it plays out."

Usually that's finishing high school at 17 or 18, entering college, graduating, getting a professional job as a lawyer, doctor, teacher or manager, then settling down, getting married and starting a family.
But since we're living through the biggest shift in education and work since the Industrial Revolution, the pressure to follow this plan makes us even more uncomfortable.
How can we expect humans who've just become adults to commit to a plan for the rest of their life in such an uncertain world? It's insane.

If you think about it, you never have even the faintest idea of what's going to happen the next time you set foot outside your house – yet you somehow try to plan the next 40, 50, 60 years of your life.
Ken Robinson suggests that, instead of fretting about the unknown, we should learn to see the potential upside in it.
An infinite number of good things can happen which might reveal opportunities you never could've dreamed of. Ken didn't start writing and speaking until he was well into his 40s.
Don't be afraid of the unknown. Everything is. And that's a good thing.

insights.title: Think about what school told you you were bad at again – are you really?

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Did you ever get the feedback from your school teachers that you were bad at something?
That you should stop trying? Or that something you were good at wasn't that valuable?
Institutional education is discouraging us in a lot more ways than it encourages us, because in school, only one kind of intelligence is valued: logical reasoning (IQ).

Math and science are at the top of the subject food chain, followed by languages and humanities (like geography, history, politics, etc.), with the arts, like dance, music, poetry, at the very bottom.
But not only does school not drive us towards creative pursuits, it actually drives us away from them.
In the school system, mistakes are punished – whereas in reality, the only way to do something creative is to do something that might be a mistake.
Think back to school. First grade, third grade, fifth grade, what did teachers make you believe you're bad at?
Do you still believe that today? Why? Was it something you liked?
Ask more of these questions, and you just might find one of your hidden talents or passions.

"These days, anyone whose real strengths lie outside the restricted field of academic work can find being at school a dispiriting experience and emerge from it wondering if they have any significant aptitudes at all" Sir Ken Robinson
Sir Ken Robinson, the author of Finding Your Element, likes to talk about three things: creativity, uncertainty and the immense capabilities of children.
Taken together, they make up much of what he stands for – that we're living through a revolution in education, and that it's time to change it.
He's the presenter of one of the most famous TED talks of all time, and one of few strong critics of our school system, saying in its current form, it's meant to make us obedient, not educated.
In this book, which acts as a sort of follow-up workbook to go with his bestseller The Element, Ken shows us what to do right now, since we can't change our education system from one day to the next.

It outlines how you can find out what you're good at and what you like, and how to combine these two things into something that makes you happy, regardless of what society tells you or what you've been trained to do in school and college.

Finding Your Element shows you how to find your talents and passions, embrace them, and come up with your own definition of happiness, so you can combine what you love with what you're good at to live a long, happy life.
With the help of Lisa Earle McLeod and Elizabeth McLeod, you can discover your sense of purpose at work through self-exploration, mindset, and conversations with the people around you.
Once you've found your purpose, don't lose sight of it. Remind it of yourself as often as you can, and don't lose sight of the big picture amongst life's daily trivialities.

insights.title: Understand that you can have both money and meaning at the same time

actions.title: Decide that your work matters.
actions.markdown: Instead of waiting for your boss or your company to give you validation, create meaningful work and remind yourself of the ways that your efforts are making an impact.

actions.title: Participate in activities that you’re passionate about.
actions.markdown: Explore activities within your company that are aligned with who you are as an individual, to give you something to look forward to every day.

actions.title: Make your job personally meaningful to you.
actions.markdown: Look for emotional threads in your job responsibilities and think about how your work significantly impacts your company, your customers, and the people around you.

paragraphCards.markdown: It is a common misconception that there is no way you can get both money and meaning in your career.
At times, people think that being employed in for-profit companies means that they are less likely to find meaning in their work due to capitalism.
Do not be disheartened by this. Instead, take time to view your job from a different perspective.

While capitalism may sound dreadful, it is what actually lifts economies and people out of poverty. If your company provides a service or a product that customers want or need, then your work matters.
Money and meaning do not contradict each other. In fact, they're tightly associated with one another.
You earn money because you work hard, and your work has a significant impact on the people around you.
Shift your perspective and you'll see that you can have both money and meaning, which is what you deserve.

insights.title: Claim your own sense of purpose

actions.title: Create a purpose statement.
actions.markdown: Come up with a simple sentence that will serve as your daily work mantra to help you stay motivated.

actions.title: Choose to be happy.
actions.markdown: Take a moment to redefine your perspective about your job. How you view your work significantly affects your happiness and satisfaction.

actions.title: Pay attention to the bigger picture.
actions.markdown: Look at the bigger picture and see how your work affects the performance of your company. Remind yourself that what you’re doing matters.

paragraphCards.markdown: Sometimes, the reason that we can't find purpose at work is because we're just waiting around for our boss to hand it to us on a silver platter.
What we don't realize is that the first person who needs to believe that our work matters is ourselves. The only validation we need is our own.
In our daily hectic and fast-paced work, it has become easier to forget that our jobs are as important as any other seemingly meaningful positions.
Take a look at the bigger picture, and recognize how your daily job responsibilities have a positive impact on your organization, coworkers, and customers.
Structure your own purpose statement that you can say to yourself during your internal pep talk.
It doesn't have to be perfect, but it does have to be specific and honest. It could be something about what drives you to go to work, or the little moments of fulfillment you feel.

insights.title: Live up to your purpose at work

actions.title: Make use of stories to animate boring meetings.
actions.markdown: Share some motivating stories to ignite dull meetings and conferences rather than focusing on the numbers and metrics.

actions.title: Have a heart-to-heart talk with your boss.
actions.markdown: Instead of assuming your boss’s poor intent, gather up the courage to initiate a conversation.

actions.title: Allow your positivity to influence your colleagues.
actions.markdown: Communicate with your coworkers who are disheartened with their jobs and be a positive influence to help them find their purpose at work.

paragraphCards.markdown: Claiming our own sense of purpose is only the beginning--we can't stop there.
We have to keep going and remind ourselves of our purpose every single day. We must leverage it to perform better, influence our surroundings, and be at peace with our work.

Having a good relationship with our coworkers and our boss plays into this. We often think that our boss only cares about productivity numbers and metrics, but avoid assuming poor intent, and simply initiate a conversation with your boss.
When we come across coworkers who used to be like us – those who are yet to find their sense of purpose at work – it's easy to feel demotivated and disheartened.
The best thing we can do is to stay consistent.
Energy is infectious. The more we talk about purpose, and the more we walk our talk, the more people will come around.
"You have the power to transform any moment of your life, and you can do it with your own thoughts and your own words." \[Lisa Earle McLeod, Elizabeth McLeod\]
Not everyone is fortunate enough to discover their noble calling at an early point in their lives, and find their way into their dream jobs.
As a matter of fact, most of us are stuck in a job we never dreamed of. We force ourselves to go to work in misery every single day, constantly wondering what our purpose truly is.
In today's exhausting corporate world, it seems that career satisfaction is only reserved for employees who are exactly where they want to be.
However, career management experts Lisa Earle McLeod and Elizabeth McLeod beg to differ. They believe you can find your purpose in just about any job.
Lisa Earle McLeod and Elizabeth McLeod operate a consulting firm that aims to help workers and companies utilize noble purpose to perform more efficiently.
Finding Your Purpose at Work takes us to the journey of self-exploration in order for us to achieve a higher level of happiness and satisfaction in our careers.
In Finding Your Purpose at Work, experts Lisa Earle McLeod and Elizabeth McLeod guide you through the process of finding purpose, happiness, and fulfillment in the job you already have.
Jon learned most of the lessons in this book from hard data.

Thousands of people have taken his 30 Days of Hustle challenge, and, interestingly, performed best after the lessons that took the pressure off. He turned his hard-won knowledge into Finish and the result shows.
The book is a fun, but powerful way to put perfection in its place and wrap up what you start.

insights.title: Suck at some things on purpose, so you’re free to be amazing at others

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: If you start up a website where you can share your writing skills, you might spend hours tweaking the design - downloading themes, cropping pictures - until you finally realize: you suck at design. And that's okay.
But exploring your lack of graphic skills allows you to focus on what you could become good at: writing actual content.
As a solo entrepreneur or artist, the temptation to do everything yourself is enormous, because at first, you have no other choice.
However, the sooner you can move away from this task-hogging, time-wasting mindset, the faster you can put more time into the core activities that you're good at and that drive your venture forward.
By strategically choosing which areas you'll accept being incompetent in, you can prioritize your strengths.

What's more, there are plenty of options to deal with these trade-offs. For example, you can now handle design in several ways:

1.  Never prioritize it at first. Just pick something out of the box and go.
2.  Then hire someone to help out with the first profits of a new project.
3.  Always set constraints in how much time you spend on visuals.
Strategic incompetence, we're telling you. It's a thing!

insights.title: Don’t let last-minute doubts kill your project

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: We'd love to tell you we're always ahead of schedule with our work, but we never am. We write about whatever fascinates us that week, and so there's always urgency to publish new pieces.
Whenever we finalize drafts early, there's a little voice inside our head right before we want to hit 'Publish.'

It says stuff like "are you sure this is good enough?" and "don't you want to edit it some more?" or even "you know this is going to flop, right?" As creators, it is our duty to shut that voice up and smash the launch button.
The reason this voice is so hard to silence is that it has a point: if we spent more time on our work, it would be better.
However, nine times out of ten times, nine out of ten people won't notice, because we're reaching for the last few percent missing for perfection, not fixing some huge flaw.
Of course we never have this problem when we're out of time.
Work always fills the time we make available for it, so when we have to sprint to make the deadline, there's no time for self-doubt.
This isn't to say you should procrastinate, but repeatedly quitting just before the finish line can have disastrous effects.

You won't just start blaming other people, for example by saying you sacrificed your dreams for your family or spouse, but you'll also reinforce the belief that you're the type of person who never keeps the promises they made to themselves.
There is nothing sadder than that.

insights.title: Track your progress to check it at times when you feel down

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: While checking your stats several times a day might destroy your blogging dream in less than a week, taking a peek once a week when you feel like nothing's happening can be a good thing.
One of perfection's sneakiest tricks is to tell us we're "not making enough progress," when actually, we've never defined what enough progress looks like!
Yes, most people won't reach 1,000 people with their writing in their second week, but as long as you reach 15 more than in the first, who cares?
Tracking your numbers is productive, as long as you check them at the right times.
Very few projects warrant daily reports, but you can use weekly or monthly summaries to visualize your progress, regardless of what perfectionism tells you.

Here are some numbers we track weekly

Money earned on various platforms.

Weight. We step on the scale every Sunday morning.

Daily steps taken.

Social media stats.
Don't let vague doubts kill your vibe. Look at the right numbers at the right time and you can focus on progress over perfection.
"The harder you try to be perfect, the less likely you'll accomplish your goals." Jon Acuff
One of the biggest challenges of blogging is statistics.
Not that you'd have to calculate anything, but most blogs die because people keep checking their numbers, which, inevitably, suck at first.
While we know all we need to do is write consistently for a long enough time, everyone wants their first post to go viral.
Before we even begin, we've made a rule in our heads that says "if it's not that, it's not perfect and thus, not worth it."
We don't know what the rule is, but perfectionism has ensured our project's dead in the water.
This is the exact problem Jon Acuff addresses in his latest book, Finish.
So far, he's shown us how to quit the old, start anew, and do over when we fail. Now, it's time to kick perfection to the curb and finish anyway.

Finish identifies perfectionism as the biggest enemy of your goals, in order to then help you defeat it with research backed strategies to get things out the door while having fun, taking the pressure off and cutting yourself some slack.
Some of the insights in First Bite are surprising, and all of them are important. Awareness is key, it all starts with learning about how we work and what biology and history tell us about eating.

insights.title: Children will make good food choices on their own, if we let them

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Who had the biggest impact on your eating habits? Your parents, of course!
Chances are that, if you were always told to finish your plate, you still eat whatever's in front of you today, even when you're already full.
Or if your mom always allowed you to snack before dinner, you probably still do that today. The eating habits of our parents become our eating habits.
Therefore, the only right way to get your kids to acquire good eating habits is to lead by example.
One thing that's proven to never work is forcing kids to "eat the right stuff" – especially when you're not doing it yourself. Kids will see right through the "salad scam" and simply refuse.
But imagine letting your kids choose to eat what they want. A nightmare, right?

Maybe not. In 1929, a study was done letting babies as young as six months self-select their food. The babies were all given a selection of 34 foods and then allowed to choose among everything from milk to kidney.

The study continued for six years, and the kids were never pressured into selecting. Astonishingly, over the duration of the study, all children chose all foods, and even went for the healthiest ones when sick.
