So don't stress about letting your kids decide what to eat – especially with you being a good example not that much can go wrong.

insights.title: Grandparents tend to make their children and grandchildren overeat

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Did your grandma use to tell you to "have just one more bite" when you were little? Or to finish your entire plate? Or to have dessert, even when you said you were full?
Why do grandparents do that? And is it any good?
First of all, no, it's not good, of course. It just makes you fat. And that's exactly what grandparents want.
But they mean well. You have to remember that your grandparents likely lived in times when food wasn't always readily available.
Most grandparents have been through a war, famine or food shortage at some point in their lives, so their natural tendency is to want something better for their children and grandchildren.
It's the equivalent of rich parents paying everything for their kids, and thus spoiling them.

While your grandparents think you'll be well prepared with a few extra kilograms of weight, chances of a food shortage are very slim in most places nowadays, which turns these good intentions into bad weight problems.
This problem is especially prominent in China, where most parents work and grandparents take care of the kids, making them chubby on purpose.
So watch how your parents influence your kids' eating habits (and your own).

insights.title: Know when you’re hungry and when you just “want to eat” to spare yourself plenty of unnecessary calories

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Of course nutritional value is a problem nowadays, with salt, sugar and fat being the primary components of most processed foods.
But the worst calories to consume are still the ones you never needed in the first place. Welcome to comfort eating.
Just like food scarcity has become rare in the Western world, so has hunger. But if food is always available, it's very easy to mistake appetite for hunger.
When you're bored, sad, frustrated or not satisfied with something, food is an easy, fast, and readily available choice.
Studies have shown that children can learn to regulate how much they eat within a few weeks, and for adults a week is enough.
So the next time you're about to eat a Snickers bar, ask yourself: are you really hungry? Or just bored?
"The way you teach a child to eat well is through example and patient exposure to good food. And that fails, you lie." \[Bee Wilson\]
Do you ever find yourself excusing unhealthy eating habits? Perhaps you find it hard to give up that slice of chocolate cake because it feels like something you've ALWAYS done.
Telling ourselves our eating habits are hardwired into our genetic code is a welcome excuse. It allows you to avoid taking responsibility for how you look and how healthy you are.
But at the very latest when we have kids, it might be time to look in the mirror, suck it up, and say: "Alright, it's time to set a better example".
Awareness is always the first step. That's where books like this one come in.

By educating yourself about the history of eating habits and what research says really makes us eat the way we do, you'll be well on your way to improving your diet (as in "way of life," not weight loss program).
First Bite explains why your eating habits were acquired, but not hardwired, in your childhood, and pinpointing how you can change them for the better.
All time management tactics are only as good as the goals you want to achieve with them, so this really addresses the root of the problem, instead of just scratching the surface.
After you've read The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, get First Things First next, especially if you like Dr. Covey's work.

insights.title: Ditch the status symbol of urgency and attend to things by importance

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The battle of urgent vs. important is a recurring theme in Dr. Stephen R. Covey's work (remember the Eisenhower matrix from The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People?) and is the foundation of the principles in this book.
Our lives would be pretty easy if everything that was important to us was also urgent, but most of the time these things are vastly different.
Dinner with your family, exercising and finding meaningful work are all important, but they're not as urgent as the client who's expecting to hear from you or the deadline at work.
There are two reasons we often choose what's urgent over what's important…
1.  Urgency is a status symbol, especially in the Western world. If you're not busy, you must be lazy - that's the assumption.
2.  Checking items off a long to-do list gives you a rush of adrenaline and dopamine, and therefore satisfies your biological needs.
In the long run, this leads to regret, but is actually something that's preventable.
When you've committed to a night of board games with your kids, don't let your boss's sudden dinner invitation get you off schedule.

Say no to urgent things whenever you can. You can't always skip work dinners, but you sure can prevent the distrust and disappointment in your family by sticking to the commitments you've made more often than not.

insights.title: Imagine your 80th birthday to make decision-making a piece of cake

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Have you ever met someone who found it really easy to make decisions, and envied them? Chances are they had a strong vision for the future.
Knowing where you want to be in 5 or 10 years makes aligning today's decisions with the future a much easier task than when you're just drifting around.
Sometimes you might have to take a slight curve, but you'll always know how to get back on track.
For example, when Gandhi first started leading people, he was shy and a really bad and constantly nervous public speaker.

But his vision of a society in which all people are equal made it easy to decide and practice speaking every chance he got in spite of his fear, and to become the person he needed to be to make his vision a reality.
Here's a great question to ask yourself and instantly make deciding a lot easier: What would my ideal 80th birthday look like?
Do you see a lot of friends and family at a charity dinner? Your business partners and staff? Or just the one person you love the most on a remote beach in Asia?
The goals you want to see yourself have accomplished when you look back when you're 80 are the goals you need to start on working right now.

insights.title: Switch from an independence and competition mindset to an attitude of interdependence and cooperation

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The lifestyle of urgency and rushing around is mostly a result of seeing ourselves as independent and in constant competition with everyone else.
The only way to overcome it is to realize that we all depend on one another and can only succeed if we cooperate.
For example, even at Apple, there is no one person that can build an entire Macbook by themselves. Or even a mouse! Not even Steve Jobs could.
Only by coming together and cooperating as a team the people who build the processors can help those who build the case, and eventually combine everything into a great product.
Whether you're trying to build a business, improve your love life, learn more, leave a legacy or even just survive, you need other people to help you out along the way.
Ditching the competition mindset will allow you to look for win-win solutions, instead of pushing people out of the way.
This can then result in both short-term and long-term benefits on your way to keeping your first things at the top of your priority list.
"Where you're headed is more important than how fast you're going." \[Stephen Covey\]

Another book from the "old but gold" category. Published in 1994, First Things First went against the even then popular "get more done in less time" approach and took a look at how you can work on what matters without burning yourself out.

Most of us live our lives by the clock. Appointments, to-do lists, urgent events and deadlines have us rushing from one thing to the next, while never getting to what actually matters, nor even stopping to think about what that is for us.

This book will help you exchange the clock for a compass that holds your values and principles, so you can be sure you're facing true north at all times – because direction matters a lot more than how fast you're going.

First Things First shows you how to stop looking at the clock and start looking at the compass, by figuring out what's important, prioritizing those things in your life, developing a vision for the future, building the right relationships and becoming a strong leader wherever you go.

First tip: Read the Happiness Hypothesis first, then this will make even more sense. It lists Flow as the best option of one of the two voluntary activities you should strive for, to maximize your happiness.
Second tip: Think back to when you were 8-14 years old. What did you enjoy doing the most? Chances are your flow activity is somewhere in there.

Flow is so packed with insights. It makes sense from start to finish and it's a very down-to-earth call-to-action for happiness. It doesn't scream at you to get happy, like some of the more over-enthusiastic self-help books, but just shows you the path that'll most likely get you there.

insights.title: Pleasure and enjoyment are two different things

actions.title: Be aware of pleasure over enjoyment.
actions.markdown: Before spending your money on something you ‘really want’, ask yourself whether it will bring you pleasure or enjoyment? If the former, then save your money for something less materialistic that will bring you real, long-lasting joy.

paragraphCards.markdown: Pleasure is what most people nowadays confuse with happiness.
It comes from sensory experiences, like eating a pizza, getting a massage or having sex, and takes away your control of your attention.
When you're busy munching on a tasty slice of chicken supreme, you can't really control what you pay attention to because all of it is taken up by your sense of taste.
Enjoyment, on the other hand, comes from concentrating and consciously focusing, which gives you back your control over your attention.
This is where true happiness lies, as enjoyment allows you to work towards your most important goals and to go beyond the limitations of your genes.
Many people opt for pleasure instead of enjoyment, which the world makes easy as we seem to live in instant gratification-land now, but this is also why many people are so miserable.
How can you find enjoyment? By trying to spend a lot of time in flow.

insights.title: Flow is where challenges and skills match

actions.title: Find your flow.
actions.markdown: Choose an activity, big or small, that you find rewarding - that you really love and want to do more of. Then, go do it. Make sure it isn’t too hard to begin with, and keep adjusting the difficulty to continue challenging yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: Flow is what's behind every good video game.
It is the state where you are so immersed in the activity you're doing that you completely forget about all your worries and anxieties, and you look up after hours wondering where time went.
How can you trigger it? Two things…
1.  Pick an activity you find rewarding, something that's meaningful to you, without any external incentive (like money or fame).
2.  Make sure the challenge of the activity matches your skill level.
The first part is straight forward. It means you should have fun.
Plant a tree, draw a comic, write an article about the Minions, whatever you think is meaningful to you.
There can't be any money involved. Don't do it for fame, wealth, or even religion. Just because you think it's awesome.
Part two is a bit harder. Flow is triggered when the challenge isn't so hard you'll get frustrated, while your skills aren't so good already that you get bored. It's right in between.

If you decide to pick up chess, play on an easy setting against your computer first. Then, get a friend to play against you who's slightly better than you. Once you consistently beat her, you can move to the next level.
Basically, flow is where your life feels like the perfect game: you just want to keep on going and going and going.
So make some time for your hobbies or take up a fun project – you never know what the skills might be good for.

insights.title: Life goals are irrelevant, so set a life goal

paragraphCards.markdown: You can create your own meaning of life. To do so, you simply have to set an ultimate goal for your life.
Here's the best part: It doesn't matter what that goal is, as long as it keeps getting you into flow without caring what other people think.
This is the best thing a book could tell you. It's all you want to hear.
Go set some crazy goal and tell others to get lost if they tell you it's stupid.
If it keeps you challenged so your skills keep growing and gets more complex as you go along, you're golden.
Do it everyday, even if no-one sees. Do it for the sake of itself. The more you do of that, the more successful you'll be.
"A joyful life is an individual creation that cannot be copied from a recipe." \[Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi\]
Flow is a simple title, but you might have a little more trouble announcing the author's name: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi (it's mi-ha-yee cheeks-sent-me-high).
Published in 1990, Mihaly digs into "the state of effortless work", where challenges and skills align perfectly and time seems to fly.
Flow explains why we seek happiness in externals and what's wrong with it, where you can really find enjoyment in life, and how you can truly become happy by creating your own meaning of life.

Focus feels like an encompassing instruction manual for attention. It really covers most of the relevant bases where most other books only address specific areas and issues, like willpower or leadership.

insights.title: Once your brain feels fried, just let your thoughts wander

actions.title: Take your downtime seriously.
actions.markdown: Just like you time manage your work and always make sure it gets done, do the same for your downtime. Allow your mind to rest from focus, and let it wander instead into creativity and mindlessness.

paragraphCards.markdown: You probably know about open awareness. All kinds of attention are valuable – not just the one that's laser-sharp and focused.
When you find your mind wandering a lot, that doesn't necessarily mean it's wandering in the wrong direction.
Sometimes taking a break is exactly what we need, because it makes our mind wander towards the thing we've been dying to figure out.

For most of us, downtime seems to be a luxury we can't afford, but in reality we can't afford not to relax, because when you can't seem to make any sense of what's in front of you, you'll only get frustrated and perform even worse.
Especially if your work requires intense focus, which is true for engineers, software developers, writers and mathematicians, for example.
It's important to let your mind roam freely and practice "mindlessness" sometimes.
When you take a walk outside and leave your work at your desk, your subconscious starts to come up with creative ideas based on you being openly aware of your surroundings.
Studies have found that we can generate up to 40% more original ideas when letting our minds rest.

insights.title: You can’t do anything better for your willpower than work on something you love

actions.title: Find your inner willpower.
actions.markdown: Make sure you love what you’re doing. If you don’t enjoy it, your willpower will always remain low. Be happy in your choices and committed to your cause, and productivity will follow.

paragraphCards.markdown: Sometimes you need to work on something for several hours in a focused manner, ideally in the state of flow. What you need to make that happen is willpower.
You might know that nutrition, sleep and exercise are important determinants of how much willpower you can muster, but one you might not have heard about is doing work you love.
Studies have recently found that the psychological component of willpower is a lot bigger than we thought, meaning most of it actually comes from your mind, not your body.
The reason your willpower gets stronger if you do something you love is that if your work reflects your goals, it becomes effortless.
Late nights, confronting big obstacles and the patience you need until you see it through come a lot easier when you're 100% convinced that what you're doing is the exact right thing for you to do.
George Lucas, for example, when creating the original Star Wars, went rogue and split from his production company. A difficult move, but he was afraid his creative vision would be compromised.
In the end, because he believed in his idea, he did everything that was necessary to make it a success.

insights.title: Think of distant problems as immediate to better plan for the future

actions.title: Treat your goals as imminent threats.
actions.markdown: Imagine your dream has an expiry date, that if you don’t get the ball rolling now, it will go off and be too late. Don’t let yourself plan it for ‘sometime in the future’. Put a deadline on making it happen.

paragraphCards.markdown: We bet you have a dream. A crazy one. Something no one really cares about, but you.
And even before you knew that working on it might boost your willpower, we're sure you wanted to. But you didn't.
It's the first 10 pages of your manuscript that have been sitting inside your desk drawer since 2012. The scaffold that collects dust in your attic. The high school reunion party you never threw.
These things make life worth living, and are what we all want to accomplish in that short time we're here – yet we keep procrastinating on them because they don't have deadlines.
The regret of having had a shitty life is too far away to cause you to panic now, because it'll only come when you're too old to change it.

But if you imagine these problems as serious, immediate threats right now (for example, climate change - same thing), then you can stop choosing what makes you happy in the short-term but doesn't solve the long-term problem.
Traffic jams are often solved by building new highways, but all that does is create more room for traffic jams and therefore, actually promotes them.
Focus on the larger context and imagine the consequences of long-term issues as happening tomorrow, not 50 years from now.
You'll make much better decisions in the here and now.
"Directing attention toward where it needs to go is a primal task of leadership." \[Daniel Goleman\]
We're almost a decade into the rise of the smartphone empire and among many great benefits, we suffer one phenomenal loss as a result – our attention goes out the window.
If your life feels like a series of quick hits and dopamine fixes, it's time to put the smartphone on airplane mode for a while.
Relying on these devices more than on our minds has left us with an attention span that's less than that of a goldfish. Now that's something to worry about.
International best-selling author Daniel Goleman aims to give you some of it back with his book Focus.
Focus is the "hidden driver of excellence". We'll explore why in the following insights, along with Goleman's tips on mindfulness, willpower, leadership, empathy, and success.

Focus shows you that attention is the thing that makes life worth living and helps you develop more of it to become focused in every area of life: work, relationships and your own attitude towards life and the planet.
If you like crime novels, thriller movies, or just want to get better at figuring out what's going around you, then Forensics: The Anatomy Of Crime is for you.
A great related read is What Every Body Is Saying. Two thumbs up for this one!

insights.title: Forensics works from the outside in

paragraphCards.markdown: Let's say you light a firecracker on New Year's Eve. The firecracker explodes into lots of pieces with a loud bang.

The next day, you have to clean up – and because just collecting dirt and throwing it away isn't much fun, you decide to try and piece it back together to make things more interesting. (Note: Don't ever really try to do that – this is just a thought experiment!)
But where would you start? Probably at the place where it exploded, right? Because that's where most of the pieces are.
But that's a mistake. Forensic scientists never start with the source.
If you start with the source, you'll automatically jump to conclusions about the bigger picture, which might lead you to miss crucial details.
For example, based on the three big firecracker parts at the site of the explosion, you might think there can't be more than 15 parts in total.

But if you work from the outside in, collecting everything you can find before you start making assumptions, and slowly bringing everything back to the source, you're much more likely to put together what's really going on.
Looking at everything that's on the outside and then slowly working towards the inside is a key principle of forensics.
Fire scene investigators, forensic pathologists, and bloodstain analysts all do their work this way.

insights.title: One of the biggest advancements in forensics was in fingerprints, and was discovered by chance

paragraphCards.markdown: Many of science's greatest discoveries were originally made by chance.
When Alexander Fleming accidentally left his Petri dish unprotected for two weeks, he wasn't expecting to discover the invention of penicillin.
Archimedes had his Eureka! moment in the bathtub when he found out how to measure the volume of objects.
The now-standard forensic tool of fingerprint identification is no exception to that rule.

In the 1870s, Scottish doctor and missionary Henry Faulds set up a medical mission in Japan, where on a trip to an archeological site, he discovered you could see some of the marks ancient pottery makers had left on their work in excavated clay fragments.
If you dusted them with powder, they'd become a lot clearer to distinguish.

After looking at his own fingerprints and some of his friends', he hypothesized they might be unique, a theory that helped him prove the innocence of one of his staff when his hospital was broken into.

Convinced that his system would help solve crimes, he passed it on to none other than Charles Darwin (you know, the inventor of the desk chair, among other things) who in turn passed it on to statistician Francis Galton.
It took some doing, but after an Argentinian prison started adding fingerprints to all its records, a guy named Edward Henry started using the system in India and brought it to Scotland Yard.

insights.title: Computers will help us crack even the toughest cases in the future

paragraphCards.markdown: The power of computers and the internet permeates everything now, and of course crime investigation benefits from this as well.
Some of the hardest cases to crack are missing children, where only one in six is found thanks to someone identifying a photograph.
This is because children's faces aren't fully formed, which makes them harder to distinguish than adults'. This is why it's sometimes harder to guess the gender of young children.
However, computers are starting to get really good at facial reconstruction, which uses the 22 bones of the human skull to derive facial features and characteristics.
The combined power of CT scans, X-rays and fast iteration of various models, thanks to fast computing, allows investigators to get a picture that closely resembles the victim much quicker.

The first time facial reconstruction played a central role in solving a crime was in 2001, when 5-year old Rowena Rikkers's brutal murder was solved thanks to a clay reconstruction of her face, based on the bones of her skull.
Let's hope that, with the aid of computers, the rate of crimes solved will keep increasing in the future, helping us make further progress towards a crime-free world!
"We make high demands on the people we expect to deliver justice, and we don't always appreciate how much it eats away at them." \[Val McDermid\]
If you're intrigued by crime fiction, then you'll love this one.

Val McDermid has written countless novels, but she's also written Forensics: The Anatomy Of Crime, a non-fiction book about the science that's the lifeblood of her crime stories, explaining all aspects of forensics in great detail.
If you're aspiring to decipher clues in your life like Sherlock, then this book is for you.

Forensics: The Anatomy Of Crime gives you an inside look at all the different fields of criminal forensics and their history, outlining how crime investigation has changed dramatically within the last 200 years.

Founders at Work contains a wealth of valuable information – even to somebody with no intention of launching a startup. It's a good sampling of some of the smartest business minds. A true one-stop-shop.
We find it as interesting to learn from their mistakes as from their accomplishments.

insights.title: Starting with an idea is good, but having a talented team is best

actions.title: Don’t fixate on just one thing.
actions.markdown: Sometimes having a great team is more effective than having a brilliant idea, so get the right people together and start brainstorming. Throw your creative ideas at the wall, and see what sticks!

paragraphCards.markdown: In 1993 Joe Kraus, the co-founder of the early web search tool Excite, teamed up with five of his friends from Stanford University.
They demonstrated that having a good team proved more important than having a good plan.
Kraus and his friends weren't even sure what their business was going to be, only that they were all passionate and intelligent individuals. All they needed was a goal.
It came together at a taco stand, where Kraus and his friends began brainstorming a solution to search all of the new information in digital formats.
They knew that people would need a new means to search and narrow down the information they were looking for.
Their attention soon turned to the web.
After showing that their technology could scale to search massive databases, they got $3 million in financing.
Their new company, Excite, became the primary search tool for Netscape, the prominent web browser at the time.
Instead of starting by fixating on a single idea, it is better to have a team that is flexible and fluid enough to run with the best way forward when it comes to the surface.

insights.title: Too much investor money can actually hurt a startup initiative

actions.title: Put your team first and the money second.
actions.markdown: Treat your employees well and you’ll see the benefits tenfold as their productivity and commitment to the company will soar, so find the money in the budget to give them a perk every once in a while.

paragraphCards.markdown: Investor money often comes with strings attached.
This can come in various forms, from the addition of investor-approved executives, relinquishing shares in the company, or a percentage of the profits.
Joel Spolsky, the founder of Fog Creek Software, made it his aim to avoid using investor capital. Joel's vision was to start a consulting firm that would attract great programmers.
He did this by creating an attractive working environment instead of a set-up that the typical investor might envision.
Rather than having programmers work in an open row of desks like a sweatshop, Spolsky gave his programmers their own office space with comfortable chairs.
They flew first class and got four weeks of vacation time every year.
Potential investors may have seen all this as unnecessary extravagance.
They'd prefer to observe an operation like this run on a shoestring with few frills.
Spolsky's other plan to make sure he didn't need venture capital was raising the price from $199 to $999 per unit.
He discovered that the higher cost made customers perceive the product as being of more value and sold more units.
Paul Graham, the co-founder of Viaweb, Y Combinator and other companies, has another approach to avoid taking venture capital.
His vision is to stay cheap, which a lot of startup founders advise. For every penny of investor money you take, you have less autonomy and you'll be at the mercy of others.
Spend little and embrace minimalist, bohemian style, rather than lavish and extravagance.

insights.title: Creating something of real value to others requires listening to your customers

actions.title: Take care of your customers.
actions.markdown: Happy buyers make loyal buyers, so have great customer service and always listen to their feedback. Make sure you aren’t cutting back on quality and setting them up to fail - otherwise, they won’t be coming back.

paragraphCards.markdown: The most common advice found when interviewing founders is the importance of listening to customers.
This is critical to creating something of real value to others.
Paul Graham believes this to be the very basis of an enterprise. Create a product or service that makes other people happy and then convert that joy into money.
This is why it's so important to listen to your customers and determine what they really want.
Honesty is also key.
In the case of Viaweb, Graham and his co-founder, Robert Morris, set out to create the best e-commerce software available.
They kept close tabs on their customers' satisfaction while also on their competitors' product quality. It was the only honest way to say that Viaweb offered the best product.
Others might argue and say the way to win sales is with charm and finesse, but Graham maintains that honesty is the most powerful tool for earning people's trust and business.
"I'd say determination is the single most important quality in a startup founder. If the founders I spoke with were superhuman in any way, it was in their perseverance." \[Jessica Livingston\]
We've all had that discussion with a group of friends where we kicked around ways to solve a problem.
How many times have you said, "This is such a great idea, we should really do it!" Or, "This will make a fortune!"
Some of these brainstorms can grow into a Google, Apple, or an Uber.
Most business concepts will fail within the first year, which is the most critical time of launching a startup.
But what really happens in the early phases of these organizations will surprise anyone on the outside.
For the most part, the only ones who've really been there to tell are the founders.

Jessica Livingston, author of the Founders at Work: Stories of Startups' Early Days, gathers a collection of unique interviews from some of these founders of great startup enterprises such as PayPal, TiVo, Yahoo, and TripAdvisor.
Want to be a fly on the wall of these successful companies? Then read on.
Let's see how the best of the best make it all happen!
Founders at Work shows you how to start a successful business based on the world's most famous and accomplished startups' founding principles.
Freakonomics is one of the best books on human psychology, with so much to learn about making good decisions for anyone.

insights.title: Three kinds of incentives dominate your life

actions.title: Give people an incentive.
actions.markdown: If you need someone to help you out or do something for you, give them an incentive. Consider the economic, social or moral benefits for them, and persuade them.

paragraphCards.markdown: Incentives have been dangled in front of your nose all of your life.
From, "If you finish your plate, you'll get some pudding," as a child to, "If you sell 100 cars this quarter, you'll get a 25% bonus."
An incentive is meant to get you to do more of a good thing or less of a bad thing, and is used by anyone who tries to influence your behavior.
There are three kinds of incentives… ![giphy.com/Ideabile/](https://media.giphy.com/media/gdlj0FJJ3bBQl8HO4X/giphy.gif)

1.  **Economic:** Involving gain or loss of time and/or money
2.  **Social :** To make you look good in front of your peers, or avoid being isolated from them
3.  **Moral:** Appealing to your conscience to do the right thing

The more types of incentives are combined, the more powerful the incentive gets.

![giphy.com/tengoplanes](https://media.giphy.com/media/ekXHRxcygW2zfrMro0/giphy.gif)
For example, the disincentive (or a negative incentive) to commit a crime is pretty strong.

You could lose your job, house and personal freedom (economic), it is one of the most morally reprehensible things you can do (moral) and of course, you'd lose your friends and your reputation would go down the drain (social).

insights.title: Experts often exploit the fact that they know more than you

paragraphCards.markdown: In any transaction between humans, incentives are the driving force at play.
The moment you figure out what makes the person across the table act the way they do (and know the same for yourself), you can make better decisions.
Sadly, lots of systems incentivize us to cheat. Information asymmetry is one of these. We all need the help of an expert sometimes.
When your knee hurts, you go to a specialist doctor, your hair is cut by a professional, and when you want to sell your house, you call a real estate agent.

For this last example, the system in place is a strong economic incentive – the agent gets a commission of the final sale price and should therefore try to maximize the selling price just as much as you, right?![giphy.com/zillowgroup](https://media.giphy.com/media/1X7lAx3f3oZwHjUbvv/giphy.gif)
Well, some simple math reveals that it's often better for the agent to abuse that she knows more than you, and get you to sell quickly.

If your agent can get you an offer for $100,000 within two weeks, and she gets a 10% commission, then that's $10,000 in two weeks. ![giphy.com/remax](https://media.giphy.com/media/VFfNB6WUBiANXhNrag/giphy.gif)

Knowing it takes her another two weeks to get an offer for $120,000 results in just $2,000 more for her, or a 20% increase in income, at a 100% increase in time spent, bringing her total down to just $6,000 for two weeks.

Using the information she has that you don't, she can get you to sell quicker and cheaper, so she can make more money. ![giphy.com/mini\_italia/](https://media.giphy.com/media/9J5cJRPyU4nB5vdjC8/giphy-downsized.gif)
Studies have shown that when agents sell their own houses, they usually leave them up for sale a lot longer and also get higher prices.

insights.title: Just because two things happen simultaneously doesn’t mean that one causes the other

paragraphCards.markdown: We usually think we're smart and can put two and two together quickly.
But more often than not, two and two end up making five, because we've confused causation with correlation.

For example, if on the 31st of a month a car dealer offers you a great deal on a car, you may suspect that he only did so, so he can meet his quota and get a fat bonus, no matter how crappy the car is, right? [giphy.com/goldmotors](https://media.giphy.com/media/WnNFjfXGj6r5eqvPIh/giphy.mp4)
But you can't possibly know what causes him to offer you that deal, just because the deal correlates with the last day of the month.
Maybe he's made a commitment to himself to improve his selling skills and double his sales that month, and this is the last car he needs.
Maybe he's made a promise to his wife to sell enough cars to be able to afford daycare for his newborn son. Or one of a million other reasons.
Similarly, take money's influence on election outcomes. ![https://giphy.com/leahdubuc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/IeS1h7HrJBXlqzFO6x/giphy.gif)
We all think whoever spends the most, gets the most votes.
But actually, successful candidates could cut their budget in half and lose only 1% of voters (and vice versa).![giphy.com/cusaonline](https://media.giphy.com/media/YrfkO0w8IdrDpdReRA/giphy.gif)
In reality, voters simply want to influence a close match or back a clear favorite. Even though money is correlated with election outcomes, it's not the cause of it.
"Morality, it could be argued, represents the way that people would like the world to work, whereas economics represents how it actually does work." \[Stephen Dubner & Steven Levitt\]
It never fails to baffle us how cheap learning has become. ![giphy.com/norafromqueens](https://media.giphy.com/media/ek4tZp8PFeSNCNNnNp/giphy.gif)
Get this: For $3.99 you could watch a 90-minute movie that details some of the best economic research of the 21st century with great animations, scenes and explanations. Ridiculous!
There are three main themes in Freakonomics.
One is incentives, the issue of how we react to rewards and punishments.
Another is information asymmetry, and which consequences arise from various gaps of knowledge and how we try to compensate for those.

The last big theme is causation vs. correlation and how we often try to explain things the wrong way.

![Harshita Gupta](https://media.giphy.com/media/MVYF5GiCRON89mTlhC/giphy.gif)

Freakonomics helps you make better decisions by showing you how your life is dominated by incentives, how to close information asymmetries between you and the experts that exploit you and how to really tell the difference between causation and correlation.
As we learn in Free to Focus, the secret to productivity is more about HOW we use our time, rather than trying to create more of it. Avoid working overtime (or even weekends!) at all costs.
Even if you think you're helping out your team, in the end, you'll only burn yourself out. Make rest and relaxation a priority, and your work will get even better because of it.

insights.title: You’re less productive when you try to work faster, but you can change your mindset toward productivity to fix this

actions.title: Be free to focus.
actions.markdown: To be productive, break your time down into short periods of deep work. When you’re sat at your desk, you’re fully focused with no distractions. But once you stand up, your mind is free to recharge.

paragraphCards.markdown: Do you ever feel like your work life is like a leaky boat? Between meetings, reports, and projects, you've got an endless stream of tasks coming in and can't ever seem to stay afloat.  Every time you try to get water out of the boat, more comes in.
If only you could work faster, you think. But aiming for speed alone will only decrease your productivity.
When you try to move things along faster, you waste any free time you might glimpse at because you're adding more to your already-too-busy schedule.
What's worse, you might have the misguided notion that working overtime will make your work life better.
You might excuse your time spent working overtime because you think it's only temporary. In reality, working extra hours will make you far less productive.
Jack Nevison discovered this when he put together the results of many significant studies on work.
Science shows that people that put in more than 55 hours a week are less productive than those who work fewer than 50.
What you really need is a new outlook. Rather than aiming for effectiveness, you should shoot for freedom, both to focus and to relax.
Freedom to focus is when you give yourself time for the deep work needed to accomplish your most important tasks.
It's draining and you can't do it for very long, but that's why the freedom to do nothing is so important.
The more efficient your rest is, the more productive you will be during work.

insights.title: Schedule and protect your leisure time if you want to become more effective at work

actions.title: Eat, sleep, work, play, repeat.
actions.markdown: You won’t be more productive if you cancel on friends, work late, and stew in your stress. A healthy lifestyle is the best way to get stuff done, so work your set hours and then enjoy your free time as you choose, before getting a good night’s sleep. It’s all about balance.

paragraphCards.markdown: Your brain takes up 20% of your body's energy. When you use it to work hard, you drain your mental and physical battery just like the battery on your phone.
Knowing this, it's easy to see why your natural habit of cutting down on recreation when work gets busy is so bad.
Still, some of us have the mistaken idea that energy is the same throughout the day and that time is flexible.
The truth is, neither of these vital resources are infinite.
Instead, learn and take advantage of the fact that you get your best work done in the morning.
You might have been taught that rejuvenation is a waste of time, but it's one of the core pillars of a truly productive life.
Sleep is the first principle of recovery that is vital if you want to get the freedom to focus.

When you're sleep deprived, you are worse at problem-solving, focusing, and decision-making.

You also have a harmful tendency to cut your social life short when your schedule fills up.
But when you nurture your relationships, you strengthen your emotional well-being, which in turn boosts your energy, motivation, and mental health. And your productivity too.
Although it might feel inefficient, play is another vital component of restoring energy. Schedule a regular time to do what you enjoy just for the sake of it.

insights.title: Get the courage to say no to what’s not important and look for the hidden “no’s” behind every “yes”

actions.title: Learn to say “no”.
actions.markdown: If you make the plan to go home, cook a nice dinner and get an early night, treat that as a deal made with yourself. Just like you’d always say “no” to someone asking you to cancel on someone else, don’t feel bad for saying “no” to cancelling on yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: "If you say yes to this, what are you saying no to?" \[Michael Stanier, author of "The Coaching Habit"\]
Learning to say "no" is a vital productivity tool.

Anyone who knows anything about productivity and focus knows about the importance of learning to set proper boundaries. These people maintain the ability to deny unnecessary tasks and unimportant requests.
That's because they understand the time and energy drain hidden in these "un-priorities".
These efficiency gurus recognize that they can't add more time to their schedule, so they protect it with the power of no.
Imagine a coworker asks for your help on a project one night, but you've already planned a workout that evening.
All you have to do is say that you've got an appointment, and leave it there. This isn't technically a lie, either, because the appointment is an important one with yourself!
You can also use rituals to protect your time. Establish morning routines to help you focus on your most important goals.
At night, set up a pattern of accountability for the day and preparation for the next day to set yourself up for success.
"Productivity should free you to pursue what's most important to you. The goal, the true objective of productivity, should be freedom." \[Michael Hyatt\]

The power of focusing hard on the right things at the right times and then resting is exactly what you'll learn in Michael Hyatt's Free to Focus: A Total Productivity System to Achieve More by Doing Less.
Maximise your productivity, win at work, and succeed at life with Free To Focus, the latest offering by business coach and New York Times bestselling author Michael Hyatt.

Game Changers is a never-ending source of information on personal growth and wellbeing. It gives advice on anything that can enhance your control over your brain and body, inspiring you to lead a more fulfilling life.

insights.title: Decide who you want to become and use time and language accordingly

actions.title: Create more routine.
actions.markdown: This isn’t just get up, clean your teeth, then get dressed - go deeper. Simplify your choices by pre-planning a regular cycle of both outfits and meals. Keep your brain in autopilot for the day-to-day, so it can focus on the other stuff.

actions.title: Don’t say “I’ll try”.
actions.markdown: Don’t just try - get it done. Chances are you can, if you really want to. By ‘trying’, you’re allowing yourself to give it a shot but probably fail. When failure is not an option, you’ll set your mind to it and make it happen.

paragraphCards.markdown: Imagine a day of your life in twenty years' time. What will you be doing? Who will you be with? What impact will you have on the world?
Prioritize your tasks in the present according to this vision of the future.
Delete the items on your current to-do list that are not aligned with your goals. And don't do things you hate, just to prove to yourself or others that you can!
You know, many famous CEOs wear similar clothes every day. By developing routines, they are able to decrease the number of daily choices and avoid decision fatigue.
You can apply the same principle to other things, like food.
Do you remember what happened the last time you bought food while hungry? You probably ended up over-buying, or choosing unhealthy items that you might regret binging on later.
If you plan your meals for the week in advance, you'll probably pick healthier options for yourself.
You can cycle through a weekly meal plan prepared in advance quickly and easily. It also reduces the chances of you from spontaneously binging on unhealthy meals or take-outs.
Unlike your clothes, your words must be chosen carefully.
We often set ourselves boundaries through language. When we use limiting words such as "can't," or "try", we tell our subconscious mind that failure is an option.
But to perform at their full potential, your brain and body need to know they must succeed.

insights.title: Your wellbeing is essential for optimum productivity

actions.title: Take control of your health.
actions.markdown: Get 8 hours’ sleep every night. Exercise every day, even if it’s walking - get your 10,000 steps. Then, eat like grandma. Chuck out the processed stuff and eat real, wholesome foods.

paragraphCards.markdown: Arianna Huffington, the founder of the Huffington Post, built her company working more than 120 hours a week. But one day, she passed out while working, hit the desk and broke her cheekbone.
Since her collapse, Arianna has slept 7-9 hours per night and found each day the time for walks, yoga, and meditation. And now she feels more productive and creative than ever!
She even wrote Thrive, a book where she promotes a culture of wellbeing and denies the assumption we have to burn out in order to succeed.
Good sleep, nutritious food and proper exercise will empower you, making it easier to achieve your goals.
We spend so much time sitting that we don't know how to move anymore, thus risking hurting ourselves when we finally work out.
Start a functional movement practice with a coach before getting into an actual exercise practice.
We really are what we eat, since our energy and mood depend to a great extent on our gut bacteria. Treat them well and they will serve you.
So start feeding your own health and eat like your grandmother.
Your grandmother belonged to the last generation that didn't have access to industrial food, so her meals were based on whole, unrefined ingredients.
Your grandma was probably always pestering you to finish your vegetables and eat some protein, so why not honor her wishes, and keep your body healthy in the process?

insights.title: Being rich won’t make you happy, but being happy might make you rich

actions.title: Keep a gratitude journal.
actions.markdown: Find three things every day that you’re grateful for and write them down. You’ll feel immediately and increasingly better.

actions.title: Try out meditation.
actions.markdown: Monks meditate for several hours at a time - but that’s the extreme. Just five minutes a day can train you to be content in your own thoughts, and keep your mind calm.

paragraphCards.markdown: Among the hundreds of top performers Dave Asprey has interviewed, nobody considers money as a source of joy.
Although many of them are millionaires, they see money as a side effect of taking control of their minds and pursuing their passions.
While people are more likely to be happy when their basic needs are met, increasing their income further won't increase their happiness.
So if you want to be happy, stop chasing money and decide to be happy right now.
Abandon conditional happiness, which depends on external circumstances, for sustainable happiness, which depends on you.
Cultivate your inner peace by focusing on gratefulness for what you already have.
You can train yourself to be happy by following daily routines like journaling and meditating.
Happiness makes it far easier to change your circumstances and even the whole world. Thus when you practice it, more good will come into your life.
Then consider meditating. Today there's plenty of guided meditations on Youtube and smartphone apps.
It's easier than you may think and very effective at decreasing stress.
Meditation can take you out of the fight-or-flight state, in which your response to external inputs is often a mere reflection, powered by the primitive parts of your brain.
It gives you the time to think before reacting. If you practice it, you'll be able to find more things to be thankful for and fewer things to regret.
"You must focus on what makes you happy today because being happy unlocks a new level of potential in everything you do." \[Dave Asprey\]
Nutritionist, entrepreneur, and author Dave Asprey coined the term biohacking, which means manipulating our ancient biology to better serve our modern goals.
To discover biohacking, Asprey sought advice from experts by interviewing almost 500 highly effective individuals in his Bulletproof Radio podcast.

Our brain is a prehistoric operating system designed with only one goal: keep us alive to propagate the species. It focuses on 3 basic things that Asprey calls the 3 Fs: Fear, Feed, and F… reproduction.
Thanks to our brain's focus on the 3 Fs, we generally don't like taking risks, we're often impulsively driven to eat anything in sight, and we spend a lot of energy on sex.

In Game Changers: What Leaders, Innovators, and Mavericks Do To Win at Life, Asprey uncovers all the hacks he's discovered for programming the brain to chase after goals, rather than blindly obeying the 3 Fs.
Game Changers reveals the secrets that the world's most successful entrepreneurs equip themselves with in order to hack their biology and win at life.
The thing about Getting Things Done is: it works great – but only if you rigorously stick to its rules.
It just might be the best productivity system there is, but it's also demanding and thus very easy to fall off the wagon. ![giphy.com/afv/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ornjU8Cd8FW1nhG6s/giphy.gif)

But even if you struggle to use the system in full, it's still good to use parts of it and adapt it to your own needs. Other productivity systems, like The ONE Thing or The Power of Less appear to be a little more forgiving, but then again, maybe they're just not as powerful.

insights.title: Use a collection bucket to store things outside your mind, and stay focused

actions.title: Get yourself a collection bucket.
actions.markdown: Whether it’s a physical bucket next to your desk and pieces of paper, or an app in your phone, get yourself somewhere you can jot down reminders when they come to you. Don’t let your thoughts distract your productivity.

paragraphCards.markdown: You know that horrible feeling you have once you remember you have to buy milk? You can't seem to un-remember it and it keeps nagging you, while all you're trying to do is work. ![giphy.com/jonasmosesson/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oz8xCX30CNCJZigSc/giphy.gif)
"Buy milk, buy milk, buy milk, buy milk, buy milk, buy milk, buy milk, …Dammit brain, shut up!"
Well with a collection bucket, it will.

Your collection bucket can be a simple piece of paper, a notebook or a note inside Evernote, a note on your phone, or even a physical bucket in your office.![giphy.com/stinasketch/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUNd9EmBu43k92EXjW/giphy.gif)
It serves as a means to collect all interruptions, whether they come in the form of thoughts in your mind or to-do's handed over to you by coworkers.
Whatever lands in your brain or lap while you're busy working goes in there. [youtube.com/user/highperformancelife](https://youtu.be/gCswMsONkwY?t=75.56&e=99.04)
This lets you deflect interruptions as they occur and keeps your mind from derailing while you're on a productivity roll.

Of course this system is only good if you empty your collection bucket or buckets regularly - David Allen suggests weekly.![giphy.com/sehsuchtberlin/](https://media.giphy.com/media/26tPlwDlBTVls6Cbe/giphy.gif)

Your brain will only get a feeling of relief from putting something in your collection bucket when it knows that whatever lands in there will be taken care of sooner rather than later. ![giphy.com/sehsuchtberlin/](https://media.giphy.com/media/26tP4mS08o114G2kg/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Create a ‘next actions’ list for all your projects to avoid thinking in the moment

actions.title: Create a next actions list.
actions.markdown: Instead of a to-do list, break your tasks down into smaller ones, each a chunk of 30 minutes. Then feel free to prioritize them by importance, or filter them by time, date or location.

paragraphCards.markdown: Here's the major problem with to-do lists: they trick you into thinking you can know in advance how much you'll be able to achieve.

Sure, you can make a list with 17 items, but none of that accounts for interruptions, crises, delays, other people or, and this too happens, a simple lack of energy where you're just not able to do as much. ![giphy.com/sehsuchtberlin/](https://media.giphy.com/media/d2Z0FNDo0cCVwwjm/giphy.gif)
So try this instead: create a 'next actions' list, where you list out all the specific tasks (that take less than 30 minutes) of your current projects.

That way you always know what to work on next when you have the time and energy to work. You just pull out the list, pick a task and go. ![giphy.com/sehsuchtberlin](https://media.giphy.com/media/26tPc9tPS7Nw5RY2I/giphy.gif)
You can even have multiple "next actions" lists and sort them by project or location of where you're able to do the tasks on it.

For example you could make these lists: laptop with wifi, laptop without wifi, phone, notebook. Now, when you're at the airport and your flight's been delayed, but there's no wifi and your phone is dead, you can still pull out your notebook list and do something on paper.

insights.title: Do a weekly review of everything to stay up to date

actions.title: Update your to-do list on a regular basis.
actions.markdown: To-do lists update naturally - not just when things get done, but when things get left so long they become irrelevant. Update your list once a week. If things are sitting there but never getting done, just cross them off.

paragraphCards.markdown: There are several lists in the GTD system and the thing with all lists is this: they're only as good as they're up to date.
Therefore, a weekly review is crucial to making the whole GTD system work.
Empty your collection buckets on Friday afternoon, for example, and then update all your lists. You'll get a bird's eye view and make sure everything is complete.
This is the part that makes the whole system stress-free and if you slack on it, you'll pay the mental price. ![giphy.com/karlamontz/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohc1eCAo0oBkyDtN6/giphy.gif)
If you set the day to go through your to-do list on a Friday when that's also the day you have your big work meeting, you'll often not get around to it.
Then you end up doing the most recent tasks on it over the weekend, but leave the older, less pressing ones for the future.
That in turn makes you wary of putting more to-dos on there, as you're not sure when you'll actually do them.
"Your mind is for having ideas, not holding them." \[David Allen\]
Getting Things Done hardly needs an introduction: it's the bible of productivity. ![giphy.com/soultrain/](https://media.giphy.com/media/26FeWNsNqHq2nRhC0/giphy.gif)

David Allen has sold over 1.5 million copies of his simple, yet effective productivity system. ![TNW\_Con\_EU15-David\_Allen4.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/TNW_Con_EU15-David_Allen_-_4.jpg/512px-TNW_Con_EU15-David_Allen_-_4.jpg)
The book has been revised and updated in 2015 to reflect the changes in technology, since it was originally published in 2001 – over a decade ago.
The GTD system has always been timeless, though. You could do it on paper, online, or now on your smartphone, the second you put down the book.

Getting Things Done is a manual for stress-free productivity, which helps you set up a system of lists, reminders and weekly reviews, in order to free your mind from having to remember tasks and to-dos and instead let it work at full focus on the task at hand.
Giving Your Elevator Pitch teaches you to ensure that your personal message not only sticks with another person, but that it matters.
With this course, you'll be able to make a genuine and lasting connection.![giphy.com/tonyawards](https://media.giphy.com/media/fdMdtjkuWPWLwuq4jC/giphy.gif)

insights.title: The best way to connect is always to be prepared

actions.title: Know your long-term goals.
actions.markdown: Your elevator pitch needs to communicate where you are in your career, and where you intend to be in the future. Use your long-term goals to communicate what’s most important to you, and express where you’d like to get to.

paragraphCards.markdown: An 'elevator pitch' is given its name as it directly relates to the small amount of time you would have to quickly connect with someone if you were sharing an elevator. ![giphy.com/westfunk/](https://media.giphy.com/media/S8BY5l1YAfN7VIOhOk/giphy.gif)
When the elevator arrives at its intended floor, the person will leave, so it's essential that they do so with a good impression of you.
Therefore, having a pre-prepared elevator pitch can lead you to being a more effective professional.
"Periodically working on your pitch forces you to think about your professional identity, who you are, and where you're going." \[Dr. Todd Dewett\]
It's important to have a long-term view of your life's goals, and to regularly evaluate your aspirations and decisions. ![giphy.com/later/](https://media.giphy.com/media/MEGE27CGOBMgWNU84K/giphy.gif)
With this in mind, you can gauge the way others respond to your goals, and edit your pitch accordingly. Opportunities open up when you can make a strong and lasting connection with someone.

To achieve success, you need to know the right people, rather than just depending on having the proper knowledge. Sometimes it really is who you know, and not what you know. ![giphy.com/Pepephone/](https://media.giphy.com/media/SSJYIjDeLmVbrMVEeh/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Communicate the value of connecting with you

actions.title: Benefit the connection, not just yourself.
actions.markdown: Don’t just regurgitate a prepared speech - be thoughtful and relatable. In an elevator pitch, you want to come across as being able to help the other person, so plant a seed in their consciousness of what you have to offer.

paragraphCards.markdown: When you know there's a clock ticking on a conversation, it's easy to ramble on and not meet the main objective.![giphy.com/EOnederland/](https://media.giphy.com/media/mCsBI4yPF8RKH271b4/giphy.gif)
Successful elevator pitches, therefore, need to communicate the benefits of forming a connection with you quickly and clearly.
The pitch is a verbal extension of your business card with more information - but should contain less than your full resume.
"Your elevator pitch is a form of interpersonal communication that, when done correctly, acts like a catalyst that makes others want to know more about you." \[Dr. Todd Dewett\]

This pitch need only be the beginning. Give someone a good foundation of what you have to offer, and they're more likely to care about your resume, LinkedIn profile, website and more. ![giphy.com/MokaPOS15/](https://media.giphy.com/media/IgAalIiaqavFQVOFJo/giphy.gif)
The goal, however, should not be to sell yourself or all your skills, but to create a lasting connection. [giphy.com/SHOPLINE/](https://media.giphy.com/media/dZLioXwkCJKPnduT3X/giphy.mp4)
Inform others about your professional achievements and goals, and have them go away thinking about it.

But remember - the pitch should add value to the person you are trying to connect with, so it needs to be relatable, not just all about you. ![giphy.com/boomeryang/](https://media.giphy.com/media/Mn2QocOK4rSSc9QXuH/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Maximize your time with the right pitch structure

actions.title: Offer unique facts to stand out.
actions.markdown: Being distinctive calls for standing out. Offer some facts that you know are highly unique to your personal experience. Find what makes you different. Say something that not many would. Be yourself to sell yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: To make the most of 15 to 20 seconds of communication, you need a plan on exactly what to say and when.![giphy.com/PebblesInc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/WUJ4oP8E4PvtRv1WEK/giphy.gif)
Following an initial greeting, your elevator pitch should communicate who you are, what you do, where you have worked, and where you would like to be.
You need a brief sentence for each that is concise and to the point.

Then, if your pitch is good, the conversation can develop further.

![Company representative person giving business card](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1167967942.png)
It doesn't have to end with you offering information about yourself.
The perfect pitch also requires the person you are sharing with to give some information on themselves.

If you know the person you're speaking to (not personally, of course, but by reputation), make your elevator pitch distinctive and more relatable, rather than highly specific.![giphy.com/sauts/](https://media.giphy.com/media/TgraNsLyiOeiUtkNym/giphy.gif)
This calls for being clear with the language you use. Every word should be deliberate.
Non-technical language and a lack of jargon is essential - you don't want to lose the other person's attention.

Clarity in your communication means that you will be more memorable, and could even lead to the beginning of a great conversation. ![giphy.com/fransolo/](https://media.giphy.com/media/24depzSrxxZeoRwY86/giphy.gif)
"Every audience is different, so think just a little about how you might speak in a way that allows them to hear you." \[Dr. Todd Dewett\]

Having a strong network is essential to being a successful professional. Building that network, however, is complicated, as the hustle and bustle of everyday life means that people have minimal time to interact with you. [giphy.com/butler/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6gbchrcNIt4Ma8Tu/giphy.mp4)

The key to building a strong network is consistently creating quick and positive connections that expand your possibilities. You should never underestimate the importance of making a connection with anyone you meet. ![giphy.com/driverseatinc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/d9N562y9h8ly6L7EsE/giphy.gif)

Dr. Todd Dewett shows us that any connection could lead to a future employer or a potential client; professional growth or even friendship. ![terrificspeakers - dr-todd-dewett](https://cdn.website.thryv.com/59ad917449c84b2ba28a5d49123c9506/dms3rep/multi/cc179bb3-41c7-4990-9557-c72603f8343b.jpg)

Having a personal elevator pitch allows you to tell a compelling story of who you are as a professional to maximize connection building. Giving Your Elevator Pitch is a course for anyone seeking to advance themselves both professionally and personally.

With the right skills, it's possible to pitch proactively while communicating with professionals at all levels. Being prepared with an elevator pitch means that you won't ever have to miss out on opportunities to form lasting connections. [giphy.com/takeme/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0Iy2Cb86blyuftja/giphy.mp4)

Giving Your Elevator Pitch explains how to make an excellent professional first impression within the first 15 seconds of meeting a new person so that they can become a valuable addition to your network.

Grammar Foundations sums up all the necessary rules of grammar with detailed examples and exercises, so that you can create flawless and effective sentences. Regardless of your level of English, there's something to learn for everyone.

insights.title: There are eight part of speech - but nouns and verbs are the ones to know

paragraphCards.markdown: How can you nail a sentence without completely understanding what elements it's composed of? Well, there are eight parts of speech you should start your grammar goals with…

1.  Nouns
2.  Pronouns
3.  Adjectives
4.  Adverbs
5.  Prepositions
6.  Conjunctions
7.  Interjections
The most important parts of speech are the two that can independently make a sentence: noun and verb.
"Nouns answer the question of who or what the sentence is about, and may even answer where and when." \[Judy Steiner-Williams\]
A noun can be either a concrete or abstract noun; common or proper noun; singular or plural noun.
Then there are collective nouns. This is where it gets tricky, but there's always an easy way to understand this.
A collective noun represents a group (eg. a group of people, a family). Always use singular pronouns and helping verbs while referring to collective nouns.
The verb shows the action and the state of being of subjects.
We always talk about something that's happening or the state-of-being of things, and that's why verbs are at the heart of every sentence.

Apart from the past, present, and future tenses that treat verbs according to the tense rules, you must also make sure that singular helping verbs are used with singular subjects, like 'I am' or 'she is' and the plural equivalents for plural subjects like 'we are' or 'they are.'

insights.title: To construct a clear sentence, think of a clause as a single thought

paragraphCards.markdown: Even if you've understood the basic rules of each tense, it's highly likely that your sentences are either awkward or incomplete.
We have a tendency to speak in a rather informal way. So, before forming a sentence, you need to know what a sentence is made of.
A sentence is, of course, made of words. When these two words are a subject and a verb, you have a clause.
If a clause does not make complete sense on its own, it's called a dependent clause. This means you might require an independent clause to create the whole meaning.
For instance, "Even though she promised that she would attend the party" is a dependent clause that does not quite make sense. But when combined with "she decided not to go," it makes complete sense.
Meanwhile, "she decided not to go" is an independent clause, as it can stand alone even without the earlier part of the sentence.
You can use a combination of independent clauses, dependent clauses, and conjunctions to form multiple sentence structures that convey a complete message.
A simple sentence consists of a single independent clause.
A compound sentence consists of two or more independent clauses combined by compound conjunctions like 'and' or 'or'.
But when one independent and one dependent clause are combined like in the previous example, a complex sentence is formed.
Similarly, when there are two independent clauses combined with one dependent one, this is known as a compound-complex.

insights.title: Avoid parallelism errors to keep an overall flow in your writing

paragraphCards.markdown: "Whether it's words, clauses, and phrases, they need to be parallel - in other words, in the same form or pattern. Why? Mainly because once a certain pattern is used then the reader expects that consistent arrangement and can more easily understand the ideas." \[Judy Steiner-Williams\]
Parallel structure requires sentences to be centered around the same types of 'verbals'. These can be gerunds, participles, or infinitives, named 'verbals' due to their connection to verbs.
In a sentence with multiple verbals, you need to be careful to keep them in the same pattern. This keeps an overall flow of the sentence intact.
A gerund is identified by an -ing put after a regular verb. This -ing converts the verb into a noun that can be used as a subject or object.
In "sleeping is beneficial," 'sleeping' is a gerund, and works as the subject in the sentence - despite sleep being a verb.
A participle, on the other hand, puts -ed after verbs, and so turns verbs into pronouns and adjectives.
"Shocked, John could not utter a word." Here, 'shocked' works to further define John, and hence is an adjective.
Finally, an infinitive adds a 'to' before a verb and converts it into an adjective, a noun, or an adverb, as there is no direct subject attached.
"To be, or not to be, that is the question."

"Readers do know. They do care. And a wrong word or misplaced punctuation mark may even

change your intended meaning." \[Judy Steiner-Williams\]

You might have thought at least once in your life that whoever got the idea of making English language so inconsistent, impossible to master, and extremely exhausting must have had the intention of annoying people.
But regardless of how you feel about it, grammar is to language as seeds are to a watermelon: maybe annoying, but part of its very core.
Writing and communication expert Judy Steiner-Williams has been teaching writing and communication to young students, adults, and businesspersons for decades.
In Grammar Foundations, Steiner-Williams makes it all simple for you to learn grammar rules using application and practice.
With this course, you will finally be confident enough to write 'their' and 'they're' - at the right time, in the right sentence.

Grammar Foundations helps you improve each element of your writing mechanics including parts of speech, sentence structure, and some of the common errors by focusing on applying the grammar rules instead of just learning them.

Yuval Noah Harari is a smart man without a doubt. He grounds his arguments in science, and his vivid stories add up to a coherent picture. While some may say his newer books, which issue warnings to not overstep our bounds, are too gloomy, his ideas are always worth considering.
You may not agree with everything he says, but there is definitely a lot to learn from his work. Homo Deus is no exception.

insights.title: Stories are what make us the strongest animal on the planet

paragraphCards.markdown: In democratic elections around the world, millions of people make a concerted effort to agree on choosing a group leader.[giphy.com/election2016/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6Zt1HGohqLXxcTgQ/giphy.mp4)
They're one of the best demonstrations of our ability to cooperate on a massive scale.[giphy.com/miseleccionmx/](https://media.giphy.com/media/RHKsdS6INr1ZmFmKX4/giphy.mp4)
This skill is at the heart of why humans have won the evolutionary race. But how did we develop it?
Well, it's rooted in our communication.![Transform logo, change icon,](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1447217180.jpg)
Humans have told stories since the dawn of speech. Because we can all decide what stories we believe in individually, the best stories win.
Over time, we've become more intelligent, which is why, usually, the story that wins in the long run is whichever one benefits us the most as a whole.

Take religion, for example. Back in the Middle Ages, the story of Catholicism brought together many European nations in the Crusades.[giphy.com/historyuk/](https://media.giphy.com/media/efOvlSWuArbmaA4mqV/giphy.mp4)
They abandoned the wars they had with one another to fight a larger one. Today, 1,000 years later, we realize that narrative only served a small portion of our population.
Therefore, religion is slowly being replaced in more recent generations. But with what? [giphy.com/archivesherault/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7TKKRcram9dgwFIk/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: Today’s dominant narrative is humanism

paragraphCards.markdown: Back when the world was less connected, narratives naturally formed regionally.
But nowadays, we're all aware of the many different religions, political movements, and belief systems around the globe. ![giphy.com/lwz](https://media.giphy.com/media/YU7JFa3TcjIM6b1JZo/giphy.gif)
Thanks to the internet, it's become obvious to many that there is no one, right choice for any of them.
As a result, the story that dominates the world today is humanism. [giphy.com/UF/](https://media.giphy.com/media/yoJC2zZXY7tQLU42ZO/giphy.mp4)
In this view of the world, humans are the central element and our individual freedom our greatest asset.
We believe in science, rationality, progress, technology, and self-actualization.
There are many variants of humanism, and respecting all of them is important, but the most commonly chosen one is liberalism.
Liberalism allows us to express humanism in everyday life by translating its ideas into specific moral codes, laws, and political aspirations.

Even campaigns for a certain cause, like climate change awareness, less waste, or redistribution of wealth, are often simply liberal narratives in disguise. ![giphy.com/ryanseslow](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7btQ1Oh8RaYUkT3a/giphy.gif)

insights.title: All our future narratives involve algorithms, but if we’re not careful, they could replace us altogether

paragraphCards.markdown: Since their invention, computers have quickly become a big part of our lives.[giphy.com/hardlyart/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IgJpUz3wQaSOX6g/giphy.mp4)
Often more efficient at performing tasks, they allow us to enjoy more comfort in many areas.

Algorithms make our work easier, help us monitor our health, and even contribute to our recreation by giving us more ways to express ourselves.[giphy.com/xponentialdesign/](https://media.giphy.com/media/4H3Ii5eLChYul9p7NL/giphy.mp4)
Therefore, it's not really a question of whether algorithms will be part of our future, just how.

Two trends Yuval Noah Harari sees appearing at the horizon are techno-humanism, often called transhumanism, and dataism.[giphy.com/robob3ar/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41YyLf6Z267ntXVu/giphy.mp4)
Transhumanism argues that humans should merge with technology to enhance their capabilities and keep up with the power of algorithms.
Dataism, on the other hand, suggests we "get out of the way" and let algorithms become as powerful as they can become on their own.
The former is already manifesting in military technology, athletics and health, but it also means giving up parts of what makes us human, like empathy.

The latter might eventually lead to some Matrix-style scenario, in which the machines get rid of us because we're just in their way.[giphy.com/SafranGroup/](https://media.giphy.com/media/r3oOElXxOl0mVpoKzg/giphy.mp4)

No one knows which narrative will win and if it's even one of these two, but one thing's for sure: the story of humanity will never be boring.[giphy.com/SafranGroup/](https://media.giphy.com/media/PBWcuiuYXcqC0svER3/giphy.mp4)
"This is the best reason to learn history: not in order to predict the future, but to free yourself of the past and imagine alternative destinies." \[Yuval Noah Harari\]

As unfathomable as it may sound, the numbers don't lie: we're more likely to die of suicide than war, obesity than starvation, old age than poverty. [giphy.com/nasa](https://media.giphy.com/media/ux6AQI6MBwGqY/giphy.mp4)
What's even more astonishing is that we've managed to put all these fundamental, human ailments in their place in just the last century. But that begs the question: What's next for the human race?

In Homo Deus, Yuval Noah Harari tries to deliver an answer. ![Human and fake monkey hand evolution from primates concept](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1076871143.jpg)

After covering our past extensively in his global, multi-million-copy bestseller Sapiens, Harari now turns his eyes toward the future of mankind.![Yuval\_Noah\_Harari\_cropped.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f9/Yuval_Noah_Harari_cropped.jpg)
Following a brief recap of human history, he describes the narratives we currently use to make sense of the world. He also outlines which ones could mark our demise if we're not careful.
Homo Deus illustrates the history of the human race, from how we came to be the dominant species to which obstacles we must overcome if we're to continue to thrive.
For some people who want to find love, being single can feel like a constant personal failure, with obsessive thoughts and cycles of regret making everyday life an excruciating ordeal.
By staying mindful of your thoughts, focusing on your values, and living in the moment, you can rewire your brain for happiness and optimism about what is yet to come.

insights.title: Practice mindfulness

actions.title: Stop scanning your ex’s social media.
actions.markdown: There’s nothing to be gained from engaging in psychological traps that will make us feel worse. Note the emotions driving these behaviors, and ask yourself what else you could do instead.

paragraphCards.markdown: When you find yourself getting low about your dating prospects - or lack thereof - what do your thoughts look like? What is the voice inside your head saying?
The first step in achieving peace and clarity around your dating life is to learn to accept and pay attention to the negative thoughts that are coming up for you repeatedly.
Instead of allowing yourself to be hijacked by tough thoughts or emotions, notice them, acknowledge them and continue to pursue what's meaningful to you.
Make note of negative thoughts or thought patterns that come up repeatedly.
Unhealthy psychological habits keep us stuck in a mindset of negativity and prevent us from feeling joy in the moment.

"The belief that your happiness hinges on an external circumstance that you can't control (i.e., meeting a romantic partner) not only makes it harder to find love, but it also sets you up for unhappiness." \[Jennifer Taitz\]

insights.title: Break out of the soulmate trap

actions.title: Stop obsessing and start living.
actions.markdown: Instead of ruminating on past loves or stressing about potential future failures, let your values drive you. Notice when your emotional mind is taking over, and try to recenter yourself in logic and mindfulness.

paragraphCards.markdown: As humans, we tend to fixate on the idea that there's one 'best' love option out there for us, and that one person is our soulmate.
But getting caught up in the idea of perfection is inherently limiting, and can lead us to disappointment and despair when we don't immediately find it.
Let go of perfectionistic standards in relationships and open yourself up to the possibility that people can - and will - take care of you in ways that are surprising, lovely and healthy.
Take all of that time you would have spent obsessing over perfection in a partner and channel it instead into self-compassion.
By valuing yourself more, you can increase your faith and improve your hope for actually finding a partner who is well suited to fulfill your needs.
"Your task is not to seek for love, but merely to seek and find all the barriers within yourself that you have built against it." \[Rumi\]

insights.title: Find appreciation intrinsically, rather than through external validation

actions.title: Practice Loving-Kindness Meditation.
