actions.markdown: Each day, spend a few minutes channeling loving thoughts towards someone you love or someone who’s going through a rough time. Picture each person receiving your well-wishes, and open yourself up to the possibility that you deserve the same.

paragraphCards.markdown: Whether you've gone through a bad breakup or you're just sick of dating in general, shifting your value system to find validation intrinsically rather than externally can feel impossible.
But good self-care is essential, whether you're happy to be single or not.
Whether you're struggling with self-criticism, feelings of worthlessness or an enduring belief that life will never go your way, there are ways to reprogram your brain towards joy and gratitude.
Take a bit of time each day to think loving thoughts towards others, give back to your community, and practice giving your tough emotions moments of grace and acceptance.
By opening yourself up to compassion towards others, it will eventually become easier to feel it towards yourself.
"Since you get more joy out of giving joy to others, you should put a good deal of thought into the happiness that you are able to give." \[Eleanor Roosevelt\]
"The point of feeling joy is not to attract others, but to live well, because YOU deserve that." \[Jennifer Taitz\]
As human beings, we're hardwired for relationships.
When we perceive ourselves to be lacking in intimate connections, we tend to fall into thought patterns of loneliness and depression.
It's easy to feel like if we don't have romantic love now, it's a personal reflection on us, and that it will be impossible for us to find it in the future.
But Jennifer Taitz, a clinical psychologist trained in mindfulness-based cognitive therapies, knows how to stop these negative thoughts.
In this book, Taitz teaches us how to override our emotions and listen to our logical minds.
By learning how to identify, isolate, and replace our negative thought patterns, we can avoid the emotional avalanche of stressing about not having met 'the one' and get back to living joyfully.
In this book, clinical psychologist Jennifer Taitz tells us how to enjoy the present moment and stave off feelings of hopelessness while pursuing our romantic goals.

paragraphCards.markdown: How To Change Your Mind is a fascinating read that Michael Pollan serves up in his usual well-researched and digestible style. Whatever your stance on alternative medicine and psychedelic drugs, this book will have you rethinking some of those notions.

insights.title: Mazatec Indian tribes of Mexico introduced mushrooms containing psilocybin to Western travelers

paragraphCards.markdown: When we think about the term 'psychedelic drugs', often what comes to mind is illegal substances synthesized in some remote lab.
We might also think of shady deals conducted in some dark alleyway. It's easy to forget that the true origins of these drugs are in nature, and that they're actually organic.

It was during the 1950s in southern Mexico when western travelers first discovered mushrooms containing psilocybin. The Mazatec Indians have been using the mushrooms for centuries as part of their spiritual rituals and also as an agent for healing.
It wasn't until the late 1950s that chemists began to artificially synthesize psilocybin in laboratories.
And it was nearly 10 years later when people began to view these substances as a danger to society. This was the beginning of the war on drugs.
Drug criminalization policies ignore the fact that humans have long consumed mushrooms to provide a mystical, spiritual experience.
Of course, some mushrooms can be dangerous or even deadly, so it's not recommended to forage for them without extensive experience and expertise.

insights.title: We are actually seeing things we can’t normally see during a hallucinatory experience

paragraphCards.markdown: Have you ever heard somebody describe their hallucinatory, psychedelic trip experience? You might have heard them talk about changing colors, melting objects, and otherworldly lights.
Does this mean that psychedelic trips enable us to see things that we normally can't, or are we just hallucinating?
In 2014, a study on psychedelic drugs was conducted at the Imperial College London.
Neuroscientist Robin Carhart-Harris and his colleagues used brain imaging technology to gather more details on how psilocybin affects brain activity.
The neuroscientists could show a side-by-side comparison of how different areas of the brain interact normally, and while under the influence of psychedelics.
Studies showed that under the influence of psilocybin, the brain is rewired dramatically.
Areas that normally function independently from one another begin to communicate. Each specialized section becomes less contained and the brain becomes more integrated as a unit.
Many neuroscientists believe this interconnectedness produces a profound and visual drug trip experience that can be magical and mind-blowing.

If you can imagine areas of the brain that are normally dedicated to emotion, memory, and visual processing all suddenly interacting together...this is what prompts a whole new way of seeing, and in such a vivid way.
When the events surrounding and during the psychedelic trip are positive, it can lead to new and transformative insights and ideas.

insights.title: By creating a new sense of connection, psychedelics can help alleviate depression

paragraphCards.markdown: Psychedelics are becoming increasingly more acceptable and mainstream.
As recently as 2017 the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) called for a study that would demonstrate the effectiveness that psychedelics have on treating those with depression.
In spite of the many prescription pharmaceuticals available, depression still remains one of the most widespread illnesses in the country.
So far there's a good body of evidence to confirm that psychedelic drug treatment is an effective means in alleviating depression.

The first evidence to support this came from a 2016 study by Robin Carhart-Harris at London's Imperial College. Of the participants in the sample, 80% reported an improvement in their symptoms, while more than 60% said that their depression was gone completely.
This was a small sample of 20 people, all receiving a week of treatment. There is still much testing required to assess the lasting duration of the treatment and sustainability over time.
But what is almost certain is that one of the ways psychedelics work to ease depression is by allowing patients to find a new sense of connection in their lives.
People with depression can look at something of beauty in nature and fail to feel a sense of happiness.
But according to some of the test participants, psilocybin has some property to reconnect them to the world and the people in their lives.
"Normal waking consciousness feels perfectly transparent, and yet it is less a window on reality than the product of our imaginations - a kind of controlled hallucination." \[Michael Pollan\]
We all know somebody battling mental illness, addiction, or cancer. Sadly, these are all part of life's experience and we can't escape them. Or can we?

If you knew there was a new miracle drug that proves to fight depression, cure addiction and make end-of-life transitions peaceful and painless, would you consider it? What if the treatment was in the form of psychedelic drugs?

In his No.1 New York Times bestselling book, How to Change Your Mind: What the New Science of Psychedelics Teaches Us About Consciousness, Dying, Addiction, Depression and Transcendence, Michael Pollan investigates this revolutionary treatment.
Pollan personally experiments with these mind-expanding drugs, once considered dangerous, toxic and a sure road to danger.
How To Change Your Mind reveals striking new evidence on psychedelics, confirming their power to cure mental illness, ease depression and addiction, and help people die more peacefully.

If you are a person or business that feels unsure if what they are doing is right for them, or you just want to better understand yourself and how you 'operate' as a person, this course is for you. It can teach you to make better decisions, set your goals, and go on to achieve them.

insights.title: Whenever we are trying to achieve something, we set a goal - and at the first sign of trouble, we give up

actions.title: Make a list of who you are.
actions.markdown: Get to know yourself better. Write down all of your strengths and ‘good’ traits, and then all of your weaknesses - your ‘bad’ ones. It is not always easy to face insecurities and weaknesses, but it’s certainly the path toward turning them into strengths.

paragraphCards.markdown: When we set a goal, most of us tend to pick it based on a lacking skill or strength. Rarely will anyone take their weaknesses into account.
That is why, when we hit the first bump in the road, it is overcome by our weaknesses - and we give up.
Fortunately, that doesn't have to be the case if we can turn our insecurities to our advantage.
It is important that, before we set a goal, we overcome our strengths and weaknesses in order to work in our favor and so that we can bring our goal to the end.
Make a list that's divided into two columns and write down your weaknesses in one, and your strengths in the other.
Then, in order to overcome certain weaknesses or things you don't like about yourself, you have to first face the root cause.
Sometimes we look at things the wrong way or at their base value, but you need to look for the real cause of the issue.
For example, do you think that "honesty" is a virtue because you truly value it, or because you just learned that from others?
Do you have lying down as an insecurity because you were told off for it in childhood? Can it actually be a good thing?
The question we need to ask ourselves is - why are we allowing such things to stand in the way of our success?
By becoming aware of our weaknesses, they can in turn become our strengths.

insights.title: There is a difference between goal and purpose - and successful people know it

actions.title: Set yourself a massive goal.
actions.markdown: Start by thinking of someone extremely successful - a role model to you, perhaps. Carefully analyze the behavior and habits of that person. Then, try to follow that pattern and apply it in both your work and personal life.

paragraphCards.markdown: A purpose is the reason we get up in the morning. A goal is then a step towards that purpose.
But not everyone has revealed their purpose, and so cannot set their goals to align with it.
There are people who are never truly satisfied. They do their job because they are good at it, but they don't see the point.
If they are lucky, this can be a trigger to look for a purpose: to set a huge goal and to diligently fulfill it step by step.

"Smart goals do not work, they set us up for mediocrity at best! Highly effective people and organizations set massive goals and focus on smart or realistic steps that take them to their massive goals."
Having massive goals and purpose makes decision making easy.
When we are determined by purpose or a big goal, we don't mind minor setbacks. We just brush them off and push our way through all barriers and failures towards success.
When we find a big purpose, a real sense of being or importance, there is nothing that can come in our way and stop us from trying again.

insights.title: Psychology says that all insecurities from people with anxiety or emotional challenges can be reduced to three things: control, security and acceptance

actions.title: Place your insecurities into three groups.
actions.markdown: Write down all of your worries and stress, anything that’s been bugging you, then divide each one up into a loss of control, security or acceptance. You will overcome any challenge more easily if you’re aware of what you’re facing.

paragraphCards.markdown: When we are afraid of failure, we are actually afraid of losing control.
This is the most common result of an uncertainty, and what a lot of things boil down to. The other two possibilities are a loss of security or acceptance.

If our insecurity is that we are afraid to start a business, for example, we can consider it fear for security. If we are afraid to step up with an idea, we are actually afraid that we will not be accepted.
When we manage to group all of our insecurities into these three groups - control, security, and acceptance - a lot of our work can be done for us.
It is only by truly getting to know our fears and barricades that we have a chance to remove them. It requires hard work, but there's a big reward at the end.
In order to overcome our fears, the most important thing is to not pay attention to other people's opinions.
Is it really that important for everyone to accept our views? Can we ever have total control over anything? And can we achieve really great goals if we never step out of our comfort zone?
When you set a goal, you don't need to pay attention to interference.
Just listen to those around you who matter, and don't allow the opinions of others to cloud your judgment or sway your beliefs.

"For 30 years of my life, I hadn't set myself one goal…not one. My goals were set by my teachers, my parents, and my bosses. I let my life be determined by other people. The worst thing was, I thought I was doing just fine." \[David Hyner\]

When we analyze what successful people have in common, we can see that they all have one common drive: Purpose. They were absolutely all purpose-driven. How can we get there? Can we set our goals and maintain them? The answer to both questions is - yes we can!
David Hyner interviewed more than 200 high achievers and it changed his life and business forever. He learned that successful people set massive goals, but achieve them step by step.

They focus on achievable and realistic steps, and most importantly, they are consistent. They do not pay attention to what other people think of their unusual process. They do what is important - they get work done.
Through this course, we can precisely learn how to set goals and maintain them. We will be able to identify our true values and insecurities, and learn how to turn them to our advantage.

Knowing our core value brings us to better decision making. Learning our insecurities gives us an opportunity to suppress their negative effect. During the course, we will meet who we really are and explore our own strengths and weaknesses.
PURPOSE: How to Find your Why teaches you to understand who you really are, helps you find the way to effortless decision making, and makes your life easier.

How To Say No To Your Family can allow you to develop the confidence to say "no" to your family, and to the requests that demand a compromise of your own needs, whilst still keeping a healthy relationship with them. That way, everybody wins.

insights.title: Self-awareness is the first step towards achieving the confidence to say no

actions.title: Don’t let your autopilot take over your needs.
actions.markdown: If you have not looked inside enough, you’re more likely to say yes even if you don’t want to. Always say yes to yourself first to build a healthy relationship with your family.

actions.title: Practice a five-minute self-talk.
actions.markdown: Before making a decision, first ask yourself why you’d say yes. Secondly, ask yourself why you could not say no. And finally, evaluate the consequences of saying yes.

paragraphCards.markdown: In order to achieve self-awareness, you first need to know what it entails.
Self-awareness is when you look deep into your internal thinking process that affects your decision-making.

When you feel conflicted by the external pressure from your family members, or your perception of their expectations from you, it requires a three-step process to self-reflect on what you truly want from the situation.
What you need to master are your thoughts, your feelings, and your needs.
Thoughts are the most important ingredient when it comes to self-awareness, because they directly determine how you feel and how you behave in the moment.
Therefore, it's important to evaluate what you are thinking in the situation - for example, when you're asked to drive your aunt to the hospital but you're really busy at whatever you're doing.
You might already feel guilty, even before you think about not attending to the request.
You've decided for a half-yes right at the time when you need to get a thing done urgently.
This is when you need to make a quick judgment about your own priorities: your needs and your emotions.

insights.title: Go beyond your fears of saying no by reasoning with your loved ones

actions.title: Don’t avoid conflict, solve it with clear communication.
actions.markdown: Avoiding conflict elongates the consequences of conflict. Try to communicate your needs with the family member who you’re struggling to help at the moment. Explain and come to an understanding.

actions.title: Work on your expectation management.
actions.markdown: Families often expect you to say “yes” all the time. Manage their expectations towards you. Be honest to both yourself and them.

paragraphCards.markdown: There can be many reasons you might feel reluctant to refuse to do something for your family.
It might be due to an unspoken fear and anxiety you occasionally feel because of the relationship dynamics within your family.
No one wants to hurt their loved ones or to be unresponsive to their needs.

However, you need to keep one thing in mind: if you cannot respond to your own needs, no matter how much you pay attention to the expectations of your relatives, you will never be satisfied with yourself.
And that's why it is essential to knock into your fears of saying "no" to them.
Such fears are at the heart of the consequences when refusing to commit to a certain task.
Dig into these consequences, and try to come to a solution to the problem.
What will be the result of your saying "no", and how will this help you to deal with your family members?

insights.title: Embrace your “no” fully by reading behind the surface of a favor asked

actions.title: Define your longings and create balance.
actions.markdown: When asked to do something you don’t want to do, keep the peace and instead, define your uncompromisable needs. Save both yourself and your loved ones from an unnecessary conflict that might affect your relationship.

paragraphCards.markdown: When you say a half-yes to a request, like a "yes, but," you subconsciously create an expectation towards the other person that you owe them a favor.
This expectation, however, is not communicated, and because of this, the other person might feel like they owe you something.
A half-yes is essentially dishonesty that leads to resentment - even if you gave your time and energy to a person.
Instead, you should be very clear about your own needs first.
Remember, you can always fill the gap left by your "no" by coming up with creative solutions.
For example, if your aunt needs driving to the hospital, remember she doesn't necessarily want you to do it.
If you really tap into it, you will find that she merely wants to reach hospital comfortably.

Your creative solution would then be to get her an Uber that can drop her there safely. This way, you're not only fulfilling your needs, you're also fulfilling your aunt's needs without a possible conflict.
Embrace your "no" by avoiding dishonesty. All you have to make sure is that you make it clear what your needs are.
A blunt "no" can create the same resentment as a thoughtless "yes" - and no one wants that.
"Once you grow awareness of the barriers that prevent you from saying 'no' when you really want to, new possibilities of choice and freedom open up." \[Rachel Smaltz, Cara Crisler\]

When it comes to developing your communication skills, the most difficult thing to learn is to have the confidence to prioritize yourself before others. It's especially difficult when the others are your loved ones.
So, how do you say "no" to your family without taking the risk to offend them? Expectation management is what comes to mind. However, it is easier said than done.
Rachel Smaltz and Cara Crisler actually make it easy for you to balance self-worth and family expectations.

While Smaltz's bestseller book, Awaken Your Confidence, has helped people literally awaken their confidence, Crisler has been helping clients develop personal relationships by resolving familial and professional conflicts for decades.

In this course, How To Say No To Family, Smaltz and Crisler combine their years of expertise to help you build self-confidence to say no to your family - especially when you need to say yes to yourself.
You have to know yourself, overcome your fear, and embrace your decision fully.

How to Say 'No' to Family helps you to communicate your true needs, emotions, and thoughts with your family without fearing the outcome of saying "no", using a thorough process of self-reflection that builds your self-confidence.

paragraphCards.markdown: How To Start A Business With No Money is a bestseller that has quite possibly the smartest business advice that you will come across.

insights.title: There is incredible power in just getting started

actions.title: Make a choice to be in business.
actions.markdown: Stop with the procrastination and second-guessing your decision to do business, and choose to be in business so that you can succeed.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The best way to succeed in business is to be in business." \[Trent Dyrsmid\]
Simple enough, right? Because without a business to begin with, success would not even be possible.
This is the most uncomplicated advice that any business person can apply, and it is the smartest advice that you can take.
Once you start a business, it becomes possible to explore all the different avenues available to achieve success.
When you get your first thought of what kind of business you would like to be in, getting started and going through the motions of discovering what works will drive you to success.
The truth is that this one piece of business advice should change your thinking and help you move from a starting point into a journey that reveals how you can achieve success.

insights.title: Learning helps any business get better

actions.title: Take every challenge as an opportunity to learn.
actions.markdown: When things get tough, do not give up. Instead, identify all the opportunities for you to learn how to get better and branch out.

paragraphCards.markdown: Trent Dyrsmid is the creator of the 'green dot theory'.
According to the green dot theory, once you start your business, you probably won't not find the success you're seeking. Things seldom turn out the way you originally imagined.

However, it's only once you're in business that you'll discover the different ways to succeed. For example, you may want to sell green dots because you've decided this is a winning idea - but you won't know until you get out there and start selling.
If your business doesn't immediately hit the ground running, that doesn't mean you should throw in the towel altogether.
The only sure-fire way to prevent yourself from achieving the success you desire is to give up altogether.
Although you may start a company with one idea in mind, you might discover down the road that a byproduct will help you change course and improve things, little by little.
Maybe green wasn't your colour after all. But it's only by exploring the idea and giving it a go that you can realize that, in this instance, red dots are in fact the better choice_._
Business has its ups and downs. Sometimes things will go well, while at others, things will be harder. But while you are in business, it becomes easy to see opportunities.
Learning from experience helps a business get better.

insights.title: You can become better by paying attention to the competition

actions.title: Find your weaknesses.
actions.markdown: Look to your competition to help you find your weaknesses. Then you can improve your service delivery and learn from their successes and mistakes.

paragraphCards.markdown: There are times when the easiest way to learn and achieve success is by paying attention to the competition.
This requires you to look at what they are doing and learn what steps have led to their success.
By understanding the competition's strategy, it becomes easier to create something better.
For example, whilst coming up with his green dot theory, Trent Dyrsmid struggled to come up with his own business concept for six months.
He played around with different ideas, before finally looking into the other similar companies offering similar services that were already out there doing it.
That was how he discovered there was in fact a better way - right in plain sight.
With knowledge of what the competition does better, you can understand what the customer is looking for and then block the competition from taking your place.
This is how you find another opportunity to generate revenue and a different way to deliver services that you may not have figured out on your own.

"If you ask 100 people that question, you are going to get 100 different answers. This is because most of the people you ask are going to talk to you about a specific business model, sales idea or marketing tactic, etc." \[Trent Dyrsmid\]
In business, many people want to know how to become successful. The easiest way to get the answer to this question is by asking different people who've already got there.
However, the problem there is that each person you ask will probably give a different answer. With so many answers to choose from, you can quickly feel overwhelmed.
With over 13 years of experience running his own business, Trent Dyrsmid has found a straightforward answer that brings all this advice together.
This answer is so incredibly simple that the first time you read it, it may not make any sense. However, the moment you apply it, the road to how to become successful in business becomes clear.

How to Start a Business with No Money provides a straightforward strategy that cuts through potential answers on kick-starting a business, giving you the one secret to succeed at any business even with no money.

paragraphCards.markdown: Happiness expert and author Jay Kumar, PhD, certainly has some powerful lessons to offer here.

insights.title: Manipulate your brain’s natural wiring to choose happiness

actions.title: Keep things in perspective.
actions.markdown: When your plans are next frustrated with unexpected bad weather, slow down. Take a breath. Consider whether this has really ruined your day, or if you can adapt your plans. Don’t waste unnecessary time and energy stressing over daily events that you cannot control.

actions.title: Allow your work to be a bridge for you to find a deeper sense of meaning.
actions.markdown: Understand that money and meaning does not contradict each other. You can have both! Choose a career that creates work that is personally meaningful and purposeful to you.

actions.title: Accept inevitable changes.
actions.markdown: Let go of the things you have no control over, and learn to accept unavoidable changes that may sometimes be thrown your way.

paragraphCards.markdown: Our brain is wired to remember negative experiences more strongly than the positive ones.
Did you know it takes an average of five 'good' or empowering thoughts to outweigh a single negative one?
Fortunately, we can overcome our brain's natural wiring by shifting our perspective.
Remember that happiness is a practice. It is something we have to pursue, and it is attainable.
The first step in the path towards choosing happiness is understanding what factors sabotage our ability to be happy.
A human brain fundamentally seeks safety, security, and stability in order to survive.
Whenever something happens that compromises any of our fundamental needs, we tend to feel sad, angry, or anxious.
Discern between perceived threats and real threats to avoid stressing out over things that don't really matter.
Take care of the things that you can control and let go of the ones that are completely uncontrollable.
Once you understand that change is the only constant thing in life, you will be more equipped to face whatever life throws your way, whether it's pain or pleasure.

insights.title: Seek and establish real-life connections

actions.title: Make time to socialize with others.
actions.markdown: Put your phone down and allocate time each day to meet new people, hang out with your friends, or spend time with your loved ones. Yes, that means in person!

actions.title: Build a tribe composed of the people you trust.
actions.markdown: Introduce your loved ones to each other and establish a social circle that will serve as everyone’s support system.

actions.title: Remind yourself that everyone, including you, has a contribution.
actions.markdown: Fuel your need to feel needed! Remind yourself that you are a vital part of your tribe. Recognize the tiny ways your loved ones show you they care, whether it be remembering something you said last week, or sending you a funny video they think you’d like.

paragraphCards.markdown: We are living in an over-connected era, yet many of us are disconnected with each other in real life.
We spend so much time on our gadgets that we forget to forge and maintain real-life connections.
As a matter of fact, research reveals that technology addiction is one of the many factors that sabotage our happiness.
At our core, humans are social beings. We naturally seek a deep sense of belonging in our community.

Studies show that the same area in our brain that processes physical pain is triggered when we experience social rejection, such as losing a loved one, being betrayed by a friend, or being an outcast to a social circle.
Make sure to include socializing and spending time with your family, friends, and colleagues in your schedule.
Regardless of your work environment setup, it's important to cultivate and maintain in-person connections.
By doing this, you avoid the likelihood of feeling isolated and lonely, thus boosting your happiness.

insights.title: Allow your happiness to be contagious

actions.title: Offer a helping hand to those who need it.
actions.markdown: Practice empathy and help people who are in distress, even if it requires you to go out of your way. Remember that you would want to be helped if the situation is reversed.

actions.title: Let the people around you manifest your positivity.
actions.markdown: Consistently display a positive energy to empower the people around you to do the same, thus resulting in a happier group environment. This is particularly powerful in the workplace. Your efforts won’t go unnoticed!

paragraphCards.markdown: Energy is contagious.
The best way to cultivate a happy environment, both at work and outside the office, is to let it start with you.
So, whatever you're doing, take it as an opportunity to teach by example, and be nice.
Being compassionate, empathetic, altruistic, and tolerant puts us one step further to becoming truly, genuinely happy.
Showing kindness can be as simple as opening the door for somebody, or even saying hello to someone in the street. When you see someone in distress, offer a helping hand.
Most powerfully of all, a simple act of kindness has a ripple effect.
The person who receives your kindness is much more likely to show kindness to somebody else!
Even for the people who aren't the direct recipient of your kindness, simply witnessing a positive act will condition them to do something good as well.
In this way, positive energy really is contagious.
"Happy brains make happy people. Happy people make a happy enterprise. Happy enterprises make a happy world. It all starts with you." \[Jay Kumar\]
We all want to be happy. However, in today's disconnected, chaotic world, it can seem difficult to find the happiness we're so longing for.
What's worse, a human brain is wired to strongly retain bad thoughts, and easily forget about the good ones.
Thankfully, with the help of this course from Dr. Jay Kumar, we can learn the strategies needed to unlock our brain's ability to choose happiness.
A university professor, motivational speaker, social philosopher, and entrepreneur, Kumar's mission is to empower and educate you into achieving health and happiness in your life.
He also appears on a weekly basis as an expert on the "Doug Stephan Good Day" radio show.
His bestselling book, "Brain, Body, & Being", is a comprehensive approach to the subject of happiness, and how best to achieve it naturally.
In this course, Kumar pulls back the curtain on the concept of happiness, thoroughly investigating the strategies we can use to attain genuine happiness in our life.

How to Train Your Brain for Happiness takes us on a journey towards finding happiness not just at work, but in our overall sense of being, as happiness professor Jay Kumar, PhD, shares insights, techniques, and cutting-edge research into our psychology and behavior.

insights.title: ‘Imposter syndrome’ is normal, natural and a promising sign

actions.title: Learn to master the ‘four traps of self-doubt’.

actions.title: Recognize that ‘anxiety’ and ‘excitement’ are two sides of the same coin.
actions.markdown: Your body fires the same impulses whether you’re looking forward to something or dreading it. Identifying which you’re feeling is entirely your choice.

paragraphCards.markdown: The pervasive feeling that you somehow don't 'deserve' to hold the position you hold is merely evidence that you haven't settled for the easy route.

It's natural for creative people to question themselves: it comes with the territory. ![giphy.com/sundayelephantcreatives/](https://media.giphy.com/media/lQbHFZjKoZIaDzZlXF/giphy.gif)

The fact is, if you're not feeling anxious, you're not pushing yourself hard enough. Your comfort zone is a false friend; real achievement happens outside it. ![giphy.com/sundayelephantcreatives](https://media.giphy.com/media/jqx2RPQLlQ1dPlTlB3/giphy.gif)
Fortunately, 'imposter syndrome' is easily dispelled by action.

Start work, begin performing, and your true worth soon becomes apparent - to yourself as much as anyone. ![giphy.com/sundayelephantcreatives](https://media.giphy.com/media/0JhY3tHqJE97NJlWpM/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Real confidence follows from deciding to try

actions.title: Action: Trust in the ‘5-Second Rule’
actions.markdown: When you feel yourself hesitating, take control. Count backwards from five to one, and on one, decide to act.

paragraphCards.markdown: Loudness often stands in for confidence, but it is nothing of the sort. ![giphy.com/Aisforai/](https://media.giphy.com/media/dbVNzOSyUd1kQmOIaM/giphy.gif)

In fact, those who self-identify as 'introverts' are far more likely to succeed in their creative and commercial endeavors than self-styled 'extroverts'. ![giphy.com/Drawmama/](https://media.giphy.com/media/U6dZ3LgY20uXNi9WzJ/giphy.gif)
Confidence is not innate; it's a skill that follows from competence. Once we begin to work, we find that self-doubt is as fragile as unfounded confidence; it simply disappears.
The flipside is that confidence must be worked on, practiced and valued. Cultivate it, and it becomes a habit that replaces the damaging default of doubt. Neglect it, and it will erode.

Failure is nothing to fear. Picasso created perhaps 100 masterpieces out of 50,000 paintings: James Dyson made almost 5,000 prototypes before launch. ![Sir\_James\_Dyson\_CBE\_FREng\_FRS.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Sir_James_Dyson_CBE_FREng_FRS.jpg/1024px-Sir_James_Dyson_CBE_FREng_FRS.jpg)
Nothing worthwhile comes easily, and initial rejection is no reason to give up on your dream.
Success is pretty much a numbers game. Keep at it.

insights.title: Just five core habits can make all the difference

actions.title: Action: Replace accidental habits with deliberate ones.
actions.markdown: Forego phone usage before bed and in the morning, avoid the snooze button, make incremental progress towards your goal, and limit your work hours; you will see guaranteed results.

paragraphCards.markdown: The habits of success are many, but Robbins strongly recommends adopting five simple rules that take you a long way towards changing your life for the better.

First, never use your phone in the bedroom. While studies show that 33% of us admit to checking email during the night, this one should be obvious. ![giphy.com/Smulderstextiel/](https://media.giphy.com/media/dvaTRoKpKWB0IsW0i8/giphy.gif)
Second, never hit the snooze button. Far from being a friend, it's profoundly counterproductive; our sleep patterns are smart, sophisticated and easily undermined.
Third, leave your phone alone in the morning too; spend quality time with your own thoughts and aspirations before allowing the world to intrude.
Fourthly, be sure to make one step a day in progress of your main objective, no matter how small. ![giphy.com/flowuer](https://media.giphy.com/media/ejJ737TahRzNkFO5EV/giphy.gif)
Finally, set a finish time and stick to it. Don't allow work to take over your life or personality.
Most creative solutions occur to us outside of 'work time' - all the more reason to be sure to limit it.
"If you have a problem that can be solved with action, you don't have a problem." \[Mel Robbins\]

Mel Robbins is among the world's most in-demand motivational speakers, trusted by brands, businesses and pioneering individuals to challenge entrenched habits of thinking and help her clients reach their full potential. ![Mel\_Robbin.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c5/Mel_Robbin.jpg)

Mel is adamant that most self-doubt comes down to learned habits that, once identified, can be addressed and relatively easily un-learned. ![giphy.com/nathanhughesdesigns](https://media.giphy.com/media/gSUt0h0wPD6D06P22Y/giphy.gif)
Robbins notes that creative people are by nature plagued by self-doubt. [youtube.com/c/melrobbins](https://youtu.be/uFRsR1UuiPk?t=0.00&e=7.88)
As creative work is effectively an extension of the self, any criticism can be felt as a personal attack - so the 'four traps of self-doubt' find fertile ground to grow and hamper progress.
The course demonstrates simple, effective methods to overcome these persistent, self-made problems and acquire the 'genuine' confidence that characterizes reliably successful operators.

Robbins is unashamedly a "tools person". Her aim is to equip you with the strategies and tactics that can be deployed to defeat self-doubt whenever it raises its head. ![giphy.com/ludvago](https://media.giphy.com/media/dW0GOm57g8kzQFuSAz/giphy.gif)

While primarily aimed at people in creative industries, Mel's inspirational advice holds true for anyone keen to stop unwittingly sabotaging their own chances of success on the way to achieving the professional and personal fulfilment they deserve.

In this Creative Live class, leading motivational speaker Mel Robbins teaches us to identify and analyze the unhelpful habits of belief that hold us back, and replace them with practical, effective tools that really work.

paragraphCards.markdown: By practicing and perfecting these steps in creating a perfect elevator pitch, you can advance your career and achieve your goals effortlessly, whether that's presenting a new idea to your colleagues, or even asking your boss for a salary raise.

insights.title: Engage with a relatable dilemma to capture your audience’s attention

actions.title: Identify who you’re talking to, and what you want from them.
actions.markdown: There’s no one generic elevator pitch that will work for every single person, so it’s important to recognize who you’re speaking with and your goal behind the interaction.

actions.title: Figure out what’s a problem that you can solve for them.
actions.markdown: Let them know that you have a solution to the issue that they’re dealing with and that’s what will get you whatever you want from the person you’re speaking with.

actions.title: Make your question extremely personal to them.
actions.markdown: When constructing your hook, it should be personally relatable to them so you can grab their attention and have them all ears on what you’re saying.

paragraphCards.markdown: When creating a pitch, the first step is to come up with a narrative hook that will grab the listener's attention.
The hook is a personalized question or statement that the individual or group of people you're talking to can relate.
There is no generic statement that will work for everyone, so your questions should be curated specifically, depending on who you're speaking to.
First, identify who you're talking to and what you want from them.
For instance, if you're speaking with your boss, your underlying goal might be to propose a new idea how to better run the company.
Or if you're talking to a hiring manager, you could be looking to land a job. And if you're conversing with a potential customer, you could be selling a product or service.
Understanding your audience, and the desired outcome from the interaction, will make it easier for you to determine a personally relatable question.
Once you have their attention, state a problem that you can offer a solution to. Your ability to solve a problem for them is what's going to help you achieve your goal.

insights.title: Explain what you do, and communicate your value

actions.title: Identify a problem, then offer a solution.
actions.markdown: Explain your proposed solution, detail exactly what you will be doing, and how it will solve their problem.

actions.title: Describe the impact of your work.
actions.markdown: Focus on the purpose of what you’re promoting, and the positive impact it might have. If your listener becomes invested in what you’re selling, how will their life change for the better?

paragraphCards.markdown: When pitching yourself, make sure you connect yourself to your 'hook'.
Go into further detail on how exactly you can solve their problem.
This is a crucial part in developing your elevator pitch, because this is the point where your listener will either see your value, or they won't.
In this step, you have the opportunity to demonstrate your value and prove your worth.
Whether you're promoting your company, products, services, or yourself, it's important to provide detailed information on what you're promoting and how it could benefit the people you're talking to.
Talk them through what you have to offer, step-by-step, and detail the positive impact it could have on your surroundings. Share the purpose and the meaning behind the work you're doing.
Most importantly, you have to believe in the significance of what you're promoting. If you don't, people will see right through it.
You'll have a much harder time persuading others to believe in what you're pitching, if you don't genuinely believe in it yourself.

insights.title: Promote an achievement, and demonstrate your passion

actions.title: Show off your achievements to increase your credibility.
actions.markdown: To make yourself appear more trustworthy, boast any credential you may have, whether it’s a testimony from a customer or a certificate of recognition from your company.

actions.title: Prove that you genuinely love what you do.
actions.markdown: If you’re not oozing with passion while talking about the work you do, no one’s going to believe the importance and the value of your work!

paragraphCards.markdown: People buy into individuals when they're certain they can trust them.
You encourage others to trust you when you prove that you're not just all talk, but you have an excellent track record too.
No matter how excellent your product or services are, no one will put their trust in you if you don't have any proof to back them up with.
To build your credibility, show off a testimonial from a recent client or customer, or an award that you've won.
It's also a good idea to talk about the size of your customer database.
This is where you'll have the chance to prove your credibility and trustworthiness.
Talk about what you're promoting with enthusiasm and eagerness.
People have to see that you're passionate, and genuinely believe in the importance of the work you do.
Because if your listener sees that you don't care about what you do, you won't be able to convince them of the value of your idea.
Love what you do, so you can inspire others to love it as well.
"Nobody cares how much you know until they know how much you care." \[Aimee Bateman\]
Elevator sales pitches are not necessarily just for salespeople.
Even if you don't work in the sales industry, an elevator pitch can be useful in different circumstances: at a networking event, when talking to customers, or proposing a new product or idea.
Whichever industry you belong in, knowing how to develop an elevator pitch is highly beneficial to your career.
In this course, you'll learn how to craft a pitch that will make others interested in your idea, product, or project in no more than 30 seconds.
Career consultant Aimee Bateman has a proven strategy for developing pitches that guarantee a good first impression—in as little time as it takes to get to the first floor.
Bateman is also the founder of Careercake, a careers content platform.
In this course, she walks us through the simple steps in building the perfect elevator pitch, as well as how to effectively promote both our organization and ourselves.

In How to Create a Perfect Elevator Pitch, Aimee Bateman shares the importance of the elevator pitch, how you can take advantage of it in whatever field of work you're in, and the simple steps to developing the perfect pitch and advancing your career.

paragraphCards.markdown: Even the most confident people have problems with job interviews. Knowing there is an effective way to prepare for the job interview is a huge relief for many, and How to Rock an Interview is here to help by combining theory and practice in the easiest and most usable way.

insights.title: Create your job interview strategy

actions.title: Tell yourself about you.
actions.markdown: Prepare your answer to the “tell me about yourself” question. Get together a good introduction that covers the main points, and practice out loud to find the most comfortable way to deliver it.

paragraphCards.markdown: Having an impressive opening an interview and grabbing the attention of the interviewer seems, to most job seekers, to be a difficult or unpleasant task.
In an interview, we have to find a catchy way to present and highlight our skills, knowledge, experience, and other advantages.
Unfortunately, most people are untrained to use storytelling techniques - the secret weapon to job interviews.
In order to make a good impression, candidates have to find a way to use their voice to express their accomplishments.
The interviewer should be impressed, but without it feeling excessive, forced or inauthentic.
If talking about your accomplishments feels uncomfortable, rehearsing out loud could be an effective way to get used to talking about yourself.
Interview preparations are not only necessary but could be crucial for a positive outcome. However, too much practice can lead to over-rehearsed and ungenuine presentation.
The 'bullet point approach' could be an ideal solution for finding the golden balance between fake and excessively relaxed.
Anticipate the interviewer's questions and lay out your answers, along with any key points you'd like to get across about yourself.
A little practice can make our speech sound natural and sincere - just be careful not to let it sound too memorized.

insights.title: Do some research on the company and position

actions.title: Research the company.
actions.markdown: Put some effort into researching the company. Check their website for current projects, key names and faces, and a bit about how they started. Use these findings to compose the answers that will impress the interviewer.

actions.title: Collect more information.
actions.markdown: Use different sources, ask friends or family, and do your research. Look up similar job ads that have been posted. Investigate the position to understand the job description.

actions.title: Organize a video practice.
actions.markdown: Video yourself in a mock interview. Analyze them afterwards, and work on your speech, body language, and face gestures.

paragraphCards.markdown: In most interviews, at some point, the interviewer will ask candidates to explain why they choose to apply for that position in that company. This is a moment when using generic answers is not recommended.
To make the most of the interviewer's questions, you should investigate the position and prepare a more detailed answer in advance.
Ensure your answer matches up with your CV and previously gained experience, and is aligned with the company's values and the role description.
The point of collecting information about the company and job is not only to let the interviewer know that we put an effort into research, but also to be ready for any situation.
In some cases, the atmosphere could be cold, and not the best one to show how proactive and energetic we are.
Additional sources and information let you take control of the situation, and even show your leadership skills.
Companies are often looking for people who are motivated to succeed and would be sincerely happy to get the job.
It's important to express genuine enthusiasm for the role, and let them know how interesting an opportunity you believe it to be.
People who struggle with self-presentation, or those with a low-key personality, should take some time to practice showing their enthusiasm and genuine interest in advance.

insights.title: Improve your overall presentation

actions.title: Prepare a good ending.
actions.markdown: Work on some possible questions you could ask at the end of the interview. Finalize your answers or any concluding points that you’d like to make that will emphasize your best qualities, and end the interview on a positive note.

paragraphCards.markdown: Body language is important for the overall presentation, but it should not be the main subject of our interview preparations.
Focus on what you're going to say first. Once you master what to say, you can begin to practice how to say it.
When it comes to a method for communication, focus and engagement are equally important for any type of interview, as we usually have around two minutes to catch people's attention.
From an interviewer's perspective, the STAR Format is often used in career literature and courses.
The STAR format helps to prove that you have a certain quality that the role requires.

When presented with a certain Situation, what Task were you presented with? What Action did you take, and what was the Result? Having a couple of your achievements that you can break down into this approach could be very beneficial.
Finally, the best way to end the interview in a positive way is to ask some carefully thought-out questions.
Asking the interviewer for feedback, on the other hand, can be counterproductive. Instead, this question should be more position-oriented.
Pre-plan your questions as part of your research in advance, based on what you've discovered about the company and the role you're applying for.

"An interview is a kind of different interaction than anything else we do. But with a little bit of coaching, you can see people make a huge difference, and getting good at interviewing is a major life improvement opportunity." \[Pete Mockaitis\]
Every interview is a stressful experience and people often miss the opportunity to get the job of their dreams because they get too nervous or shy.
Thankfully, Pete Mockaitis has the recipe with a few little tricks up his sleeve, and useful techniques to overcome these obstacles.

Mockaitis is experienced in coaching and training, and also an author of other courses related to this subject. His systematic work involves demonstrations, examples, and guidance through this step by step process.
For those who want to prevent failing job interviews or never again left to wonder if it went well, this is a simple and effective instruction course that's easy to understand and apply.
How to Rock an Interview has been created for people who want to learn how to emphasize their best qualities, present themselves most suitably, and achieve the best result at job interviews.

How to Study for Exams teaches you how to personalize a range of techniques and create the perfect study experience. You will learn to retain the information you need in a short amount of time, and achieve success with any assessments coming your way.

insights.title: Understanding is more effective than memorizing

actions.title: Take the stress of testing.
actions.markdown: Rather than thinking of testing as something that you will pass or fail, focus on the recall element of testing. Check what you remember after each paragraph as you are studying.

paragraphCards.markdown: Richard Feynman was a famous physicist responsible for the Feynman Technique. The key principle behind the technique is that once you have understood a topic well enough, you should be able to explain it to anyone.
When you're studying, it's important that the topic makes sense to you so much that you can explain it to a five year old - not just the what, but the why, too.
"Testing ourselves is the most fundamental part of understanding anything and learning anything."
Active recall is a way of testing yourself to ensure that all the information you have understood can be drawn out when needed.
With active recall, you can evaluate how much information you've been able to retain, and identify any gaps. This is more effective than simply highlighting key points within a text.
Taking notes during class can assist with understanding and recall; however, handwritten notes are more effective than notes which are typed out.

Handwritten notes allow for more intense thinking, allowing for a better grasp of the content. Typing, on the other hand, is more passive by nature, and is more about hand-to-brain coordination than improving memory.

insights.title: Strategic repetition and some retrospect will help you retain information

actions.title: Use mind maps.
actions.markdown: For visual memorization, create a mind map. Have your topic at the centre, and add branches with each one representing a key aspect of what you need to remember.

paragraphCards.markdown: Repetition is the key to improving what you understand, and then go on to remember.
When you go through a topic over and over, each time you remember a little bit more. But when you study something, after a while, you'll forget at least half of what you went through.
You need to set out intervals, daily, weekly, or monthly, and keep going over the same content. This is known as space repetition.
"The Retrospective Revision Timetable is one where instead of deciding in advance what topics to study, you decide on the day based on what topics you have done in the past."

Retrospective revision requires you to look back at what you've covered that day, and then look to see what you could do to improve that knowledge. It's more like ticking off a checklist than creating a timetable, compiling things to read through in the future.
Flashcards are a tool that many who study are familiar with, typically with a question on the front and an answer on the back.
You can choose to create your own flashcards or, these days, work with apps that already have created flashcards for you - such as Anki.
Apps like Anki also have an algorithm for space repetition, so you can test yourself on different topics over a set period.

insights.title: Learn to manage pressure to get focused

actions.title: Elevate your focus with music.
actions.markdown: The best music for studying is instrumental music with no lyrics. The process of study can be more enjoyable and allow for greater focus, but without the distraction of singing along.

paragraphCards.markdown: Effective study requires focus: the ability to sit down and work without any distraction from what you're trying to achieve.
Though many people are tempted to study for hours, part of remaining focused requires taking regular breaks to avoid burnout.
Extensive hours of non-stop study can harm both physical and mental health.
"You don't even think about getting distracted because you are enjoying what you are doing and are fully immersed in it."
It would be best if you got rid of the culprits that will cause you to get distracted while you're working. This almost certainly includes your phone and its many vibrations, alerts, and sounds.
Put your phone on silent, and even change the display to greyscale and turn it over to discourage yourself from constantly looking at it while you need to study.
To remain focused, a brief break can go a long way. Try using the Pomodoro technique, where you study for 25 minutes, and then take a five minute break.
Do this for a total of four working sessions, and then follow it up with an extended 30 minute break.
You can even create your own version of this technique that works well for you, but just make sure you're giving your brain some cool-down time.
"There are three key steps to effective studying: understanding, remembering, and focus."
Preparing for an exam can be taxing, as you try and remember as much information as possible to give you a good chance at passing.
You have to focus on maximizing the amount of knowledge that you've learned, while minimizing the total time that it took to learn it.
Drawing on his experience as a medical student, Ali Abdaal, who's now a doctor, reveals how he was able to study effectively, while also running a business and maintaining a YouTube Channel.

How to Study for Exams is a course broken down into three parts. The first part focuses on understanding what is fundamental to effective study, the second part on memorization, retention, and mind, and the third part on maintaining focus and motivation.

How to Study for Exams will help you discover strategies for understanding information, recalling what you have learned, and retaining your focus, so that it becomes easier to have exam answers at your fingertips.
How to Be Promotable is all about refining and developing your skills, as hiring managers want candidates who are willing to improve their individual and professional character.
By implementing the skills in this course, you too can be 'promotable,' allowing you to reach your full potential at work.

insights.title: Prove your value

actions.title: Reflect on what needs improving.
actions.markdown: Reflect on your current strengths and weaknesses, and decide what needs improvement. Discussing these in your next 1-on-1 with your manager shows your engagement and self-awareness.

actions.title: Ask for feedback.
actions.markdown: Asking your line managers or team members for feedback is another way to start, as you get to see your strengths and weaknesses from someone else’s perspective.

actions.title: Build your relationships.
actions.markdown: Try to connect with as many members of your company as possible, not just those in your team. You’ll be seen as an optimistic, friendly team-player, and an essential part of the office!

paragraphCards.markdown: Contrary to what you might think, your value is not necessarily about your individual strengths – in fact, your value is not about you, per se, at all.
Instead, your 'value' as an employee is determined in the way in which you contribute to your company - your importance, worth or efficacy. You must prove these 3 things as often as you can.
"You always have to compare your strength \[…\] to the value that it has on the team and organisation." \[Aimee Bateman\]
Whatever strengths you have, whether it be communication or excellent time organisation, make sure your managers are aware of them.
If you are a pro at statistics and have noticed an increase or decrease in profits, have you raised it to your line manager?
Have you gone the extra mile to clear up a few databases, research new statistics or even fixed a problem with your own solution? Your value should always positively impact your organisation.
There are many ways in which you can make yourself more promotable.
Putting yourself out there around the office, by saying hello and making conversation, will ensure everyone in the company knows your name.
Improving your value will open many avenues for you.
If you know your role (and the company) back-to-front, then you can use your previous knowledge to your advantage in future, higher-ranking positions.

insights.title: Work relationships are important

actions.title: Start conversations.
actions.markdown: Whether it’s passing someone in the corridor or sharing an elevator, these day-to-day interactions are great networking opportunities - so don’t be shy!

actions.title: Find common ground.
actions.markdown: Common interests are a perfect way to build relationships with your co-workers, so ask them what they like to do out of work, and see if you can relate this to your own interests.

actions.title: Be positive.
actions.markdown: Maintaining a positive attitude when dealing with various situations will automatically draw our co-workers in, as positivity is infectious in the workplace.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you want to get promoted, then establishing and maintaining your relationships is twice as important as refining your skills.
You must be able to build positive relationships and connections with your team and senior managers.
"It's not just about who you know, it's about who knows you." \[Aimee Bateman\]

Establishing positive, work-balanced relationships and connections means that even when you are not in the room, your colleagues will speak of you highly, which is very important in building your "employee value".
When hiring managers open up new roles in the company, they'll look internally first, asking senior-ranking staff if they know anyone who'd be a great fit for the role.
So naturally, you need to expand your networking beyond your team and into other departments, in case other, exciting positions might come up in the future.
Building relationships at work benefits everyone involved.

If you were to create a working relationship with the individuals who have a stake in the organisation, they would be able to help you remain on track with your individual progress, perhaps even going a step further by mentoring you for a promotion.

insights.title: Rejection is actually a good thing

actions.title: Try again.
actions.markdown: If at first you don’t succeed...Trying again showcases your great willpower which is an essential trait if you want the promotion.

actions.title: Refine yourself
actions.markdown: Developing your skills is a must after a promotion rejection, so focus on the areas that need work. Ask for feedback from your hiring managers.

paragraphCards.markdown: Dealing with a promotion rejection can be tough.
Perhaps you're embarrassed that you've been rejected, and that others might know.
However, you can use this rejection to make you more determined to try again.

As Bateman teaches, the ability to handle rejection well is "part of being a leader - it's part of being a great, great ally within the business - proving you can build resilience, that you can deal with rejection."
Once you've spent some time building your skillset, most companies would want you to apply for that promotion again.
This is especially true if you can prove that you've learned from their previous 'no', and can prove how you've since developed your individual and professional character.
To be clear: just because you've been rejected from a promotion does not mean your 'employee value' has decreased.
It's perfectly normal to feel down about the rejection. Just remember that one door closed is another door open.
The ability to pick yourself back up again, and find the confidence to apply for future roles in future, display great leadership qualities, like willpower and resilience.
Appreciate the opportunity you were given. Now you can continue to hone your skills to make sure you'll be successful the next time you try.
"Private victory is already yours. You've already started improving. You've already succeeded. Nobody can take that away from you." \[Aimee Bateman\]
Getting promoted requires more than just doing your job – you have to go above and beyond what's expected of you.

It feels like an unspoken business rule: no one tells you about how to immerse yourself in company culture, network with others inside and outside of your team, or how to add enough value for you to get noticed.
But those who climb quickest up the career ladder do just that.

Career consultant Aimee Bateman is the founder of Careercake, an online platform that offers advice on every aspect of the workplace: from getting your ideas heard, tackling workplace discrimination, to tips for social anxiety.
Bateman's prime objective is to get her clients promoted, helping them build new skills, new relationships, and how to add value to a company and team.
With Bateman's expertise under your belt, you'll feel ready to handle any workplace-related problem with confidence and ease.
If you want to boost your confidence levels and secure that promotion you deserve, then this course is perfect for you.
In a few easy steps, you can become 'promotable'.
From building important networking skills to dealing with job rejections, How to be Promotable shows how you can increase your chances for a promotion in a few easy steps.
How To Develop Your Career Plan demonstrates that successfully building a successful career requires commitment and being proactive.

insights.title: A career plan helps us identify our next career move.

actions.title: Reflect on your current situation.
actions.markdown: Think about what you are looking forward to in your career as well as what you might be good at.

paragraphCards.markdown: Developing a career plan allows us to assess all of the options that are available to us, by giving us a chance to reflect, research and review.
Reflection involves thinking about what we are good at, whether on a professional or personal level; things that we might find interesting and might not have explored yet.
It also gives us a chance to explore how we want to feel in our next role, as well as what we hope to get from the role.
Developing a career plan also requires conducting some research.
The research process allows us to go beyond the available options to pick the right fit for ourselves.
For example, if we have an interest in writing we might look into becoming journalists or content writers.
Lastly, we will need to engage people to review the information and thoughts developed in the reflection and research stages.
There is a lot we can learn by bouncing ideas of friends and family if we allow ourselves to be open to feedback.
It's also really important to give this exercise the energy it deserves, because it will form the foundation of our career plan.

insights.title: When we put effort into creating a Personal Development Plan, we become focused.

actions.title: Make sure your objectives are SMART.
actions.markdown: Use the acronym SMART to measure how solid your goals are. SMART is for specific, measurable, attainable, relevant and timely.

paragraphCards.markdown: A Personal Development Plan (PDP) is the tangible product of a reflective process meant to help us focus on our goals better.
The plan clarifies what we need to do to reach our goals and if we take it seriously enough, it becomes easier to meet targets.
Because we are likely going to keep on adjusting our goals,a PDP is never quite finished; we need to constantly work on it, edit it and improve it.
Individuals and organizations alike can benefit from using this tool for personal and corporate development.

To get the most out of a PDP, it should be in plain sight where it can be easily and constantly reviewed; serving as a reminder of the goals that we have set for ourselves and what we need to do to achieve them.
It's also a good idea to have several copies in different places at home and at work.
Creating a Personal Development Plan is quite simple.
We can use a template from the internet, copy one from the office or just create our own from scratch using a program like Microsoft Excel.
All we have to do is start putting down our objectives and everything we need to do to get there.
This will be a guide towards the steps that need to be taken to achieve those objectives.

insights.title: It is important to have someone that will hold us accountable.

actions.title: Write down the characteristics of an ideal mentor.
actions.markdown: It’s easier to find the right mentor when we know what we are looking for and can constantly make a reference to a list.

paragraphCards.markdown: It is important to have at least one person to hold us accountable to our developmental goals, by motivating us, guiding us, sharing their experiences and helping to identify our blind spots.
That is where a mentor might be handy.

paragraphCards.markdown: This is a classic read-it-when-you-need-it book, perfect to reach for in those moments when we're not feeling like our best selves. ![giphy.com/barbara\_pozzi](https://media.giphy.com/media/J1eACEECR5feuN8Jq8/giphy.gif)
If you struggle a lot with shame and lack of self-esteem, then you could learn a lot from Brené Brown, and I Thought It Was Just Me (but it isn't).

insights.title: The first step of understanding shame is to define what it means to you

actions.title: Define your own shame.
actions.markdown: Think back to a few instances where you felt ashamed - that includes unworthiness, guilt, paranoia, and general insecurity. Define what it was for you, and why you felt it. That is the first step to forgiving yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: We talk about our feelings all the time, yet we know quite little about them.
When you say, "I'm hungry," do you know where that hunger comes from? What happens in your body when you feel it?

Hunger is an easy one, because it's mostly physical. But the situation becomes endlessly more complex when we try to understand shame. ![giphy.com/anchorpoint](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUPGcMuUXfnxchQwwg/giphy.gif)
In her initial research, Brené Brown interviewed over 300 people, after which she arrived at the following definition...
Shame is a deeply painful sensation that stems from the belief that we're not good enough, and that this shortcoming will prevent us from being accepted by and belonging to a group.
In that sense, shame usually arises in conjunction with other people. ![giphy.com/clarin\_](https://media.giphy.com/media/dZMEJb8sJUA5p6lrDR/giphy.gif)
For example, when we seek compassion by sharing one of our vulnerabilities, and end up being rejected instead.
However, this lack of empathy can also come from yourself. ![giphy.com/clarin\_](https://media.giphy.com/media/kgOrwiK82aY1M117QQ/giphy.gif)
What's important to understand about these shameful feelings is that the only one who can forgive you is yourself.

insights.title: Practicing critical awareness helps us better handle feelings of shame

actions.title: Always be critically aware.
actions.markdown: When something goes wrong, before you start to panic or worry, or generally let your emotions get the better of you, just step back. Take a moment to breathe. See the bigger picture and realize - it’s not your fault.

paragraphCards.markdown: The point of defining what shame means to us isn't so to have some arbitrary definition locked and loaded to spit out in a quiz show.
It's mostly a small step towards helping us notice when we feel ashamed.
Seeing ourselves from the outside in any present moment is the key to adjusting our reaction to the situation. ![giphy.com/qieerwang](https://media.giphy.com/media/ckFKmq1GO4OKGMtC3x/giphy.gif)
Dr. Brené Brown calls this "critical awareness".

For example, when she noticed her audience doze off during a talk she was giving, she reminded herself that they only had a short lunch break, and the promised pizza served at the end of the talk was the major incentive to be there in the first place.
By reminding herself of this, Brown prevented herself from retreating into shame mode, and kept her cool.
Critical awareness allows us to see why and how things happen, as they happen. ![giphy.com/jefcaine](https://media.giphy.com/media/6YjuKpfem6f0oR6gxN/giphy.gif)
It provides a chance to pause and see the big picture, before shame takes over and freezes our minds.
If we use this pause to consider the context of where the feeling of shame comes from, and address it directly, we can dodge the bullet.

insights.title: Anger is an easy outlet to channel shame into, but it’s not productive to do so

actions.title: Assess your anger.
actions.markdown: Next time you have an outburst, think about where it came from. Are you genuinely enraged by the situation - or are you covering up something else? Control your anger, and instead, try to be calm and controlled, choosing logic over emotion.

paragraphCards.markdown: Shame is a private, internal emotion.

However, if we don't have the critical awareness to identify when shame is creeping up on us, it can quickly descend into something a lot more visible: anger. ![giphy.com/chabaski\_](https://media.giphy.com/media/8PjBJEZ2Hd9rbSEDXG/giphy.gif)
Anger is a tempting cop-out when we're ashamed. ![giphy.com/rebeccahendin](https://media.giphy.com/media/1ziC1kBvFLrYGZWTIW/giphy.gif)

Blaming others feels relieving in the moment, creating the illusion of regaining control by taking charge, but we all know how this ends: we regret our outburst, know it's really our own fault, and ultimately feel worse.
Some common outlets of frustration include: traffic, noisy hotels, or lagging internet connections. ![giphy.com/slimjimstudios](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0HlKQPTHOGNUPTZm/giphy.gif)
While the Stoicism method is a useful way of fighting rising feelings, admitting that shame is part of the issue allows us to fix the issue a lot sooner.
Don't condemn anger, though. It's a useful emotion – just not when it's used to cover up another one.
"Shame corrodes the very part of us that believes we are capable of change." \[Brené Brown\]
Shame is one of our private emotions. Chances are, the less we openly talk about it, the more we feel it.

Whether it's getting rejected, getting fired, or lashing out on someone we shouldn't, we've all felt shame at some point, and psychologist Brené Brown's I Thought It Was Just Me (but it isn't) helps us further understand this painful, powerful emotion. [youtube.com/c/TED](https://youtu.be/psN1DORYYV0?t=832.70&e=852.00)

Here, Brown explores the way shame can impact our daily lives, and provides effective strategies to help us better combat it. ![/Brené\_Brown\_Wikipedia.jpg/512px-Brené\_Brown\_Wikipedia.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Bren%C3%A9_Brown_Wikipedia.jpg/512px-Bren%C3%A9_Brown_Wikipedia.jpg)
I Thought It Was Just Me (but it isn't) helps us understand and better manage the complicated and painful feeling of shame.
