paragraphCards.markdown: Ikigai is an incredible concept that can benefit many people.
Whether you feel stuck in your job, want to live longer, or just desire a deeper level of happiness and meaning, finding your reason to live will help you significantly.

insights.title: If you want happiness and long life, discover your ikigai – a reason to wake up in the morning

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Okinawa, Japan is home to some of the longest-living people in the world.
Their secret is ikigai.
The Japanese word has two characters: 'iki' which means life, and 'gai,' or value.
Finding your ikigai can be as simple as asking four basic questions...
1.  What are your strengths? Think of what you do better than everyone else.
2.  What does the world need? Imagine something you see that the world lacks.
3.  What are your passions? Picture the things that you could do all day without stopping.
4.  What can you earn a living doing? You have to make money from your craft, so how can you do that?
Your ikigai might take you a short time to discover, or it could take much longer.
Once you find it, however, you may realize that you never want or need to retire.
Retirement is associated with an increased risk for many health problems.
Searching your ikigai is the perfect way to never retire, and thus avoid deteriorating faster in your old age.
However, your ikigai doesn't _have to_ be connected to your job. Your purpose may come from a hobby or your family relationships.
Do whatever you find gets you up in the morning, just make sure that you never give it up.
Okinawans forced into retirement continue to stay active with their hobbies and in their community, which helps them live longer.
Research has shown that the elderly people of Okinawa have remarkably lower rates of dementia and heart disease as a result of their purpose and activity level.

insights.title: Okinawan elders know a thing or two about well-being, and we should follow their advice if we want to live as long as they do

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Seniors have so much wisdom to share with the world from their years of experience.
Those of us that are young might sometimes pretend like we know everything, but we should learn a thing or two about life from the generations before us.
One tip from Okinawan centenarians is to worry as little as possible.
It helps to slow down, take our time, and realize that we don't have to have it all figured out right away.
Anxiety has a myriad of negative health effects.
Focus on enjoying life for what you have, instead of being afraid of what might go wrong.
A great way to do this is to connect with everyone around you, even strangers.
Okinawan old-timers suggest smiling and having an open-heart towards everybody you meet.
Your friendliness will help you develop many friendships throughout life.
Okinawan elders recommend maintaining those relationships as well.
When you become a grandparent your replacement of worry with friends may also help your grandchildren visit more often.
Japanese centenarians also endorse eating healthy, waking up early, and making sure you have enough movement throughout your day.

insights.title: A key component of staying healthy is to keep moving throughout the day, no matter how little

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Residents of Okinawa suggest that you don't always need to play a sport or go running to be healthy.
Longevity and health are more about finding simple, consistent ways to move more through the day.
Intensity may deter consistency, so Okinawans strive for simplicity in their forms of exercise.
A walk around the neighborhood or a day in the garden are just a few simple ways they maintain movement frequently.
Radio Taiso, a Japanese radio show, has helped Okinawans exercise for years.
Large groups of Japanese tune into the station and listen to directions on how to exercise.
In the present day, most watch online or on the television, but the show still continues throughout the day in Japan.
With simple exercises, like lifting your arms above your head and bringing them down again, Radio Taiso is an easy to repeat form of exercise for the Japanese.
Whether you find an exercise program like that or not, always make time for small, consistent amounts of movement in your day.
"Essentials to happiness in life are something to do, something to love, and something to hope for." \[Hector Garcia Puigcerver\]
Do you want to live a long life? How about a happy one? What if you could have both?
The secret to a long life actually comes from finding joy and purpose every day.
Most of us think of these ideals as mere dreams that only a select few achieve.
The people of Japan, however, have practiced ikigai, their "reason to live," for centuries. It helps them live longer, more joyful lives.
This practice is what makes Japan part of the five 'Blue Zones' of the world, where people live the longest.
Many people find themselves trapped in the never-ending need to do everything faster, better, and harder.
In contrast, discovering our ikigai will help us slow down and enjoy life more. Identifying our life's purpose also helps us live longer.
Hector Puigcerver, author of Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life, is a native European who moved to Japan in 2004 and became enamored with Japanese culture.
In this book, he breaks down how we can use ikigai to live better.
Ikigai explains how we can live a longer and happier life by having a purpose, eating healthy, and not retiring.
Set foot on your allyship journey as soon as you can!
There are many people just like you who are committed to making the world a better place, where everyone is treated fairly and with respect.

insights.title: Be brave and realize that allyship starts with you

actions.title: Befriend others who are on the same mission as you.
actions.markdown: Surround yourself and build relationships with people who are as dedicated as you in becoming a true ally and creating a world free from prejudice.

actions.title: Call out oppression whenever you witness it.
actions.markdown: Never be silenced by fear. Be brave enough to reprimand actions of bias, prejudice, discrimination, and oppression.

actions.title: Take accountability for your mistakes.
actions.markdown: Being courageous is not about whether or not you’ll make a mistake. It has more to do with your willingness to take responsibility for the mistakes you’ll inevitably make along the way.

paragraphCards.markdown: Make time to self-assess, and evaluate what you're capable of.
Identify your biases, skills, and expertise that may come useful along the way.
It's also critically important to surround yourself with like-minded people who are on the same journey as you. This community will help continuously improve your way of thinking and behavior.
As you progress on your journey, you will inevitably come across people who are biased, discriminating, and oppressive.
When this happens, it's not enough to turn a blind eye and be silenced by fear.
Be courageous enough to rebuke wrongful doings. Develop a specific approach to influence that will help you persuade people to join you on your allyship journey.
Be ready for possible complications that you may encounter along the way.
Understand that mistakes are bound to happen, but it's how you take accountability for your actions that matters.
Ultimately, being brave is all about practicing the four Cs, namely: capacity, community, context, and complications – the fundamental principles of courage.

insights.title: Practice cultural humility by staying humble

actions.title: Receive constructive criticism without being defensive.
actions.markdown: When someone expresses that your behavior or joke has offended you, keep an open mind. Focus on honing your emotional intelligence so that you avoid reacting in a defensive manner.

actions.title: Remember that even if something doesn’t offend you, it might offend somebody else.
actions.markdown: Practice empathy and be sensitive to how others feel, because you never know how something that may seem insignificant to you could trigger someone’s emotions.

actions.title: Accept that you don’t have to be right all the time.
actions.markdown: Overcome your unnecessary urge to be right all the time. Be humble enough to swallow your pride when you’re wrong.

paragraphCards.markdown: We're so caught up in wanting those around us to understand our intentions that we forget to be understanding ourselves.
This is why empathy, and our ability to put ourselves in somebody else's shoes, is crucial in cultural humility.
We don't necessarily have to agree with everyone we meet, we just have to respect their feelings.
Shift your perspective and view feedback as a gift rather than offensive criticism.
When someone approaches you to let you know that you've offended them in some way with your words or actions, resist the urge to defend yourself.
You don't always have to explain yourself, you just have to be humble enough to just listen and respect what somebody has to say.
Most importantly, accept that there are some things that may not seem like a big deal to us but could hurt someone else's feelings.
Unless we have walked in that person's shoes, we will never understand how these small details could lead to a lot of pain.
By practicing humility, it will be easier for us to remain focused on the person we want to be an ally to.

insights.title: Dedicate your life to your continuous allyship journey

actions.title: Commit to a lifetime of learning.
actions.markdown: Spend time reading books, taking courses, and listening to podcasts regularly to demonstrate your commitment to a lifelong journey of continuous education.

actions.title: Take good care of yourself.
actions.markdown: Help and support other people, but don’t forget to make time to take care of yourself too.

actions.title: Leverage your privilege to support others.
actions.markdown: If you have the privilege of a formal education, significant financial means, or any other advantage you may possess, make use of your blessings. Share your knowledge and help other people in need!

paragraphCards.markdown: Allyship is a lifetime journey, not a one-stop destination, so you must be willing to commit your life in creating a world free of prejudice.
Continuous learning is also a vital part of this process. Read books everyday, listen to podcasts, take courses, and always be in pursuit of knowledge.
Taking good care of yourself will also enable you to take better care of others.
This may feel counterintuitive to you at first, but as the famous saying goes, "you can't give from the bottom of an empty cup."
Build relationships with people who are as dedicated as you in the journey of allyship to surround yourself with positivity.
Find sources of inspiration that will motivate you to keep going. It could be your natural environment or the people within your community.
Don't forget to celebrate achievements every step of the way, no matter how small they seem.

paragraphCards.markdown: Using lessons learnt from Influence People with Persuasion Psychology, it's relatively easy to begin using the fundamental Social Psychology principles and techniques here.
The lessons make it even possible to develop our own persuasion techniques.

insights.title: As much as possible, do your negotiating in person rather than over email

actions.title: Make the request face-to-face.
actions.markdown: Others are much more likely to yield to a request when you make it in person. So if you can, make it in person.

paragraphCards.markdown: "On average, if people are asking you a favor in person, you're much more likely to say yes than if the same person emailed to you that request." \[Andrew Luttrell, PhD\]
Have you ever found yourself avoiding starting up a difficult conversation, because the thought of doing so makes you feel so uncomfortable?

Let's say you need a colleague at work to help out with a big task, but you know that this colleague is already at full capacity. You know the request will annoy your colleague, even though you need their help, and you get scared of even asking.
Because you're nervous about a confrontation, you end up asking the colleague over an email - and probably with a few phrases like "sorry to ask!" and "I know how busy you are!" in there too.
Research proves that you're much more likely to find success in persuading others when you ask in person.
Research participants regularly report feeling much more awkward about turning someone down in-person, particularly if they had to make direct eye contact.
On the other hand, participants found it much easier to let someone down over email for the exact reason that they didn't have to witness their reaction.
The next you need to persuade someone to get on-board with whatever it is you're doing, make sure you talk to them in person.

insights.title: Once committed, people are more likely to see it through

actions.title: Get your foot in the door.
actions.markdown: We can start by making a small request that we know sounds relatively reasonable and then follow up with a bigger request after the person has already committed to the first request.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Through the Consistency Principle, you can gain compliance by creating opportunities for the other person to be consistent. by creating situations in which for the person to not comply, it would be inconsistent. That's when you'll see the most compliance because people want to be consistent. so give them that opportunity." \[Andrew Luttrell, PhD\]
We are socialized to feel that when we make a commitment to someone else, we have to see it through.
Typically, people find it difficult to back out of their commitments as they don't want to be seen as shallow or inconsistent.
As masters of persuasion, we can use this psychological tendency to our advantage. This is called the Consistency Principle.
If you want others to help you on a large task, don't immediately lay out how big the task is. All you need to do is to ask for their help.

Once they've agreed to this request, then you can lay out in detail what you'll need for them. However, if someone knows right from the start how large your task is, there's a pretty good chance they will say "no".
People hate breaking promises or going back on their word. So once they've made a commitment, they'll stick to it, even if it wasn't what they originally agreed to.

insights.title: Perceived short supply drives demand

actions.title: Create the perception of scarcity.
actions.markdown: By creating the impression that an item will be available for a short period of time we can increase perception of scarcity and therefore that item's value. This strategy also helps to create a sense of urgency, which produces more results.

paragraphCards.markdown: People have a tendency to believe that "things that are inaccessible to us are somehow more valuable than the things that are readily available".
As a result, people are more motivated to get something if they believe that it is in short supply.
This means that we can make something more desirable by "creating a perception of scarcity".
It's a technique that is quite popular with marketers because when people perceive the product or service to be in limited supply they rush to get as much of it as possible.

"People value something scarce even more when it was once abundant. If something has always been limited in quantity, then it is certainly seemingly valuable, but when it was once abundant and now it's not, now the perception of value goes way up." \[Andrew Luttrell, PhD\]
"When it comes down to it, just ask." \[Andrew Luttrell, PhD\]

insights.title: The Power of Interior Design

actions.title: Take a look at the interior of your home and identify areas that do not have balance and are not harmonious
actions.markdown: You can start on your interior design journey by identifying issues in your own home. This could be something as simple as decluttering an area so that it emits more positive energy.

paragraphCards.markdown: We may not be aware of how powerful interior design is, but Lauren Cox does.
In Interior Design Basics: Simple Steps to Your Perfect Space she explains how a chaotic space that is not well-designed can have an adverse effect on our mood by creating negative energy.
For this reason, interior design is not just about creating a visually appealing space.
It also involves creating a harmonious and balanced atmosphere in our home.
The way we design the interior of our home needs to reflect the way that we use it, and we need to think carefully about what we do in each space, such as entertaining or working.
Having this awareness means that we can ensure the choices we make create the practical, creative, and supportive environment that we need.

However, Cox explains why we do not have to start from scratch to embrace the power of interior design; "I think with interior design, you really can make changes on any budget and it doesn't mean that you have to start from square one. We can work with the pieces that you already have to create a space that feels really lovely and representative of who you are".
We can start to make changes to our environment without investing significant financial resources.

insights.title: Interior Design Principles

actions.title: Take a look at the color wheel and choose colors that you would use for your interior design
actions.markdown: Remember that you should usually choose a main color to focus on. You can then choose at least two complementary colors for accents or features in your interior spaces. These colors should be next to or opposite your main color on the color wheel.

paragraphCards.markdown: In the course "Interior Design Basics: Simple Steps to Your Perfect Space", Lauren Cox introduces us to four principles of interior design; color, balance, scale & proportion, and rhythm & repetition.

As she says, "You could be mid-century, you can have an eclectic touch, you could be a really transitional or traditional style, and no matter what your style is it all comes back to these key principles of interior design."
These principles act as a foundation for our interior design exploits.
They give us the guidelines we need which we can use along with our creativity.
Cox explains that using color involves looking at the color wheel and concentrating on a main color with at least two complementary colors to add an accent.
These accents can be in the form of artwork or pieces of furniture.
Balance is about the use of asymmetry and symmetry to ensure that our space feels as though everything has its place.
Scale & proportion is the most mathematical of the four principles discussed in "Interior Design Basics: Simple Steps to Your Perfect Space".
It requires us to determine how the items we choose fit with each other and within the interior of our home.
Finally, rhythm & repetition involves designing a space so that the eye knows exactly how to travel through it.
We can make use of information such as color trends, and design trends on sites like Pinterest, to get inspiration for the design choices that we make while using these principles.
However, we always need to be mindful of our own preferences and tastes when making decisions.

insights.title: Understanding Our Own Design Style

actions.title: Look at the different styles that you see around you and online and make a note of what appeals to you.
actions.markdown: The best way to define your style choices is to look for styles around you that inspire you. You should then determine what you like about the style, whether it be colors, shapes, or patterns. You can take this information and put it to use designing the interior of your personal space.

paragraphCards.markdown: Lauren Cox talks to us about how we should take the design principles of color, balance, scale & proportion, and rhythm & repetition and see how they fit into our own personal style preferences.
In "Interior Design Basics: Simple Steps to Your Perfect Space" she explains how we can define our style, combine it with other styles, and allow it to evolve.
Cox explains that "Havenly Interior Designs", the company where she is a design program manager, has developed four groups of styles that have their own sub-groups.
These groups are classic, contemporary, modern, and eclectic.
Classic encompasses designs like farmhouse and traditional.
We often see muted colors and a lot of symmetry in this type of design.
Modern styles are usually minimalistic.
Function is usually at the forefront of this type of design and furnishings mostly have a defined purpose.
Eclectic designs feature many colors and patterns with the appearance of being collated over time.
We have to be careful with this type of design as it can appear chaotic if it is not well thought out and executed.
Contemporary designs tend to involve aspects of the other design styles.
They are often simple with perhaps an added pop of design or color.
Cox shows us that our own style will normally be a sub-group of more than one of these main styles.
We can look for inspiration on sites like Pinterest and even in the world around us.
We can then put this inspiration to use to help us understand where our own design preferences lie.

"We spend a lot of time in our home, so it's really important that they feel really beautiful and representative of who we are as an individual. paragraphCards.markdown: In Introduction to Philosophy, expert lecturers from the University of Edinburgh teach you the basic principles of philosophy, from its meaning to its political and moral dimensions, and show you how to think about the world around you, as well as your life!
Use this course as the encouragement you need to start deeper conversations with your friends. Why is the world the way it is, and is there any other way it could be?

insights.title: Philosophy is about learning how to think differently

actions.title: Be a little more like the skeptics.
actions.markdown: Philosophical skeptics, like David Hume, believe that philosophy answers questions about how our minds perceive the world, but that perception could always be wrong, and we ought to question it.

actions.title: Walk the walk.
actions.markdown: Philosophy is not just about metaphysical thinking -it needs to be practiced. Implement techniques for verifying validity, soundness, and arguments.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Philosophy is that distinction between thinking in a particular way, and working out whether some way of thinking is the right way. It corresponds to the distinction between some particular academic subject, and doing philosophy about that subject." \[Dr. David Ward, Senior Lecturer at University of Edinburgh\]
While participating in science is about the action of practicing in scientific studies, participating in philosophy is defined as the act of thinking about various objects and activities.

With that in mind, philosophy about science revolves around asking ourselves questions about science and putting it in perspective, thinking about its implications. It's an activity, rather than a subject of study.
Philosophy can be practiced on any subject or topic, imaginary or real.
Important tools that need to be implemented to think "right" include questioning the validity and soundness of an argument, as well as the justifications for its premises.
Sharpen your critical thinking with the Getter cases.
The Getter cases put justifications in perspective.
We could see the hour on a clock and trust it, but what if the clock had stopped functioning without us knowing? The lesson here: Do not always accept things for what they appear to be.
If you want to use testimony as an argument or proof, you could assume, like philosopher Thomas Reid, that humans are generally trustworthy, and therefore take testimony as fact.
However, you could also (like philosopher David Hume) consider testimony as unreliable justification, and seek further information on which to base your reasoning.

insights.title: Practice asking yourself questions to boost your philosophical abilities

actions.title: Envision new possibilities.
actions.markdown: Even knowledge is a concept that philosophers argue about: considered unattainable by the skeptics like Hume, and reachable through science by the scientific realists.

actions.title: Be sharp and precise; wording is everything.
actions.markdown: Be careful with your word choice, particularly when making arguments! Obeying the law means following it by belief, while complying with the law means following it by pure obligation.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Philosophers, a bit like the child, are always asking more questions, always demanding that we step back further. But they're also a bit like the adult who's trying to talk to the child, trying to answer and explain their own questions."
Questioning is the number one tool of an aspiring philosopher. This means that philosophers are not only tasked with asking questions, but also must try and come up with the answers.
Basic terms such as knowledge, friendship, or law seem easy to understand.
But if you take a step back and truly ask yourself what these everyday concepts mean, and how they impact our reality, you might be surprised at the complexity of the answers.
Let's take the keyword 'morals', for example. In philosophy, morals can be considered under three different categories.
1), Objectivism states that morality is equivalent to the objective truth.
2), Emotivism views morality only as a reflection of our emotional state, so it cannot be true or false, because our own feelings impact how we perceive the world.
3), Relativism only views morals in relation to something else. For this one concept, there are three schools of thought regarding the most accurate definition of the word.
Any topic can be redefined, researched, questioned, debated. Whatever you think you know, or don't know, you might just realize that you're wrong!

insights.title: Time travel is a legitimate philosophical dilemma

actions.title: Fuel your imagination.
actions.markdown: Philosophy is not only about questioning what we see; it’s also about wondering about what could be.

actions.title: See every possibility as potentially fruitful, but keep an eye open for contradictions.
actions.markdown: With time travel comes the question of meeting your past self, and therefore bi-locating. But is that even possible?

paragraphCards.markdown: "An interesting question from physics and time travel: what sort of laws of nature would govern the physical world that had systems that time travel in it?" \[Dr. Alisdair Richmond, Senior Lecturer at University of Edinburgh\]
Time travel has fascinated the masses for many years.
Explored through movies, books, and even comics, the concept of time travel has allowed all of us to begin a philosophical quest to understand what it means to break the barrier of time.
One of the most fascinating concepts in relation to time travel is the grandfather paradox.

The major objection to the possibility of time travel is the idea that a person going back in time would necessarily cause, by their actions, contradictions to the outcomes that are supposed to happen in the present.

If you went back in time, and accidentally distracted your grandfather from meeting your grandmother, this action would be contradictory with your very existence - which is why the grandfather paradox is the biggest objection to Lewis's theory.

However, after many years of research, american philosopher David Lewis rejected the grandfather paradox. His studies ruled that time travel is logically possible, because you'd never end up distracting your grandfather.
In fact, if you were to time travel, you'd ultimately fail at any goal to disrupt the past.

Whether it's a malfunctioning weapon, a distracting meeting with a beautiful stranger, or even slipping in a puddle, something would always get in your way to prevent you from changing the course of history!

"A fascinating argument from David Deutsch and Michael Lockwood argues that realistic physics would have to imagine that time travel takes place in many, many histories." \[Dr. Alisdair Richmond, Senior Lecturer at University of Edinburgh\]
"Philosophy needs vision and argument." \[David Hume, Scottish philosopher\]
Do you ever stop and wonder at the infinite curiosity of a child, constantly asking questions about how the universe works, and why things are the way they are?
The childlike sense of needing to understand our surroundings is the core drive of any aspiring philosopher.
If you want to learn more about philosophy and its inner workings, curiosity is the only thing you need to get started.

Whether you have a background in human sciences or not, expanding your consciousness in a way that allows you to further your understanding of life, human relationships, or even the physical world is what philosophy aims to provide.

In this course, the University of Edinburgh's Eidy Research Center opens its door to teach you the basic principles of asking questions, thinking more expansively – and, ultimately, making better life decisions.
Is morality universal? Are governments to be obeyed or challenged? Is time travel possible, and what would it entail?
These are questions that this course will help you think about, learn about, and answer in multiple ways, because that's what philosophy is all about.
Philosophical thinking will guide you down an infinity of paths. It encourages participants to expand their perspectives, critical abilities, and decision-making.
Are you ready to quench your thirst for knowledge?
In Introduction to Philosophy, senior lecturers from the University of Edinburgh's Eidy research center deliver an easy-to-digest, eye-opening course on the basic principles of philosophy.
Though a lot of the listening techniques in Just Listen probably aren't anything new to anyone who has read books on communication, there is plenty to learn here.
Goulston combines psychiatry and research to give readers excellent tips they can use to get through to people in everyday life.
From learning how to make great first impressions to convincing an angry person to think rationally again, there are many lessons in how to improve the way you listen and talk to others.

insights.title: If you want productive conversations, listen first

actions.title: Give others the space to talk.
actions.markdown: The next time a friend approaches you with a problem, give them the space to offload their emotions without trying to jump in with a solution, particularly if they seem stressed or upset. Sometimes your friends just want a shoulder to lean on.

paragraphCards.markdown: Have you ever been in a situation where you're stressed out about something, but when you seek comfort from a friend, they immediately try to come up with solutions?
The truth is, whenever we feel big emotions, we don't want advice. We just want to share what's happening and have someone listen to and feel with us.
When we listen to others first, we give them ample chance to talk about their concerns and how they feel.
Listening first gives others the space they need to start thinking it through and disputing irrational feelings if necessary.
To illustrate this lesson, Goulston gives an example of a man who has a gun to his head and is ready to take his own life.
When the police and negotiations team arrive, they try to calm him down by pointing out there are other options but aren't getting through to him.
Another officer approaches and listens to the man. He says something to the effect of: "I'll bet you feel this is the only way out."
The man says yes, and the officer listens to his feelings.
After a little while, the man starts to calm down and consider options other than ending his own life.

insights.title: To listen and be receptive, we must activate the rational part of our brain

actions.title: Encourage verbalizing difficult emotions.
actions.markdown: Let your friends know that your company is a safe, judgement-free zone. Allow your friends to put words to their feelings, even those they’re ashamed of, so they’ll be able to analyze them a little more rationally.

paragraphCards.markdown: When it comes to thinking about the world around us, we have three main layers of thinking.
The first layer is our instinctual, reptilian brain.
It is responsible for fight-or-flight, and is quick to react, even before analyzing.
The second layer is the mammalian layer, and it's a bit more advanced than the reptilian.
This part runs on emotions.
When we feel overwhelming feelings of anger, love, or sadness, they're coming from the mammalian part of our brain.
The last (and most evolved) part of our brain is our rational layer. It collects evidence, analyzes, and arrives at logical conclusions based on the data from the other layers.
The important lesson from these layers is that we need to make sure that the person we are talking to is using their rational layer.
When we feel threatened, the immediate reaction is to use either our emotional brain or the reptilian fight-or-flight.
But if we can express these feelings out loud, we allow ourselves to cool down and figure out a solution.
On the flip-side, when we are communicating with others, we need to let them work through their feelings before those emotions become a problem.
Once we listen and address how they feel, others will feel understood, and can listen with their rational part of their brain to what we have to say.

insights.title: If we’re vulnerable, others will want to listen to us

actions.title: Bare your neck.
actions.markdown: Openly admitting to your emotions, especially negative ones like sadness, shame, or fear, will make space for your conversational partner to do the same. Remember: vulnerability encourages connection.

paragraphCards.markdown: When all seems lost, "bare your neck."
When you don't feel like you are getting anywhere and start to feel angry, try instead to reach inside and show your vulnerable side.
Let's admit it: it's hard to be vulnerable.
But vulnerability is an invaluable tool for communication.
When we show emotions of sadness or fear, it gives people the chance to connect with us.
Chances are, they have felt the way you're feeling. And when you share your vulnerable feelings, others will feel for you and want to help.
The less vulnerable we are with people, the less likely they are to want to listen to us.
Vulnerability allows for connection.
And furthermore, when we are vulnerable, people are more likely to be open and honest with us.
When we allow people to be vulnerable with us in turn, both conversational partners can work to find out what's behind each other's emotions.
"Perceiving is just believing. Misperceiving is deceiving – and worse yet, prevents achieving." \[Mark Goulston\]
Have you ever talked to someone who only talks about themselves?
They'll tell you all about their last vacation or their kids. Yet they don't care to ask you about your life. Isn't it kind of exhausting?

It's hard to talk to people like this because a good conversation requires reciprocation. As humans, we want to be heard and understood, and we need to give people that in return by listening to them.
What if we need to get a message across to someone else?
How do we get them to listen to us?
We often have situations where we need to get through to people; whether it's a disgruntled employee, an insecure spouse, or an unhappy client.
To convince people to listen to us, we simply need to listen to them first.
If you want to learn how to get people invested in what you have to say, and reach those who seem unreachable, Just Listen is the book for you.
Author Mark Goulston is a psychiatrist and business coach for major organizations.
Using the most up-to-date research on listening and persuasion techniques, he helps us get our message across to just about anyone by learning to listen better.
Just Listen teaches us how to communicate our messages to anyone with proven listening and persuasion techniques.

We live in a time of technology, with a plethora of dating apps readily available at our fingertips. But the quest for true love is as difficult as ever, and Weigel's work is a great hack into finding our way to it.

insights.title: Dating was invented when women started moving to cities

paragraphCards.markdown: Out of all things, the one you'd least expect to yield a big influence over dating is probably economics.
Yet, without some economic developments, we wouldn't even be dating at all.
The Industrial Revolution with its shift towards big factories and lots of manual labor required a lot of workers in one place.
The factories huddled together, creating infrastructure around them and big cities were born.
Women moving to the city worked mostly as factory workers, sales personnel, and house servants.
Before then, relationships were in the hands of parents and relatives, the matchmakers of the 19th century.
But now, both men and women were out of the house, independent, and had a chance to meet one another.

Because few people could afford spending money on entertainment like a night at the theater or a restaurant, let alone big apartments that weren't crowded with 7-8 people, most dating was done in public.
People snuck away some quiet, romantic time in parks or dark alleyways.
The wealthier middle class "called" on each other instead.
Men knocked at a woman's door, a servant would take the name and if the lady was interested, the two would spend some quality time with each other – under strict supervision, of course!

insights.title: Consumption became a central part of dating in the 1920s – and it still is today

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Historically, the wealthier middle class are the reason dating sites like OkCupid ask for your brand preferences before your personality traits, and why Tinder thrives on judging people's looks.
The women working as sales reps in shops in the early 1900s, so-called "shopgirls", infused dating with a big chunk of consumption. Here's how:
Since only rich people could afford to shop, working in a shop was a good way to meet a rich man, and turn that man into a rich husband.
The shopgirls mimicked rich women so perfectly in their behavior and exclusive taste that it was hard to tell the difference between who was shopping in a store, and who was working there.

This new model of judging people based upon their taste and consumer preferences stuck, and it still influences us today: we check what kind of movies, brands and artists people like on Facebook, and a big part of first impressions is how people dress, including what the label says.

insights.title: Today’s hookup culture started all the way back in the 1950s

paragraphCards.markdown: Being a parent in the 1950s wasn't a lot of fun.
All you knew about dating was for finding a spouse, and now your children start telling you they're "going steady" with their latest girlfriend or boyfriend.
While technically, going steady meant dating, it also meant there was a decent chance you'd sleep with each other – or, at the very least, wouldn't stop at kissing and hugging.
The younger generation saw this as a ritual for coming of age, much more than a lifetime commitment to a single-person and so premarital sex became more and more accepted.
By the mid-50s, going steady was such a huge trend that children tried it as early as 11 years old!
Of course parents were worried a lot about this.
They weren't familiar with the idea, and were afraid their children would just sleep around.

The institution of marriage wasn't really hurt in the end, but a significant portion of people who married in the 50s later admitted they had definitely given out more than hug and kiss to potential partners before finally settling down.

"There's no better life than a life spent laboring at love – exerting effort not because we have to, but because we believe that what we are bringing into being is valuable and we want it to exist." \[Moira Weigel\]
There's always something to complain about when looking at the current state of dating.

Maybe you didn't want an arranged marriage in 1884. Some will have thought it sucked you had to make lots of money to be attractive in the 1920s. And not everyone was happy with the whole "free love" thing in the 60s.
The fact of the matter is: Dating is going to be what it's going to be.
Whatever era you're alive in, you're just gonna have to deal with it and find your way anyway.
Moira Weigel, a PhD candidate at Yale has written just the book for it. It's called Labor of Love: The Invention of Dating.
Labor of Love illustrates the history of modern dating as we know it, starting from its origins in the late 1800s all the way to the dating websites and apps we know today.

Jeff Walker is a fascinating, humble man, so if you're into biographies, the full book is worth a read. However, if you want to start an online business as quickly as possible, the nuts and bolts of Walker's launch formula is more than enough to get started.

insights.title: The money is in the list

actions.title: Start a squeeze page.
actions.markdown: The primary goal of a squeeze page is to get your users to sign up for an offer, and put in their email. Keep your squeeze page content to a minimum, offering a deal so enticing that users will jump to get your updates in their inbox.

paragraphCards.markdown: Even if it sounds cheesy, it's true: The money is in the list. If you're not active in the internet marketing space, you might not be familiar with the expression.
This "list" Jeff Walker is talking about is an email list.
Even though the social media buzz killed a lot of email's popularity, it is still considered the medium with the highest engagement by most marketers.

Emails have a long half-life, meaning they don't disappear into oblivion after the first 10 seconds (like a Twitter post), the first 4 hours (like an Instagram picture), or the first day (like a Facebook post).
Many more people interact with emails than do with posts on social media, and can you remember the last time you changed your email?
You'd probably change your phone number first.
What's more, with an email address, you own people's contact information. That's not the case for ANY other platform.
Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, they can all shut down your account tomorrow and you're left with nothing. But you can always reach out to people whose email you have.
It's hard to grasp how powerful a list is, but can you think of an event hall in your town that seats 1,000 people? Think of it as filled to the brim.
Now, imagine you could send an email to all of these people at the same time, telling them all about your latest product at once.
Boom! And that's just 1,000 subscribers, which you can get in 3 months. Imagine a list of 100,000 people. Mind blowing, right?
To get started, all you need is a simple squeeze page, where people only have two options: Sign up for your list in exchange for a gift, or leave.

insights.title: Use a pre-launch to build up excitement before your actual launch

actions.title: Harness the power of a pre-launch.
actions.markdown: Build anticipation for your product release by offering enticing product teasers in the run-up to the event. This step isn’t about giving everything away before launch; more, to spark enough curiosity that you’re guaranteed attention on launch-day.

paragraphCards.markdown: Remember how the world could not WAIT for the latest Star Wars movie to be released, spurned on by the countless teasers: trailers, gimmicks, talk show appearances and behind the scenes clips?
That's the power of Hollywood marketing, and there's no reason you can't do the same.
Internet marketing pioneer Jeff Walker suggests giving your email list three great pieces of content the week before you launched, spaced 2-3 days apart each.
He calls this a pre-launch, and it serves the purpose of building buzz and anticipation around your product.
Video is a great medium for this, as it's always perceived to be high quality.

If done right, people will already eagerly wait for your actual launch to start by the time you make your product available and hopefully, just like a movie theatre on Star Wars release day, they'll beat down the front door.

insights.title: Use seed launches to sell ideas before building them

actions.title: Test the waters with a seed launch.
actions.markdown: Use a seed launch to rouse interest in your product before it’s even hit the shelves. Once you’ve approached people with your idea, update once in a while via email with product developments to keep the idea fresh in their minds.

paragraphCards.markdown: What if we fancy ourselves as budding entrepreneurs, but have no idea for a product, nor an email list to launch it to?
Here's a good way to start. Jeff calls it the seed launch.

First, you come up with an idea. You approach people about the idea 1-on-1 and build a very small email list (less than 100 people). Then you launch the idea to that list, giving them the option to buy.
Notice how "build the product" isn't part of the process. In a seed launch, you only build the idea once enough people have confirmed that they want it.

That way, you can make sure your idea doesn't fall flat on its face, you make a bit of money, and can then later launch an incredibly refined product to a much bigger audience. It's a win on every level.
If you've ever pre-ordered a copy of an online course or even a book, then that was probably what went down behind the scenes.
The world has changed, and the only true security is your ability to create value and get paid for that value." \[Jeff Walker\]
Say what you will – some people have impeccable timing.
Like when Jeff Walker discovered that you could sell via email in 1996.
Being one of the early internet marketing pioneers, he's had quite some time to build and perfect the way he markets products online over the past 20 years.
When he realized that even at professional conferences, no one knew what he was talking about, he took on the responsibility of teaching others how to launch as well.

He has a course called Product Launch Formula, and Launch shares much of that in book-form, plus gives a lot of context on his biography and how many of the most successful launches he did came to be.
If you don't know what a launch is, who you're supposed to launch to, and what to do to get started, we've got you covered.

Launch is an early internet entrepreneur's step-by-step blueprint to creating products people want, launching them from the comfort of our home, and building the life you've always wanted, thanks to the power of psychology, email, and the internet.

There are many great examples in Leaders Eat Last of both good and bad leadership in action. The evolutionary standpoint the book took is refreshing, explaining how leadership even became necessary – and the idea that safety means progress is a real eye-opener too.

insights.title: Safety means progress, and leaders provide safety

actions.title: Build a circle of safety around your team.
actions.markdown: Divide up tasks according to your team’s strengths. Try to avoid scattering responsibilities absent-mindedly, and instead assign one big ‘responsibility’ each. As a leader, it’s your job to take care of picking up anything else.

paragraphCards.markdown: Think about the last time you made significant progress on a fun little side project of yours, where there was nothing to gain but the joy of doing it.
Were you worried about paying that month's bills? Probably not.
You could focus entirely on making progress on this side project because, in that particular moment, your basic needs were already secured.
If your basic needs weren't spoken for, it's unlikely that you would've been able to spend 8 hours playing guitar.
Our brain always defaults to safety mode, and the reason is simple: it had to in the past, or we wouldn't be here.
Today all of our safety problems revolve around money, but our ancestors had tons of safety issues.
Our ancestors had to hide from enemies, avoid diseases, hunt and gather their own food, and, oh, run away from saber-tooth tigers.
Progress only started happening once our ancestors decided to work together and start delegating tasks.
For example, if your caveman friend Joseph took care of collecting berries while your cavewoman friend Jenny looked for a nice cave, it would've left you time to focus on crafting a new spear.
That's why a leader's job is to provide safety to his followers so that they can focus on making progress towards their shared vision.
The bigger the circle of safety around the group, the faster the progress.

For example, Google draws a pretty awesome circle of safety around its employees. Free food, ask-any-question meetings, and 20% time put aside for experimenting with projects is a pretty safe environment to be in.
Once you're not worried about avoiding threats, you can start improving.

insights.title: Responsibility means truly caring about other people, so don’t get detached

actions.title: Invest in your team.
actions.markdown: Make your employees’ wellness a priority by organizing team bonding activities or care packages. If you bump into an employee in the corridor or in the elevator, strike up a conversation with them, no matter their rank in the company.

paragraphCards.markdown: Let's say we manage the finances of our company. In that case, our responsibility might be to allocate the budget in such a way that we maximize the profits.
But in reality, it's our job to make sure the money goes to the people that will use it the best.
Maybe you want to shut down a division. If so, you're not only shutting down a part of the company, you're robbing people of their safety, by firing them from their jobs.
This doesn't mean you should try to save everyone, but you have to be aware that the consequences of your actions as a leader directly impact the lives of people.
That's why empathy is the most important trait of a leader. If you can really put yourself into other people's shoes, you will truly care about them, and thus be worth for them to follow you.
It's easy to become detached as your company grows, but nothing good comes from focusing too heavy on money and logistics.
You don't want to become the kind of leader that makes decisions at the expense of human beings.
For example, in 2009, the Peanut Corporation of America knowingly shipped contaminated peanuts to maintain cash flow, causing a nationwide salmonella crisis.

It's easy to blast out a mass email. But it's a great reminder to remember that there's a human being behind every email address. No matter how many employees you're managing, you should never lose sight of that.

insights.title: Technology has turned us into performance addicts constantly looking for the next dopamine hit

actions.title: Keep an eye on your social media usage.
actions.markdown: Social media can be a useful tool if used strategically, but if you’re starting to feel drained, then cut down on your hours and phone up a friend instead.

paragraphCards.markdown: Once upon a time, our ancestors relied on adrenaline rushes of dopamine to help them escape larger-sized predators.
While we don't spend so much of our time these days running away from bears, our brains are still regularly hit with dopamine. How? Through social media.
These days, if we want a quick rush of dopamine, we change our profile picture on Facebook.
Making changes to our social media profile is much easier than actually going out and making a difference in the world, so our brain will settle for the "Like" on Facebook very happily.
Remember that social media is addictive but incredibly harmful, and over-usage will only make you feel empty inside.
Social media is a breeding ground for insecurity, and insecurity is not a great quality for a leader.

Sacrifice a few of your weekly social media hours for genuine human connection. Even better, try your hand at volunteering, where you can use your time to help others in less fortunate positions than you.
This will give you a greater sense of purpose, and a great sense of purpose makes for a great leader.
"It is not the genius at the top giving directions that make us great. It is great people that make the guy at the top look like a genius." \[Simon Sinek\]
Simon Sinek's TED talk is one of the most popular of all time, and so is his accompanying book, Start With Why.
His latest bestseller, Leaders Eat Last, tries to answer the question of why today's world seems to be split into leaders and followers – and what makes a leader worth following.
Leaders Eat Last teaches where the need for leadership comes from historically, what the consequences of bad leadership are, and how we can be a good leader in the modern world.

Leadership Strategies for Women teaches us that organizations suffer when they choose not to hire, develop, support, or promote individuals (both male and female), and that diversity and inclusion are necessary for the collaboration and success of any organization or team.
This is an important subject that everyone should be aware of so that we can all move towards gender equality for all involved - even outside of the workplace.

insights.title: Gender intelligence is about recognizing biases

actions.title: Recognize your biases.
actions.markdown: If you find yourself prejudging someone, assuming that because of their gender that they will behave a certain way, step back and analyze.

paragraphCards.markdown: Although men and women both process information effectively, differences in cognitive abilities and brain structure can be seen between the two.
Interestingly, the male brain uses about seven times more gray matter, which indicates deep thinking and can be used for concentrated or singular tasks.

On the flip side, the female brain uses about ten times more white matter, or the brain's networking grid, which indicates information processing, used for quicker transitions between tasks and greater connections between ideas.
Additionally, women were noted to have a slightly larger hippocampus, which acts as the human memory center. Thus, women tend to notice and remember more about a particular place or situation.
It's important to recognize that we all have gender biases, but that our brains can generally be retrained through understanding and regular self-reflection.
Of the many out there, unconscious bias and confirmation bias have the biggest effect on women and minorities around the globe - and the two work hand-in-hand.

Unconscious bias is defined as the implicit associations or subconscious attitudes towards a group, and confirmation bias is defined as the tendency to seek evidence or agreement that our preconceived beliefs are correct.

insights.title: Stand up for yourself and do the work that will show off your skills

actions.title: Get useful feedback.
actions.markdown: Men and women often receive very different types of feedback for similar performance challenges. Make sure your feedback is substantive and actionable, regardless of gender.

paragraphCards.markdown: When choosing your role or responsibilities in a project, consider your skillset.
Be sure to have an idea of the skills that you already have, and those that you wish to develop.
The end goal is to optimize your time and efforts spent on tasks that require those skills, while minimizing the mundane or unnoticed work.
Many types of mundane work are considered grunt work or housekeeping work. Unfortunately, women are more likely to take on these types of tasks.
However, do not be afraid to politely decline when asked to tackle office chores. Your chosen roles at work should showcase or highlight your skills, rather than diminish them.
Imposter syndrome not only makes it hard to accept praise, but also instills a fear of being underqualified.
In most instances, workers suffering from imposter syndrome describe themselves as incapable, incompetent, or fraudulent.
Ultimately, fear prevents employees from pursuing a promotion, or from taking the leadership position on a team or project.

There are five key methods for combating imposter syndrome:

1.  Recognize your feelings
2.  Voice them out-loud
3.  Reframe your thoughts
4.  Collect positive experiences
5.  Consider seeking professional help

insights.title: Practice communication strategies

actions.title: Stop apologizing.
actions.markdown: Women apologize more than men, even when there is no fault, mistake, or wrongdoing. Unless you are directly responsible or somehow to blame, stop saying ‘sorry’ over nothing.

paragraphCards.markdown: Choosing the right words is important, and can make you a polished communicator - but words only account for about 7% of the message.
In reality, the majority of a message is communicated nonverbally, through both your tone and body language.
These nonverbal signals are usually subconscious and can be emotionally charged. Those receiving them may then respond in a similar fashion.
It's important to craft and deliver your messages carefully. As a female leader, consider how your nonverbal behavior makes others feel.

Remember to pay attention to all the many aspects of a conversation: how you approach one, how you touch or do not touch other employees, how you control your timing, how you use gestures, and how confident you appear.
Although frustrating, women face the issue known as the 'double bind'. Simply put, it's the balance between being assertive and likeable, or agreeable.
Essentially, choosing to speak up versus sitting quietly comes with the decision of whether a woman wants to appear competent or agreeable - but not both.
Find ways to combat the double bind, such as explaining motivation or intention prior to voicing a strong opinion, or warning others of it in advance.
"Women and men have different strengths. And by harnessing both, organizations and their people can thrive."
Despite their work performance, and increasing prevalence in the workplace, women are often paid less and promoted less often than men.

Unsurprisingly, some tricky situations can come up, especially when discussing the topics of gender and leadership, stemming from issues including gender bias, communication barriers, and imposter syndrome.
Although research indicates that women are just as accomplished and just as goal oriented as their male coworkers, women hold fewer positions of leadership.
According to Dr. Daisy Lovelace and Dr. Carolyn Goerner, business professors and instructors for this course, gender disparity in leadership has to change.
For organizations that do promote workplace equality, the competitive advantages are endless, such as higher levels of innovation, job satisfaction, and employee engagement.

In this course, Leadership Strategies for Women, you will learn to recognize the strengths in both the male and female brains, as well as how to develop your leadership skills, identify strategies for receiving useful feedback, and understand the concept of the double bind.
The course teaches effective communication and negotiation strategies that women can take to genuinely connect with others, while still conveying a clear and concise message.

Leadership Strategies for Women covers the difficulties faced by women reaching for the top tier of today's businesses, including differing expectations, norms, realities, promotions, and earnings in the work environment from their male counterparts.
When Dr. Brett Andreatta wrote this course, she did so from a place of emotional experience with people and companies.
As a result, she can explain effective but straightforward guidelines to help you lead with emotional intelligence.

insights.title: Discover and understand your emotions

actions.title: Identify your emotions.
actions.markdown: Most of the time, we feel our emotions subconsciously. We hardly notice that we feel these emotions. Hence, the first step to take is to identify your emotions.

actions.title: Understand your emotions.
actions.markdown: Now that you've identified these emotions, you need to know why you feel this way. You have to understand the experiences that you've had that influence your current actions.

actions.title: Record the emotions.
actions.markdown: You can also try to put these emotions down in a journal. While trying to discover these emotions, you may notice so many. Therefore, put each down in detail for easy remembrance and better actions.

paragraphCards.markdown: As a leader, you're your first follower, so if you need people to follow you, you must first have personal emotional intelligence - and the root of being emotionally intelligent is knowing yourself.
You need to understand the type of feelings you have, why you're feeling that way, etc.
Also, it will help if you get to the root cause of all your behaviors.
Your experiences, environment, and significant events in the past all shape the person you are today.
You have to take time out to replay your life back in your head.
You don't have to remember all; the memories you recall - good or bad - are very likely the ones that influence your lifestyle the most.
Take a walk back to when you were a child, remember where you grew up, your family, and many more.
After you identify your emotions, make sure you record them down.
Get a book where you'll write your feelings down and relative causes.
Understand these feelings, then consciously work on them.
It's great to know about these emotions, but what is more important is to work on them. When you work on them, you can start to change the way you react to situations in the future.

insights.title: Explore your emotions to understand others

actions.title: Stay sensitive.
actions.markdown: The same way you took conscious time out to study your emotions, you should take time to explore the feelings of others. You can try to watch them consciously and notice their work culture, values, and beliefs.

actions.title: Understand their emotions.
actions.markdown: Before you can take action on other people's emotions, try to understand the reasons behind the emotions. You can talk to them and ask why they act the way they do.

actions.title: Show empathy.
actions.markdown: Do not just ask people questions for answers. Give them meaningful advice, talk to them about their emotions. Give them that necessary support, and you'll earn their trust.

paragraphCards.markdown: When you have understood your emotions, the next step is to explore the emotions and take control.
It's always best if you have personal control over your emotions.
When something fearful or wrong happens, consciously try to take some thoughts before you take action.
You can try to understand if you're about to show the right emotions. It's always best to identify your triggers, too.
After you know your emotions and can now control them, you have to put this understanding into your relations with other people.
Try to understand people's reactions emotionally.
Naturally, if you took the time to understand your emotions, you will find it relatively easy to understand the feelings of other people.
All you need is to make a conscious effort to identify their behaviors and values.
You can try to ask your colleagues meaningful questions to stay informed.
Doing this will help you build a rapport with your colleagues. In fact, it may surprise you how much people want to talk.
A good leader needs some level of empathy.
You should come to terms with your followers and relate directly to them emotionally.
With empathy, you'll connect to clients, colleagues, followers, and family and they will eventually trust you emotionally.

insights.title: Practice emotional intelligence leadership

actions.title: Identify problems.
actions.markdown: When you lead, you play a vital role in the success of an organization. There's a need for you to be on top of every situation. Therefore, when there’s change, identify the problems before they come.

actions.title: Brainstorm solutions.
actions.markdown: When you notice problems, look for different solutions. After that, brainstorm and choose the best solution that solves the problem without too many side effects.

actions.title: Help employees with change.
actions.markdown: Change never comes easy for anyone, including you as a leader. So, when there's a new rule, you need to employ emotional intelligence before passing change on to your followers.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The success of any organization rests on its ability to change. Emotionally intelligent leaders play a key role in both catalyzing and facilitating change in an organization." \[Dr. Britt Andreatta\]
As an emotionally intelligent leader, you need to create an emotionally intelligent atmosphere.
For example, in an organization, some employees may feel threatened due to the proficiency of their colleagues and their actions may reflect this while working with others.
The responsibility rests on you to understand the factors behind their actions, talk to them, and balance the team for overall organizational success.
When there's a change in the way you lead, there's a need to apply emotional intelligence while implementing these changes.
For starters, you need to see problems before they become pronounced in an organization.
Because some workers haven't seen these problems and their consequences, they may reject a change.
You also have to explain to your colleagues the need for a change.
More importantly, you have to focus on communicating this without tampering with their emotions.
"Cultivate your own company with change. Finding ways to embrace change and successfully manage the psychological challenges affiliated with change." \[Dr. Britt Andreatta\]
"More than 3000 studies on emotional intelligence have shown that it contributes to both professional and personal success."
There's a general school of thought that believes your performance depends solely on your intelligence quotient. But this neglects the importance of emotional intelligence.
Emotional quotient or intelligence may not be as popular as IQ, but it positively affects your personal and work progress. Unfortunately,  few understand the importance of emotional intelligence.
As the name implies, emotional intelligence relates to how you handle emotions. And since only humans have feelings, it means how you take your emotions as well as that of others.

You are self-intelligent when you know your character, rules, and how best to manage your emotions. You become people-intelligent when you understand how people react and are able to maintain healthy, meaningful relationships with them.
Emotions directly affect and shape how you think, talk, respond — almost every sphere of your life. The emotional system is a complicated one, but there is some research information.

Dr. Britt Andreatta, a former employee at Lynda.com and current CEO of 7th Mind Inc, put this course together to practically show you how to increase your emotional quotient and implement emotional intelligence as a leader.
In Leading with Emotional Intelligence, Dr. Britt Andreatta uses her unique leadership, psychology, and neuroscience experience to explain the technicalities in your emotional system.
More importantly, she shows you how you can stay in control.

Emotional intelligence is a critical leadership skill you should always learn. In this course, thought leader Dr. Britt Andreatta describes the way the emotional system works and how to utilize this personally and professionally.

Learning to be Promotable is a course for the resilient worker. It can show you what it takes to communicate with your superiors, achieve your career growth goals, and to push yourself towards the promotion you've been striving for.

insights.title: The right mindset and behavior will always make a good impression

actions.title: Think about your words.
actions.markdown: Be aware of the words you say and how you use them. Make sure your communication highlights your knowledge and ability to work with other people.

paragraphCards.markdown: Before you can consider being promoted, you must ensure that you are good at what you do.
Only when you stand out and meet the job's expectations (and more) can a superior consider you worthy of taking up more responsibility.

The three fundamental skills you should have for any position are:

1.  The ability to meet deadlines
2.  To be solution-oriented
3.  Good communication
"Differentiate yourself from the pack when reaching for a promotion by being courteous." \[Lisa Earle McLeod, Elizabeth McLeod\]
Courtesy extends beyond saying please and thank you. It means being respectful of other people's time, using eye contact when talking, and going out of your way to help your colleagues when possible.
Being kind and polite in your communication and interactions also goes a long way.
Getting a promotion does not require you to always take on the role of the hero. You need to know when to step up, and when you need help to step down.
To get a promotion, focus on stepping up in these three ways…
1.  Making sure your time is being used to suit the new opportunity.
2.  Ensure you have the right skills, and showcase them.
3.  Assess the value of the new task at hand - more to your boss than to yourself.

insights.title: Make sure that you leave a good impression with all co-workers

actions.title: Practice sounding confident and strategic.
actions.markdown: If you have to interact with senior leadership, practice sounding confident. Have a detailed introduction of yourself at the ready to kick off the conversation.

paragraphCards.markdown: As you seek to stand out from others, on your journey to get a promotion, your communication skills come to the forefront.
In-person communication is often how you make your first impression, so strengthen your emotional impact with good eye contact.
Your facial expressions and body language are key to your communication, so take cues on how to communicate from the other person's tone - both for face-to-face and written communication.
"As much as you want a promotion, you can't expect your team to work their hearts out just to benefit you." \[Lisa Earle McLeod, Elizabeth McLeod\]
It's important to work well with others so that you build up a tribe of supporters.
Your work should be impactful and connect to the sense of purpose of the people you interact with, so that they will then go on to vouch for you.
When communicating with others, consider the result you think they would want to get, rather than the one you want to give.
Your boss may not be the final decision maker when it comes to you getting a promotion - but chances are they're a key influencer.
Your boss needs to be able to see that your work is aligned with the organization's long-term goals.
A good plan is to discuss what's happening in the industry and share your thoughts, especially on trends and opportunities for growth.
It also helps if you make your boss look successful as a result of your work.

insights.title: Identify ways to turn a negative situation into a positive one

actions.title: Teach yourself to react positively.
actions.markdown: Change is inevitable and often met with resistance, so always look to identify the positive impact of change. Adjust to the role you can play to make the change seamless and effective.

paragraphCards.markdown: When seeking a promotion, you should showcase your wins in the right way.
Rather than your day-to-day activities, wins are great accomplishments that you have achieved in the course of working, and should shout about.
Showcasing your wins is not bragging; it's about communicating that your work has made an impact, and you have added value to the organization.
"Owning failure is actually an important part of leadership." \[Lisa Earle McLeod, Elizabeth McLeod\]

When you fail, it's important to take responsibility for it and share a resolution for the issue at hand. This is an indication that you are learning from your mistakes, rather than getting defensive.
Having a conversation about your failures should always end on a positive note, using words like "Thank You" for helping find a resolution, rather than saying "I'm sorry."
Do not allow an atmosphere where your peers are not interested in promotion to pull you down. Use it to reveal your ambition and to help you stand out.
Surround yourself with hard workers who are moving towards making a positive impact on the organization.
Remember that if you get your promotion, you need to be able to work with them.
"You deserve a career that provides you with financial reward and one that fuels your spirit." \[Lisa Earle McLeod, Elizabeth McLeod\]
Getting a promotion is not automatic, even if you are very good at what you do. Often, it requires showcasing that you have the best skills for the job, and interacting with the right people.
There are challenges that you may need to overcome, including organizational changes, failure, and tough bosses.
In this course, strategy and leadership experts Lisa McLeod and Elizabeth McLeod reveal the mistakes that hold people back from promotions, and what to look out for when seeking a promotion.
The course explains the importance of being intentional when you want to be promoted, and shares how to handle disappointment in the event that you miss your chance.
Learning to be Promotable is a course that all workers can use, and applies to those who are ready for a promotion now and anyone planning to get one in the future.
Discover how to handle rejection, as well as how you can get your co-workers to support you on your journey to promotion.

Learning to be Promotable provides strategies on how to advance in the workplace, including different behaviors to adopt, the best ways to communicate, how to handle failure, and the words to use when you are asking for your promotion.
Less Doing More Living combines the new technologies we can use to implement a lot of older productivity advice in a better way with classic, minimalistic, tips on letting go of what's non-essential.
Ari Meisel has built a great system to remain both effective and efficient, and some of the lessons are very counter-intuitive.

insights.title: Create an external brain to save space in your own

actions.title: Get yourself an external brain.
actions.markdown: Have a Google, browse some apps, and find an organization tool that suits you. Stop jotting things down on scraps of paper or scrawling up your arm - let your tech do the heavy-lifting.

paragraphCards.markdown: Think you can remember everything and juggle multiple things at a time? Not really, do you?
But we still try, every day. Instead, let digital technology help you out here!
By creating an external brain, for example, you can use a tool like Evernote to literally store every information you potentially come across.
To-do lists, groceries, decoration ideas, articles, notes, it's a one stop shop for everything.
Texts, pictures, and even hand-drawn notes go in there, and it's searchable, meaning you can find everything again easily.
There's no storage limit, and the algorithm organizes things in a way which is similar to how your brain saves information.
It links similar posts together in bigger networks and therefore the search results are very accurate.
Stop trying to remember everything, it's just not necessary any more. Remember - knowing means knowing where to find it.

insights.title: Customize your life to save time and even make money

actions.title: Don’t be afraid to customize.
actions.markdown: If there’s something in your home or at work that just doesn’t suit your needs or is impractical in some way, only you can fix it. Find a solution - and if there isn’t one already, find someone who’ll create it for you!

paragraphCards.markdown: Do you know how sometimes architects shape rooms in a really weird way?
There's often that one little space in the corner where your desk is that's not really accessible, because nothing fits there.
Ten years ago, if you wanted a custom shelf to exactly fit into that corner, the only way was building it yourself.
Today, you can have the same thing done and shipped to you within a matter of days, thanks to 3D printing.

Ari Meisel, for example, used Shapeways to build a custom wall mount for his computer. All he had to do was sketch a design on paper (yes, bad drawings are okay) and have someone on Fiverr turn it into a 3D model.
The model was then uploaded to Shapeways and a week later, his own custom wall mount was in the mailbox.
And if you thought that's brilliant, consider this: he then used Shapeways's website to sell 6 more of these wall mounts to others, who had the same computer as him, and made $400 off of it.
Customizing your tools and adapting them to your own needs can not only make your life easier, but also help others who have the same problem.
Compare that to "being difficult" by wanting something custom in a restaurant. An entirely new perspective, right?

insights.title: Use upper and lower limits to trade quantity for quality

actions.title: Trade quantity for quality.
actions.markdown: Add an upper limit for the material things that take up your time, then add a lower limit for the experiences you want more of. Rules are good when they’re reminding you to prioritize your priorities.

paragraphCards.markdown: Deliberately limiting yourself is one of the most freeing things you can do. You can give it a go with upper and lower limits.

An upper limit is a maximum you can't exceed, for example the number of pieces of clothing in your wardrobe, the amount of time you can spend on Facebook each week, or the number of burgers you get to eat in a month.
A lower limit, then, is a minimum you can't fall below. These are helpful for the things you always want to do but keep putting off, like exercising, spending time with family, or traveling.
Ari has an upper limit for the number of electronic devices he can have, and a lower limit for doing at least one trip per month, for example.
Both of these help you trade quantity for quality in your life, and not let work or possessions take up the time you actually want to spend on what's truly important.
"Optimizing your life starts with establishing self-awareness." \[Ari Meisel\]

Ari Meisel has done it all. Biohacking, real estate, building websites, productivity coaching, running triathlons. When he was forced to face Crohn's disease at a very young age, he felt hopeless at first, but eventually developed an unbreakable spirit.
He not only overcame the disease but is now sharing his combination of techniques and story all over the world as a speaker, author and coach.
Less Doing More Living is the 2014 bestseller that contains most of his wisdom on productivity and taking back the time in your life to do what really matters to you.

Less Doing More Living is based on the assumption that the less you have to do, the more life you have to live, and helps you implement this philosophy into your life by giving you real-world tools to boost efficiency in every aspect of your life.

Neil Rosenthal's lessons in Love, Sex, and Staying Warm are relatable and easily applicable. No matter what stage of the relationship you're in, there's something for everyone to learn to ensure you're one of the happy couples that stay happy.

insights.title: Learning to be a good partner requires you to adopt a student mindset

actions.title: Do romance their way.
