actions.markdown: Establish how your partner defines romance. Different people value ‘romantic’ in different ways, be it love or sex, words or gestures, so make sure that you’re paying attention to their idea of romance, and not just playing out your own.

actions.title: Go offline.
actions.markdown: Being constantly connected to social media, news outlets, and shopping sites can get in the way of relationships. When you’re at dinner, watching a movie, or out for date night, stay present and keep your phone switched off.

paragraphCards.markdown: We often expect the early stages of a relationship to require the most work. [giphy.com/hollyoaks](https://media.giphy.com/media/iIY3W1cfet64fB2hrZ/giphy.mp4)
Once we know everything about each other, we mistakenly think we can stop trying and that things should come naturally.
Relationships are not a destination, they're a journey. [giphy.com/lovecrafthbo](https://media.giphy.com/media/3UbymY4c36MYgK7e5x/giphy.mp4)
Just as you will continually change over time, so too will your needs from the relationship.
You need to start to see yourself as a 'student husband' or 'student wife'. [giphy.com/alternatino](https://media.giphy.com/media/jQ8CUkNCN9bRD4N6NW/giphy.mp4)
Students don't just assume they know everything. They're open-minded: beginners who are ready and willing to learn.
Similarly, a partner must assume that they aren't the perfect husband or wife. [giphy.com/hallmarkchannel](https://media.giphy.com/media/8OVf9nLoxMJNJGaMU7/giphy.mp4)

If you automatically presume you've got all it figured out, you'll stop listening. You won't pay attention to feedback, or realize when you're being given a lesson. Don't go thinking you'll graduate one day either.
While the two of you continue to grow, that desire to grow together is founded upon a willingness to learn. [giphy.com/olifox](https://media.giphy.com/media/cJ5Ch1jM8N5pgxPZgn/giphy.mp4)
"It is easier to get a marriage license than it is to get a driver's license. It is easier to get married than it is to be happily married." \[Neil Rosenthal\]
As with any form of study, a student's workload is made a lot simpler by having a good teacher.
As a teacher, you must be calm and gentle. You have to decide which lessons are the most important, prioritize those, and let the rest go.
When your student is struggling to grasp a new concept, you must be patient. [giphy.com/nbcthevillage](https://media.giphy.com/media/w8ZKm4EsahNeeMD7Zs/giphy.mp4)

If you can both learn to intertwine the roles of good student and gracious teacher, the two of you can start to nurture real intimacy. [giphy.com/coldplay](https://media.giphy.com/media/ZZTnRPCqQqd6lSvsdL/giphy.mp4)
"Great relationships aren't 50/50. They're 100/100." \[Gregory J.P. Godek, author\]

insights.title: When you start the fight, you’re probably not voicing what’s really upsetting you

actions.title: Analyze your arguments.
actions.markdown: Before you go and shout at your partner for doing wrong, stop and think. Ask yourself if that’s really the reason you’re angry, or if there’s more to it. Keep asking ‘why’ until you get to the root of the issue.

actions.title: Control your anger.
actions.markdown: Anger often comes out harsher than you meant it to. Close your eyes and breathe. Sleep deprivation, hunger, and stress can all contribute to outbursts of negative emotion, so calm down before you take it out on someone else.

paragraphCards.markdown: The occasional bit of conflict is inevitable in any relationship.[giphy.com/laurenjenkins](https://media.giphy.com/media/SqlP7SlYdRA31xt7AW/giphy.mp4)
The closer two people get and the more time they spend together, the more likely it is that they'll occasionally lock horns.
But how many of us really stop to question why we're angry? We shout about such trivial things – but what if that problem wasn't so insignificant after all?
There are a lot of seemingly small battles that are actually just a symptom for something larger. [giphy.com/1091](https://media.giphy.com/media/ZwiblwKDIe2dBCrdik/giphy.mp4)

For example, are you angry that he's messy, or is it that he doesn't pull his weight which then further burdens you? Is it that she works too much, or that she's choosing to spend time at the office instead of with you, and you don't feel valued?
If you're going to resolve your conflict, you first need to make sure that you are in fact verbalizing the real problem. Only then can your partner look to do better.

In order to understand what's really going on, you need to learn to empathize - something surprisingly few people are good at. [giphy.com/blvkjvck](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IgijlLCuoT1ucr6/giphy.mp4)
Empathy requires you to put yourself into your partner's shoes, and feel what they're feeling. You have to understand what it must be like to be in their position, and show compassion.
"If you don't temporarily suspend your own feelings and opinions, you're not being empathetic." \[Neil Rosenthal\]

If both of you can learn to look at things from the other's point of view, you'll start to make decisions with them in mind. [giphy.com/hallmarkchannel](https://media.giphy.com/media/1yLU2mgcJYdlKretx7/giphy.mp4)
You'll do the washing up more often, and start consciously leaving the office on time.
Then, when you are caught out, you'll be more likely to apologize and look to learn from your mistakes. [giphy.com/thelumineers](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2YWoVWuTU4aUDAmk/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: A healthy sex life is about more than just sex

actions.title: Take the lead.
actions.markdown: Both men and women alike enjoy it when their partner makes the first move. Tell them you want them, touch them, and put their hands on you. Make it happen.

actions.title: Try saying ‘yes’.
actions.markdown: If your partner is coming onto you, even if you’re tired or distracted, find it in you to say ‘yes’. Reject them too often, and they might stop trying. Chances are you’ll enjoy it once you get going, so try to be open-minded and go with it.

paragraphCards.markdown: When you first meet someone, those early days of dating are always so exciting. You go out, you talk, you flirt, and you have a lot of sex. [giphy.com/ihc1nfinity](https://media.giphy.com/media/oz9mksfw9DgI6Ek01v/giphy.mp4)
But this doesn't go on forever. The longer the two of you are together, the more accustomed you become to their company, and gradually the sex declines.
"The day-in and day-out routine that gets established in a long-term relationship can be very deadening to eroticism." \[Neil Rosenthal\]
Like anything else, a healthy sex life takes conscious effort, persistance, and planning. [giphy.com/1091](https://media.giphy.com/media/1xpCKg3dKB8btEuQGj/giphy.mp4)
Put a date in the diary for it in advance. Find a book of different positions, and check them off as you try them.
Leave suggestive notes around the house, and send seductive texts while they're at work. Tell them you think they're sexy and what you've been thinking about doing to them.

Sex is something you can work on, even with the smallest of gestures, to keep that eroticism present in your relationship. [giphy.com/grownish](https://media.giphy.com/media/Ww26qobcIQV7ZMGRs2/giphy.mp4)
But sex isn't just about what happens in the bedroom.
"Foreplay does not begin a few minutes before the main event; it starts at the previous erotic encounter." \[Neil Rosenthal\]

You're told to add 'novelty' to keep things 'interesting', so you might start contemplating a threesome or googling S&M for beginners. [giphy.com/netflix](https://media.giphy.com/media/ce1bv0MCDXTa19LMHc/giphy.mp4)
But sex in an adult relationship is founded upon what happens in between sessions, and how you spend your time together.
You need to live as lovers, and not simply co-exist as man and wife. [giphy.com/neighbours](https://media.giphy.com/media/xLa3cqJOmLlfX2lvah/giphy.mp4)
Recreate the romance that you used to put time into when you first met. Travel, take a class together, and talk intimately about your hopes and fears in life.
Rediscover the connection that was what made you choose this person in the first place. [giphy.com/cbc](https://media.giphy.com/media/257OmSQOSMjnymASmz/giphy.mp4)
"You just need more creative and personal ways of living your love, because while falling in love just happens, staying in love never happens by itself." \[Neil Rosenthal\]
Most of us have been in a relationship at one time or another. [giphy.com/sonymusiccolombia](https://media.giphy.com/media/WfXQpCwemYCnm/giphy.mp4)
We met, we spent loads of time together, we fell in love, maybe we even got married. And then things got tricky.
We fight, and we don't know why. We don't have as much sex as we used to. We had kids and got high-powered jobs, and there just doesn't seem to be time for 'us' anymore.
Neil Rosenthal has spent the past 35 years working as a marriage and relationship counselor, and newspaper columnist.
In Love, Sex, and Staying Warm: Creating a Vital Relationship, Rosenthal has collated some of his most important lessons, covering everything from sex and romance to resolving conflict.

Whether your relationship is still new or you've known your partner your whole life, there's always something you can learn to help keep that flame alive. [giphy.com/hallmarkchannel](https://media.giphy.com/media/9DtxNhYNeVM6kmum24/giphy.mp4)
Love, Sex, and Staying Warm is a collection of marriage counselor and newspaper columnist Neil Rosenthal's best writings to help any couple find happpiness in their relationship.
Memory-improvement book How We Learn is about the "how" of memory formation, and how we can use the way our brain works to our own advantage.
Moonwalking With Einstein is all about the "what", giving specific techniques for actively improving our memory.
Foer's provision of historical background and context is an interesting angle, and dismisses the "well, we have smartphones now" argument in thought-provoking ways.

insights.title: Memory has become less and less important throughout history

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: We didn't always have the attention span of a goldfish, but today it sure seems that way.
Imagine if our memory had always been so bad. We wouldn't be here today if our elders had not remembered a few important things.
Before the invention of scripture, memory artists were today's equivalent of quarterbacks.
King Cyrus of Persia was known for knowing all the names of his soldiers, and Socrates mocked writing for making people forgetful.
No wonder: Anything that was written before 200 BC had no punctuation, all texts were basically just word strings.
If you didn't already know what you were reading, reading was useless.
If there's one guy to blame for the decline of memory, then, we'd have to point the finger at Johannes Gutenberg.
In 1440 he invented the printing press, and it was all downhill from there.
Once we could store information externally, physically store it anywhere in our house, and access it at any time, the need to remember things significantly declined.
This tendency has continued ever since, and taken a major turn for the worse with the invention of smartphones and globally available internet.

insights.title: Our collective ‘bad memory’ is by no means fixed

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Just because our collective societal memory is much poorer than it used to be doesn't mean we can't improve it.
You might know that the average number of list items we can store in our short-term memory is 7.
However, this capacity can be extended, as shown in a study by K. Anders Ericsson and William Chase from 1980.
Test subject S.F. expanded his ability to memorize digits from 7 to 79 through over 230 hours of repeating number sequences to himself, a technique also called the phonological loop.
Similarly, it's been found that chess players have a so-called 'chess memory'.
Because they are an expert in their field, they perceive the board differently, and focus on the most important parts of it based on their experience.
It's called chess memory because it is limited to chess, and won't help them do better on general memory tests.
The lesson? Through repetition, practice, and becoming an expert in certain fields, we can increase our capacity to memorize.

insights.title: Chunking and Memory Palaces are 2 great techniques to instantly improve our memory

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The ability to memorize a larger number of items is one thing – we're bound to hit an eventual ceiling there.
But the ability to recall better and faster is where it really gets interesting.
2 quick examples of this are Chunking and the Memory Palace.
Chunking simply means dividing one string of information into several.
Can you remember 1117200112241999 just by looking at it once?
Us neither, but we can remember 2 dates in a row: 11/17/2001, and 12/24/1999.
Fascinating, right? By creating 2 chunks of differently formatted information, memorizing a string of seemingly random numbers becomes easy.
If we now put these dates into context, it'll be even easier.
Try thinking up a significant date that's personal to you around these dates – 12/24/1999 can be seen Christmas Eve 1999, for example.
Meanwhile, the memory palace is a technique where, in our minds, we visualize walking along a route we know really well (like our home), and put memories in certain locations along the way.
For example, you could go through your childhood home and place the items from your shopping list on the kitchen table.
Then, when you're in the grocery store, all you have to do is to mentally enter the kitchen and see what's there.
Once you see tomatoes, onions and potatoes on the table, you know what to shop for. You can even have multiple routes for different kinds of memories.
"If you want to live a memorable life, you have to be the kind of person who remembers to remember." \[Joshua Foer\]
It's safe to say that author Joshua Foer has lots of memory credentials – he won the 2006 USA Memory Championship, and set a new record for memorizing a deck of 52 cards: 1 minute and 40 seconds.
When he's not busy memorizing stuff, Foer works as a freelance writer, writing for The New York Times or The Washington Post, for example, as well as a speech on TED talk.
Moonwalking With Einstein not only educates us about the history of memory and how its standing has declined over centuries, but also gives us actionable techniques to extend and improve our own.
No matter how big the group of people you work with or in, Move Your Bus forces us to face some tough truths: the 80/20 principle is real.
Whether that means 20 people are riders, or 200, there will always be those that are just floating along, and it's up to us to get them to move.
Good read for both sides, employers and employees!

insights.title: High expectations are productive as long as they’re still possible for others to deliver on

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: First of all, what's this book's bus-themed title even about?
"Moving your bus" is one of Ron Clark's metaphors. It's used in the context of teaching organizations how they can make progress, and what teamwork looks like.
Have you ever watched The Flintstones? It's one of the most popular cartoon shows of all time, superseded only by The Simpsons.
Because The Flintstones is set in the stone age, all cars and buses on the show work through footwork – only if all passengers run, the bus moves forward.
Organizations work the same way: _everyone_ has a role to play, some bigger, some smaller, but only when all team members work together and give their best can you really move forward.
Even in elementary school classrooms, teachers' coach Ron Clark has always believed in high expectations being an incremental part of teamwork.
Set the bar too low, and people won't even bother trying.
But when you set it high, you also have to clearly communicate what you expect from people and hold them accountable to it, so that they have a chance to deliver.
In a company, that means managers should request specific outputs, and encourage people to work in small doses.
For example, a written, two-page report about last month's sales performance within two days is a challenging but nonetheless clearly defined goal.

insights.title: Remember that everyone performs at different levels – we must work with people on an individual basis

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Having high expectations is good, but remember: what high expectations are is different for everyone.
A two-page business sales report might be an appropriate challenge for a junior sales manager, but too easy for the head of sales, and almost impossible to write for a call center agent.
Using a bus metaphor, teachers' coach Ron Clark defines the five different groups we can find in organizations:
The driver(s), who steers the bus and pushes everyone forward – these are usually the managers.
The runners, who are the top performers, work hard and always have great, creative input on how to move on.
The joggers, who are diligent and consistent workers, but only switch into high gear occasionally.
The walkers, who are still steady, but rather slow, aren't that fond of change, and will sometimes slow the bus down.
The riders, who only run when someone's watching them and otherwise use their intelligence to hide behind the crowd.
As you can see, the span of motivation levels, work ethic and performance level within these five groups is huge – so naturally, you'll have to deal differently with all these groups.
Some people might naturally move up through these levels, while others might move down.
Some will eventually have to get off the bus altogether if they don't get themselves into gear (looking at you, riders).

insights.title: Don’t feel entitled to anything and instead learn patience – you’ll thrive in meritocracy

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: No matter how hard of a worker you are, there's one very important lesson to remember: let go of your sense of entitlement. Forever.

Because most of us are used to a consumerist environment, we often feel like we should get the promotion, the full bonus, the credit, the award, when we really know deep down that someone else worked harder for it.
But that's not how meritocracy works.
If we really want to thrive in a capitalist system (no matter whether we like the system itself or not), letting go of our entitlement mentality is the only right choice.
Nobody owes us their attention, their money, let alone their recognition, and we sure don't deserve an award just for showing up to work on time.
While we're working towards our high expectations, we should work on actually becoming more deserving of what we want.
Only zero expectations and infinite patience lead to immediate results.
"Treating everyone fairly isn't treating everyone equally." \[Ron Clark\]
What if you were told that next Monday, you'd have to teach a class of schoolchildren?

Not just any class, either, but a 4th grade class in one of the toughest schools in Harlem, New York City. A class that's known for causing trouble, going through six teachers in three months, that will probably also refuse to work with you?
How would you do it? How would you approach this problem?
If your gut reaction is "How the hell am I supposed to know?", then you know how Ron Clark felt in the late 90s, before taking on this exact challenge.
For lack of a better idea, he just tried everything. Being strict. Being nice. Being open. Being honest. And eventually, it worked. He got through to the kids.
So much so, in fact, that their grades drastically increased, and they ended up scoring higher than the school's honor class in the state exam.

Since 2007, Clark's been inspiring and helping teachers and educators to make those kinds of changes in their own classrooms, running the non-profit Ron Clark Academy middle school in Atlanta, Georgia.
_Move Your Bus_ is Clark's fourth book, and it's about recognizing the different groups of people in organizations, plus how to deal with them accordingly.

Move Your Bus sheds some light on the different tiers of every organization, be it a school or a company, how leaders can inspire these different groups, and how individuals can move up and become more valuable to the organization they serve.
Make Your Bed is an inspiring book that exhorts us to think big while taking care of the small things.

You meet 10,000 people in your life, but even if you affect one in ten people and they do the same for someone else, the world is going to be a better place within a few generations. [youtube.com/c/TexasExes/](https://youtu.be/pxBQLFLei70?t=87.00&e=119.10)
Each of us can make a difference.

insights.title: Making your bed in the morning can lead to more tasks completed by the end of the day

actions.title: Make your bed.
actions.markdown: Before breakfast, before using the bathroom - the moment you get out of bed every morning. It will set you up for a productive day, and prevent extra stress before settling down to sleep at night.

paragraphCards.markdown: As a US SEAL cadet, William H. McRaven had to make his bed to perfection first thing after waking up. [giphy.com/brat/](https://media.giphy.com/media/tsULC7XjGSMU9yDNY9/giphy.mp4)
If he failed to follow the bed-making code, he had to perform the sugar cookie ritual, which has nothing to do with treats, as you can imagine.
It's more about diving into the cold waters of the Pacific Ocean and then rolling around on the beach until you are covered head-to-toe in sand.
But why is making your bed so important? ![giphy.com/Aisforai/](https://media.giphy.com/media/VbnW8c9G3ICRUXTjH1/giphy.gif)
While making your bed may seem trivial when bigger assignments are waiting for you, starting off with this small task makes you feel a little proud and ready to deal with the rest of your tasks.
And if you have a miserable day, coming back to a bed made – by you – will make you feel tomorrow will be better. [giphy.com/ikeausa](https://media.giphy.com/media/KD8Ldwzx90X9hi9QHW/giphy.mp4)

After a serious injury, McRaven spent many months lying on a hospital bed that had been wheeled into his government quarters. When he was finally able to stand up unaided, the first thing he did was adjusting the bed.
It was his way of showing that he was recovering and moving forward. ![giphy.com/bynorafikse](https://media.giphy.com/media/KdBdnqyve3OnStQ67a/giphy.gif)
"I sometimes fell short of being the best, but I never fell short of giving it my best."\[William H. McRaven\]

insights.title: If you want to change the world, never ever ring the bell

actions.title: Try to take failures as motivation.
actions.markdown: Easier said than done: don’t let a setback stop you. Grit your teeth and let it spur you on to give it another go.

paragraphCards.markdown: During SEAL training, William H. McRaven and his fellows had to withstand uncountable challenges of strength and courage.

Giving up at any time was very easy: they just had to ring a bell hanging in the center of the compound and they would be free, immediately.

![giphy.com/fanshawecollege](https://media.giphy.com/media/VcxS6Pr8xbdoyuiO50/giphy.gif)
Never ring the bell if you want to achieve big goals in life.

You may have heard of the Circus, another legendary punishment known to make many cadets quit the SEAL training. It's two hours of additional calisthenics, paired with non-stop harassment by SEAL combat veterans.
During the training, McRaven was part of a swim team that constantly came in last place and had to face the Circus many times a week.
At the moment of the graduation test though, they came in first: all those hours of calisthenics had made them stronger.
Life is full of Circuses. You fail, you keep training yourself, you get stronger.![giphy.com/aisforai](https://media.giphy.com/media/QYSwLM9aetskAl1bg6/giphy.gif)

Once McRaven's team had to swim four miles in the dark. Scary enough in itself, but that night there were even reports of big white sharks near the coast.[giphy.com/lunaresalethia](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7TKql8EjyZ832EBa/giphy.mp4)
Since it was the only way to complete the SEAL training, they swam anyway.
If you want to achieve your full potential in life, don't let fear stop you.

"You will face a lot of Circuses. You will pay for your failures. But, if you persevere, if you let those failures teach you and strengthen you, then you will be prepared to handle life's toughest moments." \[William H. McRaven\]

insights.title: Find someone to help you paddle if you want to make a real difference in the world

actions.title: Build your personal team.
actions.markdown: The whole is greater than the sum of its parts – a team of people who love and support you, and share the same values and goals, will help you find your strength even on the bad days.

paragraphCards.markdown: "We will all find ourselves neck deep in mud someday. That is the time to sing loudly, to smile broadly, to lift up those around you." \[William H. McRaven\]
SEAL cadets have to overcome Hell Week, seven days of endurance tests when many of them call it quits.
During their Hell Week, William H. McRaven and his fellows had to spend a whole night sitting, covered in cold mud.[giphy.com/channel7au](https://media.giphy.com/media/aiRoZ5Jegppv8jNZNt/giphy.mp4)
In the middle of the test, some of them seemed ready to give up. Then one man began to sing. ![giphy.com/ascap](https://media.giphy.com/media/LQtdUKIFU8JAWwq1AB/giphy.gif)
One by one, the others followed him. Suddenly the mud felt less cold and the dawn closer.
Sometimes life gets very hard: the loss of someone you love, a disease or something you are not prepared for may crush your spirit.

These are the moments when you need to dig inside yourself and bring out all your strength. But you also need the help of your friends and family. [giphy.com/darkbean](https://media.giphy.com/media/MdeSslU80bVsTtWxEh/giphy.mp4)
Years ago, McRaven was badly wounded in a parachute accident and he had to go through months of recovery and rehabilitation.
He's sure he would have surrendered to self-pity and depression if his wife hadn't been there to support him.

In McRaven's view, life is like a small rubber boat: you cannot paddle it alone. It takes a team of good people to get you where you want to go. [giphy.com/Ovationtv/](https://media.giphy.com/media/pyuZNLrbWBgVakHTGn/giphy.mp4)
"Find someone to share your life with. Never forget that your success depends on others." \[William H. McRaven\]
"If you want to change the world, start singing when you're up to your neck in mud." \[William H. McRaven\]

In 2014 Admiral William H. McRaven gave the commencement address at the University of Texas at Austin.![ADM William H. McRaven 2012.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/34/ADM_William_H._McRaven_2012.jpg)
While encouraging the students to improve the world, he gave many life lessons that could be of help.

He had learned most of them during his Navy SEAL training – six months of runs in the sand, obstacles courses, unending calisthenics and continuous harassment by veterans, who wanted only the strongest to get to the end of it.
[youtube.com/c/TexasExes/](https://youtu.be/pxBQLFLei70?t=271.09&e=276.44)
As a cadet, McRaven learned that success doesn't depend on social status, race or religion. It's not how good your parents were to you or which school you went to that determines your future.
It's a combination of the little actions and help from others that makes people successful.
The admiral's speech went viral on YouTube and later became a book.![giphy.com/FashionDrug/](https://media.giphy.com/media/SY99UqU94nSIPOpyXA/giphy.gif)

In Make Your Bed: Small things that can change your life… and maybe the world, McRaven stresses that life is unfair, as everybody knows. What defines great men and women is how they deal with life's unfairness.
Make Your Bed encourages you to pursue your goals and change the lives of others for the better by showing that success is a combination of individual willpower and mutual support.

Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus addresses some of the most common relationship problems couples experience. It highlights the key differences between men and women in how they think, act, and communicate.

Every individual is unique and some may not fall into these patterns, but the book provides solid examples and "aha" moments in your quest to figure out the opposite gender.![giphy.com/lookhuman/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2JJwSHqR1t11I3Qc/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Men need to process their problems in their head while women want verbal communication

actions.title: Be there for them, not for yourself.
actions.markdown: If she has had a bad day, don’t hand her a list of solutions - just sit, listen and comfort. However if he is a little quiet, don’t force it or take it personally - let him come to you when he’s ready.

paragraphCards.markdown: After a long day at work, Tom and Mary come home with work-related issues on their mind. As they both sit down for dinner, Mary starts talking about how her boss is making her work too much.![giphy.com/globaltv](https://media.giphy.com/media/2yzIGtlxWZNSJHnKNc/giphy.gif)
Tom, being the problem-solver he is, starts offering solutions. This upsets Mary since she only needs Tom to listen to help her feel better.

Tom, on the other hand, wants to solve his work-related issues in solitude or by taking his mind off work while watching TV. He only feels the need to talk to Mary about a problem when he wants her to give him a solution.
Mary feels sad because Tom isn't talking about what's bothering him as she does.
In both cases, Tom and Mary try to fulfill each other's needs the wrong way, so they end up fighting.

To solve this issue, Tom can listen to Mary without offering solutions unless she specifically asks for help. Mary can let Tom process his emotions by himself when he needs to.![ove\_padlocks\_on\_the\_Butchers%27\_Bridge\_%28Ljubljana%29.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Love_padlocks_on_the_Butchers%27_Bridge_%28Ljubljana%29.jpg/640px-Love_padlocks_on_the_Butchers%27_Bridge_%28Ljubljana%29.jpg)
As a man, you can let women talk without offering solutions and deal with your own issues later.
As a woman, you can wait for men to solve their problems by themselves until they feel better.

insights.title: Women need to feel loved, whereas men like the sense that they are useful

actions.title: Appreciate the one you’re with.
actions.markdown: Chances are your partner does more for you than you realize, so never take them for granted. When they do something for you, however small, even if it’s not done perfectly, show that you appreciate them for it.

paragraphCards.markdown: One Sunday afternoon, Tom decides to fix a broken bookshelf by himself. After watching Tom work for hours, Mary tells him to call his brother for help.

Tom doesn't like the advice because he wants to feel useful by fixing the bookshelf by himself. All he needs from Mary is an appreciation of his efforts and trust in his skills.![giphy.com/digijing](https://media.giphy.com/media/l3q2PwxrzxW6JseU8/giphy.gif)
Mary, on the other hand, does all the dishes, laundry, cleaning, cooking, and other household tasks on most days - and she is happy to do it.
But when Tom doesn't acknowledge the care she provides, Mary starts resenting him.
If Tom appreciated the small things Mary does for him, he would fulfill Mary's need to be loved and respected.![giphy.com/microsoftstore](https://media.giphy.com/media/xlMWh89tib67i2jSJO/giphy.gif)
In both cases, a lack of voluntary appreciation creates tension and needless problems.
As a woman, you can show men that you trust them and let them help when they want to, so they'll feel useful.![giphy.com/sherchle](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT39Dbyi999nDnJF84/giphy.gif)
As a man, you can repeatedly show women how much you love them to make them feel fulfilled.

insights.title: Men and women may use similar words, but mean different things

actions.title: Don’t read too much into it.
actions.markdown: Some people like to dramatically exaggerate; others like to quietly downplay. Don’t start over-analyzing that it’s something you did wrong. Just talk to them about what’s on their mind in their own time, and try to come to a conclusion that suits you both.

paragraphCards.markdown: One day, Mary brings up the issue that Tom has been too busy to spend time with her. She says: "We never go out together!"

As a result, Tom bursts out in anger, reminding her of all the times they did go out together and all the things he's been doing for the family.![giphy.com/angrybirds](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oEdv6UfpU2K6jHot2/giphy.gif)
But when Mary uses the word 'never,' she doesn't really mean never. She is trying to express her feelings about Tom not having paid attention to her lately.
In Tom's mind, however, she actually means 'never,' and he gets frustrated about her using this word.

On another day, Tom is overthinking an issue at work. Mary senses Tom's tension and asks what's wrong. Tom replies: "I'm fine. Don't worry about it."![giphy.com/Barbara\_Pozzi/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6nUNpJn4VznakjKM/giphy.gif)
Mary interprets this as a sign that things are not fine and that she needs to interrogate him further to find out what's wrong. She keeps questioning Tom until he gets angry.

When Tom says "I'm fine," however, he actually means that he is fine and wants to deal with his problem alone. Should he be in the mood to talk and ask for solutions, he'll let Mary know when he feels like it.
Mary doesn't understand this, which leads to frustration and anger from both sides.
Men are often quite literal, women tend to use more words as mere expressions of a general feeling.
As a man, you can focus on the feelings of women rather than their words alone ![giphy.com/lidiaontheroad](https://media.giphy.com/media/RJzcOklIMBPqVHUL5o/giphy.gif)
As a woman, you can stop trying so hard to find the hidden meaning behind men's words because they'll often say what they mean anyway.
"When men and women are able to accept and respect their differences, then love has a chance to blossom." \[John Gray\]

Tom and Mary have a relationship in which they are tired of dealing with the same issues over and over again. There is nothing wrong with them. They simply fail to understand the differences between men and women.

Like Tom and Mary, many couples fall into such patterns that turn a loving relationship into a failed one. Men and women think differently. They have distinct emotional needs and communication preferences.

If you're among the many who find it difficult to read the opposite gender, Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus: The Classic Guide to Understanding the Opposite Sex will enlighten you. [https://giphy.com/latenightseth/](https://media.giphy.com/media/yNs2a0jRkYxy6191B2/giphy.mp4)

Once you know how you and your partner differ, you'll see each other from a new perspective and understand each other better. This knowledge will improve your relationship and resolve many of the struggles that arise from misunderstandings.
Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus helps you improve your relationships by identifying the key differences between men and women.

paragraphCards.markdown: No Excuses! is a useful book in which to improve almost any area of our lives, and abandon the dreaded "Someday Isle" that so many of us live in.
Instead of wondering what could have been, why don't you actually get out there and start making your dreams happen?
No Excuses! provides many step-by-step techniques that can help we practice self-discipline for long-term happiness.

insights.title: For a rewarding life, we must constantly improve yourself, and plan our actions with The Seven Step Method

actions.title: Take accountability with the 7-Step Method.
actions.markdown: Achieving your long term goals requires breaking down your long-term goals into sizeable, easy chunks. When you pick apart your dream you can better understand all the steps you’ll need to make it reality.

paragraphCards.markdown: Self-actualization implies skills and knowledge.
In order to move from average to excellence, you should allocate 3% of your income and a little time every day.
What about staying at work a little longer to learn something new, or reading a book instead of watching TV at home?
You can also learn a lot from people who are successful in your field. Observe how they dress and talk.
Try asking them for self-improvement tips, and what they turn to for inspiration: what books to read, what courses to take.
Self-actualization also requires thinking long-term. To put this into practice, you need the 7\-Step Method.
1.  Define your goal exactly. For example, if you want to save money, also decide how much.
2.  Write down your specific goals.
3.  Set a deadline – a realistic one. If your goal is complicated to achieve or requires much time, break it into subtasks and set a deadline for each.
4.  Think about the obstacles you may face in the process, and the resources you'll need to succeed, including skills. Then make a list of actionable steps to acquire them.
5.  Organize the list by sequence and priority, remembering the most beneficial tasks must be completed first. Then add all of them to your calendar.
6.  Start today with your first step!
7.  Take action every day, even if it's small, to get closer to your goal.

insights.title: Take care of the 5 Ingredients Of Happiness in order to feel in control of your life

actions.title: Nurture the 5 Ingredients for Happiness.
actions.markdown: When you make a proactive effort into your Financial Independence, Health and Energy, Relationships, Meaningful Work, and Self-Actualization, you make a commitment to yourself to treat yourself right.

paragraphCards.markdown: The more we understand that anything that happens to us is mostly a consequence of our own actions, the happier we'll be.
On the other hand, it's usually the people who feel powerless and at the mercy of external circumstances that feel unhappy with their lives.
To feel good about ourselves, we must take control of our life by working on the 5 Ingredients Of Happiness.
1.  Financial Independence – Working is much better when you know you don't need to. So try to live with 99% of your income, and save 1% to slowly build your freedom from money.
2.  Health and Energy – You can be truly happy only if you are healthy, with a high level of energy.
Don't worry, it's never too late to start exercising! And also to eliminate from your diet the free whites: flour, sugar, and salt.
3.  Relationships – Since we are social animals, most of our happiness comes from the positive relations we are able to build.
To improve them, stop taking things personally and don't blame your problems on others.
Also, be the first to give what you wish to receive, friendship and forgiveness included!
4.  Meaningful Work – Working a job that we enjoy makes us happier, but we also like to be engaged and feel useful.
5.  Self-Actualization – This is the feeling you are living at your full potential, becoming everything you want and are capable of. Start working towards it now!
Abandon the "Someday Isle", where most of humanity lives, procrastinating their actions for a day that will never come.

insights.title: Fear is normal, and we can overcome it by making our own Disaster Report

actions.title: Build your own Disaster Report.
actions.markdown: Minimize your fear of worst case scenarios lingering at the back of your head by actually letting yourself fully ‘go there’ for a moment. When you indulge in this terrible fantasy, you start to see that even if you do hit rock bottom, there are still ways out again.

paragraphCards.markdown: A lack of self-discipline is not the only thing that can prevent us from realizing yourself.
Maybe the fear of failing and losing your money is holding you back from undertaking your personal challenges.
However, so-called "brave" people are scared too--they've simply mastered the discipline of taking action anyway.
So how can the rest of us do this too?
Author Brian Tracy offers a technique to overcoming fear called The Disaster Report.
1.  Write down your fears in as much detail as you can manage. Are you concerned about not being good enough and looking bad, or about losing all your savings?
2.  Describe the worst-case scenario. When you analyze it rationally, it will lose part of its scary power.
3.  Find solutions for the worst-case scenario. Let's suppose you lost some money. You can still find a new job and earn it back.

4.  Take action to ensure the worst-case scenario doesn't manifest itself. This will lessen your anxiety for two reasons: bad things will be less likely to happen and anyway you'll be too busy to think of it.
Another trick to avoid getting stuck in your worries is pretending not to be worried at all.
As Aristotle taught, you can develop a quality by just acting as if you already had it.
In other words, "fake until you make it."
"An average person with average talent, ambition and education can outstrip the most brilliant genius in our society if that person has clear, focused goals." \[Brian Tracy\]
We all need financial security, self-realization, and fulfilling relationships to be happy. We know this, and, most of the time, we even know what to do to get all these things.
So how come we don't get them?
According to Brian Tracy, the reason is that we lack self-discipline, which is the key to achieving any goal.
With self-discipline, the average person can do miracles. Without it, even the luckiest and most talented person won't rise above mediocrity.
In No Excuses!: The Power of Self-Discipline, Tracy urges us to start acting today and build our own happiness, through the application of the many techniques he has fine-tuned over the years.
No Excuses! teaches that self-discipline is the key to success, giving us practical advice to master it and thus achieve self-actualization, happy relationships, and financial security.
No-Drama Discipline provides a fascinating look into the developing mind of young children.
It contains many relatable examples of how to handle the conflicts that come with raising kids.
The advice is totally doable and helps turn discipline into a positive teaching experience, instead of the part of parenting that most parents dread.

insights.title: Take the opportunity to teach your child when they misbehave

actions.title: Teach by example.
actions.markdown: Remember that your child’s brain essentially works like a very powerful sponge. Children notice everything, and they’ll copy your behavior, too. If you want your child to take on certain qualities, the best way to ensure this is to take them on yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: First, we need to make sure we separate the term 'discipline' from 'punishment'.
We do this by making sure our disciplining is proactive, rather than reactive.
When our go-to is time-outs or spanking, this only creates resentment and fear, which isn't good for parents or for children.
Instead, we learn to use the magical parenting tool that is "connect and redirect."
First, we take time to connect with our child, then redirect them to correct the behavior.
Remember last time you blew up over something small because you were tired?
That same regulatory part of your brain, compromised because of a lack of sleep, is still developing in your child.
However, we have a better opportunity with our children. Their brains still aren't fully developed. We can nurture and shape them.
Everyone has what we call the "downstairs" brain; the part of the mind that controls basic needs such as digestion and breathing.
Our "upstairs" brain is responsible for empathy and emotion.
In a child, the "upstairs brain" is still developing, and thanks to neuroplasticity – our brain changing as a result of experiences – we can help children learn to use it more often.
The mind is capable of evolving. Because of this, teaching our children, instead of punishing them, will always be the most effective form of discipline.

insights.title: Connect, rather than punish, so the brain can receive feedback

actions.title: Connect and redirect.
actions.markdown: When your child is acting out, remain calm. Reassure them that you understand their emotional response, explaining why you empathise. Explain why this reaction is not suitable behavior, and redirect them to other ways of expressing themselves. Encourage them to communicate their feelings openly.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you want to discipline your child effectively, you need a loving relationship.
The key to developing that love is encouraging children to live in a receptive state of mind, and this can be best achieved by connecting with them.
Say your 3-year-old sees a lollipop at the grocery store checkout stand, and you say, "No, not today."
The toddler goes into full-on meltdown mode on the grocery store floor.
People are watching, and now you're not sure if you should give your child the lollipop to get her quiet, or stand your ground to teach a lesson.
What do we do in situations like this?
First of all, don't dismiss the child's feelings, no matter how silly they seem.
Withholding empathy will make children feel misunderstood, and only make things worse.
Instead, find a way to connect. Comforting your child, and acknowledging their feelings, will encourage them to cooperate with you, and engage the upstairs brain.
However, some kids will take more time to calm down, so allow them this time – even an entire day, if necessary.
The more you make time to connect, the more they will feel loved.

insights.title: Search for the “why”, and refrain from lecturing

actions.title: Keep your discipline positive.
actions.markdown: Instead of trying to scare children into doing what you want, work to encourage cooperation by emphasising the rewards of your desired action, like more reading time before bed.

paragraphCards.markdown: Sometimes, as parents, our automatic response to misbehavior is to scold or lecture.
But what kids really need is someone who will try to understand them.
If you want to redirect them, children need to feel understood.
Rather than just telling them to stop "or else," try seeking out why they are doing something and dig deeper for a reason.
Once you figure out the reason for the misbehavior, it will be a lot easier to redirect them.
Positivity is also key.
Instead of saying things like, "brush your teeth now, or I won't read you any books," try saying "if you don't brush your teeth soon, we won't have time to read any books before bed."
Positive statements are far more likely to encourage cooperation from your child.
Keep in mind when disciplining that the way you treat your child is an example to them of how they should treat others.
In addition to positivity, remember that kids are a lot like us – they don't like to be lectured!
If your daughter is spending too much time with sports to do her homework, try not to rant about how she needs to get good grades to go to college.
Help her be part of the conversation, and ask her what she thinks would help give her more time.
Redirect in the least amount of words possible, have the child reflect on their behavior.
The more they can do this, the more they will be able to understand the connection between the way their actions affect others.
"For a child or an adult, it's extremely powerful to hear someone say, 'I get you. I understand. I see why you feel this way.' This kind of empathy disarms us." \[Daniel J. Siegel & Tina Bryson\]
We all want to be the best parents we can be for our kids, but it isn't until you actually have kids that you realize how hard parenting can be.
For starters, children are their own individuals and each will have different needs.
If you've found yourself tired of getting conflicting advice on parenting, No-Drama Discipline might be your answer.
No Drama Discipline takes on a whole-brained approach; based on neuroscience, the book explains how to best discipline your children in a way that teaches and nurtures your child.
Psychiatrist David J. Siegel and child psychotherapy specialist Tina Bryson's mission is to help you nurture your children by better understanding their developing brains.
Though the title has the word 'discipline', Siegel and Bryson emphasize that the word is not a synonym for punishment.
When we swap suffering for teaching, we can nurture our child and thus build a stronger relationship with them.

No-Drama Discipline is a refreshing approach to parenting that looks at the neuroscience of a developing child's brain to understand how to best discipline and teach kids while making them feel loved.
If you're a writer, especially a young writer, this book offers all the most important writing fundamentals you haven't heard of, and then some.

If you've honed your craft for a while already, and have consumed all the classics, Pressfield might not tell you anything new, but it'll be a refreshing reminder of core writing concepts nonetheless. This belongs in every writer's arsenal.

insights.title: Every piece of your writing needs a concept

actions.title: Find your angle.
actions.markdown: If you really want to make an impact, it’s no use spitting out a copy of someone else’s work. That doesn’t mean you can’t write the next great great dystopia or romance novel; you just have to find an angle that hasn’t been done before.

paragraphCards.markdown: Starting his writing career as a copywriter at 19, one of the first things Steven Pressfield learned in the world of slogans is that each campaign must put a unique spin on an existing idea.
Everyone hates commercials – most people even hate reading – so whatever you float in front of people's eyes better rile up some strong emotions.
Whether the reaction is "interesting," "outrageous," or "wow!", your work has to temporarily shut out all other perspectives by approaching a known issue from a completely different angle.
The approach taken by "No. 2" players in many major industries, whether it be fast food, sodas, or rental cars, work as a great example.
The "No. 2" players in any industry can turn their silver medal into gold simply by embracing that they're in the "No. 2" spot, rather than seeing it as a negative thing like you'd expect.
That's why 7Up calls itself the "uncola", and Avis promises to "try harder."
In a similar vein, the moment that diamonds were first marketed as a token of eternal love was the moment they displaced all other rare commodities in the jewelry market.
After all, if you're not proposing to someone you'll love forever, what the hell are you doing?
Before you write the first line, come up with a concept.

insights.title: The writer’s job is to solve problems

actions.title: Ask yourself: What’s the problem here?
actions.markdown: Sometimes you have to be your own editor. If you want to be a good writer, you have to look at your work with the eye of what’s going wrong, rather than what’s going right. Put your work aside for a few days before reading it over to give yourself a little distance.

paragraphCards.markdown: Thousands of hours of writer's block are caused around the world each and every single day by two seemingly simple questions: What do I write about? How am I going to say what I want to say?
Little do people know that great progress can be made with one very simple question: What's the problem here?
When you think of your writing as a way to solve a problem, you're well on your way towards the solution. The solution always lies within the problem itself.
For example, the problem of many "No. 2" companies in any given market is that their product is good, but not selling as much as their main competitor.
Once you see that you're trailing behind, you can think about how to fix it. You could openly admit it and state how you plan to win, or distance yourself from playing that game altogether.
All writing solves problems, whether it shows us how to make a lasagna in seven easy steps, or transforms our sense of self through an epic, 700-page journey.
Figure out the problem, and you'll find the solution.

insights.title: The three-act structure applies to all writing

actions.title: Use the 3 Act Structure.
actions.markdown: No matter what type of work you’re writing, try to find a sense of flow throughout the piece by presenting a scenario, a conflict, and a resolution.

paragraphCards.markdown: Boy loses his father. Evil servant takes the throne. Orphan prince grows up and wins it back.
That's the plot of The Lion King. But, with a few tweaks, it's also Aladdin, Prince of Persia, and a sub-plot in Lord of the Rings.
All fantastic stories with the exact same three-act structure. That's how universal this idea is.
From Aesop to Plato, Shakespeare to George R. R. Martin, great storytellers through the ages have all used the holy trinity of writing structure: beginning, middle and end.
Like the Hero's Journey, the three-act structure is how we connect with stories on the level of the soul. Therefore, it's not optional.
Whether you call it hook, build, and payoff, or setup, progression, and punchline, or beginning, middle and end – the rules remain the same.
Every story, every piece of text, must pull us in, string us along, and then reward us with a grand finale.

The first part kicks off the story and makes us curious as to what'll happen. The second act puts the villain on the scene, with events getting darker and darker until, in the last act, the hero saves the day.
This applies to fiction, non-fiction, page 17 news articles, and anything in-between.
The characters can be humans, animals, or constructs of the mind.
Everything is variable, as long as you stick to the path that all of the world's greatest writers have followed you before.
"If you want to write and be recognized, you have to do it yourself." \[Steven Pressfield\]
With a 50-year writing career under his belt, Steven Pressfield sure has a thing or two to share about what makes a good sentence, paragraph and book.
What's more, since he's succeeded in various career fields, you'll learn to approach writing from various angles.
Sometimes, you need to think like a marketer or screenwriter, other times you'd best wear your novelist hat.
Pressfield delivers 119 lessons in his usual, clear-cut, no-BS, witty style.
The most important? That writing is a form of deliberate practice.

Nobody Wants to Read Your Sh\*t combines the countless lessons Steven Pressfield has learned from his successful career as a writer in advertising, the movie industry, fiction, non-fiction, and self-help, in order to help you write like a pro.

insights.title: Build trust through mirroring, and focus on using the right tone of voice

actions.title: Mirror the last few words.
actions.markdown: If you want someone’s trust, you have to get them talking. Nudge them there by mirroring their words. (E.g.: “I grew up in Boston.” “You grew up in Boston?”) This naturally prompts the other party to elaborate.

paragraphCards.markdown: A great way to earn somebody's trust and to get them to open up to you is the active listening method.
Active listening means listening to people in a way that makes the other person feel understood.
One of the best ways to do this is by mirroring: repeating what the other person has just said, but with a question.
Mirroring is how you tease more tidbits of information from the other party.
The other person is more likely to talk because your mirroring makes them feel like you're similar to them.
This feeling will help them trust you, which in turn makes them more likely to work WITH you, not against you.
Tone of your voice is also an important aspect of garnering trust.
Have you ever been offended not because of something that was said, but because of the WAY that they said it?
If you're worried about the other person getting nervous or upset, try using a deep, soft voice that is reassuring and slow.
A gentler, steadier tone of voice will comfort the other party, and subconsciously make them feel like they're in a space. They're much more inclined to share information this way.
Unless you're in a sensitive situation, however, most situations will call for a more positive or playful voice.
A positive, upbeat tone makes you appear empathetic and easygoing.
A way to help you do this is by smiling while you speak. It comes through in the way you talk, and puts others at ease.

insights.title: To position yourself well in a negotiation, you need to label your partner’s emotions

actions.title: Put yourself in their shoes.
actions.markdown: Take the time to imagine how the other person must be feeling. What’s their ideal outcome? Labelling the other person’s feelings aloud will immediately relax them, and in turn make them lower their guard.

paragraphCards.markdown: When you want to negotiate with someone, don't ignore their emotions, but rather use your natural empathy skills to your advantage.
This doesn't mean you have to agree with whatever the other person says. It just means that you are trying to see things from their perspective.
When you take the time to put yourself in someone else's shoes, and acknowledge out loud how they must be feeling, you can position yourself better in the negotiation.
You can position yourself better by labeling another person's feelings: i.e, stating and acknowledging them.
Doing so will calm the other person down. In turn, they'll act in a more rational manner.
When someone labels our emotions, or we label someone else's, studies show it activates the rational part of our brain on brain scans.
This worked for Chris Voss when he was negotiating with four fugitives that they believed had automatic weapons hidden in an apartment.
He talked to them to find how they were feeling and labeled those feelings.
He acknowledged that they were scared to leave because they were scared of being shot or going back to prison.
After six hours, the fugitives surrendered.
They told Chris Voss that his talking to them had calmed them down.

insights.title: Take things slowly, don’t accept demands, and never compromise

actions.title: Never split the difference.
actions.markdown: Take your time to establish the bigger picture first. Find out as much as possible about the other party, working out all possible factors that are impacting their decisions. Once you know these, you can determine where to find wiggle room.

paragraphCards.markdown: Taking things slow, and not compromising during a dispute, will help you settle on better solutions.
Chris Voss teaches that compromising, or "splitting the difference", is always a bad idea. Avoid it at all costs!
Everyone has thoughts they're reluctant to share, or motives that they aren't even consciously aware of, so even if they ask for something, you can't be sure that's what they REALLY want.
Because of this, giving someone what they ask for doesn't always solve the real problem at hand.
This is why it's so important to not rush, even when there are deadlines.

Before you reach a conclusion, you need to make sure you've found out as much context as possible. Make sure you have lots of information about the other party, and all the factors contributing to their decision process.
If you rush the process, chances are higher that you'll have clouded judgment.
The truth is, most deadlines are set at random and are usually flexible. So take your time. That's how you'll create the best solution.
An example of this was when Voss was involved in negotiations with a kidnapper who had the wife of a Haitian police officer for a ransom of $150,000.
Voss noticed that every week, as Friday approached, the kidnappers would get more serious about the ransom. After the weekend, they got quieter again.
Voss realized what the kidnappers really wanted was significant funds to party on the weekends.
Once Voss realized the "deadlines" weren't that serious as previously thought, he knew could negotiate a much lower price, because partying in Haiti wasn't that expensive.
"He who has learned to disagree without being disagreeable has discovered the most valuable secret of negotiation." \[Chris Voss\]
When you hear the word "negotiation," what comes to mind?
Maybe you think of corporate board rooms, or even the police trying to negotiate a hostage situation.
But we all negotiate on a daily basis, whether or not you're aware of it. You're a negotiator, and it's time to start thinking of yourself as one!
Negotiation is any interaction you have with a specific outcome in mind.
Negotiation happens at home, with friends, with kids, or out shopping.
Negotiating is asking your boss for a raise. Or persuading your spouse to try out a new restaurant instead of going to the usual.
If you're a parent, negotiation is getting your kids to eat their broccoli before they can have their dessert.
As you probably know all too well, some of these interactions go better than others.

insights.title: We spend our entire lives either operating from fear or faith

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: In best-selling author Napoleon Hill's fictitious interview with evil incarnate, the Devil himself, Hill already knew one of the primary tools in the devil's belt: fear.
A few years earlier, Hill had received a death threat. He ended up hiding with relatives for over a year, paralyzed.
One night, he finally went outside and found what steel magnate Andrew Carnegie had told him years before...

"You will discover that the cause of success is not something separate and apart from the man; that it is a force so intangible in nature that the majority of men never recognize it; a force which might be properly called the 'other self.'" \[Andrew Carnegie, industrialist\]
The other self told Hill to stop giving in to fear and doubt, and finally finish his philosophy of achievement, which he did.
When we're listening to our other self, we have faith in ourselves.
We don't give in to what Steven Pressfield calls the Resistance. This is the only way to properly operate in life.
However, this 'other self' is exactly what the devil tries to undermine at every turn of our lives. He does so by dividing mankind into drifters and non-drifters.

insights.title: The Devil seeks to make us permanent drifters, never getting around to what we’re meant to do in life

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The Devil has clever ways of ruining us.
First, our minds are invaded with "the principle of habit", in order to then establish "the habit of drifting."
Here's what drifting is, straight from the horse's mouth:
"I can best define the word "drift" by saying that people who think for themselves never drift, while those who do little or no thinking for themselves are drifters."
A drifter is the antithesis of a Stoic.
Drifters let themselves be tossed around in life and allow externals to dominate their minds.
They go nowhere because they're not using their brains to think.

Later in the book, Hill explains how drifting eventually turns into a "hypnotic rhythm," which keeps people busy with trivialities, and over time, drifting becomes permanent. Unless we outwit the devil and take control of our own lives, that is.

insights.title: There are seven principles that help us gain mental, spiritual, and physical freedom

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: How can we combat the dire forces of our inner-saboteur?
There are seven principles humans should follow to find freedom in all walks of life:
1.  **Definiteness of purpose**. Choose a purpose, a grand aspiration, a big goal, and move towards it relentlessly.
2.  **Mastery over self**. Discipline equals freedom. If we're driven by impulse all your life, we'll go nowhere, like a drifter.
3.  **Learning from adversity**. Failures are just failures. Whether we learn from them, or let them stop us, is up to us.
4.  **Controlling environmental influence**. Who we hang out with matters. What our room looks like matters.
5.  **Time**. Time can make drifting and negativity permanent. But it can also make positivity and wisdom permanent.
6.  **Harmony**. In order for us to balance mental, spiritual, and physical aspects of our life, we must be the main actor.
7.  **Caution**. Always act. But we must always think before we act.
Setbacks happen to the best of us.
But those setbacks can quickly turn into lasting indecisiveness. Don't let them. Don't let the devil win.
Life's too important of a game for us to lose it.
"Your only limitation is the one you set up in your own mind." \[Napoleon Hill\]
In 1908, would-be author of the global phenomenon that became Think And Grow Rich, Napoleon Hill, interviewed the richest man in America: Andrew Carnegie.
Carnegie had already sold his steel company to J.P. Morgan at the time, amassing a fortune of some $370+ billion dollars in modern-day estimations.

When Hill told Carnegie that he planned to enter law school and interview successful people as a way of earning money on the side, the business magnate made an odd request.
Why couldn't Hill just interview people full time? Both the successes and the failures?
Carnegie was convinced people needed to learn not so much from books, but from others who'd gone through "the school of life."
Hill took the advice to heart. Eventually, he would interview some 25,000 normal people and 500 extraordinary outliers.
Think and Grow Rich was a huge success, making Hill a rather famous figure himself.
In 1938, one year after the book came out, he immediately set out to create his next work.
Sadly, his imaginary interview with the root of all evil, Outwitting the Devil, never saw the light of day.
His wife thought it too controversial for its time, which is why it wasn't published until 72 years later, in 2011.
Outwitting the Devil is an imagined interview between Napoleon Hill and the Devil himself, wringing certain truths from the root of evil that will help us avoid Lucifer's grasp and live a good life.

insights.title: China promoted its one-child policy through every available means, putting heavy pressure on families to comply

paragraphCards.markdown: In the late 1970s, there was a lot of concern about overpopulation. [giphy.com/KURUMAIMPORTS/](https://media.giphy.com/media/dUTXAiqyIQFXO83EDi/giphy.mp4)

As China was the world's most populous country with nearly one billion people, it was widely believed both at home and abroad that they were growing too fast and would eventually be unable to feed all of their people.
In 1979, the Chinese government instituted a policy limiting families to one child, intended to increase food security and living standards.

The one-child policy was promoted everywhere from billboards and theatrical performances to snack boxes and playing cards. ![One-child\_policy\_in\_China.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d2/One-child_policy_in_China.jpg)
Wang herself performed in a children's choir, singing songs praising the policy.
"The government used music and TV to show people a better life that they could imagine themselves living, as long as they followed the rules." \[Nanfu Wang\]
Born in 1985, Nanfu Wang returned to the village of her childhood to interview locals and recall growing up under the one-child policy.
Families were obliged to comply through a combination of official punishment and awards of public recognition.
Wang's own family was granted an exemption, but the social stigma remained. [youtube.com/c/TED](https://youtu.be/flb_S5JJC4k?t=65.41&e=90.14)

insights.title: The one-child policy combined with China’s allowing international adoptions ended up creating a ‘market’ for children

paragraphCards.markdown: Pressure stemming from the one-child policy resulted in many babies being abandoned or confiscated. ![Which Future in China - Baby in national flag](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_628071452.jpg)
They would then be brought to orphanages by 'matchmakers' who were paid for their services.
China began allowing children to be adopted by foreigners in 1992.

For international families looking to adopt, the process was bureaucratically straightforward and predictable. ![Tired Baby](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_689274.jpg)
For Chinese orphanages, international adoption was extremely profitable, each successful one bringing in up to twenty-five thousand dollars.

The combination of restrictions on family size and international demand created perverse incentives to channel children into the adoption pipeline. ![Newborn baby crying on the bed](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_129388706.jpg)
Orphanages employed networks of recruiters and midwives to 'find' children by any available means, with many taken from their parents or otherwise brought in illegitimately.
Local police were paid off, children's information was fabricated, and cursory notices printed in newspapers gave only 60 days for a child to be claimed before they were put up for adoption.
"Of the hundreds of kids at this orphanage adopted internationally, less than a handful of them actually seem to have been legitimately found. The rest were brought in by people." \[Nanfu Wang\]

insights.title: Although it has now ended, the one-child policy had a devastating impact on families

paragraphCards.markdown: "We are fighting a population war" was a common slogan used by the government during the One-Child Policy. China started a war against population growth, but it became a real war against its own people."  \[Nanfu Wang\]

Responsibility for enforcing the one-child policy was delegated to the local level, with midwives and family planning workers in every village. ![Cute baby retro shoes](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1168538407.jpg)

To meet goals set by higher-ups, local officials would threaten families, confiscate children, and arrange forced sterilizations and abortions. One of the nurses interviewed deeply regrets her role in these actions, while another proudly defends it.

During the one-child policy's existence, families were separated and people grew up unaware of their relatives. ![Family separation](https://www.aclunc.org/sites/default/files/styles/content_image_regular/public/separating_families_image.png)
Longlan and Brian Stuy, who adopted multiple Chinese children, founded a service to research adopted children's histories and use DNA matching to connect them with their birth families.
However, some adoptees prefer not to learn about their biological parents.
Because sons were more prized in Chinese society, female babies were often abandoned or aborted so the family could try again.
After 35 years, concern about gender imbalance and having a sufficient workforce to support an aging population led the government to end the one-child policy.

But there has been no accountability for its impact on children and families. ![a senior man is reading newspaper](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_63015907.jpg)
Journalist Pang Jiaoming, who was one of the first to publish about the one-child policy's abuses and unintended consequences, was fired and now lives in exile in Hong Kong.

"I'm struck by the irony that I left a country where the government forced women to abort, and I moved to another country where governments restrict abortions. On the surface they seem like opposites, but both are about taking away women's control of their own bodies." \[Nanfu Wang\]
China today is one of the world's most powerful and largest economies, as well as its most populous country.
But on its path to its current position the Chinese government engaged in history's largest and most controversial family planning experiment, limiting its citizens to only one child per family.

Filmmaker Nanfu Wang grew up in China's Jiangxi Province before attending journalism school in the United States. ![Nanfu\_Wang\_2019.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6d/Nanfu_Wang_2019.jpg)

Both intimate and far-reaching in scope, One Child Nation bears witness to a policy that impacted millions both in China and abroad.
A painstaking effort by Chinese-American filmmaker Nanfu Wang, One Child Nation takes a critical look at China's one-child policy and how it has impacted families throughout the country.
