insights.title: After we cross a certain skill threshold, our abilities won’t help us

paragraphCards.markdown: To debunk the myth of the 'self-made man', which might be the most popular myth of our time, author Malcolm Gladwell first looked at how many of our skills really influence where we end up in life.
Of course practice matters, and so do genetic predispositions in sports - but their influence is limited. ![giphy.com/weplaystrong](https://media.giphy.com/media/1fVXwCFwNUdnrjlc6d/giphy.gif)
As it turns out, once you cross a certain threshold with your skills and abilities, any extra won't do you much good.
For example, since the 1980s, the average height of an NBA basketball player has been 6ft7\. ![giphy.com/slimjimstudios/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2QZSithIGhPdpSdq/giphy.gif)
Even if you grow to be 7 feet tall, those additional inches won't give you a huge advantage over other players.
Gladwell also looked at law school students and their performance. ![giphy.com/snl/](https://media.giphy.com/media/MAv5RI0emuaDnalmtJ/giphy.gif)

Some law schools lower their admission requirements for racial minorities, and even though these students tend to perform worse than their non-minority peers both before and in law school, this gap completely disappears once they graduate.
They make the same valuable contributions, get paid just as much, and receive as many honors as their peers.
Once we've reached a certain level of legal expertise, other factors start to take over and influence our career.
This could be factors like social skills, how good our network already is, and even catching a lucky break.

insights.title: Being born in the wrong month can put you at a disadvantage

paragraphCards.markdown: Remember ever seeing an 8th grader in high school date a 10th grader? You were probably shocked!
You might remember the comments too - something along the lines of, "He's 2 years older than her, that's insane!" ![giphy.com/cbc/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7btPCcdNniyf0ArS/giphy.gif)
However, when you're 40 and take your partner to dinner with the neighbors, nobody would be surprised to hear that your partner is 38, 42, or even several more years older or younger than you.
That's because relative age matters, especially when we're young.
How old you are compared to your peers can give you a huge advantage or disadvantage, for example in sports. ![giphy.com/TaylorBisciotti](https://media.giphy.com/media/fnMUoQgpmlDtyyMSrj/giphy.gif)
Author Malcolm Gladwell found out that most professional Canadian hockey players, who end up in the NHL, are born in the first half of the year.
In fact, twice as many have birthdays in the first quarter as in the last.
That's because the annual cutoff date for youth teams is January 1st, meaning kids born in December have to compete with their friends who are almost a year older than they are.
When you're eight years old, you stand no chance against a nine year old in terms of strength and speed ![giphy.com/nhl/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4FGp7yJRMJLPsXuw/giphy.gif)
The difference is huge when a year makes up 12.5% of your entire life. Think through it yourself, and you'll see this happens all the time.

insights.title: Wherever you are born will have significant long-term impact on who you are

paragraphCards.markdown: Imagine if you'd been born somewhere entirely different to where you were. Warren Buffett always says he's been lucky to have been born in the United States at the time he was.
A few thousand years ago, with his kinds of genes, he'd have been some animal's lunch. ![giphy.com/bbcamerica/](https://media.giphy.com/media/h4sIGoW7qd9lJl5jze/giphy.gif)
For example, Malcolm Gladwell says there's a reason for the stereotype that "Asians are good at math." Several factors actually _are_ in favor of Asians becoming relatively good at it.
First, Asian languages are set up so that children learn to add numbers simultaneously with learning to count.

Second, hundreds of years of building a traditional culture around farming rice has instilled a great sense of discipline into Asian culture. ![Pana Banaue Rice Terraces.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Pana_Banaue_Rice_Terraces.jpg/640px-Pana_Banaue_Rice_Terraces.jpg)
Unlike farming wheat or corn, farming rice is hard. It needs a lot more precision, control, coordination and patience.

Rice farmers could also reap the full rewards of their work, whereas European farmers were often robbed of a big part of their harvest by greedy landlords and nobility, leaving them far less motivated to do their best.
Just like rice farming, math is hard. ![giphy.com/funkofficial/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUPGcqaVH1cDeKZTBS/giphy.gif)
You have to stick with problems and let the gears in your brain crunch until you work it out.
Europeans often give up a lot faster on hard math questions than their Asian peers, because neither math nor discipline are a part of their cultural legacy.
So yes, where you're born matters.
"Who we are cannot be separated from where we're from." \[Malcolm Gladwell\]
This book is where the 10,000 hour rule comes from.

Malcolm Gladwell's 10,000 hour rule states that to become world-class at anything, you have to put in 10,000 hours of practice. ![giphy.com/warnerarchive](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9DPFRD31xIOsdBjW/giphy.gif)

For those who don't fancy the math, this equals about five years of uninterrupted 40-hour workweeks worth of practice. ![giphy.com/originals](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41YtZOb9EUABnuqA/giphy.gif)
In reality, it's often closer to ten years.
Because of this, you'd expect that Outliers might be about deliberate practice \- how success is in our own hands, if we work hard enough.
But boy, you'd be wrong. The book argues the exact opposite.

Outliers explains why the 'self-made man' is a myth, and that lucky events, rare opportunities, and other external factors out of our control are what truly lies behind the success of the best people in their field.
Psychology of Influence and Human Behavior is a concise course that hones in on the psychological elements of good behavior, and how they help you in achieving personal and professional fulfilment.

insights.title: Your behavior is what you choose it to be

actions.title: Take responsibility for your actions.
actions.markdown: Become more confident in your choices and take responsibility for your actions - the good and the bad ones. Taking the confidence to take responsibility is the first step towards authority.

actions.title: Be patient with yourself.
actions.markdown: Distance yourself from external stimuli - you don’t have control over every outcome. Practice creating room for yourself, and stay patient in stressful times. Think slowly and carefully to make wise decisions.

paragraphCards.markdown: There are two models in psychology that explain human behavior: the stimulus-response model and the choice-action model.
The stimulus-response model suggests that our behavior is the result of external or internal stimuli or impulses. It detaches human will from the action.
Although the stimulus-response model is extensively used by psychologists to determine human behavior, it has an evident side-effect.
We tend to internalize the notion that we do not have control over our actions.
This means that we are not directly responsible for what we do. For example, "I failed the exam because stupidity runs in my DNA."
Dr. William Galarza suggests otherwise. Instead, he stresses the use of the choice-action approach to evaluate behavior.
According to the choice-action model, we are the active agent of any action we choose to perform. This is where self-responsibility comes into play.
It doesn't necessarily mean that we are completely free of any external or preset determiners for our action - just that there is sufficient room for you to improve your behavior.
So, it isn't because stupidity runs in your DNA that you failed the exam - you just didn't prepare for it, no more excuses.

insights.title: Your mind makes decisions based on your basic human needs

actions.title: Evaluate your needs before taking an action.
actions.markdown: Evaluating your long-term goals against your immediate needs is the key to making the right decisions. Do not let your immediate needs block your broader vision.

actions.title: Actively evaluate other people’s needs.
actions.markdown: The people you interact with every day also want to be treated with respect - just in the way you would want others to treat you. Notice their expectations and use these to create an impact.

paragraphCards.markdown: Our mind evaluates decisions it has to make based on our basic human needs and desires.
These motives include biological, psychological, social, recreational, and spiritual desires.
Biological needs come down to our physical need to survive. However, going up the ladder to our spiritual needs, they become more complex and even more fulfilling.
Although biological needs live at the bottom of the hierarchy, it can be the most overpowering one.
On the other hand, spiritual motives are at the top of this hierarchy and, if honed well, can make you a truly influential person.
When making decisions in any aspect of your life, if you actively think in the moment, you can build self-control, and choose what is right for you in the long run.
It isn't always about primal instincts, but about prioritizing what really matters. You always have the sufficient freedom to act wisely in the moment.

insights.title: To fulfil your desires, you need to work with other people

actions.title: Communicate your needs.
actions.markdown: In times of crisis, clearly express your needs to the people around you - in both professional and intimate settings. Have personal fulfilment by getting friends, colleagues and loved ones to understand your goals and how they can help.

actions.title: Listen to others and work together.
actions.markdown: To succeed, you need to be present for others around you. Take note of people’s expectations and hopes from you, and devise a solution that benefits everyone.

paragraphCards.markdown: Our mind is always occupied with multiple different desires at a time.
When you've practiced evaluating your desires and prioritizing them, you need to start observing how they are connected to one another and how they shape each other.
For example, you must have noticed that after a break-up, you don't feel like eating or going out for a couple of days. Your emotional needs directly influence your biological and social needs.
But to fulfil your desires, you need to get out of this cycle.
When Aristotle said that we are social animals, he meant it.
To break the cycle, you need other people to lean on. Most of the time, your needs are also connected to them.
But at the same time, the others need you too. It's all about give and take.
"All of your behaviours, all of my behaviours, all of them are choices we make." \[Hamed Mardanpour\]

The world is becoming increasingly corporate in its essence, and we all want the same structure and precision in our personal lives - all these concepts of self-development and growth. But how can we be successful in our daily lives without understanding how our mind operates?
Fortunately, there are people like Hamed Mardanpour who want to understand the psyche of influential behavior, and so do the homework for us.
He knocks into his clients' fears and gets them to speak and live more confidently, and has helped more than 800 individuals in the realm of public speaking.

In his other course, Professional Public Speaking and Presentation Skills, Hamed trains individuals to articulate clearly what they always wanted to share. But it is in Psychology of Influence and Human Behavior that he reveals how we function as behavioral beings.
Psychology of Influence and Human Behavior breaks down the psychology of human behavior to devise a step-by-step method to gain more control over your actions, and have a positive impact over others.

paragraphCards.markdown: Quiet will make you agree with the press: it makes introverts feel heard. Whoever shouts the loudest is not necessarily the smartest. ![giphy.com/creativewannabe\_](https://media.giphy.com/media/McbOLe9aRQu2wvhhFR/giphy.gif)
The internet might be the greatest invention of all time, especially for introverts, as it allows us to impact the world right from our living room.

insights.title: Whether you’re an introvert or extrovert determines if you like small talk

paragraphCards.markdown: Do you love when your friend Sally gives you the gossip from her latest vacation in Cancun over a quick cup of coffee? Or would you rather talk about Stoic philosophy for two hours?
The former speaks more to an extrovert, the latter more to an introvert. But why is that?
It's because of the way we process information differently. ![giphy.com/davidurbinati](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o85xrC0TF80dCdNVm/giphy.gif)

Introverts are what's called 'highly sensitive', meaning they take in the information given to them - for example, via stimuli from their environment - a lot more thoroughly than their extrovert peers.
An introvert can stand in front of a single big picture in a museum for ten minutes, continuously observing and looking for new details to be found – a horror fantasy for an extrovert.
In a similar manner, introverts don't like small talk.

They are engaged by profound conversations about life, values, morals and ethics, because it allows their highly sensitive information processing to thrive. [youtube.com/c/bbcideas](https://youtu.be/o1Y4Z0oh1GE?t=0.00&e=15.50)

Note: If you don't already know it, check out the Myers-Briggs personality test to find out your own type. It's free and very insightful. ![giphy.com/agatha](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o85xFqWwrB7qQvmus/giphy.gif)

insights.title: In Western cultures, extroverts are often presented as the ideal of success

paragraphCards.markdown: Competence and confidence are two different things. Sadly, in Western cultures, we confuse them a lot. ![giphy.com/benny-box](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41YyPr5uegK2VDEs/giphy.gif)
We often perceive whoever's the most confident to be the most competent as well. [youtube.com/c/rsaorg](https://youtu.be/rUaj7rj6MI8?t=8.70&e=28.50)

That couldn't be further from the truth, since just being a charming speaker and captivating figure does not make one a good leader. ![giphy.com/loosekeys](https://media.giphy.com/media/C9xz2ZeHr5rqiLL8y4/giphy.gif)
Being more sociable often leads people to think you're also more interesting and willing to cooperate.
But if you're an introvert, sitting quietly in your corner, just listening and taking everything in, nobody will come and talk to you.
More often than not, people will think you're a weirdo. ![giphy.com/loosekeys](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0Iy8XWFAlU2cJfK8/giphy.gif)
In our culture, extroversion is often seen as a prerequisite for success, which gives extroverts an unfair advantage.
Even the best schools, like Harvard, try to groom their graduates into extroverts.

They force them into group work, seminars, presentations - and even going out with fellow students at night as part of their program. ![giphy.com/liannedias](https://media.giphy.com/media/l46C9XdxiNKzXveLe/giphy.gif)
Go to Japan, however, and you'll find none of this. Students study quietly, take vigorous notes, and speaking without being asked is considered downright rude.
Different countries, different cultures, but in the Western world, the extrovert ideal prevails.

insights.title: Companies should adapt their workplaces to let introverts make their best contribution

actions.title: Include the introverts.
actions.markdown: Consider both the quiet and the sociable when working with your team. Allow people to do things their way - in fact, actively encourage it. Find ways to bring people together that suits both sides.

paragraphCards.markdown: Due to the extrovert success ideal, most companies are tailored to extroverts. ![giphy.com/loosekeys](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohhwjUHA9kB6LY0Le/giphy.gif)
Think about it: open offices, meetings, group brainstorming sessions, presentations of PowerPoint slides, workshops and of course, lunch at the canteen.
For introverts this means they feel constantly interrupted, overloaded with information and stressed.
This, in turn, makes it hard for them to thrive in such an environment. ![giphy.com/juliaveldmanc](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oFzm9ZDwguOVj4O7m/giphy.gif)
But not all great things were achieved by extroverts or even groups of people.

Wikipedia, for example, is a huge collaboration, but mostly of people who each sit at their computer alone at home. Einstein thought of the theory of relativity all on his own and Harry Potter was written in solitude too.
So if you have a great introverted thinker on your team, don't force them into a box they don't fit into.

Give them the option to work alone and let them flourish. As long as you keep an open mind, they'll always come to you once they're ready. ![giphy.com/animatedyoojin](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4Epa7MDlF40fJNWE/giphy.gif)
Companies should consider this and have more options for introverts to spend time alone vs. participating in group activities and meetings when they feel they have something to share.
"Spend your free time the way you like, not the way you think you're supposed to." \[Susan Cain\]

Susan Cain has a top TED talk about the power of introverts which has been viewed over 10 million times. ![Susan\_Cain\_%2834856862012%29.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Susan_Cain_%2834856862012%29.jpg/1024px-Susan_Cain_%2834856862012%29.jpg)
The reason is that her book and talk made a lot of people feel heard for the first time.
In the seven years of research leading up to the publication of Quiet in 2012, Cain uncovered the slow rise of the extrovert ideal in the public and American workplace.
This helped her understand where a lot of her personal struggles as a Harvard Law School graduate and Wall Street lawyer came from, and why she could never have thrived in these environments.
Her book is a well of wisdom about personality types, workplace relationships and human interaction. ![giphy.com/teamtumult](https://media.giphy.com/media/Pja6kqFAQsVu09B9SF/giphy.gif)
[youtube.com/c/ForbesLife](https://youtu.be/hYn6NeWemVw?t=13.10&e=31.90)

Quiet shows the slow rise of the extrovert ideal for success throughout the 20th century, while making a case for the underappreciated power of introverts and showing up new ways for both forces to cooperate.
Radical Candor shows us how important it is to just be open with people. Having that skill, combined with truly caring, is the real secret to getting the most out of everybody.

insights.title: Radical candor means being direct and honest with people, without offending

actions.title: Be honest with your team.
actions.markdown: Don’t tiptoe around the fact that one of your team members or colleagues is underperforming, or doing something incorrectly. Without insulting them, try to find a way to point this out, and help them improve.

paragraphCards.markdown: You might be wondering what radical candor is. Let's see what the definitions are, according to Google…

*   Radical: far-reaching or thorough.
*   Candor: being open and honest in expression.
In other words, radical candor is the quality of being thoroughly open and honest with others.
When it comes to work and management, this means balancing care for your team members with helping them know where they need to improve.
Developing this skill starts with building a personal relationship with each person you work with.
Show that you care, by being open and talking about things other than business.
As you continue working with individuals, having radical candor will require you to challenge them to do better when they're not doing what they should.
Be honest with them about where they are at, even if it's not easy.

An example from Kim Malone Scott's experience working for Google perfectly encompasses how to do this right. She had just given a presentation, and her boss came up afterward to compliment how well she did and give some feedback.
Interestingly, the way her boss delivered the constructive criticism was to wrap it within a compliment. She told Scott to not say 'um' as much, explaining that it can make people sound stupid.
But she added that this would be a shame, in Scott's case, because she was so smart.

insights.title: Barking orders doesn’t work - you must collaborate with your team to be efficient

actions.title: Encourage negative feedback.
actions.markdown: Give your team the green light to point out when you’ve missed something, or are going wrong. Ask them what they think of an idea or process, and if there’s any way they would improve.

paragraphCards.markdown: Have you ever thought about how exciting it is that you get to work around so many brilliant people?
If you're a leader, it can be really fun to get to lead discussions, and work closely with each individual.
The best leaders know that this is how to get stuff done. Bad managers, on the other hand, just try to boss people around.
Steve Jobs gave us the perfect example of 'collaborative leadership'. He knew that he wasn't always going to be right, so he challenged his employees to speak their mind when they disagreed with him.

He even got angry once because an employee who had given up on convincing Jobs to change his mind ended up being right. Jobs had to let the man know that he was hired to make sure that Jobs didn't make mistakes.
There are four steps to reproducing this collaborative leadership yourself…

1.  Listen to people's ideas, and create a safe space for them to speak openly.
2.  Let your team have the time to refine their ideas.
3.  Have debates to allow all options to come to the table, and then decide on one.
4.  As the manager, present the idea to your superiors to have it implemented - then make it happen once they do.

insights.title: Honest conversations will help discover your employees’ real motivations, and support them

actions.title: Set one-to-ones for no reason.
actions.markdown: Most managers only plan one-to-ones to discuss specific work projects, plans, or processes. Instead, set up a meeting with individuals to just talk about life. Find out where they’ve come from, and where they want to go next - then help them get there.

paragraphCards.markdown: Most people have big aspirations. If you as a leader aren't harnessing the powerful motivation these can provide, you're not reaching your team's full potential.
To be the kind of boss that people really care about and that makes a difference, you need to learn what people want out of life, and help them get it.
By talking with and listening to them, you can become invested in paving the way for them to reach their dreams.
When he was director of sales at Google, Russ Laraway would have career talks with employees. In one of these, Russ could tell that his employee, Sarah, wasn't being fully open with him.
After asking what other visions for the future she had, Sarah revealed she wanted to own a farm. Now they could refocus on what would really inspire her, and bring out her full potential.
There are a few types of conversations you can have to bring out people's true motivations…

1.  The life story: ask about people's entire life up to this point.
2.  The dream job: let individuals express their biggest career aspirations.
3.  The 18-month plan: explore with people where they want to be in the near future.
Try each of these, and with the power of radical candor, your whole team will be reaching new heights in no time.

"Make sure that you are seeing each person on your team with fresh eyes every day. People evolve, and so your relationships must evolve with them. Care personally; don't put people in boxes and leave them there."
Each boss you ever have will be different, and you'll learn something from all of them.
Some let you do whatever you want, and you'll have to deal with the pitfalls of your own oversight.
Others will be mean and demanding, which in turn will bring you down, hinder your progress, and perhaps ultimately make you leave.
The best leaders, however, will always be those who help you get closer to reaching your full potential. They lift you up and offer constructive criticism.
Kim Malone Scott's book Radical Candor: Be a Kick-Ass Boss Without Losing Your Humanity will teach you how to be kind and help people improve.
You'll be amazed by how helpful this new outlook on leadership is, and how it can even make managing people a little easier, too.

Radical Candor is the ultimate guide to becoming a great leader, manager, or boss. It will teach you how to connect with people, push them to be their best, know when and how to fire them, and create an environment of trust and innovation at work.
Working remotely is not always easy, but it's way better than any office job. Whether you're an employee or employer, consider it - Remote is a good place to start learning.

insights.title: You can have more freedom than ever by working remotely

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Let's say you have a regular job. You have to be at the office at 8AM every day, so every morning you have to drop off your kid at school 15 minutes before it actually starts to make it to work on time.
You drive for another 30 minutes and you're there. On a bad day, your son might get sick and you'll have to pick him up at 11AM again to take him to the doctor.

First, you have to ask your boss if it's okay for you to go. Second you'll have to cancel the 11:30AM meeting. Then, after you've been to the doctor, you have to find someone to take care of your child as you go back to work.
Well, that sucks. But what if you worked remotely?
You could have just dropped off your kid, gone back home, started working and later picked him up without asking anyone for permission.
He could stay home all day with you as you just keep doing your work from home. No meetings, no commute and no-one rolling their eyes over you taking off to take care of your child.
The freedom and flexibility remote work can give you is so powerful that it'll likely make you a LOT happier than any office benefits ever could.
What's more, you can work at whichever time works best for you – not everyone's a morning person.
Especially in creative jobs, it's hard to force inspiration to start working its magic at 9AM.

Most importantly though, you can use a lot of the time you gain back to really pursue your hobbies and dreams – writing your book, creating your TV show or traveling the world won't have to wait any longer!

insights.title: Your employees will get a lot more done when they work from home

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: One of the main reasons employers are scared of remote work is that they think people will be lazy, just watch TV all day and not do their work. But this couldn't be more wrong.
In fact, people are likely to be a lot more productive than before.
Why? Because the office is a very distracting place itself.
For one you're surrounded by other people, and people are the worst distractors of all.

"Have you seen this funny video?"

"Did you hear the news about our competitor's new product?"

"Can you help me with this bug in my email software real quick?"

Add to that coffee breaks, chit chat and having to wait for other people's input so you can continue, and you can easily see why most people probably spend less than half of their 8-hour-workday getting things done.
Of course there are distractions when working remotely as well. However, a lot of the worst ones aren't.
Working remotely eliminates meetings, interruptions from other people, and a lot of the waiting for input, and is therefore highly likely to make your employees more productive.

As a bonus, it allows managers to judge employees' work solely based on quality because other, distorting factors (which don't really matter anyway), like how nice they are to their co-workers, how often they take breaks, whether they're late a lot, etc. fall by the wayside.

insights.title: Never ever forget that there’s a real person behind every email address

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: One thing that's certainly harder to create in a remote work environment is meaningful connections between employees.
Through all the different layers of communication software, it's easy to forget that there's a real person with real feelings and needs behind every email address, Slack profile and Trello card.
To make sure employees get quality time with each other, Fried and Hansson created a virtual meeting & chat room where employees could hang out together during lunch break or 'grab coffee together'.

Remote workers have to be extra careful about how they communicate because when you can't see someone's body language, it's hard to know whether they're joking, smiling or really upset about something.
In the end, digital communication only gets you so far, so the best thing to do is to, well, actually meet.
At Basecamp there are two annual retreats each year where all employees get a chance to finally meet in person.
This strengthens all relationships across the board and reminds everyone what it's all about: having fun and working – together.
"If you run your ship with the conviction that everyone's a slacker, your employees will put all their ingenuity into proving you right." \[David Heinemeier Hansson, Jason Fried\]

In ReWork, Jason Fried and David Heinemeier Hansson explained how you can build a company without investors funding you, having millions of dollars to spend on marketing, or having thousands of meetings.
In Remote they expand on that, showing you how you can get people to be productive, work together and be happy, all without ever setting foot in an office.

The two turned their own company, Basecamp, into an almost entirely remotely run enterprise. They do have a headquarters in Chicago, but their 50 employees are spread across 32 cities all around the globe.

Over the years they found that remote work isn't just great for employees – it's great for employers too! Many companies are still scared of this concept, simply because it's unfamiliar and requires new rules to work. That's exactly what this book is for.
Remote explains why offices are a thing of the past and what both companies and employees can do to thrive in a company that's spread all across the globe with people working wherever they choose to.
Silent Spring turned out to be a milestone in raising global awareness of environmental issues.
You can see why: it's insightful and well-written.
The book also conveys the voice of a woman who stood for truth even in the face of the assaults from the chemical industry, which went after her.
The determination and knowledge shine through Carson's words on every page.

insights.title: Pesticides destroy not just the particular pests, but entire ecosystems

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Humanity "inherited" pesticides from World War II.
During the war, scientists involved in chemical warfare discovered many substances with which to kill enemies.
When the war ended, upon observation, those same substances were lethal not only to humans – but also, to insects and some other agricultural pests.
So, at first, using chemicals seemed like a great way to protect crops.
But since pesticides became more widely used, many studies were carried out which proved that most of the chemical substances had numerous destructive side effects.
These effects are the main focus of Carson's book.
The huge disadvantage of chemical pesticides is that they virtually never target unwanted pests selectively.
Once they are distributed into the environment, they get easily transmitted through water, as well as passed on in the food chain. This causes a whole variety of species to ingest chemicals.
This has far-fetched consequences, as it easily disrupts the delicate balance of whole ecosystems.
In the end, pesticides usually create more problems than they solve.
A perfect example of the dangers brought by mindless use of pesticides is the US Forest Service's mass-use of DDT for combating the spruce budworm in 1956.
Spraying the pesticide over 885,000 acres of woodland, they ended up exterminating not just the spruce budworm – but also natural predators of the spider mite.
As a consequence, the latter bred beyond control – and became a worldwide pest in the following years.
Quite a big price to pay for an inconsiderate use of some chemicals.

insights.title: Once DDT enters the food chain, it affects all the species involved

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Even if you don't care much about other living organisms on the planet, it would certainly be concerning to learn that pesticides found a way into your own body.
"But how is this possible?", you may ask. If you are not a farmer or experience other forms of direct exposure to the chemicals, you may think that you are safe.
Even if it's a big environmental problem, at least this doesn't affect your health, right?
The problem is, this is not how it works. **Pesticides – the deadly dangerous DDT in particular – transmit easily through the food chain.
** This means that even though you don't come in direct contact with the DDT, your body may still contain an amount that is potentially health- or even life-threatening.
For example, one group of people who never came in direct contact with DDT had between 5.3 and 7.4 particles of DTT per million in their system.
This may not sound like a lot – but experiments have shown that even five particles per million may already cause liver cells to disintegrate!
So how did this happen? Further investigation revealed that the DDT present in those people's bodies originated from alfalfa farms that used the pesticides for crop protection.
That contaminated alfalfa was later fed to chickens, which laid eggs that still contained significant amounts of DDT.
By eating the eggs, people in the study still ingested a dangerously high amount of the chemical.

insights.title: The two main solutions to the harmful effect of pesticides are education and biological alternatives to deal with pests

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: With all the information we possess about the harmful effects of pesticide use, we can't afford to behave as if we didn't know.
We know a hell of a lot – and we've known it for more than 50 years, at least since Silent Spring was published.
So how can we gradually walk away from the chemical crop protection? How do we make sure that we put enough attention and effort into preserving our natural environment?
The answer Carson gives us is two-fold: education and looking for less intrusive alternatives to deal with pests.
The least each of us can do is to inform ourselves about not just the effects of using chemical pesticides – but also, about the effect of human actions on the environment as a whole.
Once you start digging into it, it becomes clear that spraying chemicals on farms is just one of the many human attempts to control nature.
With the right education, we could give up the idea of controlling – and instead, start cooperating with nature.
Then, Carson says, we should look into more environment-friendly ways of dealing with pests.
We already know of such methods, we just need to make sure that we employ them.
They include, for example, mass sterilization of pests or introducing specific parasites and predators that help control the pest populations.
There are numerous innovative solutions at human disposal already. The important question, however, is: will we decide to use them?
"In nature, nothing exists alone." \[Rachel Carson\]
Silent Spring is considered THE book that started the global grassroots environmental movement.
Released in 1962, it focuses on the negative effects of chemical pesticides that were, at the time, a large part of US agriculture.
Rachel Carson and her work began initiating a shift in global environmental consciousness.
Carson was, by formal education, a marine biologist who also published a few bestselling books about the sea and ocean biospheres.
Her work is said to have led to the creation of the US Environmental Protection Agency. She was also posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Jimmy Carter.
Silent Spring carries a message that is as relevant today as it was back in the 1960s.
Humans are dependent on their living environment-- therefore, it's pure madness to disregard this environment's protection.
Because of the boldness and simplicity in how Carson articulates this truth, her book still inspires activists all around the world today.

Silent Spring is the story that sparked the global grassroots environmental movement in 1962, explaining how chemical pesticides work, what their drawbacks are, and how we can protect crops in better, more sustainable ways.
The big, fat caveat to the lessons from Startup Growth Engines is this: these strategies only work when your actual product is something that people want and need.
That part, you can't look up in a book. You have to keep your eyes open, look around, and try to come up with your own creative solution to real problems.
You have to be an artist before you can become a scientist.

insights.title: Start big, but small

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Huh? What the hell is that supposed to mean?
It means you should go for a big share of a small market.
Most startups aim for the opposite.
They'd rather grab a 1% piece of a $100 million dollar market, than 100% of a $1 million market.
The problem with the former is that you'll be the last rat to join the race, and competition ain't pretty.
The latter might not even be competed for at all.
The best way to do this is to start locally.
Limiting yourself to a physical location, where your ideal customers hang out, is the easiest way to make sure you don't reach for too much right off the bat.
For example, Facebook was initially limited to Harvard students, and Uber exclusively served people in San Francisco.
You can also focus on a certain segment online, like PayPal did with Ebay powersellers, the ones who most benefited from their product.
Going for a big share of a small market allows us to do several things:
Not drown in competition.
Collect precious data about ideal customers.
Expand gradually, by slowly swapping from one market into the one that's directly bordering it.

insights.title: Experiment with a freemium model, but only under certain conditions

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: A great way to make sure we actually do reach a substantial share of our small target market is to go the freemium route.
Freemium simply means there's a version of your product that people can use for free, with an upgrade to more and better functionality being optional.
For example, most gaming apps now work this way.
You can download and play the game for free, but to access certain features (or to advance faster), you have to pay. Plenty of software services also do this, like Dropbox, Evernote or Trello.

However, we should beware two things:

Is your product easy enough to use?

Can you offer a proper reason to upgrade later?
A complicated product, which takes some time to learn to use properly, often doesn't work in a freemium model.
People haven't invested any money, so why bother committing several weeks to learning a new piece of software?
For example, ConvertKit is an email marketing software for professional bloggers, but you have to learn a lot to use it properly.
By having to pay first, you're more likely to make use of their customer support, demos and workshops to actually learn how to get the most out of it.
Dropbox, on the other hand, is dead simple to use. The only problem you could run into is running out of space – and voilà, there's your clear reason to upgrade and buy Dropbox Pro.

insights.title: Build a free tool that solves a problem in order to get people’s attention

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Online marketers do a lot of things wrong these days, but this one they get right.

A free tool that solves a pressing problem for target customers is a great way to get yourself noticed, and potentially draw more people into your freemium model (which then helps you get that big market share of your local market).
For example, CoSchedule, a content planning software, made a 'headline analyzer', which instantly tells users how good their headline is.
Neil Patel built an SEO analyzer, which tells you what you can optimize to rank better in Google.
Social media scheduling company Buffer created Pablo, an app that lets you make beautiful images for your social media updates in seconds.
These kinds of little side projects and helpful tools can become their own platforms, drawing in thousands of potential customers.
Then, they'll give you their contact information and sometimes even a chance to personally help them, so you can learn even more about who you're serving.

"Growth is not just a concern of sales and marketing, but of product, engineering, and support too. It is this organization-wide commitment to growth that ultimately sets these companies apart." \[Sean Ellis\]
Startups can be a controversial 21st-century topic.

There's an incredible amount of noise about unicorns, hypergrowth, venture capital, great ideas, the cult of entrepreneurship, and on and on.

But really, startups aren't new.
It's just a different word for a new business.
People have founded businesses for thousands of years. The only thing that has changed is _speed_.
The speed of acquiring customers, attracting money, building an image, and of course the speed of going broke.
We don't see the 90% of startups that fail to live beyond their first five years, wound down quietly and in secret.
But you _do_ see that it took Facebook only eight years to reach 1 of 7 people on the planet.
This kind of growth speed is what all investors and founders desire, what everyone outside of startup land envies, and it's also the hardest part to achieve.
At the core of it is 'growth hacking', argues Sean Ellis. Let's take a closer look.

Startup Growth Engines shows us the strategies and tactics startups like Uber, Facebook and Yelp have used to achieve phenomenal growth in short time periods, and how we can use them to solve a big problem on a grand scale.
What an eye-opening book! Status Anxiety brings up a lot of issues that may have been stewing at the back of your head, but this book really helps bring them to the surface.
This book is recommended for those who enjoy challenging the parts of the status quo that are a waste of time and energy, and will sure to give you book motivation to keep this habit in full swing.

insights.title: Grow your self-esteem to combat the desire to be “somebody” – it’s only making you anxious

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: It's obvious that the rich try to get richer because they're greedy, right?
But it makes no sense that someone would keep trying to build wealth even after they've acquired an amount that they could never reasonably spend.
If materialism really was people's only reason for wanting more money, sooner or later they'd run out of stuff to purchase, and they'd stop.
But that doesn't happen, which means that something else is going on.
To understand this, we need to look at how it feels to be in positions of high and low statuses.
Even just the terminology we use, referring to people low on the totem pole as "nobodies", is incredibly degrading.
We all want to be "somebody" instead, and we seek status so others don't ignore us.
Another way of looking at it is that we all want to feel like people respect and love us. We want to matter to at least someone in the world.
The problem with status-seeking is that it completely overlooks our own self-worth.
If we don't know our own value, it's only natural that we'll base our identity on what others think of us.
This is part of why seeking prominence stresses us out so much.
Instead of basing your self-worth on whether or not you're a "somebody," try looking inward.
What do you like about yourself? What do your loved ones like about you?

insights.title: That feeling of restlessness you have stems from trying to live up to society’s high expectations

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Let's step back into medieval Europe for a moment.
We could talk for hours about how much better we have it today. Disease and famine ravaged the poor class while the rich stayed isolated.
Certainly people in these times had more status anxiety than we do now, no?
Unfortunately not. With a rise in common material luxuries came an increase in a desire to maintain social hierarchies.
Shouldn't we have beaten this unfortunate consequence by now?
Before the American revolution, people didn't value equality.
Once the US became a country, however, humanity also saw an increase in the desire for economic achievements.
The former hereditary class system was over.
Once people saw that their lives could improve, they sought to do so as much as possible.
But that came with a constant restlessness for more.
Once affluence became attainable, people struggled when they didn't have it.
This only worsened when they saw their neighbors owning things they didn't have themselves.
This causes angst, because we don't decide whether we have enough until we see how much others have.
In other words, what you have isn't enough until it's more than what others have. And when everyones clamors for more, everybody feels the constant anxiety to work harder.

insights.title: Philosophy can relax you by highlighting the difference between what everybody else wants for you, and what you truly need

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: One day, in the city of Corinth in the fifth century BC, a philosopher named Diogenes was sitting under a tree.

Alexander the Great found him, and asked how he could help. Diogenes simply told Alexander, the most powerful person in the world, that he could get out of the way--he was blocking his view of the sun.
This lack of concern for social status could have easily got Diogenes killed. But Alexander simply laughed it off, and commented that he might like to be Diogenes if he weren't Alexander.
This story illustrates the importance of philosophers throughout history.
They've always been around in some form or another to question the status quo.
These deep thinkers get us to ask why we value certain things and encourage us to use reason and think for ourselves.
It's the tenets of philosophy that have us stare emotions like anxiety in the face, and check them against logic.
Thus, we can beat status anxiety by realizing that most people's thinking isn't clear or logical.
In other words, you should listen to your head instead of trying to blindly follow everyone else.
Ask yourself what is truly valuable to you, and only you.
Question the traditions of society. And especially use logic to temper the irrational ways that emotion tries to get you to follow the crowd into the depths of status anxiety.
"Judged against eternity, how little of what agitates us makes any difference." \[Alain de Botton\]
These days, it's very common to be stressed out by our place in society.
We're constantly afraid of not accomplishing what's expected of us, and this fear gradually wears us down.
Alain de Botton's Status Anxiety will teach you how to let go of the false expectations that you're trying to live up to, so that you can be much happier.
Status Anxiety identifies the ways that our desire for approval makes us mentally unhealthy, and also shows ways that we can combat the disease of trying to climb the never-ending social ladder.
Daniel Pink is passionate about his message; that persuasion, when done right, is a force for good in the world.

Getting persuasion right is largely about context: the mindset of the people across the table, the frame you put around your pitch, and the precise timing. ![giphy.com/foursquareswarm](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUOxeZyHjH7IsswyvS/giphy.gif)
Pink believes that giving people autonomy to think and decide for themselves trumps a 'hard sell' all day long – and that, ultimately, good business is good business.
When you take the high road, everyone ends up better off.

insights.title: Selling isn’t about the seller, but the buyer

actions.title: Decrease your own power.
actions.markdown: Value interrogation over declaration. If you’re trying to sell something, don’t just talk at them. Ask questions, listen, and adapt accordingly.

actions.title: Agitate, don’t irritate.
actions.markdown: Get people talking among, and thinking for, themselves. Have them believe it’s their idea, not that someone has harried them into it.

paragraphCards.markdown: Successful selling isn't about what you have to sell; it's about the person you're talking to. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/My7hjBp4wH0?t=62.18&e=80.58)
More extroverts than introverts go into sales jobs, but they're seldom the best at it. ![giphy.com/benny-box](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41YyPr5uegK2VDEs/giphy.gif)
But neither is someone who's so introverted that they struggle to make eye contact. ![giphy.com/juliaveldmanc](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1J9O2yEuK4y9Dcfm/giphy.gif)
The best persuaders tend to be 'ambiverts' – people who balance confidence with humility, and listen way more than they talk.
Ideal salespeople are genuinely interested in serving people - hitting targets is just a welcome byproduct. And to serve people, you have to listen for what they're really telling you.
When pitching for business, ask yourself these three core questions: What do I want the other side to a) Think, b) Feel, and c) Do?
Always aim to start a conversation and invite collaboration. ![giphy.com/elmotionlab](https://media.giphy.com/media/j6Nt2rRLA1PLKJbjcO/giphy.gif)
You're pitching to start a relationship that goes way further than solving what they believe is their immediate problem.
Pitching what's on your presentation is only a start, and there may be a more persuasive way to go about the whole thing.

Read the other person's signals; treat any emotions they show as information. How are they feeling? Why might that be?![giphy.com/annasudit](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7ZeGmxsfBNKWYtfG/giphy.gif)

Make a hypothesis and test it out. If it's sounding like they're under pressure from on high to cut costs and aren't really listening to your quality-based arguments, ask if what you're guessing at has any truth to it.
You may not hit the target exactly, but a good guess opens a conversation.

insights.title: Reframe the issue to unveil the best solution

actions.title: Shift from problem-solving to problem-finding.
actions.markdown: Ask why someone thinks they want what they think they want. Keep asking until you get to the real need beneath the perceived problem. Show empathy, and unearth fresh opportunity.

actions.title: Value subtraction over addition.
actions.markdown: Separate signal from noise. Don’t flood people with information. Find the 1% that shines a light on all the rest. Don’t get lost in the weeds: less is often more**.**

paragraphCards.markdown: People get stuck into ways of thinking, and become fixated on the solution they think they need. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/My7hjBp4wH0?t=80.48&e=94.48)
By asking questions and opening up the wider context, you can reveal a more insightful solution - one that's more likely to solve someone's actual problem, rather than the obvious one on the surface.
Everyone is prey to cognitive bias; they think or feel a certain way because of factors unrelated to the bare facts. If we can recognize these, we can use them to our advantage.

One classic bias is 'loss framing', where we'd all rather not lose the five bucks we have than gain five extra dollars - an emotional insight that sustains the entire insurance business. ![giphy.com/socialusmarketingas](https://media.giphy.com/media/iH6bG56eoI9xaKRVcp/giphy.gif)

Framing something as a choice between three options is often more successful than trying to get people to choose a favorite from fourteen flavors.![giphy.com/leeamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1IXiYsjjADiyclPYh/giphy.gif)
'Framing by comparison' is a great tool. For example, this tire may look expensive compared to your usual choice, but compared to the knock-on costs of an accident? Not so much.

Once you study all the 'frames' available and pick the one that best suits your pitch, you can open up all kinds of unexpected avenues. ![giphy.com/liannedias](https://media.giphy.com/media/l46C9XdxiNKzXveLe/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Make it personal, make it purposeful

actions.title: Use the ‘empty chair’ technique.
actions.markdown: Position an empty place at the table when discussing a pitch or new product line to represent the people you’re aiming to persuade. Keep asking yourself, “What are they thinking?”

actions.title: Be a good friend to yourself.
actions.markdown: The more your heart is in it, the worse it can feel to be rejected - but it’s seldom a disaster. Keep faith in yourself and what you’re selling. De-catastrophize, and come back stronger.

paragraphCards.markdown: Researchers found that posters in hospitals encouraging handwashing work better when appealing to patient safety, rather than staff protection.![giphy.com/jareddweiss](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41YAqZkaq9mmgCxa/giphy.gif)
This may come as a surprise, but it shouldn't: it speaks to the reason people take those jobs in the first place.
That kind of character-based insight is gold dust when it comes to persuasion. It's always wise to seek a similar connection with the people you're aiming to persuade.

The personal angle works both ways; the more what you're selling aligns with your own values, the more credible you'll be.![giphy.com/uofcalifornia](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41lO8xEl4I3v0WmQ/giphy.gif)
If you don't truly believe in what you're selling, you won't sell it very well. The days of pulling the wool over people's eyes are behind us. The world has moved on.
This takes us straight to the purposeful pitch.![giphy.com/theoffice](https://media.giphy.com/media/dPFRoFPwy3u0QDU9Md/giphy.gif)
Before starting off, always ask yourself – if this person ends up doing what I want them to do, will they be better off? Will the world be better off?
If the answer to both questions is yes, it will shine through you. If the answer to either is no, have a long think about whether you really want to be selling it at all.
"The best way to be a good persuader is to be a decent human being." \[Daniel Pink\]
Whether we're trying to persuade a boss to agree to a raise, a client to sign on the line, or a child to tidy a room, we're selling the benefits of going along with our idea.
[youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/My7hjBp4wH0?t=11.48&e=31.48)
In one way or another, in our working lives - no matter what our job description - most of us are 'selling' most of the time.

Seeing as what comes to mind when most people hear 'sales' is overwhelmingly 'pushy' people, that doesn't sound very pleasant. But Daniel Pink shows us that it doesn't have to be that way. ![giphy.com/theoffice](https://media.giphy.com/media/ounv1hey86r5DM6WhP/giphy.gif)
Pink was once Al Gore's chief speech writer and is now the NYT bestselling author of books such as To Sell Is Human – which gives a clue to his approach.

In this course, Pink interweaves sales theory with psychology, science, and universal truths about our species which tend to share one common theme: aligning our thinking with the other person's perspective.![giphy.com/uofcalifornia](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o85xAOn2rfInNueoU/giphy.gif)
This kind of empathy is especially critical in these days of information parity, where raw 'knowledge' is available to all of us, while insight may not be.

As you embrace this new approach, you'll come to see persuasion as a service that brings genuine benefit rather than an exercise in bending someone to your will. ![giphy.com/butler](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6gbchrcNIt4Ma8Tu/giphy.gif)
If you don't believe that buying what you're selling will benefit both the person in front of you and the wider world, Pink recommends that you rethink your values.
The ideals of this course couldn't be further from the old cliché of the snake-oil salesman or used-car dealer; Daniel Pink's approach is passionate, personal and, yes, highly persuasive.

In this MasterClass, New York Times bestselling author Daniel Pink provides tips, tools and simple techniques from both academic research and his own vast experience to help you develop your own sales and persuasion skills.
In Say No To People Pleasing, Arial Els van de Schoot shares practical steps on how saying "no" when you feel "no" can improve your life.

insights.title: Identify the things you don't want, and say a firm no

actions.title: Take your time.
actions.markdown: Before you make your decision, ensure you take enough time to think about it, especially if you aren’t yet comfortable saying “no” when you’re not sure.

actions.title: Be firm.
actions.markdown: When you say “no”, ensure you not only mean it but you're also unchanging about it. Your no should be an actual “no”.

actions.title: Enforce your boundaries.
actions.markdown: To get the respect that you deserve, you must not only set boundaries for yourself, but also enforce them.

paragraphCards.markdown: It's not only important that you say "no", but that you mean it.
Others will perceive a weakly-said "no" as a prompt for a little pushing; that's usually all they'll need for it to become a "yes".
This is not right. "No" is a complete statement, and when you say it, that should be what you mean.
If you don't want to go to that party, say "no". If you don't have capacity to take on any more jobs at work, then say "no".
By saying "no", and actually meaning "no", you establish your firm rejection of certain actions and show that you don't need persuasion to change your mind.
Knowing the things you don't truly want may take some time.
This is why you need to take the time to make a decision.
Consider the things you feel are important in relation to the decision.
Learn to feel what it is that you want so that you can know what you don't want.
This helps you to be certain and reinforces the firmness in your "no" when you say it.
If you're finding it difficult to say no to the things you don't want, you need get this step right first.
You have to learn to tune into your own emotions before you start considering what others might want you to do.
Of course, some people will still probe further even after you have said "no".
It is not your responsibility to keep turning them down; it is theirs to respect your decision.
This is why your "no" should be straight-up "no", and not a yes in disguise.
Irrespective, if someone continues to bother you after you've turned them down, your response should remain a "no".
You can tell the person to respect your decision, and that if anything changes, you'll let them know.

insights.title: Give yourself a little more respect, and pay attention to what works for you

actions.title: Forget about others’ expectations.
actions.markdown: Understand that your assertiveness is for you. So, do not worry about how that makes people feel.

actions.title: Do not fear rejection.
actions.markdown: Although rejection can be painful, do not fear it. Understand that humans face rejections and it won’t take away from their value.

actions.title: Approve of yourself.
actions.markdown: If you do not approve of yourself and accord yourself some respect, it will be difficult to earn respect from others. Do not seek their validation.

paragraphCards.markdown: The first thing to understand is that pleasing people offers no benefits.
It doesn't improve the value someone has for you.
It only means you don't respect yourself enough, and you feel the happiness of those you're pleasing is more important than yours.
You're responsible for your own happiness above anyone else's. As such, you need to prioritize yourself, your boundaries, and your respect.
When you say "no" to people, you're saying "yes" to yourself.
Saying "no" to others is a conscious way of embracing yourself and enforcing your boundaries.
It is also crucial to helping you build a positive self-image.
A positive self-image means you don't do things because people want you to do them. Instead, you do things because you feel like it.
This is a nod to your self-esteem, and shows that you value yourself more than what others may think about you.
Don't think for a second that because you're firm, you're coming off as rude or lacking empathy.
You can be caring, empathic, and still firm with your decisions.
Saying "no" reflects that you have a certain level of assertiveness.
Assertiveness doesn't take away your empathy. Instead, it shapes it in a way that respects your boundaries.

insights.title: Break the people-pleasing habit by changing your everyday behavior

actions.title: Encourage yourself.
actions.markdown: Keep in mind that breaking away and changing your behavior requires your full support. Encourage yourself on the journey.

actions.title: Communicate your preferences.
actions.markdown: You need to be explicit about your boundaries and your preferences. Let people know so they know not to cross them.

actions.title: Celebrate your baby steps.
actions.markdown: When you say no to someone for something you don't want, celebrate that moment. It helps to keep you positive that you're getting there.

paragraphCards.markdown: Breaking away from a people-pleasing mindset requires you to take action.
You understand people-pleasing has no benefits, but what action are you taking to actively solve it?
Firstly, you must change your behavior and embrace new positive ways that will shape your mindset the right way.
Use affirmations to continue reassuring yourself. Affirmations keep your mind positive and boost your self-confidence.

"Saying no is okay. If I say no when I want to say no, I am saying yes to myself and a healthy connection with this person...I am my authentic me. I do what I want, and I don't do what I don't want to do." \[Arial Els van de Schoot\]
Getting to the point where you're no longer people-pleasing requires deliberate efforts. For many people, it's not a simple process.
You may find it easy saying you don't want to please people. But following through with action is difficult.
Understand that it's a steady process that requires encouragement and baby steps along the way.
Pat yourself on the back and assure yourself you can do it.
After identifying those boundaries you do not want people to go beyond, be explicit with them. Communicate your preferences.
When people know you don't want something, they may not do it as well.
"If you refuse to do what you don't want to, you're saying yes to taking care of yourself." \[Arial Els van de Schoot\]
In today's world, people find it difficult to say "no" because they don't want to let anyone down.
We think saying "no" might offend others, and as such say "yes" even when we don't want to. This makes it difficult to understand your authentic self.
People-pleasing has no benefits, either for you or the person you're pleasing. It's very important that you cut out this habit as quickly as you can.
Fortunately, Arial Els van de Schoot has lots of practical insights that can help improve your levels of assertiveness and self-assurance.

Having coached people and helped thousands of people through transforming meditations, Schoot has taken it upon herself to develop practical steps that can help you better understand why you need to say "no" to people-pleasing for good.
Say No To People Pleasing not only teaches effective and practical ways to be affirmative, but also helps you take the journey to happiness and fulfillment a step further.
In Say No To People Pleasing, Arial Els van de Schoot shares practical insights into how to say "no" to others, and in turn becoming the authentic you.

paragraphCards.markdown: We live in an increasingly polarized time, rife with misinformation and the deterioration of a shared social reality.

Neil deGrasse Tyson demonstrates the importance of scientific thinking to our civilization, and how to defend it in the face of bias and irrationality. ![giphy.com/cosmosontv](https://media.giphy.com/media/qj7Xzsc5UAmNy27D7e/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Scientific truths are true for everyone, enabling us to predict and shape the world

actions.title: Cultivate curiosity.
actions.markdown: Don’t be content with gaps in your knowledge, or facts memorized without knowing why they’re true. Try to learn something new every day, even about things you think you already know.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The most important thing you can be in life is curious - curious about things you don't know, curious about things you do know or that you think you know… Curious about how data becomes information, becomes knowledge, knowledge becomes wisdom." \[Neil deGrasse Tyson\]
[youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/0kPINNhHGNw?t=38.00&e=55.70)
Science relies on carefully observing and gathering data, and using it to predict future behavior. With enough understanding of how things work, one can even predict entirely new events.

But scientific progress is not always linear - new findings may shed light on seemingly unrelated problems, and theoretical discoveries can enable technological breakthroughs decades later. ![giphy.com/yukaidu](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUA7beBJ0GJrWScQ4U/giphy.gif)

Science is not about how much you know, but about how you think - knowing how to ask questions, evaluate evidence, and build on others' knowledge. ![giphy.com/anchorpoint](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0IynRFabOk9nfMe4/giphy.gif)
The collective scientific process does not rely on any single authority, but continued corroboration from many sources, and the questions being asked are constantly changing.
"As the area of our knowledge grows, so too does the perimeter of our ignorance."

"The good thing about science is that it's true whether or not you believe in it. That's a feature of science. That's why science works. It's why it's so powerful. It's why every country does it exactly the same way." \[Neil deGrasse Tyson\]

insights.title: To think like a scientist, we need to overcome our hard-wired cognitive biases

actions.title: Check your biases and commitments.
actions.markdown: Think about something you strongly believe in, and ask yourself what kind of evidence it would take for you to change your mind.

paragraphCards.markdown: Science reflects objective truths about nature, but we're not wired to think scientifically. ![giphy.com/yukaidu](https://media.giphy.com/media/l1BgRnFgGUYqp8UgM/giphy.gif)

Our brains evolved with many cognitive biases, like seeing patterns that aren't there, and focusing only on data points that support our view while ignoring all others. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/0kPINNhHGNw?t=75.54&e=85.98)
Some cognitive biases stem from an urge to feel special in the universe, and biases along racial or cultural lines channel this urge into group belonging in a way that harms others.

But understanding oneself as part of the universe humbles our prejudice, reminding us that we are special not for our differences, but our shared belonging to a grand cosmic process. ![giphy.com/yukaidu](https://media.giphy.com/media/PgoMcWJu4u5GErKCup/giphy.gif)
Everybody has bias, and it's impossible to be totally free of it. But the nature of science as a collective effort helps expose and remove individual biases.
Be open to having your thinking checked and challenged. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/0kPINNhHGNw?t=90.90&e=102.18)
"A skeptic, a proper skeptic, questions what they're unsure of, but recognizes when valid evidence is presented to change their mind." \[Neil deGrasse Tyson\]

insights.title: Effectively communicating science requires preparation, empathy, and understanding

actions.title: Think locally.
actions.markdown: Instead of dumping information on people, tailor the level of detail to connect with what they already know and spark curiosity to learn more on their own.

paragraphCards.markdown: "What is wisdom after all? It's the distilled essence of knowledge, once you've forgotten all the details." \[Neil deGrasse Tyson\]
Neil deGrasse Tyson's father, a civil rights advocate, told his son: "It's not good enough to be right. You also have to be effective."

Although Tyson seems to talk about science effortlessly, he puts a great deal of preparation into all of his appearances, researching the audience and format, and readying answers for any questions that might come up.
Having been a dancer in college, Neil deGrasse Tyson uses his full range of facial expressions and body language when speaking, rather than standing behind a podium.

Using humor establishes an instant connection with the audience and gets their attention, allowing Tyson to communicate complex ideas more effectively. ![giphy.com/newyorkcomiccon](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0HlyBNg53J6p6FsQ/giphy.gif)
You can never convince people by telling them they're wrong or showing them contradictory evidence - it will only make them double down.

Instead of arguing, engage people where they are, and ask them questions that follow their logic while providing new information. ![giphy.com/yukaidu](https://media.giphy.com/media/xTiTnkceDTwP0XotMY/giphy.gif)
The goal is to get them to consider the issue in a way they hadn't before. ![giphy.com/startalkradio](https://media.giphy.com/media/26gR1NFrSpet7oHdu/giphy.gif)

"We are a participant in the great unfolding of cosmic events. And for me, that gives a sense of belonging. That's a cosmic perspective that allows you to sort of sit up straight and look around and say, I belong to something bigger than my daily routine." \[Neil deGrasse Tyson\]
Neil deGrasse Tyson has given countless lectures on space, planets, physics, and the observable universe.![giphy.com/cosmosontv](https://media.giphy.com/media/5VafO4VRevAdf1f16J/giphy.gif)

Now, he turns his telescope on himself and his career as a science communicator.![Neil\_deGrasse\_Tyson\_at\_Howard\_University\_September\_28%2C\_2010.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/78/Neil_deGrasse_Tyson_at_Howard_University_September_28%2C_2010.jpg)

As an astrophysicist and planetologist, Tyson has held positions at multiple museums and universities, hosted TV series and documentaries, and authored dozens of books as well as research publications.
In the process, Tyson has become the face of scientific rationality in the popular consciousness. ![giphy.com/cosmosontv](https://media.giphy.com/media/Vm4LFTVZpZ8fVSeGqM/giphy.gif)

In this MasterClass, Neil deGrasse Tyson moves seamlessly from the massive stars and galaxies around us to the inner workings of how he connects with his audiences. [youtube.com/c/masterclass](https://youtu.be/0kPINNhHGNw?t=16.30&e=28.50)
You will learn what scientific thinking is, why it matters, and how you too can help spread it further in the world.

In this MasterClass, world-famous astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson teaches the importance of scientific reasoning, and how to effectively communicate it. ![giphy.com/cosmosontv](https://media.giphy.com/media/seZNSI40C392KcuooD/giphy.gif)
It's no secret – you are perfect, just as you are. Treat yourself with love and kindness, and that will radiate from you, drawing like-minded people towards you.

RuPaul is a true role model for anyone, and with his suggested tools at your disposal, you can slowly but surely find that your authentic self is a gift that is completely unique. ![giphy.com/rupaulsdragrace/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9GEmaEn2qKTHjpVm/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Create space to find your frequency

actions.title: Seek out stillness to find your frequency.
actions.markdown: By creating space for your unique frequency to shine, you can find all the key ingredients of authenticity from within. Check in with yourself regularly, and fortify positive internal voices to counter the negative ones.

actions.title: Examine your emotions and wounds.
actions.markdown: In order to heal, speak to your inner child. Treat them with love and kindness, and let them know that they’re not to blame for the things that have happened to them. Connect with your emotions. Allow them to flow, and counter fear with self-love.

paragraphCards.markdown: It's so important to take time and create space to find your true and unique frequency. ![giphy.com/rupaulsdragrace](https://media.giphy.com/media/1qk1sYG6lqGexnZa6J/giphy.gif)
All you need to do is be still and listen to your body, your heart, and your instincts. Meditate and listen out for a hum of energy.

By connecting with your frequency, you will shine, and that will encourage like-minded people to gravitate towards your beautiful energy. ![giphy.com/rupaulsdragrace](https://media.giphy.com/media/vwSZNNVeb6uxTTXwnT/giphy.gif)
"Your job isn't to try to make people like you. Your job is to like yourself." \[RuPaul\]
This is how you find your tribe, the people who will support you in your endeavors, and whom you will support in turn.
Seek out mentors if you need some guidance and look to famous figures who really speak to you for inspiration. ![giphy.com/rupaulsdragrace](https://media.giphy.com/media/1r8SmqXPRCkq84x7nA/giphy.gif)
In order to live as your most authentic self, you need to be able to see yourself. In those moments of stillness, notice what voices from your past come up – the positive and the negative.
Over time and with practice, you'll realize that the wounds of your past were not your fault. Speak to your inner child and say, "It had nothing to do with you."
Treat yourself with all the kindness and love that people from your past may not have shown you, and make a conscious decision to not repeat their mistakes.
Shame and fear can be balanced with love and compassion.
As an adult, there's no need to shut down your emotions.
"They are your gift to this world. Do not be ashamed of them." \[RuPaul\]
Process your feelings with a sober mind, kindness, and an understanding of your intrinsic value. ![giphy.com/rupaulsdragrace](https://media.giphy.com/media/1fhj2RprUOpqCObj2J/giphy.gif)
Through acts of self-appreciation and the cultivation of your tribe, you can then pay it forward.
Remember too that there is no such thing as failure – it's simply a catalyst.

insights.title: Learn the best way for YOU to navigate the world

actions.title: Connect with your own frequency.
actions.markdown: When you enter a room, trust that there’s no need to pretend to be anything you’re not. Trust your authentic self, and you can find confidence in managing people, places, and situations out in the world.

actions.title: Be of service to humankind.
actions.markdown: Find joy in living in service to others by overcoming obstacles, meeting the world with your own authentic frequency, and doing things from the heart. Your love is needed in this world.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The simplest act of human kindness is to acknowledge one another. Because it's acknowledging yourself, and you cannot begin to love yourself until you acknowledge yourself." \[RuPaul\]
We all exist in a communal space, and we all have a responsibility to be respectful of others.
You can't control what other people are going to think of you, and it's not your job to do so. ![giphy.com/rupaulsdragrace](https://media.giphy.com/media/3LFp1C7Hw9lE1IP0vd/giphy.gif)

There's no clear-cut formula for dealing with bullies, but understand that bullies are generally trying to feed their ego with a sense of superiority, which actually only forces them deeper into their insecurities.
"People are going to feel threatened that you have the ability to fly freely, which is what we all want to do." \[RuPaul\]
The world is filled with falsehoods and illusions, so try not to take life too seriously. When you enter the world with your unique and honest energy, it will guide and light your way.
Don't feel like you must dim your light, for whatever reason – your frequency is unique and beautiful. ![giphy.com/dinaaaaaah](https://media.giphy.com/media/M9HrYVxkNkzyYm9ZwV/giphy.gif)
You can learn to trust this energy by creating space for the divine inside your consciousness, through stillness and reflection. Stay present in moments of fear, and breathe.

Be honest with yourself. Are you more extroverted or introverted? Do social situations charge you up, or drain you? Figure this out and allow yourself to take whatever measures you need to navigate the world comfortably. ![giphy.com/bluebirdco/](https://media.giphy.com/media/Md4gOuHEm2hAbkqiJ1/giphy.gif)
Be adaptable. Imagine that every room you enter is filled with unconditional love, recognize your self-imposed limitations, and break free.
"In this world, you will be called upon to die to your old self, and be reborn to your higher self." \[RuPaul\]
