The Six Thinking Hats Method is made up of simple ideas, which you can implement without a ton of training or expensive tools and that lead to a positive effect almost instantly. Especially for big businesses with larger teams, this can really save a ton of time and money.

insights.title: The blue hat helps you think about thinking and monitor processes at all times

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Whenever you start a brainstorming session, first put on the blue hat. It's the hat to think about thinking.
Think of it as zooming out and getting a 10,000 foot view on the problem you're tackling first.

When wearing it, your goal is to answer questions like:

Why are we here today?

What's the scope of the problem we're trying to tackle?

Which other hats will we need during the session?

What are the rules of this meeting?

Since you're setting up the perimeter of your team effort here, one group member, usually the leader or facilitator of the meeting, will have to keep wearing the blue hat throughout the session, to make sure everyone sticks to the rules.
If that's you, then it's your job to tell everyone else when it's time to switch hats.
Then, ask for a conclusion or summary at the end of the session and wrap it up with the concrete, next steps you'll all take to move things forward.

insights.title: It’s important to let employees express their feelings without judgement while wearing the red hat

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Name a couple of things the color red reminds you of.
So right now you're thinking of at least one of the following: blood, roses, hearts, lipstick, apples, fire, strawberries, cherries, chilis, tomatoes, a scarf or sweater.
These are some of the things most people think of first when trying to associate the color. If you examine the words more closely, you'll realize most of them are also symbols of certain emotions.

1.  Blood = Anger, violence
2.  Fire = Rage or passion
3.  Hearts, roses, lipstick, strawberries = Love
It shouldn't come as a surprise then, that the red hat is the hat of emotion.
Whoever wears it should be allowed to freely express their emotions about a situation or problems – without any judgement or explanation.
If you're running the meeting, don't ask anyone to explain or justify why they feel a certain way. Just go around the room and have everyone tell their emotional view on the matter.
It's important to include everyone so no-one feels left out, and to not judge so people are comfortable voicing unpopular opinions.
This makes sure no resentment or grudges are carried over into the solution of the problem.

insights.title: Without wearing the yellow hat sometimes, it’ll be hard to stay enthusiastic about work projects and get cracking

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Being an optimist doesn't come easily to everyone, yet is a huge beneficial factor in overcoming failure, moving on and tackling things with enthusiasm. That's where the black and yellow hats come in.
The black one is for when you're trying to uncover weak points and flaws in your plan.
Then the yellow is to focus on an idea's positive impact and how it has the power to potentially transform your organization for the better.
This is called being value sensitive, which is when you're aware that even the most hairy ideas have value.
However, one thing to keep in mind is to ground your enthusiasm in realistic expectations.

For example, if you come up with a clever new marketing strategy, don't fantasize about how it'll make you a quadrillionaire – just estimate the potential extra business you can make and then get cracking!
"We may have a perfectly adequate way of doing something, but that does not mean there cannot be a better way." \[Edward De Bono\]
Working at a company that tries out new management practices, like the Six Thinking Hats Method, must be cool. What's even cooler though, is coming up with such a method.

In 1985, Edward de Bono came up with this way of structuring the thinking process of managers and teams, to help them dissect what's usually a messy pile of thoughts into useful categories  – six different hats that managers and their teams can take turns wearing...

1.  Blue – Management
2.  White – Information
3.  Red – Emotions
4.  Black – Caution
5.  Yellow – Optimism
6.  Green – Creativity
This helps members of an organization align their mental process so that they can solve problems with parallel thinking.
Six Thinking Hats shows you how to disentangle your own and your team or company's cumulative thinking process into six distinct areas.
It teaches you to tackle a problem from different perspectives as a group, in order to solve it with the power of parallel thinking and thus save time and money.
Charles Duhigg is gold and Smarter Faster Better is another great read of excellent tips.

insights.title: Use small reminders to stay motivated for long-term goals

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Setting goals is fun. Setting big goals is even more fun. Everyone loves it.
Especially as December 31st approaches, millions of people set out for grand achievements…and then they fail.
Why? Because while setting a huge goal is fun, working every day for years to achieve it isn't.
Writing a daily goal down on paper is one thing. Showing up 365 days a year and following it through is another.
You can stay motivated when working towards a big goal too, as long as you keep reminding yourself what you're working towards.

For example, if you want to come up with a crazy good new set of headphones which adapts to people's individual hearing, you'll probably have to start with reading a lot of scientific research papers.

These are often boring, and likely to put you to sleep. Writing "This will help me build the world's best headphones" in big, bold letters across the top will help remind you of the paper's purpose and get you to pull through.

insights.title: Set goals with the SMART goal framework to make them manageable

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Aside from staying motivated on goals, which take a while to accomplish, it also helps to break them down into manageable chunks.
Big goals shouldn't scare you, tackling them without a plan is what to be afraid of.
So consider something called the SMART goal framework.

It's an acronym for the five criteria your goals should fulfill:

Specific

Measurable

Attainable

Realistic

Time-bound
For example, if you want to write a book, you can first be **specific** by saying you'll write a book about habits, that spans three parts with 30 chapters with no more than 300 pages in total.
Your progress then becomes **measurable**, and you can strive to write, say, two page drafts every day.
This goal is **attainable**, but you should still stay **realistic** about it: you probably won't be able to write that much every day and lots of edits will have to be done.
You'll likely take longer than just 150 days, but that's alright, because at least you now have a **time-bound** schedule.
Even if it changes over time (and it will) you can already see the finish line of your goal.

insights.title: Deal with distractions in advance by making a plan for when they occur

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: "If you want to make God laugh, tell him about your plans" Woody Allen
While a good plan is nothing to scoff at, it's true that no plan ever gets executed exactly as planned.

Distractions, unforeseen problems and speed bumps will happen, and though you can't possibly prepare for all of them, anticipating some of them in advance is your best bet at sticking to the schedule.

For example, if you know that at least one day each week gets sucked up entirely by responding to emails and phone calls, you'd be best off by blocking your emails from hitting your inbox during the time you've scheduled for writing your two daily pages.
Anticipation is the enemy of distraction.
The best way to deal with distractions is to keep them from happening in the first place, whenever you can.

insights.title: Steve Jobs’s reality distortion field got its name from his team

paragraphCards.markdown: The skill that allowed Steve Jobs to create his huge vision for Apple out of nothing was not his obsession for detail, nor his sense for design, simplicity, or aesthetics.
It was his reality distortion field - or RDF for short.
The phrase was originally coined by Bud Tribble, part of Jobs's Macintosh team, who borrowed the term from Star Trek.
What it meant was this: Once Jobs decided that something should happen, he would bend reality to his will until it came true.
This extended to everyone around him.

His RDF is how he could convince a sleepless team of engineers to work another ten hours on Macintosh fonts to create the greatest computer in the world. [giphy.com/alexbobeda](https://media.giphy.com/media/4ag7akAmeAfeKTwqxf/giphy.mp4)
He also used it to make sure anyone who left an official Apple keynote was convinced the product they just saw was the best in its industry.
By using charisma, hyperbole, marketing and persistence, Jobs would pull impossible feats into the realm of the possible for himself and his audience.
This allowed him to create what has become the most valuable technology company in the world. [giphy.com/devrock](https://media.giphy.com/media/JQpOCgnGfb7FCvEVrd/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: There is one major reason for Apple’s name

paragraphCards.markdown: Ever wondered where Apple and its products got the name? Apple certainly aren't selling smoothie makers, after all. ![giphy.com/mnnfrr/](https://media.giphy.com/media/9PpY5gqRdnzP6ozDQm/giphy.gif)
Of course there are several reasons for the name, one being that Steve Jobs was often experimenting with fruitarian diets.
Jobs really liked apples. He'd just visited an apple farm on the day he decided on the company name.  ![giphy.com/pipandcricket](https://media.giphy.com/media/LkMjQL9f7NSZR8PQLR/giphy.gif)
Jobs was also inspired by the following quote:
"Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication." \[Leonardo da Vinci\]
In fact, Jobs liked the quote so much that he used it as the slogan for Apple's first brochure. He felt the apple symbolized the feeling of 'simple sophistication' perfectly.
But the one major reason for Apple's name has nothing to do with personal preferences or symbolism. [giphy.com/angryorchard](https://media.giphy.com/media/1fotl1dx6YyMFeqnKP/giphy.mp4)
It's a simple, clear-cut business decision: Apple comes before Atari in the phonebook.
Jobs had worked at Atari before, and didn't want people to see his competitor first when looking for a computer company.
Sidenote: the discussion about the name is also one of the funniest scenes of the 2013 Jobs movie. [youtube.com/c/FreshMovieTrailers/](https://youtu.be/dSaO1-Hi5v0?t=43.96&e=58.22)

insights.title: Steve Jobs did not become a billionaire from Apple products, but from Pixar’s IPO

paragraphCards.markdown: Ever wondered how Steve Jobs became a billionaire? ![Medvedev\_and\_Steve\_Jobs.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3b/Medvedev_and_Steve_Jobs.jpg)
Everyone assumes all of his money came from Apple, but his bank account actually made the biggest jump on a whole other project.
After being fired from Apple in 1985, Jobs sunk his teeth into two projects: NeXT and Pixar.
Teeth in this case also means money. ![giphy.com/anthonyantonellis/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2YOp5fNAFMp63B3a/giphy-downsized.gif)
Jobs paid a $100,000 flat fee for the logo design for NeXT alone.
That, along with countless delays and some other costly production standard demands, made NeXT a black hole where money disappeared like nothing.
In the Pixar case, Jobs purchased a majority share of the company (80%) from George Lucas for $5 million in 1986, and invested another $5 million right into the company.
By 1995, Jobs's total Pixar bill had racked up to a grand total of $50 million.
He often considered selling it, until a deal with Disney came through to produce and distribute Toy Story in 1995.
Grossing over $350 million, the movie became the most successful movie of the entire year.
This of course led to a very optimistic outlook for the company, which held its initial public offering on November 29 that year.
The company's stock was priced at US$22 per share, giving Jobs a 20x return on his initial investment and making him a billionaire overnight.
His stocks were now worth $1.2 billion. ![giphy.com/bentmob](https://media.giphy.com/media/Iaunxxt8a0x4F9kdBz/giphy.gif)
"The people who are crazy enough to think they can change the world are the ones who do." \[Steve Jobs\]

This biography was written by Walter Isaacson, former CEO of CNN and managing editor of Time Magazine. ![Walter\_Isaacson\_VF\_2012\_Shankbone\_2.JPG](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/78/Walter_Isaacson_VF_2012_Shankbone_2.JPG)
Not only is it the most detailed and accurate book about Steve Job's life, it's also the only authorized one since he wrote the book with Jobs's consent.
Isaacson conducted over 40 interviews with Steve Jobs over the last two years leading up to his death. This book is the result.

Steve Jobs is the most detailed and accurate account of the life of the man who created Apple, the most valuable technology company in the world. ![Steve Jobs Headshot 2010-CROP2.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f5/Steve_Jobs_Headshot_2010-CROP2.jpg)

actions.markdown: Stand by your principles, values and convictions. Focus on reality and truth. Talk about what is important to you and develop a habit of practicing this by writing it down.

paragraphCards.markdown: Although getting married is the easy part, being happily married is the great part and should positively impact your life in every area. ![giphy.com/nicolemilano](https://media.giphy.com/media/3JpQynnnFM9lgoQAZa/giphy.gif)
This kind of happiness can be just as powerful as a drug. ![giphy.com/alexvekten](https://media.giphy.com/media/SU3dfiNiHBAfF1GfEP/giphy.gif)
The only sure foundation for integrity within a relationship is a deep level of moral character, upon which we can base our self-respect and self-esteem.

"Marriage is often built on looks, money, popularity, clothing, education, and all of these external things. Sometimes they're just shallow, and that's what we're born with, we're born looking how we look." \[Randy Hyde\]
We often define our value by whether we respect ourselves more than others, or others more than ourselves.
This standpoint, however, creates great personal and interpersonal misery. ![giphy.com/BareTreeMedia/](https://media.giphy.com/media/VeHG3XaptjyqSf4dBP/giphy.gif)
Taking responsibility to be loyal to our values prevents us from becoming self-sacrificing, self-effacing, depressed people that give in to arrogant and angry people.
Instead, we must see ourselves and others equally.

We are who we are - but understanding that we have the intelligence to emotionally handle relationships can help us discover what is acceptable and what is not. ![giphy.com/JellaCreative/](https://media.giphy.com/media/Z8k75Komfc7LA1qO2F/giphy.gif)

insights.title: You think avoiding the argument is a good thing, but it doesn’t go away – it only brews into a bigger explosion later

actions.title: Cool off and distract yourself – alone.
actions.markdown: When you feel yourself getting worked up, go for a drive, a long walk, actively exercise, or otherwise try some relaxation methods such as deep breathing. Avoid self-indulgences such as shopping and eating unhealthily.

actions.title: Don't rehearse why you're angry.
actions.markdown: Get to a place where you can empathize, and try to understand where they're coming from. Stop trying to mind read and thinking that you know what the other person is thinking. Instead, write down what it is that you both want and compromise.

paragraphCards.markdown: Unresolved differences are one of the key causes for conflict in a marriage or relationship. They can cause anger to bubble, and cover up the love and affection.

"Research shows that anger is the mood people are worst at controlling. Rumination and brooding fuels anger's flames. We want to be involved in other people's lives. We want to know that we fit in, that we're important to them." \[Randy Hyde\]

Whilst blowing off steam gives us a rush of endorphins, anger and rage can be one of the most potent ways to cause distrust, tension and fear, and can be a threat to our self-esteem. ![giphy.com/Aisforai/](https://media.giphy.com/media/M969DDLMmP8Agjdr6J/giphy.gif)
Being treated unjustly, insulted, or demeaned is bound to trigger anger. A person needs to feel like they're in a non-judgmental environment, and thus free to take responsibility for themselves.
By reframing a situation more positively, you can slow the brakes before anger escalates into rage. ![giphy.com/bosslogic/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3b7cq3EPgW4OZIk93r/giphy.gif)
Point out the negativity of the situation, and consider the value of your time and your day being ruined.
Let the other person realize and experience the consequence of their actions, instead of just reacting to them.

insights.title: If you don’t prioritize good communication, your sex life will suffer too

actions.title: Make sex a priority.
actions.markdown: Always make time to have sex. Even if you’re tired or a bit busy, it doesn’t need to last for hours and can make all the difference. If you have a sexual dysfunction, tend to it. Make love with passion and enthusiasm.

actions.title: Don’t be afraid to just touch.
actions.markdown: Sex is an intimate act above all. Hold your partner and allow your bodies to connect through touch. Express what you’re feeling, and give yourselves permission to fully enjoy the experience.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Some people think men just want sex. Not true. The most sexually motivated people are women who are in a safe, loving relationship." \[Randy Hyde\]

Sex is a big part of most married couples' relationships. Some wait until after marriage to do so, but the majority consider it an important part of their relationship. ![giphy.com/ExplainerStudio/](https://media.giphy.com/media/EU2WfKEDLtLidbUCA6/giphy.gif)
However, when a marriage or relationship doesn't have commitment, loyalty, and love at its foundation, any emotional intimacy and healthy sexuality dies.

Sex with your partner is a vital and positive part of your relationship. It increases fidelity and wellbeing, and distinguishes your intimacy from any other type of relationship. ![giphy.com/julieannart/](https://media.giphy.com/media/cImyXBDngn0wi7KCQo/giphy.gif)
Often, couples hunger emotionally and sexually for their partner – that's part of the human experience.
A lack of communication, lazy affection, and companionship are some of the first steps towards divorce. ![giphy.com/kochstrasse/](https://media.giphy.com/media/etZNuJcNsPznXxyxRT/giphy.gif)
Instead of feeling rejected, hurt or vulnerable, practicing the continuum of affection can fill in the blanks of healthy sexuality within the couple.

Even without the full act of sex, skin-to-skin touch is important. Savor the moments of hugging and feel your partner's warmth. Hold hands and stroke their face. ![giphy.com/wsassociation](https://media.giphy.com/media/efToAplqKAirxeBPWJ/giphy.gif)
All of these small acts of intimacy can bring you closer together - for the long haul.
"We must act out passion before we can feel it." \[Jean-Paul Sartre\]

Although many couples lean on their marriage for security, stability and learning, a negative marriage can either be a living heaven, or a living hell. ![giphy.com/walla\_mazaltov](https://media.giphy.com/media/jtX4NgsRDHTcUWLqrv/giphy.gif)

The majority of divorces take place in the first seven years, then steadily decline for the following decade. After that, it levels out. ![giphy.com/BENTMOB](https://media.giphy.com/media/fXPAeZfQZlv6IcwZwV/giphy.gif)
The kids are turning into teenagers, and most couples have finally learned to become emotionally engaged.
Mature love grows as your own self-love and development deepens. ![giphy.com/loofandtimmy/](https://media.giphy.com/media/JTbsN6f3FDafoQZkpy/giphy.gif)
"It's not a lack of love, but a lack of friendship that makes marriages unhappy." \[Randy Hyde\]

With the help of licensed child and family therapist Dr. Randy Hyde, any couple wanting to learn how to improve their marriage or intimate relationship will learn from the guiding principles informed by his 35 years of experience and research.
This course demonstrates how to become emotionally and socially skilled by applying and practicing Hyde's easy, fun and powerful program.

By becoming best friends and establishing what mature love looks like, couples can set the foundation and future for themselves, their children, and their relationship. ![giphy.com/hiart/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41lSlcCUzOZKbjMI/giphy.gif)

Strengthening Marriages and Intimate Relationships imparts principles and skills any couple can adopt to have a happy and successful marriage or intimate relationship, by learning what mature love looks like.

Succeeding in Web Development is a comprehensive course for anyone seeking to start a career in web development. It will give you information on the fundamental skills you'll need, as well as how to seek and succeed in getting employment in the field.

insights.title: Finding your niche in web development will help you to climb your ladder

paragraphCards.markdown: Web development falls within two key categories: front end and back end.

Front end developers, quite simply, work on what is in front of the user. They manage the interactions between the user and the browser, and require knowledge on interfacing with servers and programming.
Back end developers work behind the scenes and servers. They create code, set up structures, and manage services.
Then, there are the full-stack developers who can handle both the front end and back end, and oversee the whole thing.
"Developers work inside and outside of teams." \[Ray Villalobos\]
Choosing to be a web developer does not mean that you will be in a room with your computer working solo. There are opportunities to work with others allowing for job satisfaction.
A good developer should not have to work relentlessly to climb up the corporate ladder, and there will always be plenty to learn as technology is constantly evolving.
Having a knack for problem-solving will make web development a meaningful and profitable career for you.
Developers usually make a fair salary, with back end developers averaging $85,000 a year, while those on the front end average about $74,000 a year.
It's possible to earn more, of course, if you're knowledgeable on the latest frameworks or languages, and especially once you build up several years of experience.

insights.title: Build up your knowledge of core technologies

actions.title: Investigate the different languages available.
actions.markdown: Programming languages are constantly evolving, and they interact with each other in different ways. As a web developer, be constantly looking to learn how the different languages can be used and interact with one another.

paragraphCards.markdown: Web development requires an understanding of four core technologies.
An essential skill to master is Hypertext Markup Language, or HTML. This language is used on webpages to describe the content and define structure, and is the easiest to master.
HTML forms the information architecture of a website, and guides how a user navigates through a site.
For design, Cascading Style Sheets, or CSS, is the language to learn. This language helps with the look and feel elements of a site, rather than its functionality.
The same content can be transformed with proper CSS use.
CSS has set rules which identify parts of pages that you want to modify, and the styles which can be applied to do so.
Programming is a skill that web developers need to consistently develop, and JavaScript is the most used programming language.
JavaScript allows for interaction within the browser, and helps with handling events, loading, and unloading media, as well as changing or deleting any element on a web page.
The fourth language to know is Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) which helps a browser connect to a server to get information, send information and also to delete information

insights.title: Learning is just as valuable as formal education for web developers

actions.title: Kick start your learning.
actions.markdown: Teach yourself web development by seeking out available resources online. Try out tools like Stack Overflow where professionals are at hand to give you advice when you need it.

paragraphCards.markdown: Many of those pursuing web development will ask whether it's necessary to have a college degree - and the answer is usually no.

Web developers typically follow one of four paths:

1.  Instructor-led training
2.  Self-study
3.  Working on projects
4.  Learning on the job with real clients.
Although a college degree is not a prerequisite, having one can significantly increase the amount that you can earn as a web developer.
A degree may give you more problem-solving skills and the ability to seek out higher-level concepts.
To kick start your learning, you can attend a coding boot camp. This will focus on teaching you the practical skills needed, but in a more condensed time frame such as 14 weeks.
Most boot camps require attendance of 40 hours or more each week, and include skill development that you may not get in a more traditional learning setting.
Only the students with the highest potential for success are selected for boot camps, so it's often a challenge to get a spot.
"A good developer needs to be comfortable with not just how to code, but also the process of how software is made." \[Ray Villalobos\]
In the past, web developers specialized in designing websites and applications, however the role has expanded.

Web development now includes the front-end developers, who do work on websites and apps; the back-end developers, who specialize in working with databases and servers; and the full stack developers, who oversee every aspect of a project.
Ray Villalobos is a teacher with years of experience teaching web development courses.
This course, Succeeding in Web Development, shares all the steps on how to become a web developer, including the consideration phase when you are just thinking about the possibility.
With Villalobos's insight, it becomes easier to decide what aspect of web design you are most suited to.
Succeeding in Web Development is an all-round course that takes you from a decision to success.
It includes information on technical skills that should be developed, and how you can then enter the workplace with your newly acquired web development skills.

Succeeding in Web Development: Full Stack and Front End explains the skills that you require to become a web developer, including languages, supporting technologies, as well as how to get a web development job.

paragraphCards.markdown: The 15 Invaluable Laws Of Growth is our kind of book!
You'll immediately feel inspired after reading anything that John Maxwell writes, and this one is no exception to that.
Its actionable tips and motivational abilities are infinitely useful, and will help anyone get up and start their personal growth journey today.

insights.title: We must ask ourselves questions to find out who we really are, and what inspires us

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: How ridiculous would it sound if a group of your friends told you that they were going on a road trip without any kind of map or GPS?
Although this sounds crazy, we in fact do it too often ourselves, with our goals.
We wander aimlessly about, never really knowing where we even want to go, let alone the path to take.
However, to walk the road to success, we first have to understand where we're at right now.
This isn't too difficult when we focus on asking ourselves the right questions.
First, are you happy where you're at right now?
Do you feel happy and fulfilled at work?
When you get up, are you excited about being alive?
If not, then that's the indication that you need to change.
Next, what will give you the type of life that makes you wake up happy?
This involves discovering your dreams, values, and personality.
Watch yourself carefully each day. Make note of the situations, work, or projects that really light you up inside.
Also, consider times when your efforts for others made you feel valuable and useful.
Also, do a reality check once you discover these things about yourself.
You won't become a basketball player if you're already in your 40s.
And if you want to become a doctor for the money or prestige, that's not motivation enough to keep you going for very long.

insights.title: The changes we want in your life aren’t going to happen by chance--we must have a proactive attitude to get them

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Nothing in the universe grows by chance.
Plants must have sunlight, water, and soil. Your body has to have nutrients in the form of food.
And your personal growth is the exact same way.
The problem for many of us is that we forget this vital factor.
We assume that somehow, the life we want will just magically happen.
It's easy to forget that nothing good has happened in the past without people getting up to make it happen!
Another problem in the way of your growth is the excuses we make.
You've probably found yourself saying things like, "If only I had the time I would…" or "when I get that raise I'll…"
The thing is, you're never ready, and the best time is now.
It's easier to accept this when you realize that personal growth is never easy.
It's painful and not usually very fun.
However, it can be more fun if we focus on what uplifts us rather than what drags us down!
Remember that when you begin, you're going to be doing things you're not good at, because you've never done them before.
That means that you'll fail, and that's okay!
There's no such thing as the phrase, "I'm bad at this!", because it's never true.
You're not bad at it, you're just inexperienced! It's completely natural that you'll stumble at first.
The best thing we can do is keep going, even when (especially when) we fall.

insights.title: We will only experience incredible personal growth after we’ve become consistent, and that requires patience

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: You know those short training montages you see in movies, when the main character transforms into a master in their chosen skill in what seems like only a minute or so?
It's very common to see the slow stages get shrunk down.
But this gives us one of the worst false impressions we can have--that personal growth is quick.
There's a reason why movies often skip the long slog to become great-- because it's often boring!
But once we realize that, and learn how to fight it, there's nowhere that our self-improvement journey can't take us!
Just admitting this fact is helpful enough. But it will also make a massive difference if we focus more on the process, instead of the outcome.
This is yet another reason why finding what it is that you love to do, and working at it, is so important.
When you're enjoying the work of learning, it won't matter to you how long it takes or how "boring" it may seem to everyone else!
When you begin to get frustrated, which will inevitably happen regardless, you can keep the bigger picture in your mind to stick with it.
Remember, the bigger the goal, the longer it takes to get there, but the reward is also larger too!
"If you do the things you need to do when you need to do them, then someday you can do the things you want to do when you want to do them." \[John C. Maxwell\]
Ever looked at yourself in the mirror, and wondered, "Is this really all there is to me?"
You yearn to become better. You're plagued by your past mistakes and failures, and you want to be successful.
But after multiple defeats, it's hard to get back up again.
Personal growth is difficult, but it is possible. All you need is a guide.
And who better to lead the way than self-improvement guru John Maxwell?

Maxwell's 15 laws for bettering life are: 1) Intentionality, 2) Awareness, 3) The Mirror, 4) Reflection, 5) Consistency, 6) Environment, 7) Design, 8) Pain, 9) Ladder, 10) Rubber Band, 11) Trade-Offs, 12) Curiosity, 13) Modeling, 14) Expansion, and 15) Contribution.
Maxwell dives into each of these in his book The 15 Invaluable Laws of Growth.
After reading this, you will finally feel confident that you can change for good, because you'll know how to do it right.
The 15 Invaluable Laws Of Growth inspires us to get up and go, showing us how change only happens when we actively nurture it and identifying the strategies to thrive in our career and life.

paragraphCards.markdown: We can learn a ton about business in this book, despite the fact it's about, well, war. ![giphy.com/adultswim/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0Extv5o4qTYxAgDu/giphy.gif)
The Art Of War is absolutely staggering, and the advice is unexpectedly practical too.

insights.title: Only enter battles you know you can win

actions.title: Find your niche.
actions.markdown: Don’t create a product that’s been done before. Competition is too great. Instead, find your niche and create something new and unseen. Give yourself a chance for success.

paragraphCards.markdown: Winners know when to fight, and when not to. Losers always fight, and thus often end up losing.

Fools enter battles and then start thinking about how to win. Strategists know how they're going to win before they even start to battle. ![giphy.com/hyperrpg/](https://media.giphy.com/media/6Tol8FOHeuaFCHcgek/giphy.gif)
Have you ever thought about the fact that the most skillful fighters often avoid battles, and that that's why they're never defeated? Take Bobby Fischer, for instance.

The most brilliant chess player of all time instantly retreated after he won the world championship, and didn't play again for 20 years. ![Bobby\_Fischer\_1960\_in\_Leipzig\_in\_color.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9d/Bobby_Fischer_1960_in_Leipzig_in_color.jpg)
So if you're starting a business, look at the industry first. Can you even win against your biggest competitors? If not, is there a different niche you can fill?
Creating a soda brand to compete with Coca-Cola would certainly be an effort in vain, given that over one billion drinks of the brand are consumed every single day.

But maybe you can create a higher-priced, eco-friendly alternative that targets single moms. That could make a fortune! ![giphy.com/signatureentertainmentuk](https://media.giphy.com/media/bEpe9GcstNcZSCOSt8/giphy.gif)
The lesson here: only enter battles that you know you can win. ![https://giphy.com/OTHERCOLORS/](https://media.giphy.com/media/YpZoXeOnD3b62vJRvW/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Deceive your competitors to impose your will on them

actions.title: Never think you’re too small to do well.
actions.markdown: You don’t need to be a ginormous corporation to make money. If your idea is good, it will grow organically. Create a killer product or service, and get brainstorming on how to attack the market.

paragraphCards.markdown: Mask strength with weakness; courage with timidity; and order with disorder.
A clever army will win not with their bodies, but with their minds. ![giphy.com/ATTHelloLab/](https://media.giphy.com/media/4a5ayaNaPF43AkeNvM/giphy.gif)

Common battlefield tactics include making it seem like you're miles away (when you're in fact close to the enemy's base) with the clever use of distractions, or surprise attacking in several different places in order to splinter opposing forces.
They're based on deceit, and supposed to manipulate the enemy into doing what we want them to.
In business, we can do the same.

It's always baffling to discover insanely profitable and dominating businesses, which, on the front-end, appear like they're a mom-and-pop store. ![giphy.com/boomunderground](https://media.giphy.com/media/zfnExdbtdTMmQ/giphy.gif)
Take Appsumo, for example. There's not much to discover, it seems like a small daily deal site, right?
Here's the kicker: Appsumo is an eight-figure business.

If you have to count, that's north of $10 million/year. They have over one million email subscribers and made $1 million in their first year (2010). ![giphy.com/appsumo](https://media.giphy.com/media/Uv9AI8eA0VjI5IriKj/giphy.gif)
There are endless examples like this one on the web, and this humbleness and modesty are a great way to throw off competitors.

insights.title: Lead your team as if you were leading a single man by the hand

actions.title: Keep your teams small.
actions.markdown: In big teams, someone always gets forgotten. Keep your teams small so that every 3-4 people have a direct manager and defined roles. Keep in touch with each one, and bring them together for larger briefings when needed.

paragraphCards.markdown: Eventually, your business will need a team. And eventually, that team will have to grow. ![giphy.com/empire/](https://media.giphy.com/media/hWMUWy03CTJc7inIEN/giphy.gif)
But as companies get bigger, they get more complex. ![giphy.com/unsigrandsoleil/](https://media.giphy.com/media/SY8caJFiMwZJJfiDsb/giphy.gif)
Every single human adds an infinite amount of feelings, thoughts and ideas to the business, and all of those have to be managed.
"A skilled general leads his army as if he was leading a single man by the hand." \[Sun Tzu\]

Whether you're managing a big army or a small one, the tools are the same: Break them down into smaller groups, and then use clear signals to steer them into the right direction. ![giphy.com/historyuk/](https://media.giphy.com/media/fx84Kq8dlpZTfbdaPY/giphy.gif)
In business, that means teams should stay small. 3-4 people is often a good number to cooperate with without things getting too complicated.
Then you can set clear signals, like sales targets, tools to use, and a daily morning briefing, to make sure everyone's on track.

Never forget one-to-one interaction with everyone on your team. If you treat your employees like family, they'll be just as loyal. [giphy.com/a24/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUOxeX5rYwL64AQTx6/giphy.mp4)
"Victorious warriors win first, and then go to war, while defeated warriors go to war first and then seek to win." \[Sun Tzu\]
The Art Of War is the most influential strategy text in all of East Asia.
How do we know? Well, for starters, the author of this book died in 500 BC. ![Enchoen27n3200.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Enchoen27n3200.jpg)
The author's name is Sun Tzu, and he was a Chinese general, philosopher and military strategist.
The book is divided into 13 chapters, each dedicated to a different aspect of warfare. ![giphy.com/nerdo/](https://media.giphy.com/media/YUuA1u6ECtD6XsEThg/giphy.gif)
The reason it's been so popular all around the world is that most of the lessons can be translated directly to other competitive fields, like sports or business.
In order to make it more actionable, we'll look at it in a business context. ![giphy.com/butler/](https://media.giphy.com/media/kbj4XwDLV2lPjuJRJS/giphy.gif)

The Art Of War has been _the_ definitive text on military strategy and warfare ever since being written in ancient China around 500 BC, inspiring generals, athletes, and businesses to beat their opponents and competition, even today.
Not that anyone had to sell us on moving to Italy before, but now we should be more game than ever.
The cool thing about this book is that the Blue Zones all lie in the most vastly different countries, which means there are a few lifestyle changes in there for everyone.
No matter whether you like Asian food, Italian red wine, or Californian sunshine, there are bound to be things in this book that you'll want to adopt.
Highly recommended read – what better book could there be to pass the time until science catches up on those anti-aging pills?

insights.title: Age is not about genes, it’s about lifestyle – and the right ones can add 10 years to your life

actions.title: Consider your diet.
actions.markdown: What do you eat? Science has linked our food choices to our aging process. By considering what we eat, we can slow down the aging process.

paragraphCards.markdown: Let's get the bad news over with first.
Right now, only 1 in 4,000 Americans lives to be 100 years old. That's 0.025%.
The good news is that centenarians are the fastest-growing demographic across the planet, especially in Western areas, like the USA or Europe.
So while living extremely long lives is far from common practice, we're getting there.
One of the first "Blue Zones" – areas where people live exceptionally long lives – to be discovered was Sardinia, a small island off the coast of Italy.
On average, 1 in 600 humans in Sardinia lives to be 100 or older.
You might be thinking – maybe it's just their genes.
But nope. According to a Danish study, which looked at over 2,500 twins, genes only account for 25% of how old we become.
What really matters is our behavior.
That's because no matter how great our genes are, we age every single day.
Living a long life is predicated on slowing down that aging process, instead of accelerating it – and that's why our lifestyle has the most significant effect.
The Sardinians, for example, live a very natural life.
They're outside a lot, move and get around naturally (with their feet), and eat a very natural, Mediterranean diet.
If we adjust your own lifestyle to be more natural, in line with how people in the Blue Zones live, we can easily add an extra 10 years to our lives.
Worth changing a few habits, don't you think?

insights.title: Drink more, eat less

actions.title: Drink more water.
actions.markdown: Drinking five to six glasses of water a day will help you live longer.

actions.title: Focus on lunch.
actions.markdown: Make lunch your big meal of the day. This means you can eat a light dinner, and not fall asleep on a full stomach.

paragraphCards.markdown: "You are what you eat." You've heard that one, right?
Of course, what we eat and drink makes up a huge part of our health – and therefore, our age – so let's check out what a centenarian's diet looks like.
First, we should drink more. No, not beer and not vodka – water. At least five to six glasses each day.
That's what the inhabitants of Loma Linda just outside Los Angeles do (the only American "Blue Zone" – an area where people live exceptionally long lives).
Add a bit of red wine each day (as consumed by almost all Sardinians daily) to your six glasses of water, and you're set. Forget sodas, heavy alcohol or other, sugar-laden liquids.
What you shouldn't forget about is food.
Centenarians usually eat a low-calorie diet, which is mostly vegetarian, and in some cases, even vegan.
Breakfast or lunch should be your main meal of the day, so you can keep dinner light and not fall asleep on a full stomach.
A good rule the people of Okinawa (another blue zone in Japan) adopt is to eat only until you're 80% full.

insights.title: Always put your family first, and let it be your life’s purpose

paragraphCards.markdown: Living long isn't just about health, it's also about our psyche.
One of the best things we can do to make sure we stay around for a long time is to live a life of purpose.
Guess when most healthy Americans die? In their first year of retirement.
Far more people die then than in their last year of work, simply because they lose their life's purpose once they stop working.
However, centenarians never stop working.
The trajectory of their life is as long as their life lasts.
This doesn't mean they slave away at a job until they drop dead, but rather continue building a meaningful life and not just stop at 60, 65 or 70.
Most of them choose their families as the center of their lives, and choose to live with them, provide for them, and spend lots of time with them.
95 out of 100 centenarians only live to be that old because they have children or grandchildren who care for them, and receive love and sometimes financial aid in return.
Focusing on building a happy and healthy family for the rest of your life also keeps you out of trouble, because you're too busy to fight and stress about petty conflicts with your neighbors.
"Drink without getting drunk, love without suffering jealousy, eat without overindulging, never argue, and – once in a while, with great discretion – misbehave." \[Dan Buettner\]
How badly do you want to live forever?
As humans, this is one of our most common collective desires: not wanting to die.
The world is already working hard at pills that slow down the aging process, but nobody knows if they'll live to see the day where average life expectancy crosses into the triple-digits.
What we do know is that some people _already_ live to be over 100 years old, and we sure can learn from them.
Author Dan Buettner has identified 5 so-called Blue Zones – areas where people live exceptionally long lives – and details what they do to become centenarians (a person who lives to be 100).
While some are obvious, like not smoking or exercising regularly, others are far more subtle. Let's dive in!

The Blue Zones gives us advice on how to live until we're 100 years old, examining the 5 "Blue Zones" of the world where people live the longest, and drawing lessons about which habits most successfully shape our lives.
Although _The Book_ was first published in 1966, it's as relevant as ever today.
That's because it tackles the timeless issues of human existence and tries to answer questions we've been asking since the beginning of time.
Whatever the year, an insight into a great mind such as Watts' is always a delight.

insights.title: We are part of a bigger whole, rather than a lonely island

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The first fallacy Watts points us to is that most people perceive themselves as entities separated from the rest of the world. In his own words:
"Most of us have the sensation that 'I myself' is a separate center of feeling and action, living inside and bounded by the physical body."
"A center which 'confronts' an 'external' world of people and things, making contact through the senses with a universe both alien and strange."
This way of looking at ourselves has far-reaching consequences.
It often leads us to put artificial barriers between ourselves and others, and fight with reality to "get what we want."
The perceived opposition between the "I" and everything else is very apparent in our language. Just consider customary phrases like "you must face reality", or "the conquest of nature."
Watts wants you to see through this illusion of "me against the world."
He explains how we are all intrinsic parts of the whole universe.
**The unity and interconnectedness with our environment is our true nature and identity – so it should have priority over the illusion of separation that our physical bodies reinforce.

**

The Book reminds us that the Earth grows people, just like it grows forests or creates waves.
That simple realization is the reason we should consider ourselves as interdependent with the world – rather than independent from it.

insights.title: Causality of events is a kind of cognitive bias

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Most of us perceive the world in binary terms.
We recognize _day_ based on its opposition to _nigh_t – and the other way around.
This kind of labeling leads us to believe that things are indeed black or white in this world.
Such a biased perception is often taken for granted, not even verbalized.
That's just how everyone sees the world – and so it doesn't cross our minds to question it.
Germans refer to such deeply embedded assumptions as _Hintergedanken_, which literally translates as "behind the thoughts."
One of the widespread _Hintergedanken_ is that life works according to the law of cause and effect.
Author Alan Watts claims that this law is nothing but an illusion.
However, once embraced, it distorts our image of reality in a way that continuously reinforces what we want to see.
To illustrate this, let's compare the "cause and effect" bias to a little hole in a fence, through which you observe the world.
Let's also imagine you have never seen a cat before in your life.
As you look through the hole, a cat passes by.
You see its head first. Then, there comes the body, followed by the tail.
If you observe long enough, the cat will pass by several times and you will conclude that the view of the body is obviously an _effect_ of the head.
Simultaneously, it gives the _cause_ for the tail to emerge a moment later.
As long as you look through the hole, it will never occur to you that the head, the body, and the tail are actually parts of one and the same _cat_.
You will continue to see them as separate events, one "resulting" from the other.

insights.title: Death is an opportunity, not a threat

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: The concept of death as the doomsday of our lives is deeply rooted in Western culture.
According to author Alan Watts, Christianity is largely responsible for that.
In Christian doctrine, the Final Judgment follows death.
It separates those who deserve to live in the eternal Heaven from the ones condemned to damnation in Hell.
There is no strong alternative to this doctrine in Western culture, other than the atheist vision of disappearing into nothingness after death.
None of that sounds particularly comforting, does it?
However, Watts points out that there are numerous traditions which treat death not as something to be afraid of.
Instead, death is an opportunity.
Death can be seen as a gateway to a new dimension of spiritual growth.
In fact, reminding yourself about the inevitability of death can greatly add to the sense of purpose and quality of your life.
As Greek spiritual teacher, G. I. Gurdjieff said: "Every one of those unfortunates during the process of existence should constantly sense and be cognizant of the inevitability of his own death (…)

"...Only such a sensation and such a cognizance can now destroy the egoism completely crystallized in them that has swallowed up the whole of their Essence, and also that tendency to hate others which flows from it."

"Irrevocable commitment to any religion is not only intellectual suicide; it is positive unfaith, because it closes the mind to any new vision of the world. Faith is, above all, openness--an act of trust in the unknown." Alan Watts
_The Book_'s subtitle is _"On The Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are."_
It verbalizes Alan Watts' meditations on the nature of humanity, our place in the universe and the spiritual aspect of human life.
Virtually every culture has its own taboos.
In Japan, for instance, it was for centuries customary not to mention sex in conversations.
On the day of marriage, newlywed couples received so-called "pillow books," which explained sexual matters.
This gave the opportunity for people to avoid a conversation about the embarrassing topic.
Back in 1966, when _The Book_ was first published, Watts already noticed that there were fewer and fewer taboos left in Western culture.
But one that remained – and probably remains until today – is the discussion around the true identity of human beings.
Watts wrote _The Book_ to unpack this taboo, and to share a perspective profoundly different from the one we usually adopt through traditional upbringing and education.
His core message points to _unity and connectivity_ as the inherent qualities of all life.
The Book is a spiritual exploration of true human nature and our place in the universe that challenges wide-spread but often misled beliefs.

insights.title: Henrietta Lacks died tragically of cancer when she was still young, but her cells still live on today

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Henrietta Lacks was a poor black farmer, born in Virginia in 1920.
She married young, and soon was a mother to five children.
She was 30 when she walked into the coloreds-only exam room at John's Hopkins, complaining of a lump on her cervix.

Doctors biopsied the lump, and a while later, the diagnosis came back as stage 1 cervical cancer. So she started receiving treatment, which at the time involved hours of excruciating exposure to radium.
The treatment left her badly burned, and were sadly ineffective. She died later that year.
It was at this time that scientists were looking for ways to keep human cells alive outside the body, in order to research diseases.
George Gey discovered the roller-tube culturing technique that involved a rotating cylinder that kept the cells in motion.

When scientists put Henrietta's cancer cells, or "HeLa," in the roller-tube, they were amazed when it actually worked. Not only were they still alive, but they were doubling every 24 hours, faster than the human body.
The aggressive nature of the cancer cells enabled them to thrive and survive outside a body.
Soon, Gey shared the news of his "immortal human cells," making them an instant celebrity.

insights.title: Though Henrietta Lacks’ cells were known around the world, people knew nothing about her or her family, until recently

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Though her cells were known and produced around the world, Henrietta Lacks and her family were largely ignored by science and the media.
After her death, her family struggled to make ends meet. Her husband, Day, had to work two jobs, and her oldest son had to leave school to raise his younger siblings.
Henrietta's children never knew what happened to their mother, as their father wouldn't talk about it.
Many years later, her daughter got the story from the doctors who were on her case.
Decades later, the family was finally able to learn about Henrietta's condition, and the groundbreaking contribution she had made to the field of medicine without even knowing.
When writing the book, journalist Rebecca Kloot reached out to Henrietta's family, but they were very reluctant to talk to her.

Though Kloot was finally able to talk to some of the family, getting information uphill battle because they didn't trust her to tell the story. The family had a general mistrust in medicine because of the medical community's past exploitation of black Americans.

One example of this was the Tuskegee syphilis experiments of the 1930s, where scientists allowed uneducated poor black men to suffer from syphilis and go untreated, so that they could study the disease.
Even though the history of the exploitation of black people by scientists is documented, there were also many fictional stories that circulated among black Americans.
Slave owners would tell stories of "night doctors" that kidnap black people for experiments, in an attempt to keep them from running away.

insights.title: Henrietta Lacks’ cells have raised ethics questions regarding cell donation in the world today

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Though Henrietta Lacks had rare, aggressive cells that made lab research possible, the same thing can, and has, happened to others.
One case was a man who had rare leukemia. His cells were similarly taken and marketed without his knowledge.
When the man found out, he sued the doctor for profiting off of his cells. But ultimately, the doctor won and continued to market his cells.
Another man who had a special antibody for hepatitis B was actually informed by his doctor of the financial potential he had. Together with researchers, he helped cure hepatitis B.
But the difference here is that Henrietta Lacks never even had the chance to claim property rights of her cells, because of her death.
The practice of isolating and marketing a patient's cells without their permission is still not illegal. There are more than 300 million tissue samples stored in the US.
Doctors require consent to obtain samples. However, they don't have to obtain further consent to use these tissues for research.
Some believe that the current laws are enough. But many argue the patient has a right to know exactly what their cells will be used for.
The future is uncertain, though many committees are now working to provide oversight in tissue sampling.

"Henrietta's were different: they reproduced an entire generation every twenty-four hours, and they never stopped. They became the first immortal human cells ever grown in a laboratory." \[Rebecca Skloot\]
If you were to walk into any biomedical laboratory right now, you'd come across HeLa cells.
HeLa cells are one of the most important tools in modern medicine. They helped with everything from finding a cure for polio, to discovering AIDs, to cancer treatments.
These miracle cells have been around since the 50s, but most researchers don't know their origin.
Henrietta Lacks was a poor tobacco farmer and mother of five young children, who tragically died young from aggressive cervical cancer.
When biopsy scientists took her cells, they found something amazing. Henrietta's cells reproduced at an incredible rate.
Today, long after her death, scientists across the world still grow her cells.
However, they did all of this without her permission, or the knowledge of her family.
Journalist Rebecca Skloot gets to the bottom of the story in her book, The Immortal Life Of Henrietta Lacks.

The Immortal Life Of Henrietta Lacks makes us smarter and more compassionate by revealing the previously unknown story of a woman with such extraordinary cells that they still live today, and have contributed to dozens of medical breakthroughs.

insights.title: There are 3 principles to intelligent investing

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Often also called value investing, intelligent investing, according to Benjamin Graham, rests on 3 principles.
An intelligent investor always analyzes the long-term evolution and management principles of a company before investing.
An intelligent investor always protects him- or herself from losses by diversifying investments.
An intelligent investor never looks for crazy profits, but focuses on safe and steady returns.
A famous quote by Warren Buffet is about his 2 rules for investing: Rule No. 1: Never lose money. Rule No. 2: Never forget Rule No.1.
That's exactly what intelligent investing is. Nobody can predict the next Facebook, but everyone can protect themselves against losses.
By doing a thorough analysis, intelligent investors find stocks with a gap between their current price and the intrinsic value the company holds and will eventually unlock.
This is based on the evidence collected from looking at the company's history and their management values.
The intelligent investor invests in a few of those companies, in order to not lose everything when things go wrong.
Then, they sit back, perfectly happy with collecting 10%, 12% or even 15% a year in returns. Oh, and one other thing.

insights.title: Never trust Mr. Market

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Benjamin Graham's most famous analogy is the one of Mr. Market, where he pictures the entire stock market as a single person.
If you imagine Mr. Market showing up on your doorstep every day, quoting you different prices for various stocks, what would you do?
According to Graham, you'd be best off ignoring him altogether, day in and day out.
Sometimes the prices he'd tell you would seem suspiciously cheap, sometimes astronomically high.
That's because Mr. Market is not very clever, totally unpredictable and suffers from serious mood swings.

For example, about a month before a new iPhone is released, stocks rally while people cue in line in front of the Apple store. But when the new phone is not exactly as expected, stocks can plummet the very next day.
As humans, we're so good at recognizing patterns that we're trying to find them even where none exist.
That's why we naturally a stock price that's been going up for 10 days must go up further – which is of course not true.
If you want to be an intelligent investor, rely on your own research, and ignore the market altogether.

insights.title: Stick to a strict formula, and you’ll be fine

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: To further remove you from the emotional stress of investing with the market, you should always stick to a strict formula when investing.
Benjamin Graham calls it _formula investing_, but it's more widely known as dollar cost averaging.
What this means is that you simply set a fixed budget you're going to invest every month or quarter, and then invest that into the stocks you've previously picked – no matter the price.
For example, if you decide to invest 10% of your income every month, that money goes to your investment account on autopilot, and then you can invest it in the stocks you already own.
This is somewhat emotionally demanding, because it requires you to invest the same amount again and again – no more when stocks are cheaper, no less when stocks are expensive.
But once you get over it, it's a great way to protect yourself against losses, which could happen if you invest a big sum right before a crash.
"Those who do not remember the past are condemned to repeat it." \[Benjamin Graham\]
Benjamin Graham would easily be the most famous investor of the 20th century, if it weren't for his student – Warren Buffett – likely the only person to surpass him in investing brilliance.
Coming from poverty, Graham became an excellent student at Columbia and, upon graduation, started his investing career with a job on Wall Street.
He wrote down his investing principles in 1949 inside _The Intelligent Investor_, which Warren Buffett calls the best book on investing ever written.
The Intelligent Investor explains value investing, which is focused on generating steady, long-term profits by ignoring the current market and picking companies with high intrinsic value.

insights.title: Our life satisfaction increases when we have more free time

actions.title: Stop working overtime.
actions.markdown: This week, set a reminder in your calendar to stop working at the time that you’re supposed to clock out at. Any extra work can work until tomorrow - don’t sacrifice your personal life for it.

paragraphCards.markdown: Most Danish citizens don't work 40 hours a week. In fact, working an average of about 1,450 hours each year, Danes work less than 30 hours a week!

insights.title: Helping others is a great way to feel better

paragraphCards.markdown: Ever heard of the helper's high? It's that happy feeling that you get when you help somebody else.
Science shows that being kind and generous lights up the nucleus accumbens, or the area of the brain that gives us the good feelings we have from eating and sex.
Even thinking about giving to charity activates this region in the brain!
From an evolutionary perspective, this is understandable, because human survival depends on communities helping each other.
So, if you want to be happier, add volunteering to the list of activities that will help you get there.
When you give freely of your time to help others, it helps you be more grateful. Research shows that volunteers have more friendships and social connections and less depression.
Unsurprisingly, you can add volunteering to the growing list of happiness-inducing activities enjoyed by the Danish, as well.
To get more service opportunities, start looking for them! The RAKtivists group is full of people who look for Random Acts of Kindness they can perform.

Look around in your community, and you will also see many opportunities to help those around you. Doing so will make you happier!
