actions.title: Use the Ackerman bargaining system.
actions.markdown: If buying, start at 65% of your target, then go to 85%, 95%, and 100%. Acknowledge that your offers are low, show appreciation each time they go lower, and end on a precise odd number.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The secret to gaining the upper hand in a negotiation is to give the other side the illusion of control." \[Chris Voss\]
[youtube.com/LewisHowes](https://youtu.be/O_iKeiPhisw?t=1379.27&e=1404.65)
Ask the other party questions and get them to elaborate in a way that leads them to reason their own way towards what you want, without you having directly suggested or asked for it.
"How am I supposed to do that? What's going to happen if I do that? How do I overcome the challenges that I have here?" \[Chris Voss\]

If negotiating as a buyer, begin at 65% of your target while acknowledging that it's too low, then move up to 85%, then 95%, then 100%. ![giphy.com/picturepressplay](https://media.giphy.com/media/bl7D9oiztFLAzgZn9t/giphy.gif)
Show appreciation every time the seller lowers the price, and make your final offer an odd number with something extra thrown in, to show you've reached your limit.
When people invest in brainstorming a solution, they'll be motivated to close the deal. ![giphy.com/spiro](https://media.giphy.com/media/TIiATEizlRKUWVgIWR/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Body language, tone, and phrasing are crucial

actions.title: Notice the signs of truth.
actions.markdown: Pay attention to a person’s tone and body language when they’re telling the truth, so you can notice when they deviate from it.

actions.title: Aim for ‘no’.
actions.markdown: Phrase your questions so that the answer you’re looking for is ‘no’ rather than ‘yes’.

paragraphCards.markdown: A person may have many ways they lie, but only one way they tell the truth. Establish a baseline for how they behave when telling the truth, and notice when they deviate.
People feel more comfortable saying 'no' than 'yes', because 'yes' implies a commitment, while 'no' makes them feel protected and in control.
Phrase your questions so that 'no' is the answer you want to get. ![giphy.com/thokamaer](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7TKo6fiRVhQlgoPS/giphy.gif)
The same phrase can have very different meanings depending on tone: for example, 'How would I do that?' can be an indignant refusal or an earnest request for suggestions.
Use a soothing, accommodating tone to invite collaboration. ![giphy.com/rewiredotorg](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ov9k5wE5YQjFPDfhe/giphy.gif)
"Negotiation is the art of letting the other side have your way." \[Chris Voss\]
When we're trying to get other people to do what we want, we often think of it as a battle of wills or a zero-sum game. But the key to a successful negotiation is to turn it into a collaboration.
As a businessman and former FBI hostage negotiator, Chris Voss has dealt with high-stakes negotiations all over the world. [youtube.com/c/LondonReal](https://youtu.be/1Wi4c-7lM8o?t=0.00&e=17.76)

The Art of Negotiation distills his extensive experience into counterintuitive but clear strategies we can use in our daily interactions. ![giphy.com/showtime](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohs4wLVXeneGAemti/giphy.gif)
By leveraging the power of empathy and emotional insight, we can turn almost any situation to our advantage by making the other person invested in helping us solve the problem.

In The Art of Negotiation, experienced negotiator Chris Voss shares his insights, from the boardroom to the battlefield, on how to tilt any negotiation in your favor - and have the other person help you get there.
When it comes to considering the success of past presidents, it's useful to consider the political agenda, not the person - and that's exactly what we have here.
The Audacity Of Hope is the place to start to understand Barack Obama, from his own words and principles. [giphy.com/obama](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2YWs7Tw2oViXktLq/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: Freedom and community are the two central beliefs of the American people

paragraphCards.markdown: The groundwork for Barack Obama's political work is based on a solid understanding of the core beliefs of all Americans. ![giphy.com/aclu-nationwide](https://media.giphy.com/media/W0R5JuDedQFfNB2B29/giphy.gif)
He believes that the founding fathers set the tone with the two documents which describe the American ideal: the Constitution, and the Declaration of Independence.
These documents center around two major beliefs that are today held by all Americans.
*   **A belief in freedom****.** That every man and woman should have the same rights and opportunities. [youtube.com/user/CNN](https://youtu.be/ueMNqdB1QIE?t=194.51&e=221.30)

*   **A belief in community****.** That working together - be that in family, at work, in church, or as a country - is the way to ensure freedom and keep democracy alive. ![giphy.com/kirstenhurley](https://media.giphy.com/media/UsMg2TIAbo3LRgAdWg/giphy.gif)
Freedom would be the aspiration.
That regardless of race, gender, class, age or religion, you could become anything and anyone in an America that affords everyone the same liberty, rights and chances.
[youtube.com/user/CNN](https://youtu.be/ueMNqdB1QIE?t=109.26&e=127.01)
However, the founding fathers knew that ensuring this freedom by sustaining a democracy wasn't easy \- no other country had done it before (and lasted).
That's why there's a focus on communal values where family, religion and patriotism are honored.

Absolute power is rejected and dispersed. No single pope, king or general should ever single-handedly decide the fate of the American people. ![giphy.com/channel/telegraphcreative](https://media.giphy.com/media/ignAZvQ8oTo0cK9XOh/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Politicians are forced to hang around the rich all the time, which makes it hard for them to do their job

paragraphCards.markdown: It's any politician's job to ensure freedom. But doing that job can be really hard. ![giphy.com/sauts](https://media.giphy.com/media/mJ8My1HDNkx1Z76KUR/giphy.gif)
Politicians are constantly influenced by a lot of outside forces - three in particular: money, the media, and large, special interest groups and organizations.

For example, since a presidential campaign alone costs millions of dollars (although the budget hardly affects the votes), politicians have no choice but to either be rich themselves already, or get plenty of sponsors and donors.

Hanging around with the top 1% and flying around in private jets makes it very hard to stay connected to the majority of ordinary citizens. ![giphy.com/5starjets](https://media.giphy.com/media/nAwEA21HTcGi6awBpW/giphy-downsized.gif)

It's the same with labor unions, lobbies, religious institutions, and big political committees \- a lot of special interest groups want to influence politicians to make sure their own interests are served well.
Lastly, the media control how politicians are perceived publicly.

Because neither honesty nor civil behavior makes a good headline, what politicians say gets distorted a lot.

![giphy.com/nowthis](https://media.giphy.com/media/iDZbLtnWixWZLlyctK/giphy.gif)
Barack Obama proposed public campaign funding and free media air time for presidential candidates as a solution to these problems.
[youtube.com/user/AssociatedPress](https://youtu.be/-MVujbmSY1k?t=0.00&e=14.34)
If politicians can't work in an unbiased way, there's no way they'll really represent the true values the country aspires to.
[youtube.com/user/AssociatedPress](https://youtu.be/-MVujbmSY1k?t=64.04&e=73.10)

insights.title: The global battles we fight today are battles of ideas, and so can’t be won with weapons

paragraphCards.markdown: Politicians face problematic influences at a time when, more than ever, we need them to be unbiased and freely speak their mind.
The US missed a real chance when they didn't change their foreign policy from the ground up after 9/11. ![giphy.com/seratakata](https://media.giphy.com/media/giuKcLqtXSrc7u5VTk/giphy.gif)
Instead of accepting that it's not states but ideologies that threaten countries today, the country dug out its Cold War policy. They focused only on smaller enemies instead of the Soviet Union.
Going to war in Iraq cost billions of dollars, and worsened America's global reputation \- not exactly two accomplishments worth celebrating.
[youtube.com/user/voxdotcom](https://youtu.be/Icq60Uxd3As?t=57.08&e=80.00)
Barack Obama suggests that threats now mostly arise from extreme ideologies.
We're not battling against other states, we're battling ideas. A battle of ideas clearly can't be won with weapons.
[youtube.com/user/voxdotcom](https://youtu.be/Icq60Uxd3As?t=43.38&e=54.00)
Only a social awakening in the places where these ideologies thrive can reform them.
America must work on its own democracy, upholding the ideal of freedom, to inspire others to voluntarily follow on their own.
[youtube.com/user/voxdotcom](https://youtu.be/Icq60Uxd3As?t=54.38&e=56.70)
This is not only the only sustainable work to resolve international conflicts; it also saves a lot of money and creates much less anti-American sentiment.
"I wish the country had fewer lawyers and more engineers." \[Barack Obama\]
Have you ever seen the speech that made Barack Obama president? [giphy.com/mashable](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41Yz9DKFp5zyzk1a/giphy.mp4)
First off, it wasn't any of the speeches he delivered during his campaign. Not during the presidential debate, or the inaugural address.
The speech that really made Obama President of the United States was given long before he ever announced to run. [giphy.com/obama](https://media.giphy.com/media/3otPoBcmuU5pAqaCIM/giphy.mp4)

In 2004, Obama spoke at the Democratic National Convention in Boston, during John Kerry's presidential campaign. His keynote address, entitled "The Audacity of Hope" was by far the best speech of the convention.
The then-senator was suddenly famous. This speech put him on the map as a serious presidential candidate. [giphy.com/obama](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohA2UAtyuBXYxWyPu/giphy.mp4)
The phrase 'audacity of hope' is one Obama picked up from his former pastor, who gave a sermon about a George Frederic Watts painting called 'Hope' in 1990.
The Audacity Of Hope expanded on his ideas from the speech, and laid out the topics that would then become the foundation for his presidential campaign in 2008.

The Audacity Of Hope explains Barack Obama's personal, political and spiritual beliefs, on which he based his 2008 presidential election campaign, which made him the first African-American president of the United States of America.

It may be frightening to realize that there are entities deliberately manipulating our behavior and how we see the world. ![cyborg hand manipulating human](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1182266338.jpg)
But The Great Hack is a much needed wake-up call about the need to rethink the role of technology in our society and shaping its future.

insights.title: Hyper-targeted propaganda is used on unsuspecting populations to impact behavior and elections

actions.title: Pay attention to your apps.
actions.markdown: Keep careful track of what apps you use and install, and what permissions you grant them.

paragraphCards.markdown: ![Target audience. A group of men with open empty head](http://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_413737255.jpg)

"All of my interactions, my credit card swipes, web searches, locations, my likes, they're all collected in real time and attached to my identity, giving any buyer direct access to my emotional pulse." \[David Carroll\]
Hyper-targeting is not just used to sell products. Cambridge Analytica originated as a branch of SCL, a military contractor specializing in psychological warfare.
These manipulation strategies were first tested in the developing world, using social media to suppress voter turnout in Trinidad, and influencing elections from Lithuania to Ghana.

After successfully working on the Brexit referendum, Cambridge Analytica was hired for Donald Trump's 2016 US presidential campaign. ![giphy.com/election2016](https://media.giphy.com/media/l2JhIUyUs8KDCCf3W/giphy.gif)

Spending $1 million/day on Facebook ads, the company claimed to have 5,000 predictive data points for every American voter. ![giphy.com/CosimoNesca/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41lX2yEwhnD6QrLi/giphy.gif)
They focused on voters in key districts by bombarding them with targeted messaging.

insights.title: Cambridge Analytica illegitimately harvested data and deceived the public

actions.title: Do your research.
actions.markdown: Learn about data regulations where you live, and what your rights are as a consumer.

paragraphCards.markdown: Cambridge Analytica accessed Facebook profile data that was only supposed to be used for academic research. ![Cambridge Analytica Files Leak](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1049734184.jpg)

Disguised as a personality quiz, the app scraped data not just from those who used it, but from their friends who had not consented to sharing their information. ![giphy.com/samjackgilmore](https://media.giphy.com/media/27sRm5PISK3xo78qsS/giphy.gif)

Since Cambridge Analytica's UK-based parent company processed the data, Professor David Carroll initiated a legal request to see what data that Cambridge Analytica had on him and how it had been used. The company refused to comply.

CEO Alexander Nix denied having any Facebook user data or working with the Leave UK campaign - both contradicted by video and computer records. He also collaborated with Julian Assange to obtain Hillary Clinton's hacked emails.

"It's incorrect to call Cambridge Analytica a purely sort of data science company or an algorithm company. It is a full-service propaganda machine." \[Christopher Wylie, former Research Director at Cambridge Analytica\]

insights.title: Tech companies are profiting while undermining the fabric of our social institutions

actions.title: Don’t believe everything you read.
actions.markdown: Make sure to seek news from reputable sources, and verify content that seems designed to stoke outrage.

paragraphCards.markdown: Former executive turned whistleblower Rebecca Kaiser argues that internet users should own the data they generate, and companies like Google and Facebook should pay them to use it. ![giphy.com/xponentialdesign](https://media.giphy.com/media/W5UoBN0YMdT1QP8Yfr/giphy.gif)

"The wealthiest companies are technology companies. Data is the most valuable asset on Earth. And these companies are valuable because they have been exploiting people's assets." \[Brittany Kaiser, former Director at Cambridge Analytica\]

Tech platforms aim to monopolize attention, and the most reliable way to do that is by stoking powerful emotions like fear and hate. In doing so, they polarize society and encourage violence. ![Human skull in digital background](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_347739644.jpg)
Facebook campaigns have been linked to mass ethnic violence in countries like Myanmar. [youtube.com/user/ComputerHistory](https://youtu.be/y26NQdTLtaw?t=3963.66&e=3996.66)
A Parliament investigation concluded that the UK's electoral laws are not sufficient to protect the integrity of elections in the face of new technological threats.
Mass targeted manipulation of the public without their awareness poses a dire threat to the possibility of free and fair elections.

"People don't want to admit that propaganda works. Because to admit it means confronting our own susceptibilities, horrific lack of privacy, and hopeless dependency on tech platforms ruining our democracies." \[David Carroll, Associate Professor at Parsons School of Design\]

By now, many of us know that the devices and websites we use are collecting our data. But what are they using it for? ![giphy.com/xponentialdesign](https://media.giphy.com/media/1zi2FQvx8c6jXZB9dm/giphy.gif)

What if your data is not only being used to sell you personalized goods and services, but to reshape your very reality? ![shape of a man combined with programming code](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1137659867.jpg)

Filmmakers Jehane Noujaim and Karim Amer previously collaborated on The Square, a documentary about the Egyptian Revolution in which a social media-driven mass movement brought down an authoritarian president.

Now they turn their lens to the darker side of social media, examining how it can manipulate people as easily as it can liberate them. ![Vector illustration of smart phone controlling man](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_1809855595.png)

Interviews and exclusive footage take us behind the scenes of the 2018 Cambridge Analytica scandal, the company's misuse of private user data from Facebook, and its role in the Brexit referendum and the Donald Trump presidential campaign.
The Great Hack casts a chilling spotlight on the forces that are being used to manipulate our psychology and our society.

The Great Hack tells the story of how consulting firm Cambridge Analytica used Facebook data to influence critical elections, and how such uses of technology threaten our democracy. [youtube.com/c/KinoCheckInternational](https://youtu.be/CAMoPbj3jQE?t=29.11&e=36.35)

The Lonely Century looks into a problem that's been known to fall by the wayside, but affects a growing percentage of our nations. It isn't just the elderly feeling alone at home, but our children and teenagers too.
Together, we must find a way to reconnect with one another, and insist that political representatives take their share of the responsibility to make the world a better place.

insights.title: Loneliness isn’t just about not having a friend to talk to, but about feeling disregarded by the system

paragraphCards.markdown: "All over the world people are feeling lonely, disconnected and alienated. We are in the midst of a global loneliness crisis. None of us, anywhere, are immune." \[Noreena Hertz\]

Even back in 2019 before a global pandemic locked us away indoors, people worldwide have been feeling lonelier than ever. [giphy.com/mollykatekestner/](https://media.giphy.com/media/9WtoCKS93m8ZW/giphy.mp4)
In 1978, a group of researchers designed the UCLA Loneliness Scale, assessing how often participants felt connections and support from others - or a lack thereof.
This provided the foundation for most studies on the subject for years, but as times have changed, the concept has become a little more complex.

Loneliness cannot simply be labelled as lacking intimacy or companionship. It is about feeling uncared for by the systems on which we depend. [giphy.com/carriepilbythemovie](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oKIPhf02cXU9W4Le0/giphy.mp4)
No longer do we have that sense of community from our fellow citizens.
Never would you ask your neighbor to borrow some milk, or say 'hello' to the person sitting next to you on the subway.
Our workplaces have left us to fend for ourselves. [giphy.com/cakefx/](https://media.giphy.com/media/j6ZT2gjDbMBFctw0ev/giphy.mp4)
Now that offices are centered around online systems, they also feature less face-to-face contact. It becomes easier to fall through the cracks, and be ignored or forgotten about by your superiors.

Unemployment rates are higher than ever. Even for those who do have a job, companies are littered with pay discrepancies, sexual harassment, and an expectation to work twice the hours the contract requires.
We as humans are further distanced from one another than ever before, and it's been building for years. [giphy.com/amonamarth](https://media.giphy.com/media/XBwWNIY6WY7g4/giphy.mp4)
Indifference and selfishness have become the norm, and empathy is now a thing of the past.
We are not lonely because we weren't cool enough at school to make friends; this is more than that. [giphy.com/sadgirlsloan](https://media.giphy.com/media/MEukKOFm4qwRXgy4gu/giphy.mp4)
We are lonely because we have lost our ability to care for others. If we struggle to treat people with kindness, equality or respect, how can we expect to receive it in return?

insights.title: Human beings haven’t evolved to embrace loneliness

paragraphCards.markdown: "Being connected to others is our natural and in fact desired state, whether this desire is conscious or not." \[Noreena Hertz\]
Humans are primates, and so are social beings by nature. [youtube.com/c/SkavlanTV](https://youtu.be/0MZ1lqbnXtg?t=187.40&e=206.00)
Some would even say that our entire existence is founded upon our ability to work together as a team, hunting and gathering as a collective, and protecting one another from predators.
As Homo sapiens, being alone and away from the group was a threat to our survival. [giphy.com/hallmarkchannel](https://media.giphy.com/media/l49JWheCDC4sjkdIk/giphy.mp4)
Human beings have evolved over thousands of years to have a biological reaction to being left alone - alert, distressed, and keen to find safety in numbers.

The sensation of loneliness has been linked to the 'fight or flight' response. When a person starts to feel lonely, their blood pressure rises along with their levels of cortisol, the 'stress hormone'.

The amygdala is the bit of the brain responsible for the 'fight or flight' reaction, and when these levels start to rise, it flares up and signals danger. ![Amygdala.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Amygdala.jpg)

This state of stress within the body, when experienced repeatedly over a long period of time, can leave a person at greater risk of disease - not just the common cold or flu, but also heart disease, strokes, and even clinical dementia (up to 64%, in fact).

Studies have shown that if you're socially isolated or feel lonely, your chances of a premature death increase by almost 30%. [giphy.com/rheabambulu](https://media.giphy.com/media/tIwmTQ64D52XTuL8xd/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: It’s going to take real teamwork to solve the loneliness crisis

actions.title: Put your relationships first.
actions.markdown: If you agree to watch a movie or have dinner with your partner, put your phone away. If you have had a long week at work, bring biscuits into the office for everyone to share. Invite a neighbor for coffee, and give your nan a call.

actions.title: Perform random acts of kindness.
actions.markdown: The simplest of gestures can make another person’s day. Give up your seat on the subway, hold open a door, give that loose banknote to a homeless person - and always remember to smile when you pass someone in the street.

paragraphCards.markdown: Since the year 2000, we have been living in what can now be called the 'Lonely Century', and the coronavirus has done nothing but throw further light on the problem. So how do we solve it?
The solution to loneliness doesn't lie just in politics, business, or us as individuals, but in all three combined. [giphy.com/blindspot](https://media.giphy.com/media/Bppnvlkv9Ik4mOh5i6/giphy.mp4)
We must look to a new way of living, with people at the center. Although it seems hard to function without money at the forefront of all that we do, it is time to let society lead the way.
People need to feel seen and heard. We need to be given a voice and a greater sense of democracy. [giphy.com/theundefeated](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oFzlUxkZTrgmChqNy/giphy.mp4)
Instead of just voting once every few years, we should be involved, even encouraged to help solve our own problems.
From local building plans to fixing the global warming crisis, citizens could be a part of local political schemes.
As unemployment continues to rise, governments could roll out jobs to assist the lonely, or those with depression, anxiety, and other mental health problems.

Amongst ourselves, we need to abolish our fear of interaction. We must get to know our neighbors, and rediscover the power of community. [giphy.com/humandalas](https://media.giphy.com/media/jVTcXdaFttkusZqfLR/giphy.mp4)
We can take greater responsibility within the relationships we already have, and make the effort to make new ones whenever possible - however daunting it may seem at first.
Although technology has created opportunities for virtual friendships via common interests or local groups, people do nonetheless feel closer when they meet in person.
Different people need to spend time together, and learn from one another. [giphy.com/barbara\_pozzi](https://media.giphy.com/media/U2APMzqCBgpEG5rYSS/giphy.mp4)

"It's a shift in mindset that's needed. We need to recast ourselves from consumers to citizens, from casual observers to active participants. It's about accepting that sometimes what's best for the collective is not what's in our own immediate self-interest." \[Noreena Hertz\]

"We have a real opportunity right now to come together to co-create a distinctly different future, and ensure that we do a much better job of listening to people from all backgrounds and enable them to have a voice." \[Noreena Hertz\]
Most of us have felt lonely at one point or another. [giphy.com/polyvinylrecords](https://media.giphy.com/media/3og0ITiFqzvVdNirF6/giphy.mp4)
Though being home alone on a Friday night can sometimes feel like a blessing, it can feel empty, isolating and repressive when it becomes a frequent occurrence.
In 2010, a study revealed that three in five adults in the US consider themselves to be lonely. In 2019, another showed that more than one in five American millennials have no friends at all.
The problem is escalating across generations, and in 2018, Great Britain even appointed a Minister for Loneliness.
Now in the midst of a global pandemic, the problem of loneliness is more acute than ever. [giphy.com/natgeochannel](https://media.giphy.com/media/cKJj8aT2r62FhKeFrx/giphy.mp4)
Although the majority are familiar with the emotion, how many of us have ever stopped to think what loneliness actually is? What does it mean, and how does it feel?

This is exactly what Noreena Hertz decided to look into for her book The Lonely Century. ![Noreena\_Hertz\_-\_Trento\_-\_1.JPG](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1d/Noreena_Hertz_-_Trento_-_1.JPG)
A thought leader, academic and broadcaster with several books under her belt, she investigates the origins of this loneliness crisis, and what it means for civilization.

By pulling in the data, meeting with the experts, and trialling some of the latest technological 'solutions', Hertz shows the 21st Century to be the loneliest yet, and explains what we can all do to solve it.
The Lonely Century takes a hard look at how widespread the problem of loneliness has become across the globe, and the havoc it is wreaking along the way.
If only we'd had Arthur Benjamin to help at school, instead of all the long and complicated textbooks that made algebra, Pythagoras or calculus hard work.
The Magic of Math gives a fresh, new look on a traditionally arduous subject, and Arthur Benjamin even has a great TED talk on the subject as well.

insights.title: Try to spot numerical patterns to make your life easier and train your brain

paragraphCards.markdown: When Arthur Benjamin was little, he loved playing around with numbers.
One day, when he tried to see which pairs added to equal 20 and would give the biggest number when multiplied, he noticed something.

Do this exercise, and you go through the pairs like:

7 x 13 = 91

8 x 12 = 96

9 x 11 = 99

10 x 10 = 100
So, you'll quickly realize that 10x10 gives you the biggest result. But if you go back through those numbers and measure the distance of each to 100, something interesting emerges.

100 - 100 = 0

100 - 99 = 1

100 - 96 = 4

100 - 91 = 9

Write it out, and you'll see that these are the first few square numbers:

0² = 0

1² = 1

2² = 4

3² = 9
Once Benjamin spotted this pattern, calculating any square number became a lot easier.
For example, instead of trying to calculate 13x13 in your head, you can break it down...
A helpful little trick - and this works for all square numbers.
Finding mathematical patterns will make your whole life a lot easier, so try to practice it whenever you get a chance.

insights.title: You can use mathemagics to impress your friends and practice your mental math

paragraphCards.markdown: Here's a little trick to practice your mental math...

Have someone go through these five steps:

1.  Think of two numbers from 1 to 10
2.  Add those together
3.  Multiply by 10
4.  Add the larger number of the two
5.  Subtract the smaller number of the two
Have them tell you the result. Here's how you can shock them by instantly telling them what their numbers were.
Let's say your friend's number was 117. Take the last digit of the number and add it to the preceding number. In this case it's 7+11=18
Divide by 2 to get the larger number. Here it's 18/2=9
Subtract the last digit of their answer to get the smaller number. Here, it comes out to 9–7=2
Not sure if this works? Run through the five original steps and see if the numbers hold up...
It may seem like nothing more than a fun gimmick, but doing math tricks like these on the regular will help you practice your mental math.
You'll be able to add, multiply, divide, and subtract numbers a lot faster in your head – something that might come in handy next time you're handed your change at the cashier.

insights.title: Unlike any other science, theories in math can be proven with absolute certainty

paragraphCards.markdown: The reason math fascinates so many scientists is that it's the only science where you can prove theories to be 100% true. By setting up a series of equations, you can create 'proof'.
These usually just take an equation that we know to be correct for certain numbers, and run through it with arbitrary variables to show it's still true if you put in any other number.
For example, you know that adding two even numbers will always result in another even number. But is that true for all even numbers?
If we define two random even numbers, m and n, we now have to try and prove that m + n is an even number too.
All even numbers are multiples of 2, so we can say that m=2xK, where K can be any integer (that is, a positive whole number like 4, 13, or 437).
In the same way, n can be a multiple of another integer, so n=2xJ

Substituting these in our m + n equation, we get:

m + n = 2 x K + 2 x J = 2 x (K + J)
But the sum of two integers is also an integer, and if all we do with the integer (K + J) is multiply it by 2, then it naturally becomes an even number. Therefore, our proof is true for all integers.
Coming up with a proof is hard, but it saves years of effort by allowing scientists to be certain without having to do endless calculations, which is what makes math a unique science.
"The methods taught in school are fine for doing maths on paper, but they are generally poor for doing maths in your head." \[Arthur Benjamin\]
Did you enjoy math in school, or hate it? A lot of us found it to be a difficult subject that took a lot of brain power and messy workings.
These days, more and more young people struggle even to make a rough estimate of their grocery bill before getting to the cashier, let alone quickly multiply numbers in their head.

Arthur Benjamin is here to help change that. His book, The Magic of Math, is here to help reignite a love and admiration for math, so that maybe we can all start to challenge our brains with logic, and enjoy the process of doing so.
The Magic of Math shows you not only the power but the beauty of mathematics, unlike you've ever seen it in school and with practical, real-world applications.
The Messy Middle gives us a realistic idea of what it takes to make it through that crucial and most painful intermediate section of any project.

insights.title: Failure or success of your project is the result of perseverance through the chaotic center

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: No matter what type of journey you are setting out on, whether it's entrepreneurial or a personal project, the messy middle is inevitable.
Whenever you initiate a new endeavor, you need to give a significant amount of initial energy.
While this power is necessary to get your project off the ground, it also isn't as hard to find because the puppy-love phase has you enamored with your new idea.
With fairytale-like wonder, we often only see the beginning or the end of ventures.
What we fail to recognize is all of the hard work and pain that occurred in the space between the founding and end.
In the middle portion of your project, you'll experience a rollercoaster of challenges.
Your endeavor itself and your own emotional connection to it will go through many highs and lows.
At times you may lack enthusiasm and feel lost. This portion of the journey will make or break you.
Whenever we persist through this challenging part, however, we later see an upward trending curve, even if that graph has multiple highs and lows along the way.
The author, Scott Belsky, is no stranger to the laborious center of any project. His online platform and company Behance struggled through a messy middle for years.
At times no-one cared about his idea, many expressed doubts, and he felt like the entire company would fall apart.
Belsky's struggles through the middle of Behance's journey helped him learn to keep going when times get tough in the middle.

insights.title: If you want to last through the hard middle of your journey, remain self-aware through trials and triumphs

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: When taking on a challenge, you will inevitably go through numerous moments of success and failure along your journey, especially in the intermediate portion.
What does it take to survive the messy middle? To come out on top, we should maintain self-awareness amid the lows and the highs.
We don't realize that both the ups and the downs impact us personally in ways that can hinder our progress.
When we are going through a great time, we let our ego take charge. This hinders our ability to make decisions effectively because our psyche makes us overconfident.
Good advice falls on deaf ears when shared with one who thinks they've got it made and that they don't need to improve.
On the flip side, when our venture is struggling, we grow insecure and vulnerable.
This leads to leaders blaming others for the difficulties the company is experiencing, which can undermine the effectiveness of the team.
Self-awareness can be as simple as remaining open to feedback.
Leaders who are less defensive and more receptive of correction, have the highest potential.
Additionally, outstanding founders of startups not only receive correction and feedback well, but they also seek it out.

insights.title: Your greatest victories come from focusing on improving what works well

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: As you are mudding your way through the messy middle of your endeavour, you will experience times of prosperity.
The key to hastening your progression toward the final goal is riding those waves and focusing on what created them in the first place.
Whenever something works well, examine the why and how, and seek to replicate and spread the improvement across your entire team.
One way to do this is through what's called A/B testing.

If you have a clickable button on your site, for example, you may send half of the people who click to one sales page and half to another. Whichever page converts the most sales is the one that you continue to use.
This process can be implemented across multiple aspects of your company as well.
"You can get the important stuff right and still lose by not enduring long enough." \[Scott Belsky\]

What was the last big project you started that eventually failed? Did you found a start-up, launch a blog, or engage in a massive art project? It's tough to see our passion projects crash and burn. This makes it all the more critical to discover what parts of our journey led to our fall.

An estimated 90% of startups fail miserably before impacting the marketplace significantly. Why does this happen so frequently? It's as if we never hear about this ugly side of entrepreneurship. The news is full of examples of highly-valued startups and their humble beginnings.
But what about all those that die out? What's the great stumbling block that makes it so hard for them to succeed? The Messy Middle will teach us the answer.

Author Scott Belsky founded and was once the CEO of Behance, the top digital networking company for creatives. Making ideas into reality isn't anything new to Belsky, as he also wrote the book Making Ideas Happen.
In The Messy Middle: Finding Your Way Through the Hardest and Most Crucial Part of Any Bold Venture, he explains how to keep that new idea moving forward.

It's possible to progress even when you get into the middle, which contains the most burdensome troubles. With these tips, you can make any project or venture prosperous by learning to weather the storms that will come your way.
The Messy Middle challenges the notion that projects grow slowly and smoothly toward success by outlining the rocky but important intermediate stages of any journey and how to survive them.
Better eating in a nutshell. Even better: The Omnivore's Dilemma does it without telling us to eat a specific diet. [youtube.com/user/thnkrtv](https://youtu.be/-T_EAoYE5aw?t=276.40&e=292.90)
Our environment needs looking after, and so does our body.

insights.title: A lot of our food problems all started with corn

paragraphCards.markdown: [youtube.com/user/thnkrtv](https://youtu.be/-T_EAoYE5aw?t=93.04&e=108.24)
In theory, corn is a great plant. It's highly adaptable, very resistant, and grows in large quantities fast. ![giphy.com/mummu](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6gDQZIgPWUGOUh2w/giphy.gif)
When the Europeans first landed in the US and discovered corn, it quickly became a household name for farmers.
But we can overdo even the best things. Technology has advanced so far that we can now alter plants at the genetic level.
The corn that industrial farmers now grow has little to do with its ancestor. ![giphy.com/kronethepowerofgreen](https://media.giphy.com/media/fXzIZkWrbBHYv332ta/giphy.gif)
In 1920, a farmer could comfortably produce 20 bushels of corn per acre. That figure has shot to 180 today – a 9x increase.
Ten years ago, it cost a farmer $2.50 to produce a bushel, but due to the already flooded market, buyers only wanted to pay $1.45 - so the government agreed to match the difference.

This gave the farmers an artificial profit for producing corn, and so ruined the supply and demand cycle of corn. ![giphy.com/kronethepowerofgreen](https://media.giphy.com/media/VCsJDLGAoxOBbBzbi9/giphy.gif)
Farmers can make a ton of money from producing corn, and continue to grow more and more, even though the market's demand has long been saturated.
The excess corn is what lands in our food in the form of high fructose corn syrup and other highly processed derivatives.
It's also fed to all kinds of animals who aren't natural corn eaters like cows, chickens, and even carnivores like salmon.

insights.title: ‘Organic’ is not as clean as we think it is

paragraphCards.markdown: You're probably aware by now that the entire processed food industry is not the greenest choice we can make.
But how much do you know about organic food? ![giphy.com/anchorpoint](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4FGtLo1mvRrl0cxy/giphy.gif)
Originally started as a counter-movement to processed and industrialized food, due to its popularity, organic food as a label has been swept up by the processed food lobby.
A huge number of the small farms that came from the organic movement had to either let go of some of their standards in order to supply the growing demand for organic food, or go out of business.
As organic businesses grew, standards were lowered.
Now, food companies can cut corners and still get away with labels like 'organic', 'free-range', and 'less pesticides'.
[youtube.com/user/Kurzgesagt](https://youtu.be/8PmM6SUn7Es?t=165.50&e=177.70)
For example, would you call 20,000 chickens in a shed with a two-week mini vacation in the tiny backyard 'free-range'? The food industry would.
And what the hell is 'organic high fructose corn syrup'?
That stuff is one of the most artificial things ever produced. ![giphy.com/uofcalifornia](https://media.giphy.com/media/l41lROcZLoYlRVdZu/giphy.gif)

insights.title: If we buy locally, we win on all levels

actions.title: Shop local.
actions.markdown: Instead of going to the big superstore chain, find your local market. Try your nearby butcher, baker and candlestick maker. Give your money to the little guy.

paragraphCards.markdown: Two words: Buy. Locally. ![giphy.com/google](https://media.giphy.com/media/63v0VgDTeLsLPjtLNn/giphy.gif)
[youtube.com/user/STCUOnlineMedia](https://youtu.be/vq13bp6jbWk?t=0.10&e=17.14)
If we get our food from small local farms, everyone will win - including us.
Due to the reduction in distance that our food travels until it eventually lands on our plate, less fuel and resources are used.
Local produce is the environmentally friendlier alternative. ![giphy.com/google](https://media.giphy.com/media/JfUjfs5rB6vvOW8DNN/giphy.gif)
Economically, we put money into the hands of the right people: small businesses.
As long as we give the majority of our money to big corporations, they'll be the ones in charge. ![giphy.com/google](https://media.giphy.com/media/31vC0Dk4in6a9FOkTG/giphy.gif)
The quality of your food is increased, because it's grown according to the season and natural circumstances on site, which makes pesticides and other artificial support unnecessary.
Ethically, this is a no brainer, and it also holds our farmer, butcher, and baker accountable.
When they know we're passing by their store every day, they're much less likely to mistreat animals or plants, because of their personal relationship with us.
[youtube.com/user/STCUOnlineMedia](https://youtu.be/vq13bp6jbWk?t=19.00&e=36.80)
So start by skipping the supermarket once in a while, and consider the bountiful options around the corner. ![giphy.com/notflipper](https://media.giphy.com/media/xTiTnsZ8v95BDWVHj2/giphy.gif)
"Don't eat anything your great-grandmother wouldn't recognise as food." \[Michael Pollan\]
[youtube.com/user/thnkrtv](https://youtu.be/-T_EAoYE5aw?t=10.00&e=22.00)
What should you have for dinner? Simple question, right? At least it was, up until a few thousand and even a few hundred years ago.
You ate what was available during that season, sold by the farmer that day. ![giphy.com/nirmarx](https://media.giphy.com/media/SYi99e7dyB5o1geW4H/giphy.gif)
Today everything is available, all the time, wherever we are. So what do we eat to stay healthy, make economic choices, and not hurt the environment?
Michael Pollan helps us answer this now highly-complicated question in The Omnivore's Dilemma. ![MICHAEL\_POLLAN.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/15/MICHAEL_POLLAN.jpg)
[youtube.com/user/thnkrtv](https://youtu.be/-T_EAoYE5aw?t=64.03&e=84.80)

The Omnivore's Dilemma explains the paradox of the food choices we face today, how the industrial revolution changed the way we eat, and which food choices are the most ethical, sustainable, and environmentally friendly.

Anyone seeking direction in their life can benefit from The Path Made Clear. Those who are fans of Oprah will particularly enjoy it, with snippets of advice picked up from wise people she's interviewed.

insights.title: If you really pay attention to yourself and your feelings, you can discover your purpose

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: We all have a calling while we're here on earth. In order to find what it is, we need to recognize what makes us who we are. These are the seeds of our identity.

For example, someone who is born with a love and gift for music probably has been watering this seed by learning to play an instrument from a young age. One day, they can bloom into a musician or a music teacher.
Sometimes, however, these seeds hide so deep that we don't find them until later in life.
We have the chance however, through choices, failures, and successes, to nurture and discover new seeds along the way.

Oprah Winfrey shares the story of her beginnings on TV to illustrate this. In her early career, she was a news anchor. It would be an exciting job for most people, but she wasn't happy with what she was doing because she felt like she couldn't be herself.
Her bosses were also unhappy with her because they felt she displayed too much emotion for an anchor. Eventually, she was let go and hired as a co-host on a talk-show.
This was considered a downgrade in her career, but she loved it. She discovered a seed that had been hidden inside that she didn't know about.
She loved to interview, listen, and engage in meaningful conversations with people. And because it was her true calling, this is where she shined.
To find what your calling is and find your seeds, lead a life full of awareness, particularly to yourself and what's in your heart.

insights.title: Being afraid is an intrinsic part of discovering your dreams

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: They say nothing worth having is easy, right? This is true to so many things, and it's true for finding your dreams.
Sometimes it's downright scary to go for your dreams, but that fear is a natural part of growing as a human being.
Every important undertaking will bring some level of fear, and the amount you feel is relative to just how significant it will be for your personal development.

When Oprah interviewed the author, Steven Pressfield, he explained that every dream he has is met with resistance. He said that the bigger our dream is, the more resistance we will feel moving forward with it.
This can be likened to Newton's law of motion. Every action has an equal and opposite reaction. That reaction comes as anxiety and fear.
Once we are able to overcome the resistance, the key to realizing our dreams comes from committing fully to them.

insights.title: Success is best measured by whether or not you are true to yourself

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: Oprah Winfrey wants to redefine the term 'success' in a way that doesn't mean material wealth.
Oprah says success is cyclical. We will experience ups and downs, and these can't define us.
When talking to the best-selling author, Sarah Breathnach, Oprah learned that Sarah started to lavishly spend in the wake of her book's success.
When the book eventually fell off the list, she was devastated. She didn't prepare herself for the fact that success comes in ups and downs.
The way people spend their money is a reflection of how they feel about themselves.
For those who experience a rush of success like Breathnach, they tend to feel unworthy of financial success and buy things to create a sense of self-worth.
Instead of a huge house or being on the bestseller list, success should be about staying true to yourself and your calling.
The ultimate goal is that we get to a point where we have a balance between our inner thoughts and our outer actions.
Things like celebrity status and net worth change with time, so to be truly fulfilled, we need our innermost self to be constant.
"There is no greater gift you can give or receive than to honor your calling. It's why you were born, and how you become most truly alive." \[Oprah Winfrey\]

Wouldn't it be nice if we all came to this earth with some sort of calling based on what we're good at that would give us purpose? In a sense, we actually are all born with a calling. We have innate strengths and interests that can guide our path.

But often the complicated nature of the world today keeps us from discovering which path we should follow. Because of this, many of us live on autopilot. We work jobs we aren't meant for, just to get a paycheck. Too many of us just float through our lives without really living.

"Everyone has a purpose. Your real job in life is to figure out as soon as possible what that is, who you are meant to be, and begin to honor your calling in the best way possible." \[Oprah Winfrey\]

If you feel like a ship without a rudder drifting through your life, Oprah Winfrey wants to help by building you a framework for a life of success and significance.

In her book, The Path Made Clear: Discovering Your Life's Direction and Purpose, she shares personal stories and wisdom from her own life as well as the lives of many other successful people who also found their true calling.
The Path Made Clear contains Oprah Winfrey's tips for how to discover your real purpose so you can lead a life of success and significance.

The parenting advice in The Power Of Showing Up is simple, actionable, and revolutionary. Many of the ideas can help kids learn to deal with complex emotions, and teach parents how to do better themselves.

insights.title: If you want to be close to your kids, give them physical and emotional safety

actions.title: Control your emotions.
actions.markdown: Children are much more susceptible to emotional trauma than adults. If you can feel yourself getting angry or upset, try not to do so in front of your kids. Take a breath, and try to remain calm.

paragraphCards.markdown: Fall over and scrape your knee, you'll probably be okay within a few days. Emotional trauma, on the other hand, isn't so easy to wipe from your memory.
When children are put into threatening or harmful situations, it will stick with them into adulthood. Their development and health can go on to decline, sometimes throughout their entire lives.
This was confirmed in a two-year-long research project involving 15,000 participants called 'Adverse Childhood Experiences'.

Those who'd experienced abuse, neglect, and other forms of dysfunction were worse at relating to others, had a harder time coping with problems, and also had more health issues. On average, they even died younger.
Sometimes, even the best of parents can still be a threat to their children's safety. The key thing to watch out for is aggression.
This can come in various forms, including physical, verbal, or implied, including body language and facial expressions.
Inevitably you're going to lose your temper at some point. To mitigate the effects of this on your kids, always apologize.
Then, spend quality time with them as soon as you can afterward to heal the relationship.

insights.title: Pay attention to your children’s desires instead of making them follow yours

actions.title: Let your kids be who they want to be.
actions.markdown: Don’t push certain interests or expectations onto your children. Encourage them to try new things, and see what sticks. Talk to them about what they enjoy doing, and help them find their speciality.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you have a best friend that you can talk to about anything, then you know how useful they can be for when times are tough.
A friend can understand you and accept you regardless of what happens, or what you think and feel.
You need this kind of relationship with your kids if you want to show up for them. Too often, though, it's difficult to keep your own aspirations out of their way.
A father might, for example, rigorously train his son to become a college athlete, but then ends up ignoring each time the boy hints at his love of music.
A mother might think of her daughter as lazy because she's getting bad grades at school, when in fact it's only because she's having a hard time fitting in.
This isn't only damaging if the kids aren't able to realize their dreams, but also if they begin to internalize these thoughts.
The girl whose mother thinks she's lazy might start believing that's actually true.
To combat this, develop a curiosity for who your kids really are. Devote time to observing them as they figure it out. Don't let your own judgments get in the way.
Let your kids express themselves freely. Plan regular time to spend just listening and talking with them, and let them be open.
Don't judge what they're saying, and they'll open up to you further.

insights.title: Give your kids emotional intelligence by soothing them instead of getting angry

actions.title: Empathize with your kids.
actions.markdown: If your child is upset, don’t just brush them off or get angry and frustrated. Instead, respond with care and affection. Listen to their needs, and help them reach the right conclusion.

paragraphCards.markdown: If you're a parent, you know how difficult temper tantrums are to deal with.
Even if you don't have kids but have seen one happening, you can get an idea of how frustrating they are.
The initial tendency in these situations is for parents to respond with anger, threats, or a time-out - but none of these work.
What the child really needs is empathy. They need you to soothe them.
When you learn this vital skill your kids will become more resilient, and will have fewer outbursts in the future.
With repeated soothing from you, they'll gain the skills necessary to do it for themselves.

One Texas school district that Siegel and Bryson worked with showed the power this has. Children who were soothed after getting upset became calm much faster than when they were punished. Additionally, the intensity, length, and frequency of their tantrums decreased.
To help your family develop this habit and reap these benefits, use the following tools…

1.  A safe space that kids can go when they're upset
2.  A list of favorite calming songs to listen to

3.  Go-to physical activities to help them deal with the emotions
4.  Signal words or phrases to use when they need your help
"Forgiveness is giving up all hope for a better past. In this way, we forgive not to condone, not to say it was fine, but to let go of false illusions that we can change the past."
Being a parent is tough. Many wonder how they ever keep up.
When work and life get in the way, it can be hard to spend quality time with them, and make sure their needs are met.
Even despite the struggle, most parents want to take the best care of their kids so they grow up healthy and happy.
Fortunately, Tina Bryson and Daniel Siegel wrote The Power of Showing Up: How Parental Presence Shapes Who Our Kids Become and How Their Brains Get Wired to help.
It will teach you how to be there for your kids, in more ways than just being physically present, so that they grow up to be confident and resilient.
The Power of Showing Up inspires parents to help their kids develop strong bonds and emotional intelligence by identifying how to be fully present.

paragraphCards.markdown: The Pragmatist's Guide to Relationships may be the most thorough book on relationships that you ever come across. It challenges your thought patterns, can help you see the strengths and weaknesses of your own relationships, and gives you actionable advice going forward.

insights.title: Use the six efficient relationship lures to find a great partner

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: A relationship lure is the value you offer a potential partner. It sets the stage for the short and long-term quality of the partnership, so it's vital that you get it right.
Relationships lures work like fishing lures. If you want to have a specific kind of relationship, you've got to use a certain lure.
When we make an excuse like "all guys are the same", we're just trying to attract someone the wrong way.
If a fisherman thinks all fish have whiskers, he'll only use bait designed to catch catfish – and catfish(ed) is all he'll get.
There are 12 lures in total. The first six are dominance, niceness, sexual exploration, easiness, sneakiness, or a promise of love. These are inefficient, however, and lead to unstable relationships.
The last six work better in securing a good, lasting relationship…
1.  **Pygmalion:** Appeal to a person's desire to improve themselves by identifying their potential and working with them to achieve it.
2.  **Status:** Show how you'll elevate someone's status through their being with you.
3.  **Self-Identity:** Highlight how a relationship with you reinforces your desired partner's idealized vision of themselves.
4.  **Friend With Benefits:** Sometimes being close friends can make the transition into a relationship easier.
5.  **Long-Term Relationship:** Openly explaining that you're looking for a long-term relationship will appeal to those who want the same.
6.  **Social Construct:** Matchmaking is still a great way to meet someone. All parties are vetted through their friends, so there should be a decent amount of shared values.
These lures are not the end of a good relationship but the beginning.
Use them wisely, and, once you've found someone, the real work begins...

insights.title: The beauty of a good marriage lies in sharing your mental load

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: A good relationship is founded upon 'cognitive integration'. This is when both people share out responsibilities and support each other in the workload.

For example, one person might not have to worry about dealing with the finances, but can still help out with work and home admin. The other might then never have to do the food shopping, but that doesn't mean they don't help cook from time to time.
When you work together, you'll be able to do more than double what one of you could do alone.

The three levels of cognitive integration are:

1.  Separate
2.  Siloed
3.  Integrated
Cognitive separation is when people are simply roommates that share some income, have sex, and maybe even kids or pets.
If you're in a cognitively siloed relationship, you divide entire life domains, like finances or child-raising, between each other.
A cognitively integrated couple, however, shares the various stages of the decision-making process across all domains of life.

insights.title: Find a partner that’ll unlock your potential, and help them do the same

actions.title: \[Action Title\]
actions.markdown: \[Action Description\]

paragraphCards.markdown: People always say: "Never marry someone out of the expectation they will change." There's some truth to this, but people always change.
There's always an opportunity to help your partner become the best version of themselves – and vice versa. Imagine a good friend always pushing you to do your best.
We all want our friends to support us, but when it comes to supportive lovers, society isn't as encouraging.

"While you may or may not spend the rest of your life with the person you marry, you will have no choice but to spend the rest of your life as the person into whom your partner transforms you." \[Simone, Malcolm Collins\]
That's why you must look for a partner who will love you as you are while encouraging you to reach higher.
Most often, the traits you already want to change will be the same ones your companion will want to help you improve, so this isn't as hard as it sounds.
To train your partner in return, express both disappointment in their bad actions and pride in their good actions by praising them.
"It would sound truly bizarre for someone to expect a successful career to 'just happen naturally'. Yet it is entirely normalized to expect that good relationships will." \[Simone, Malcolm Collins\]
You put a lot of effort into planning and preparing your career. It's normal to put in 40, 50, or even 60 hours a week.
You have big goals and you know only hard work will get you there. So why don't you think the same way about your relationships?
A great career takes hard work, and we know that, and yet we expect our relationships to bloom naturally.
It's an all too human mistake we all make from time to time, but the truth is that your relationships have a far greater impact on your happiness than anything else.
Consider this: a single horse can pull 8,000 pounds, but when two horses work together, they can haul 24,000 pounds. That's three times as much at just double the effort.

Just like having an intentional strategy helps you build a great career, thinking through how you approach partner acquisition and relationship structure can lead to the rewards of extraordinary relationships.

This is what Simone and Malcolm Collins will help you with in The Pragmatist's Guide to Relationships. The Collins have started The Pragmatist Foundation to uplift people through this philosophy, and all of their books' proceeds go to this charity.

The Pragmatist's Guide to Relationships is an extremely comprehensive manual to all components of relationships. It will help you find the people you want and need in your life, attract them, and keep them around.
The Pragmatist's Guide to Relationships is an extensive, practical guide to finding a companion, be it for marriage, dating, or sex and building a healthy, happy life with them.
The sheer scale of space makes it unlikely we're the only place with the critical ingredients to support life, while also making it really hard to look.
But if, like Carl Sagan, you greet the prospect of extraterrestrial life with more hope than fear, the knowledge here will give you cause for optimism.

insights.title: Our search for extraterrestrial life is shaped by what we know about our own planet

paragraphCards.markdown: Astronomers pretty much agree that when looking for potential life, the best clue of all is the presence of water.
But even on our extremely watery planet, life sometimes has to go to amazing lengths to locate it.
Nature can be very inventive, so any clues we can gather from our own world's more extreme examples help us know what to look for in space.
Scientists study alien-style landscapes like the ones on and around Hawaii before sending their rovers off to examine other planets.
Hawaii is home to over 25,000 species, making it one of the most dynamic living habitats we know, and a great source of information on the resilience of life.
The Ohia tree grows in dry Hawaiian caves, finding its water in moisture condensed from the air, while the fat leaves of the Silversword pick up enough humidity from the wind to thrive.
The Messenger probe found ice on the surface of Mercury, and Mars has lots of it, frozen at the poles and buried in its soil.
Microscopic life on Mars is actually quite likely, and studying Earth's more reclusive inhabitants helps point the way to finding it.

Some of our deep-sea bacteria thrive on clouds of sulfur leaked by hydrothermal vents from the Earth's core. There's every reason to suppose that similar things might be happening on other celestial bodies.
"I am constantly reminded of the tenacity of life. Perhaps life on other planets is far more common than we realize." \[Lisa Kaltenegger, Director of the Carl Sagan Institute, Cornell University\]

insights.title: We’re as likely to find the first life on a moon as a planet

paragraphCards.markdown: As far as we know, the basic elements necessary to support life are water, carbon, and a source of energy - which doesn't have to come from a star.
Some planets' moons have oceans of water beneath the surface, so the tides caused by their host planet's massive gravitational pull produce plenty of energy.
Voyager confirmed that while Saturn is a stormy ball of hydrogen and helium, at least two of its 82 moons are a lot more promising.
"For years, we have searched the planets in our solar system for signs of alien life. But perhaps it will be a moon that first confirms that we are not alone." \[Lisa Kaltenegger\]
Titan, the largest of Saturn's moons, has a dense atmosphere mostly made of nitrogen and contains vast lakes of hydrocarbons - the basic components of amino acids, proteins, and possibly life.
When the probe Cassini visited Saturn's smaller moon Enceladus, it looked like a dead ball of ice - until huge plumes of water spouted through the cracks at its south pole!
A liquid ocean makes life much more likely.
Jupiter has even stronger gravity than Saturn, and at least two moons with liquid water.
The icy crust of Ganymede, the largest moon in this solar system, may conceal more salt water than all of the Earth's oceans combined.
In 2022 an ESA spacecraft will take a closer look at Europa, another of Jupiter's moons, whose icy surface is scarred by mysterious red cracks.
Radar will reveal whether Europa's exterior hides another vast liquid ocean – and potential lunar life.

insights.title: We’re already making exciting discoveries way beyond our solar system

paragraphCards.markdown:
"When light filters through a planet's atmosphere, it creates a spectral fingerprint, telling us if the planet possesses the essentials for life." \[Lisa Kaltenegger\]

Our galaxy, the Milky Way, is home to massive clouds of gas and dust that scientists have called 'The Pillars of Creation' - a 'star factory' that produces billions of stars over billions of years.
Many of those stars will be circled by planets, presenting endless possibilities of finding one that can support life in some form.
The most Earth-like planet so far was found in our neighboring solar system, and given the name Proxima B.
The super-sensitive Kepler space telescope hunted for planets beyond our solar system, by spotting tiny dots that ever so slightly dim the star's light as they pass.
Even while focused on around two percent of the night sky, Kepler found thousands of planets orbiting alien suns, which we could then observe with telescopes back on Earth.
The first alien planet ever seen by humans is over 120 light-years away and nearly 13 times the mass of Jupiter.
As our telescopes become smarter and more powerful, we'll get better at seeing smaller planets more likely to contain life.
The hope is to spot a planet with the tiny halo indicating an atmosphere - a potential habitat.

"The search for extraterrestrial life, and especially extraterrestrial intelligence, is one of the key philosophical, scientific and human questions that have been posed." \[Carl Sagan, cosmologist and astrobiologist\]
In 1977, Carl Sagan sent a 'message in a bottle' attached to the outside of NASA's two Voyager spacecraft.
Although Sagan's postcard to the cosmos has had no response so far, it fascinated one filmmaker enough to set out on his own investigation of our hunt for alien life.
Steve Amezdroz cut his teeth as an Art Director on the original Mad Max films.
In his new documentary, Amezdroz turns his attention to one of mankind's biggest questions: are we alone in the universe?
The Search for Life in Space checks in with our planet's foremost experts for updates and insights into the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
The film's settings move from the usual suspects like observatories, to unexpected ones like the ocean deep below Hawaii.

As Carl Sagan's interstellar postcard pushes ever further into space at 11 miles per second, The Search for Life in Space explains how our own investigations are bringing us closer to an understanding of what might be out there.
This mind-expanding film examines the likelihood of finding life beyond our planet, and brings us up to speed on the latest research.
