actions.markdown: Spot negativity as it starts to arise, stop to acknowledge its presence and what it means, and then swap its toxicity for calm logic and understanding.

actions.title: Write down your emotions.
actions.markdown: Venting might make you feel better in the moment, but you’ll actually feel worse throughout the day. Instead, write down how you feel in a daily journal, which has been shown to encourage growth and healing.

paragraphCards.markdown: "I am not what I think I am, and I am not what you think I am. I am what I think you think I am." \[Charles Horton Cooley, Sociologist\]
In a world filled with distractions, it can be almost impossible to retain a grip on who we truly are. [giphy.com/liannedias/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0MYJZbQQ8vFmmdLq/giphy.mp4)
With our parents, school, social media, and TV all vying for our attention, our own identity becomes clouded.

We lose sight of what we want from life, and instead play different roles to achieve certain ideals: the high-flying professional who pays the bills, the perfect partner who takes care of the kids, the kind friend who shows up to every birthday party.

The roles we take on benefit us in many ways, but they allow us to become inauthentic - and this can leave a person feeling hollow, lost and unfulfilled. ![giphy.com/kochstrasse/](https://media.giphy.com/media/zphBqJ6SRlP5jlkVUJ/giphy.gif)
One of the key ways we can let go and find freedom is to reject the negativity that filters into our lives. [giphy.com/matvoyce/](https://media.giphy.com/media/UqpjszfpiOiLA0L5le/giphy.mp4)
We spread and receive negativity on a daily basis, preferring to complain rather than celebrate small joys or wins.

Bad things do happen, but dwelling on them can cause us to feel insecure, hurt or competitive. And negativity is contagious. ![giphy.com/georgelaw/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l378dlnLfAbviROAE/giphy.gif)
Instead of getting lost in our emotions, we must learn to become objective observers and lead with awareness.
Monks choose not to get upset or frustrated. They step back and allow the moment to pass them by.
It's important to acknowledge feelings as they arrive, and realize what they mean. But instead of reacting compulsively, address the emotion and silence the negativity.
Make room for rational thought, and allow meaningful action to take charge. ![giphy.com/gracemandeville](https://media.giphy.com/media/U6SedgaFzjZ7KCGSAw/giphy.gif)
"Negativity is a trait, not someone's identity. A person's true nature can be obscured by clouds, but, like the sun, it is always there." \[Jay Shetty\]

insights.title: Happiness lies in finding your ‘Dharma’ in both work and play

actions.title: Always look to improve your skills.
actions.markdown: We always say we don’t have time, but it just isn’t true. Next time you have ten minutes before work, on your commute, or before bed, listen to a podcast or watch a YouTube video. Learn new techniques and skills - ten minutes goes a long way.

actions.title: Do the Vedic Personality Test.
actions.markdown: Dharma categorizes us into four different personalities: Creators, Makers, Guides, and Leaders. Do the test and find out which one you are, and which career path might best suit you.|

paragraphCards.markdown: "Your time is limited, so don't waste it living someone else's life." \[Steve Jobs\]
Monks are renowned for their minimalist lifestyle - free of material possessions and shallow distractions.
But for monks, letting go is not about restricting your life, but opening the mind to new possibilities and discovering your Dharma.
There is no one word in the English language to translate the term 'dharma', but it can often be considered as your life calling.
Dharma combines passion and skill, while looking to help the world or serve others. ![giphy.com/watykang/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUOwGk5VRjOXzjJAWY/giphy.gif)
Passion + Expertise + Usefulness = Dharma

Many people choose a career without really considering whether they'll either enjoy it, be good at it, or take meaning from it. [youtube.com/c/TheOutcomeChannel](https://youtu.be/mJ7BonG6hKI?t=48.25&e=111.22)
Most of us are pretty good at what we do, but don't really take pleasure in it. Then we take up hobbies in our spare time that we love, but don't really have time to get good at.
Dissatisfaction with our work often catches up with us in the long run. ![giphy.com/mariannaraskin/](https://media.giphy.com/media/McOkHi1s4yXmCztGRM/giphy.gif)
If you can find your Dharma, you can achieve greater fulfilment in more areas of your life.
First, you must identify your passions; the things that bring you joy. ![giphy.com/Pithagraphic](https://media.giphy.com/media/MAjILFi7zfzxf2xKGX/giphy.gif)
Then, you can consider your strengths. What are you good at? And if you don't really enjoy it, then how might you?
One way to find pleasure in a seemingly boring skill is to consider it a stepping stone for the future. ![giphy.com/lidiaontheroad](https://media.giphy.com/media/d5xV9C7Z7oYiNaOFUR/giphy.gif)
Sure, learning to budget is dull now, but it might help you set up your cake-making business in five years' time.
When it comes to usefulness, don't be immediately disheartened - in the 21st century, most things are more useful than you might think.
The amount of stuff being sold on Etsy and eBay by people sharing their hobby and making money off it is astounding. ![giphy.com/porucz/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7bubCmPeUyHHQ9zO/giphy.gif)
Once you can assess these three areas, you can start to discover how you can rework your life and find greater happiness.
"Your Dharma is already with you. It's always been with you. It's woven into your being. If we keep our minds open and curious, our Dharmas announce themselves." \[Jay Shetty\]

insights.title: To be grateful and serve others is the ultimate form of fulfillment

actions.title: Be grateful every morning.
actions.markdown: When you wake up, instead of checking your phone, take a moment to stay in bed, close your eyes, and bow your head. Think of all the good things you have in life: the people, the light, the warmth, even the coffee waiting for you downstairs.

actions.title: Start a gratitude journal.
actions.markdown: Take a moment each day before bed to write down five things you’re grateful for, both that day and in general. You might find that it will help you sleep better.

actions.title: Find opportunities to be of service.
actions.markdown: Write down every place you go in the course of the week. Then, look at each one and see where you could be of service - a person to help, a project to join, a fundraising opportunity.

paragraphCards.markdown: "Even if your life isn't perfect, build your gratitude like a muscle. If you train it now, it will only strengthen overtime." \[Jay Shetty\]

Monks spend years training their minds, not only to look inwards upon themselves, but to look outwards at the world around them. ![giphy.com/lululemon\_asia/](https://media.giphy.com/media/h8gBrFmKsSwcza1Qkf/giphy.gif)
Monks learn to recognize the things that they value, and be grateful. This can be anything from new opportunities, happy memories, and kind words or gestures, to a new pillow or a box of chocolates.
A lot of us are so caught up in our own daily struggles that we don't see the good things in life. [giphy.com/milkteethmotion/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4KhNBgG8RaItFkDS/giphy.mp4)

The sun brings us heat and light; trees give out oxygen and offer shade; water is there to drink. And that doesn't include having a roof over our heads, a soft bed to sleep on, and the latest smartphone in our pockets.
Being able to appreciate the small things is the key to happiness - and the science backs it up, too. [giphy.com/stefanieshank/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0HlUZNyQ8jHgYedy/giphy.mp4)
Gratitude and kindness have been linked to better mental health, self-awareness, and relationships.
One way to find our gratitude is by actively serving others in meaningful ways. ![giphy.com/AlexandraFive/](https://media.giphy.com/media/ewR5JerBIcPu4gdkVb/giphy.gif)
Sure, many of us help people by giving money to charity or holding a door open, but many people believe we have to solve our own problems before we deal with others'.
It's important to remember, however, that by serving others, our own lives improve. It helps us appreciate the things we already have, and share our wealth with others.
1.  **Service connects us.** It's harder to help from home, so it encourages us to go out into the world and interact with other people.
2.  **Service amplifies gratitude.** By helping others, you gain a greater perspective of what you have yourself.
3.  **Service increases compassion.** It allows you to see what you have to offer and how you can help.
4.  **Service builds self-esteem.** You feel good knowing that you're making a difference in the world, even if it's only to one person in one moment. It gives you purpose.

"Selflessness is the shortest route to inner peace and a meaningful life. Selflessness heals the self. We seek to leave a place cleaner than we found it, people happier than when we found them, the world better than we found it." \[Jay Shetty\]
"If you want to train your mind to find peace, calm and purpose, monks are the experts. Why shouldn't we learn from the calmest, happiest, most purposeful people on earth?" \[Jay Shetty\]
As today's busy world moves faster than ever, more people have started turning to ancient philosophies in search of mindfulness and purpose. Jay Shetty took it one step further.
At university, Shetty would spend the semester studying for a management degree and interning with a top financial consulting firm.
However, during his holidays, he would fly to Mumbai and spend time at an ashram learning to be a monk. [giphy.com/balazsvarga/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7bu90hyq7fI1uk7u/giphy.mp4)
After four years alternating between bars and steakhouses, and sleeping on the floor, Shetty decided that the big career his parents had encouraged brought him little joy.
So, on his day of graduation, he returned to India. [giphy.com/bypriyashah/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6wrAGrygEMdv5zdC/giphy.mp4)
Shetty stayed at the ashram for three years, before deciding to return to the UK. ![Jay\_Shetty\_Headshot\_New.png](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/Jay_Shetty_Headshot_New.png)
Shetty's friends began to turn to him to shed the stress built up in their business lifestyles, and before long, he found himself giving lectures on meditation at corporate conferences.
Now, with his autobiography Think Like a Monk, Jay Shetty wants to share his most important lessons with the rest of the world.

People aren't born monks; they choose to transform themselves, and it can be taught. ![Vector color line sketch meditating monk](https://prod-static.uptimeapp.io/content-team/Shutterstock/shutterstock_738910009.png)
Think Like a Monk teaches how we can let go of the things that don't matter and find the things that do, so that we might learn to live happier and more selfless lives.
Kahneman's thinking in Thinking Fast And Slow is very scientific, and backed up with math and facts, yet simple to understand. We highly recommend this book!

insights.title: Your behavior is determined by two systems in your mind – one conscious and the other automatic.

paragraphCards.markdown: Kahneman labels the two systems in your mind as follows.
System one is automatic and impulsive. [https://youtu.be/PirFrDVRBo4?t=39.00&e=58.00](https://youtu.be/PirFrDVRBo4?t=39.00&e=58.00)

It's the system you use when someone sketchy enters the train and you instinctively turn towards the door and what makes you eat the entire bag of chips in front of the TV when you just wanted to have a small bowl.

System one  is a remnant from our past, and it's crucial to our survival. Not having to think before jumping away from a car when it honks at you is quite useful, don't you think?

[Julia Yellow](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IgonrlrjFymvQ1a/giphy.mp4)
System two is very conscious, aware and considerate. [https://youtu.be/PirFrDVRBo4?t=62.00&e=78.21](https://youtu.be/PirFrDVRBo4?t=62.00&e=78.21)

It helps you exert self-control and deliberately focus your attention. This system is at work when you're meeting a friend and trying to spot them in a huge crowd of people, as it helps you recall how they look and filter out all these other people.

System two is one of the most 'recent' additions to our brain and only a few thousand years old. It's what helps us succeed in today's world, where our priorities have shifted from getting food and shelter to earning money, supporting a family and making many complex decisions.
However, these two systems don't just perfectly alternate or work together. They often fight over who's in charge and this conflict determines how you act and behave.

insights.title: Your brain is lazy and thus keeps you from using the full power of your intelligence.

actions.title: Be aware of your two brains.
actions.markdown: When you need to make a decision, even one as simple as “Should I cook dinner or just get takeout?”, be aware of your process. Don’t just let autopilot take over and think fast. Take the time to concentrate and make educated decisions.

paragraphCards.markdown: Here's an easy trick to show you how our two brain systems affect us; it's called the bat and ball problem.
A baseball bat and a ball cost $1.10. The bat costs $1 more than the ball. How much does the ball cost?
Take a second. … Got it?
If your instant and initial answer is $0.10, we're sorry to tell you that system 1 just tricked you. Do the math again…

Once you spent a minute or two actually thinking about it, you'll see that the ball must cost $0.05. Then, if the bat costs $1 more, it comes out to $1.05, which, combined, gives you $1.10. [TipsyElves.Com](https://media.giphy.com/media/26gR0YFZxWbnUPtMA/giphy.mp4)
Fascinating, right? What happened here? When system one faces a tough problem it can't solve, it'll call system two into action to work out the details.

But sometimes your brain perceives problems as simpler as they actually are. System one thinks it can handle it, even though it actually can't, and you end up making a mistake.

![Holden Mesk](https://media.giphy.com/media/JQLWWXdGzMW9eGyQuH/giphy.gif)
Why does your brain do this? Just as with habits, it wants to save energy. The law of least effort states that your brain uses the minimum amount of energy for each task it can get away with.

So when it seems system one can handle things, it won't activate system two. In this case, though, it leads you to not use all of your IQ points, even though you'd actually need to, so our brain limits our intelligence by being lazy.

insights.title: When you’re making decisions about money, leave your emotions at home.

actions.title: Don’t let your emotions get in the way.
actions.markdown: If you have to make a financial judgement call, don’t let your emotions cloud your vision. Look at the situation objectively, weighing up the pros and cons, then use your rationale to make the best decision for you.

paragraphCards.markdown: The foundation of today's work in economics used to be founded upon Milton Friedman's research into the field.
Eventually, however, we understood that the homo oeconomicus, the man (or woman) who only acts based on rational thinking, first introduced by John Stuart Mill, doesn't quite resemble us.
Imagine these two scenarios, which choice would you make for each one?
1.  You're given $1,000. Then you have the choice between receiving a fixed $500, or taking a 50% gamble to win another $1,000.

2.  You're given $2,000. Then you have the choice between losing $500 or taking a gamble with a 50% chance of losing another $1,000.

![Odibz](https://media.giphy.com/media/ygzkZPxmh6HgUzbYFz/giphy.gif)
If you're like most people, you would rather take the safe $500 in scenario one, but the gamble in scenario two. Yet the odds of ending up at $1,000, $1,500 or $2,000 are the exact same in both.
The reason has to do with loss aversion. We're a lot more afraid to lose what we already have, as we are keen on getting more.
We also perceive value based on reference points. Starting at $2,000 makes you think you're in a better starting position, which you want to protect.

Lastly, we get less sensitive about money (called diminishing sensitivity principle), the more we have. The loss of $500 when you have $2,000 seems smaller than the gain of $500 when you only have $1,000, so you're more likely to take a chance.

Be aware of these things. Just knowing your emotions try to confuse you when it's time to talk money will help you make better decisions. Try to consider statistics, probability and when the odds are in your favor, act accordingly. ![Lidia on the road](https://media.giphy.com/media/RJzcOklIMBPqVHUL5o/giphy.gif)
Don't let emotions get in the way where they have no business. After all, rule number one for any good poker player is "Leave your emotions at home."
"Nothing in life is as important as you think it is, while you are thinking about it." \[Daniel Kahneman\]
Say what you will, they don't hand out the Nobel prize for economics like it's a slice of pizza.

Ergo, anything published by Daniel Kahneman is probably worth paying attention to.

![wp-content](https://www.thinkingheads.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Kahneman-web.jpg)
His 2011 book, Thinking Fast And Slow, deals with the two systems in our brain, whose fighting over who's in charge makes us prone to errors and false decisions.
It shows you where you can and can't trust your gut feeling and how to act more mindfully and make better decisions.

Thinking Fast And Slow shows you how two systems in your brain are constantly fighting over control of your behavior and actions, and teaches you the many ways in which this leads to errors in memory, judgment and decisions, and what you can do about it.

Unconscious Bias is a course by diversity and inclusion expert Stacey Gordon, designed to help us acknowledge and address our own unconscious bias in order for us to make rational decisions to eradicate inequality not only at work, but also in life.

Remember that people often copy the behaviour of others--so if you empower yourself to be more mindful of your own biases and to challenge the prejudiced beliefs of others, others will soon follow your lead.

insights.title: We must understand the impact of unconscious bias

actions.title: Improve your company’s hiring and evaluation process.
actions.markdown: If you’re in a position to make modifications to your company’s recruitment process, make sure to bring in candidates from diverse range of backgrounds through to interviews.

actions.title: Voice your opinions regarding unfair recruitment procedures.
actions.markdown: If you believe a company needs to address its own biased recruitment process, and have even rejected a job offer because of this, take the opportunity to shed some light on workplace discrimination.

paragraphCards.markdown: The world population is 51% male and 49% female, an almost even division.
However, when we take a closer look at companies in any industries, the same equal ratio doesn't apply in leadership in the workplace.
As a matter of fact, reports by the World Economic Forum reveals that 96% of the S&P 500 companies are run by men.
Whether you're the one recruiting or the one looking for a job, there are many ways to promote equality within the workplace.
Start paying attention to the bigger picture, and understand how even a small amount of bias can dramatically affect a business.
Every person you hire can either be an asset or a liability to the company, and it all comes down to decision-making.
Decisions based on favoritism or personal relationships will cost a company a lot of money.
When other employees see someone getting promoted because of connections, not merit, they will leave.
Imagine the price of replacing everyone because of one wrong decision. Avoid expensive mistakes by addressing biased practices and treating everyone fairly.

insights.title: Identify different types of unconscious bias

actions.title: Be wary of treating employees favorably purely because of a personal connection.
actions.markdown: Consider how others might feel (and react) if you show preferential treatment towards one employee, just because you have a personal history or something in common with them.

actions.title: Forget about stereotypes and assumptions.
actions.markdown: Never allow a good first impression or assumptions about certain groups cloud your judgment of a colleague, and hinder you from seeing people for who they really are. Work on building long-term assessments of others, rather than going off your immediate reactions.

actions.title: Be open to new information, even if it contradicts your initial perception.
actions.markdown: Develop a standard system of data evaluation to make it easier for you to think objectively when reviewing your argument, and comparing it to the information that disproves your point.

paragraphCards.markdown: There are five forms of unconscious bias, namely: affinity bias, halo bias, perception bias, confirmation bias, and bandwagon effect.
Affinity bias refers to our tendency to be in favor of people who have something in common with us. It can be someone we went to the same school with, or share interests with.
Failing to see red flags about someone because of a good first impression is called halo bias.

Meanwhile, perception bias is all about our inclination to form assumptions and stereotypes about specific groups, thus making it difficult for us to make objective judgments about people who are part of that group.
When we have initial perceptions, we're likely to disregard opposing viewpoints simply because we don't want to believe that we were wrong all along, which is what confirmation bias is about.
Groupthink, also known as bandwagon effect, occurs when you find yourself conforming to everyone's decision as a desperate attempt to fit in.

insights.title: Accept that we’re all biased in some way--this is the path to overcoming your prejudices

actions.title: Acknowledge your own biased behavior.
actions.markdown: Admit that you have your own fair share of one-sided beliefs, attitude, and behavior and commit to addressing your unconscious bias moving forward.

actions.title: Perceive people as exactly who they are, and not based on stereotypes.
actions.markdown: Forget all about the initial speculations you’ve made in your head and avoid categorizing people based on their race, ethnicity, gender, and other stereotypical factors.

actions.title: Don’t make wrong decisions in an attempt to fit in with the people around you.
actions.markdown: Be aware of when you’re tempted to conform to everyone else’s judgment simply because you’re afraid to be the only one with a different opinion.

paragraphCards.markdown: Studies in cognitive science reveal that our brain only processes 40 out of the 11 million pieces of information we receive every second, meaning that many of our thoughts and beliefs remain unconscious, bubbling away under the surface.
This lack of awareness is what makes us display biased behavior without even realizing it.
Ask anyone if they're prejudiced, or even bigoted--very few will admit to it.
But being ignorant of our own bias makes it even harder for us to make things right.
The first step to conquering unconscious bias is to be aware of our own prejudiced behavior.
It's time to put our egos aside, and admit that we may have made assumptions or decisions based on bias in the past.
Not only this will help us fix the current situation, but it also takes us a step further into making sure it never happens again.
It may seem like unconscious bias is out of our control. But the truth is, biases are knee-jerk reactions, not a final verdict.
Recognize that many of your biases are beliefs taught to you by society at large, and you've been subjected to them from a very early age.
Our thoughts affect our behavior, and our behavior affects the people that surround us.
By recognizing the reality that we're all biased, we can all work together to be more mindful of our thoughts and actions when relating to others.

"Tackling the underlying unconscious bias can be achieved by acknowledging the problem exists, ensuring there is widespread awareness of it, resolving to do something about it, and becoming accountable for your actions."
Making calls based on a biased viewpoint plays havoc with our decision-making process.
It hinders us from making logical decisions that could cause significant damage to our career and life further down the line.
What's worse, we're often so blinded by prejudice that we fail to recognize our own biased beliefs, attitudes, and conduct.
Our unconscious bias shapes the way we perceive the world around us.
Its impact is huge, whether we're victims or perpetrators of it.
It's time to see through this illusion, and remain consciously aware at all times.
Fortunately, diversity expert Stacey Gordon possesses a great understanding of unconscious bias and how to overcome it.
Gordon is a Human Capital and Diversity Consultant with expertise in recruitment. She has spent years working in Fortune 500 companies and non-profit organizations to promote diversity and inclusion.
In this course, she will bring light to the subject of unconscious bias, and how we make significant steps towards addressing inequality and lack of diversity in the workplace.
Learn how to make rational, objective decisions as Stacey Gordon shares how to acknowledge our own unconscious biases, understand the repercussions, and successfully combat prejudice.
Upheaval is definitely for those who are interested in politics and history. There are good lessons to take out of it, but the average person might find it to be a bit of a slow read.
However, one of the greatest takeaways are the 12 Factors to consider when you have an issue - these are definitely applicable to everyday life.

insights.title: Both national and personal problems require examination of 12 factors to find a solution

actions.title: Inspect your problem with the 12 Factors.
actions.markdown: Although the 12 Factors are often applied at national scales, you can steal these tricks to scrutinize your own problems, too. The next time you find yourself stuck in a rut, apply the 12 Factors to your problem to find a solution.

paragraphCards.markdown: Anyone who's reached adulthood has probably experienced some sort of crisis in their time.
Maybe it was an identity crisis of adolescence, or maybe it was at another time of transition such as mid-life or retirement.
Life crises can come on suddenly or gradually, but whatever the reason, it's probably a sign that the way you're approaching life isn't working quite right for you and it's time for a change.
The same thing happens to countries. Sometimes nations rule that their current state of affairs aren't working, and there needs to be a change.
For example, take the estimate that US cities will have a technology crisis every 12 years. As technology changes, infrastructure and systems that keep the city running will quickly become obsolete.
Author Jared Diamond identifies 12 Factors that can help us find a solution, whether it's personal or at a national level:
1) Acknowledging the problem. You can't address a problem if you choose not to see it.
2) Taking responsibility and choosing to respond.
3) Differentiating between what needs to change, and what is important enough to your identity that it shouldn't change. This is also known as selective change.
4) Get help from those around you.
5) Look at the way others have responded to similar crises.
6) Recognizing your identity, whether national or personal.
7) Doing an honest self-appraisal.
8) Recognizing and learning from crises you've experienced in the past.
9) Dealing with failure with patience.
10) Having flexibility.
11) Determining core values.

12) Identifying what is making selective change difficult.  
  
Let's look at history now to see how some of these may apply.

insights.title: We can look at Japan and Germany for ways to find solutions to tough problems

paragraphCards.markdown: Traditionally, Japan has held isolationist views. So naturally, when the US came knocking in the 1850s, demanding access to ports for trading in the Pacific on their shores, Japan wasn't happy.
Many didn't want the deal because there was no benefit to Japan, but others thought it was foolhardy to believe they could continue to be isolated.
This all came to a head when a new leader tried to modernize Japan and open it to foreigners, which led to a coup and a civil war.
The war ended in a new leader, which brought in the Meiji era.
The new leaders soon realized the other leaders were right: Japan couldn't remain isolated, and needed to be modernized to become a respected player on the worldwide stage.
They first acknowledged the problem, then sought out ways to change by having an honest self-assessment.

They made selective changes, such as welcoming Western education and building military power, while keeping much of their tradition. These selective changes happened gradually and took patience, but it prepared them to win their first battle against a Western power when Russia attacked at Tsushima Strait.
Germany also faced a huge crisis following WWII. Millions were lost, the country was divided, and there was a lot of destruction.
Following WWII, Germany was divided into East and West. The East became the Democratic Republic of Germany, which many saw as a more restrictive government, and they fled to the West.
The rest of Europe began to see that the West was no longer a threat and included them in the Marshall Plan, a scheme designed to help European countries recover from war.
Then came selective change for West Germany. They made their own currency and joined the free market.

West Germany also implemented a string of reforms - wanting to make Germany less authoritarian and give women more rights, for example. Chancellor Willy Brandt went on a foreign relations trip asking other nations for forgiveness for the War.
Through West Germany's flexibility and patience, they were eventually able to reunite the country in 1989.

insights.title: The world faces a variety of threats that can only be solved by working together

actions.title: Become a global citizen.
actions.markdown: Nationalism encourages a “your problem, not my problem” attitude, but we must recognize the importance of protecting our planet, not just our nation state. Find the empathy in yourself to become a global citizen, and recycle your plastics!

paragraphCards.markdown: In the book, author Jared Diamond gives five other examples of countries that overcame crises in the modern era. It's impressive to see how nations overcome dire circumstances and become prosperous through selective change.
Today, nations have become so intertangled through globalization that it's more important than ever to look at the crises we face as a planet.
Pressing problems include nuclear weapons, depletion of natural resources, climate change, and unequal wealth distribution, but the question also applies to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Increasing CO2 emissions are causing temperatures to rise globally, causing a myriad of other problems like rising sea levels and killing vital species.
Overfishing and deforestation must also be slowed down if we want the earth to remain sustainable.
Many of these problems can be at least partially fixed by reducing our consumption.
To do this, we all as people on earth must work together to acknowledge the problem, take responsibility, and make selective changes.
This collaboration is the only way we as a world will be able to steer away from the crises we are heading toward.
"Success is not guaranteed to well-intentioned decent people, nor necessarily denied to evil people."
If you've ever been through a tricky situation, you know that getting out takes a lot of discipline.
The solution usually comes through what's known as selective change. That's when you identify the problem and figure out what needs to change and what doesn't.
Running a country through times of crisis requires a similar approach.
Whether we examine the crises of Chile and Indonesia in the 1970s, or Germany and Australia following WWII, we see similar problems with the solutions found through selective change.
In Jared Diamond's Upheaval: Turning Points for Nations in Crisis, we take a fascinating look at seven countries facing crises.
It will surprise you to see how similar problems arise in different countries that seem so different from one another. And you'll be enlightened to discover how each of them solved these issues.
Upheaval enlightens you by telling the stories of seven countries that fell into crises, including how they got there and what they did to get out, identifying the common threads between them all.
If you've got an inquiring mind, you'll love these scenarios and the science that Munroe uses to answer them in What If? This book is funny, educational, and comes highly recommended.

insights.title: If the Sun suddenly stopped pumping its light and energy to us, it wouldn’t be all bad - maybe

paragraphCards.markdown: What are the consequences on Earth if the Sun goes dark without warning? Interestingly, there are actually a few benefits in this situation. ![giphy.com/nasa/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l378xGKOFPkHM2Vxe/giphy.gif)

For one, solar flares wouldn't pose a risk to us anymore. The geomagnetic storms that follow solar flares disrupt Earth's magnetic field.![Magnetosphere\_rendition.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f3/Magnetosphere_rendition.jpg)

In 1859 one such storm sent strong currents through telegraph wires. The extra energy started fires and obliterated communications. ![Coronal\_Cloud\_1.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/72/Coronal_Cloud_1.jpg)
The problem is, we have a lot more wires now, and another storm like that would be devastating to our modern world. Without a Sun, this hazard is no more!
Also, we would save a lot of money in many different places if our Sun were gone.
Take the bridges we use to cross rivers and lakes. Without a Sun, the water freezes so think - we can just drive on it.
That means we don't have to spend money to maintain all those bridges anymore, saving an estimated $20 billion in repairs each year.
We'd also spend significantly less on trade.

Because of our Sun, we have time zones. These differences in time across the world make it hard to conduct business internationally. ![Standard\_Time\_Zones\_of\_the\_World\_(October\_2015).svg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Standard_Time_Zones_of_the_World_%28October_2015%29.svg/640px-Standard_Time_Zones_of_the_World_%28October_2015%29.svg.png)
If we had no Sun, we would all be in the same time zone and have no problem communicating. The global economy would soar with that kind of cost reduction.

All this sounds like fun and games until you realize that without a Sun everybody on earth freezes and dies. It's probably better we keep the Sun around. ![giphy.com/feistmusic/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3ogwG0cKu7x87xU6VG/giphy.gif)

insights.title: You probably don’t want to do what would be necessary to eliminate the common cold

paragraphCards.markdown: Do you remember the last time a cold kept you home from work or school? Although a day off is nice, having a sore throat and fever is no picnic.
Wouldn't you do whatever was necessary to eliminate the chances of ever getting a cold again?" Well, the science doesn't really check out on this being a good idea.

The common cold thrives by spreading from person to person. If we quarantined everyone for a couple of weeks, however, we could starve the virus and it would die. ![giphy.com/originals/](https://media.giphy.com/media/JpdvqUB2xeydKPZA0I/giphy.gif)
Sadly, two weeks is enough time for society to collapse entirely.
Before we get there though, let's look at the medical implications of this scenario.

People with weaker immune systems sometimes carry the cold virus for years. They'd need a lot longer time in quarantine to eradicate this sickness completely. ![giphy.com/butler/](https://media.giphy.com/media/dVuyBgq2z5gVBkFtDc/giphy.gif)

Economically, this decision is devastating to humanity. Our overall annual economic production is roughly $80 trillion. If all industrial activity halted for two weeks, we'd lose trillions of dollars.
Practicality takes the cake for why this is a bad idea. Evenly dividing the world's land area between all people in the world means that each person would be 77 meters away from the next.

While this is enough to stop the sickness, some people will have to stand in the tundra or scalding desert and that doesn't work so well. ![giphy.com/IntoAction/](https://media.giphy.com/media/kEWZESFn7G0NCMEhTr/giphy.gif)

insights.title: If you believe in having a random soulmate, chances are you’ll never find love because almost nobody will

paragraphCards.markdown: Do you believe that you have a soulmate out there just waiting for you to find them and fall in love? ![giphy.com/balazsvarga/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6EhIYtN8Q7TKZs2Y/giphy.gif)
You're going to want to think again about that idea after learning about the math behind it.
Even with the assumption that our soulmate lives at the same time we do, the odds of ever meeting them are wildly small.
Let's also say that locking eyes is the requirement to find your soulmate, and you did that every day with about 24 new people.
Over an estimated 60-year lifetime, the math gives you meeting eyes with about 50,000 people. ![giphy.com/americangods/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oKIPq6NYrAn4P5dPG/giphy.gif)
About seven billion people live on earth. Whittling down our options of preferred sex and age, we come out with about 500 million potential soulmates.
Arithmetic on these numbers gives us about 10,000 of our estimated 60-year lifetimes to make eye contact with every possible soulmate.
Let's then say that this was true and society had to change to accommodate the idea of the soulmate. ![giphy.com/Barbara\_Pozzi/](https://media.giphy.com/media/LwHaQCGZMdD9Ghalrl/giphy.gif)
Even if we could chat with potential soulmates for a large part of our days, it would take decades for everyone to find the one.
"Remember: I am a cartoonist. If you follow my advice on safety around nuclear materials, you probably deserve whatever happens to you." \[Randall Munroe\]

What do you think would happen if someone threw a baseball at 90% the speed of light? Do you know how fast you can hit a speed bump and still live? Or have you ever thought about how much force Yoda actually outputs in Star Wars? ![giphy.com/starwars/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7abBAEIlO4kWucQ8/giphy.gif)

If you've ever wondered what would happen if some of the craziest and most impossible events actually happened, you're not alone. What do you get if a former NASA roboticist opens up his website to field wacky questions and answer them with science? That's where Randall Munroe comes in. ![giphy.com/teamcoco](https://media.giphy.com/media/iFm6NS9rTpld4j0dXo/giphy.gif)

He is the author of the webcomic xkcd, which also hosts his "What If?" platform. Anyone can submit any question they can think of to his site, and Munroe uses real scientific principles to answer his favorites. ![giphy.com/channel/donohoe](https://media.giphy.com/media/xTk9ZE94CfWTe2fzMI/giphy.gif)

A few years ago, some of the best questions and answers were compiled into a book called What If?: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions. If you like science and you like humor, you're going to love this one.

What If is a compilation of well-researched, science-based answers to some of the craziest hypothetical questions you can imagine. ![Randall\_Munroe\_ducks.JPG](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Randall_Munroe_ducks.JPG/514px-Randall_Munroe_ducks.JPG)

Who Cares Wins is a crucial book that's straight to the point and easy to follow. It covers a wide range of topics at the forefront of the climate crisis debate, all backed up by interviews with some of the most important people on the hunt for change.
Whether it's energy, fashion, politics, or meat and dairy, this book can feed you all the facts you need to walk away and make a thorough, educated decision for yourself.
In her book, Lily Cole is here to pave the way to a greener, longer future for us all.

insights.title: With consumption driving our climate crisis, we need to buy less stuff

actions.title: Just buy less.
actions.markdown: Buy one expensive coat that lasts ten years, not ten cheap ones; sharpen your knives when they’re blunt, don’t replace them; learn DIY to make your own and to repair what breaks; avoid single-use plastic in place of cotton shopping bags and steel water bottles.

actions.title: Buy better quality.
actions.markdown: Stop wearing synthetic fibres, such as polyester and nylon. Organic cotton produces up to 94% less greenhouse gas than its non-organic alternative, as well as removing the risks that come from pesticides to both its farmers and the land.

actions.title: Eat local, organic and seasonal.
actions.markdown: Organic, pesticide-free vegetables may cost more - but still less than meat. Treat yourself to the array of alternative fruits and vegetables available to you, and save meat and cheese for only really special occasions. Your appreciation for them will go up tenfold.

paragraphCards.markdown: "How much do we need individual change; how much system change? How responsible are we? Sometimes it feels like you can't even breathe without stealing oxygen." \[Lily Cole\]

Most of us believe that the extent of our political contribution comes when we vote every few years, but that really isn't the case. [giphy.com/a24](https://media.giphy.com/media/26gJyIRlH6ctt3cvS/giphy.mp4)
Every small decision we make in the way we live our lives shapes our political, economic and social reality.
And the principal way that we ourselves get involved in politics is by speaking the universal language of money.
Consumption is one of the driving forces behind global warming. [giphy.com/xponentialdesign](https://media.giphy.com/media/1zKRbqUmytgKKjTqtY/giphy.mp4)
Companies are run on the basis of just selling as much as they can, whilst we are being told to buy more and more 'stuff'.
And so the question remains - can we really shop our way out of crisis?
Does change stem from each of us saying 'no' to certain products and manufacturing methods, and 'yes' to B-Corps and eco-friendly alternatives?
There are three main culprits in this battle of consumerism, and awareness for the damage all three are causing has shot up over the last few years.

1.  **Fashion:** More people are boycotting brands with sweatshops that exploit poorer people in foreign countries (notably women and children). [giphy.com/kinolorber](https://media.giphy.com/media/brp0hqL4KnGc8/giphy.mp4)
Instead of shipping clothes from all over the world to be worn once and discarded, we're switching to sustainable brands that use eco-friendly materials.
2.  **Food:** Animal agriculture generates more greenhouse gases than all forms of transportation combined. [giphy.com/mootvideo](https://media.giphy.com/media/NRu2pvPwPRWHLNb3e5/giphy.mp4)
One study at the University of Oxford concluded that avoiding meat and dairy is the 'single biggest' way to reduce environmental impact on the planet. Maybe going vegan isn't such a bad plan.
3.  **Plastic:** We produce 300 million tons of the stuff every year, over a quarter of which ends up in the ocean. [giphy.com/bbcearth](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o752df1BeOvfwxuzS/giphy.mp4)

Plastic takes a lot of oil to manufacture, contains toxic materials, and takes a long time to degrade - some scientists estimate up to 1,000 years - so thankfully we're starting to switch to multi-use alternatives instead.
Being 'environmentally-friendly' can seem like a pricey way to live, but ask yourself not why sustainability is so expensive, but how the rest of it can possibly be so cheap?

insights.title: By 2050, we should be off fossil fuels altogether

paragraphCards.markdown: The biggest cause of global warming has been, and remains to be, the burning of fossil fuels.
One or two degrees doesn't sound like much, but for the Earth, it can have massive consequences. [giphy.com/bbcamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/j2BdFX4ds8yIVcSXyM/giphy.mp4)
Therefore, one of the main changes we're starting to see is the development and widespread use of renewable energy.
We once used water and windmills across the countryside, growing food in greenhouses with sunlight and burning wood for warmth - and now we're turning back to these natural sources for help.
Wind power now generates 4% of all global electric power and Iceland, a frontrunner in the sustainable energy game, runs almost entirely off geo-thermal energy.
People used to believe that it was a luxury to go renewable but things are changing rapidly. [giphy.com/ge](https://media.giphy.com/media/OnavQV9tvZVks/giphy.mp4)
As VP of Environment, Policy and Social Initiatives at Apple, Lisa Jackson, says, "One of the great things right now about clean energy is that it's actually cheaper than dirty energy."

The cost of solar panels has dropped by 99% and the number of companies branching out into the industry is increasing. [giphy.com/neweconomy](https://media.giphy.com/media/fsiPKqstShACDBbie0/giphy.mp4)
Scientists at Stanford University have predicted that the world could run off 100% renewable energy by 2050. However to reach a goal like that requires united political intervention.
Governments will have to enforce strict targets for companies to hit if we're going to transform the globe.
The future of our energy sources will need to become comparable to that of healthcare or education. [giphy.com/subpoprecords](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6EhStHFJ6qXFrWKs/giphy.mp4)
Given that $100 billion was spent on the Apollo space programme but only $3 billion has been put into solar panel research and development, there's definitely some room for improvement.

insights.title: The solution lies not only in sustainability, but a shift in mindset

actions.title: Be mindful and stay present.
actions.markdown: When you find yourself stressing about work or finances, take a moment to breathe. Center yourself and consider the greater relevance of such a thing. The world is a vast thing with seven billion people on it - never forget that.

actions.title: Be loving of Mother Nature.
actions.markdown: Try to be grateful for nature in all its glory. When you eat a vegetable, look at where in the world it came from; picture the country and imagine the person who picked it for you. Reconnect mentally with the Earth to gain a greater understanding of its physical importance.

paragraphCards.markdown: We as humans live according to sociological concepts that we ourselves created; countries divided up into nations, and functioning upon the exchange of money.
But what if the world ran without money?

What if the economy did not dictate our ability to function, but instead something else - perhaps a Gross National Happiness (GNH) as is implemented in Bhutan? [giphy.com/historyuk](https://media.giphy.com/media/j4kLBF1Nya5Iq9NGrX/giphy.mp4)
Human beings are wired to be givers.
When we do something entirely out of kindness, our brains release oxytocin (the 'love hormone') which in turn produces a natural high.

Like penguins that huddle for warmth or birds that fly together and take turns fighting the wind, for us too, generosity is a survival instinct. [giphy.com/bbcamerica](https://media.giphy.com/media/8cH8HXyEp5fBBDqKVv/giphy.mp4)

Homo sapiens used to run off a gift economy: by trading 'gifts' based on trust of reciprocation, rather than monetary transactions. The idea of 'private property' is, after all, a relatively new concept.
Perhaps now we must look to our past in order to find solutions for the future. [giphy.com/lazoo](https://media.giphy.com/media/4QFBn7Or4Qw43x6qVs/giphy.mp4)
Western society always thought itself superior, having 'discovered' a 'new world' - as though the indigenous people already there were just part of the scenery.
But now, as we find ourselves heading into a mass extinction, we are looking to these indigenous ways of living to improve.

To manage our land and interact sustainably with nature, and to focus much, much less on the materialistic things that have dominated our lives. [youtube.com/c/NatGeo/](https://media.giphy.com/media/k5kbTIJ8BhziIpKsDt/giphy.mp4)
"The most important part of a move towards sustainability begins in our hearts and minds: in the way we see the world, one another, and our place within the whole." \[Lily Cole\]
Life is short. Time is our most precious possession. [giphy.com/butler](https://media.giphy.com/media/37QOWrwGOljUCbdDxd/giphy.mp4)
If it's time we want to keep, then we need to reconnect with the world around us. Only then will we realize our responsibility to save it.
This may not be the end - just like we used to believe the Earth was flat, there is still so much we don't know. But is it a risk we're willing to take?

"If you put a frog in boiling water it will jump out, but if you put a frog in warm water and slowly heat it to boiling point, the frog will stay until its end. Our planet is slowly warming around us, and yet we haven't jumped." \[Lily Cole\]

We've all heard about the dangerous state our planet is in. Every time we turn on the news, we're bombarded with talk about global warming, dying species, melting ice caps and burning forests. Many would consider this the moment to panic - but not Lily Cole.

Lily Cole was well-known in the fashion industry as a model before breaking into film as an actress. ![Lily Cole, London, 6 June 2013 (cropped).jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Lily_Cole%2C_London%2C_6_June_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg/504px-Lily_Cole%2C_London%2C_6_June_2013_%28cropped%29.jpg)
But perhaps what many don't know is that she also graduated with honors from Cambridge University, campaigns for various charities, and is a devoted activist for the environment.

In her book, Who Cares Wins, Cole interviews people across different industries who are committing their lives to creating a more sustainable future. [giphy.com/xponentialdesign](https://media.giphy.com/media/ZeXNzr0So7owKIeAeL/giphy.mp4)
She explores constructive methods for facing these challenges head-on, from fast fashion to the food crisis.
In this book, Cole explains why, despite the fear and unpredictability of it all, there is still cause for optimism. [youtube.com/user/MarieClaireTV](https://youtu.be/2IsSUBK_ffg?t=11.14&e=26.00)

In Who Cares Wins, actress and activist Lily Cole presents a comprehensive walkthrough of the problems the Earth faces today, highlighting changes that must be made both by individuals and the systems that govern our way of life.

Reni Eddo-Lodge has given us a sobering look at why uncomfortable conversations about structural racism are critical between people of color and white people, as well as between white people themselves.

insights.title: Recognizing systemic racism in Britain can be difficult if you don’t know its history

paragraphCards.markdown: Many white Brits deny that structural racism still exists in the United Kingdom. That's at least partly due to the lack of Black history education in Britain.
Colonialism, imperial conquest, and Britain's participation in the trans-Atlantic slave trade laid the foundation for systems of racial oppression that persist today.

Thousands of enslaved people from Africa were trafficked through British ports.![Slaveshipposter.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Slaveshipposter.jpg/406px-Slaveshipposter.jpg)
Because few slaves were kept within the isles, a lot of people are unaware of the extent to which Britain built its Caribbean and North American colonies and wealth on slavery.
Britain began trading enslaved people in 1562 and the act abolishing slavery was introduced in 1833. This means that slavery was commonplace for a longer period of time than it has been illegal.

The subjugation and exploitation of people of color wasn't kept to Africans.![IJzeren voetring voor gevangenen transparent background.png](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9e/IJzeren_voetring_voor_gevangenen_transparent_background.png)
Under British colonial rule, more than a million Indian subjects were enlisted to fight for the Crown during World War I with the understanding that India would gain its independence in return.

The promise wasn't kept, and more than 70,000 Indian soldiers died in a war in which their highest rank was not equal to the lowest white soldier's.![IndianArmyMGCrewFlanders1914-15.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fc/IndianArmyMGCrewFlanders1914-15.jpg)

After World War II the government actively encouraged people in former colonies to immigrate to the UK, but controls were later put in place after racial tensions began to rise rather than address the root problem.

insights.title: To create a truly inclusive society white people have to talk about white privilege

actions.title: Have hard conversations.
actions.markdown: Make a point of talking with other people in your private and professional life about racism.

paragraphCards.markdown: "When I talk about white privilege, I don't mean that white people have it easy, that they've never struggled, or that they've never lived in poverty. But white privilege is the fact that if you're white, your race will almost certainly positively impact your life's trajectory in some way." [Reni Eddo-Lodge]
By now, we've all heard the phrase white privilege.[https:youtube.com/channel/UCejYxz_-OD7ApJniESN1Rpg/](https://youtu.be/ZLgbw_A1mLI?t=5.52&e=95.63)
But what is privilege, how do we recognize it, and how do we talk about it with poor whites who feel the effects of classism?
At its core white privilege is the absence of difficulties in life that are direct results of skin color.[youtube.com/c/audiblecouk](https://youtu.be/fvJak1vkbIE?t=22.48&e=73.81)
As the cultural default in countries like Britain and the United States, whiteness is the lens through which social standards are seen and set.
White privilege simply means that no matter how hard life may be for a white person, skin color doesn't add an extra barrier to their opportunities.
If you're white, people may look at you askance for all kinds of reasons, but not because of your skin color.

Most white people go through life never having to consider how their color affects their daily activities, let alone major opportunities like college or career paths.[giphy.com/valparaiso-university/](https://media.giphy.com/media/TgGXTXZXsh4gmwar5X/giphy.mp4)
Part of the reason that white privilege is so hard for many white people to understand is that they don't talk about it in close relationships.
Even in progressive white circles where racism is discussed, people sometimes claim they 'don't see color'.

But color-blindness is only possible in a world where people of color are treated as full equals, and people of color know differently.[giphy.com/sarahwintner/](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUA7bjwn4QH5i0XbWw/giphy.mp4)

insights.title: White people need to understand the intersections of oppression

actions.title: Be an ally.
actions.markdown: White people can help by financially or administratively supporting anti-racism organizations run by people of color.

actions.title: Intervene when needed.
actions.markdown: Step in if necessary in bystander situations.

actions.title: Don’t just perform anti-racism.
actions.markdown: Take concrete political action rather than simply liking or sharing material on social media.

paragraphCards.markdown: There are plenty of working-class white people who keenly feel that they are less-than, pushed down by a crushing economic system. How do you tell them that they're still privileged?

"It is an absence of funny looks directed at you because you're believed to be in the wrong place, an absence of cultural expectations... an absence of a lifetime of subtle marginalisation and othering – exclusion from the narrative of being human." [Reni Eddo-Lodge]
Talking about intersectionality may help. [youtube.com/user/nph32/](https://youtu.be/O1islM0ytkE?t=0.00&e=26.47)

It takes a willingness to listen, but it's important to explain that although people may experience classism, they don't have to contend with racism on top of it. [giphy.com/YWCA_Australia/](https://media.giphy.com/media/wJssrr9sIMW4V6DuMK/giphy.mp4)
It's the intersection of multiple forms of oppression from different roots that compound the Black and ethnic minority experience of structural racism.
A Black woman, for example, likely has experienced sexism as well as racism and possibly classism. [giphy.com/news/](https://media.giphy.com/media/Fi6xxHyuoX0fDJhzUK/giphy.mp4)
Working-class white people still hold a privileged place in society - as bad as it may feel - merely because of their skin color. And we have to keep talking about it.

Some white people talk about seeing the end of racism, as if it's a foregone conclusion, but people of color know it's not.[giphy.com/magnoliapics/](https://media.giphy.com/media/idjBBvVzvOjF71kFJ6/giphy.mp4)

Changes are incremental and anyone who wants to contribute to the anti-racist movement has to be in it 'for the long haul'.[giphy.com/magnoliapics/](https://media.giphy.com/media/TJskE3ITo4nRtgpqj2/giphy.mp4)

"The default is white. Because we are born into an already written script that tells us what to expect from strangers due to their skin colour, accents and social status, the whole of humanity is coded as white." [Reni Eddo-Lodge]
"How can I define white privilege? It's so difficult to describe an absence. And white privilege is an absence of the negative consequences of racism." \[Reni Eddo-Lodge\]
There are a lot of buzzwords and phrases in the popular discourse on racism: anti-racism, white privilege, intersectionality.
But what do these terms really mean, and what do they signify in personal terms as well as the larger social context?
For white people, these words can have deep meaning or none at all.[giphy.com/nowthis/](https://media.giphy.com/media/cLx03sF3GvU8nCCIgR/giphy.mp4)
For people of color like Reni Eddo-Lodge, these are facets of society that they experience every day through the systemic racism that exists in the United Kingdom and countries like it.
Reni Eddo-Lodge is a London-based journalist, activist, author and speaker on anti-racism.[youtube.com/c/foyles/](https://youtu.be/2vJZdeSqfFY?t=0.00&e=10.62)
What began as a fed-up blog post in 2014 has now blown up into a larger, positive, and continuing conversation about structural racism in the UK.
Why I'm No Longer Talking to White People About Race is a personal yet deeply researched book about why conversations with and between white people about race are crucial to social change.

payload.title: Why I’m No Longer Talking to White People About Race

paragraphCards.markdown: Whether you are a manager of a call centre looking to improve your service or a newby waiter trying to aim for customer satisfaction and healthy tips, Working with Upset Customers by Jeff Toister will help you deal with angry customers, learn from them, and improve your service.
When you know that the trick is always to defuse the situation, you'll quickly learn to handle these situations calmly and politely.
The customer may not always be right, but they'll react much better if you treat them as if they were!

insights.title: There’s little victory in proving a customer wrong

actions.title: Empathize, but don’t patronize.
actions.markdown: Empathize with the customer because it validates their feelings, but do not go so far as to be condescending and belittling; this compromises your position.

paragraphCards.markdown: "The customer might be wrong, but it's our job to help them be right." \[Jeff Toister\]
Unfortunately, the customer really is always right. Proving a customer wrong will only damage future relationships, and it can even hurt your business.
Therefore, when customers complain, it doesn't help to take it personally. Try to avoid doing so.
When humans are confronted with a threatening situation, our flight or fight response kicks in.
When an angry customer confronts you with a problem, you might experience physical symptoms like a red and hot face or sweaty palms.
The key is to catch these symptoms before your anger boils over. If you can calm yourself down, you can deal with the customer's problem constructively.
The best tactic to use when the customer confronts you is to Acknowledge and Refocus.

Acknowledge what the customer has said, and empathize with them. This makes the customer feel heard, and should immediately defuse the situation, because you're taking them seriously and paying attention.
Refocus by moving the conversation in the direction of a solution. By doing this you distract the customer from their anger, instead showing them that you want to help.
However, there's still a difference between customer anger and abuse, and where to draw the line.
The key things to look out for are when a customer starts yelling, swearing, threatening, trying to intimidate, or even initiating physical contact.
Your safety takes priority over customers' issues. Call in security or a superior if you are face-to-face.
If abuse happens over email, on social media, or a review site, always remain professional and do not engage. Their behavior reflects on them, and not you.

insights.title: Learn, grow, and recover from angry customers

actions.title: Introduce LAURA.
actions.markdown: Be the best customer services representative you can be with LAURA: Listen, Acknowledge their issue, Understand why they are angry, Relate to their pain, and Act by providing a solution.

paragraphCards.markdown: Always try to preserve relationships with customers. Bad reviews are bad for business and can direct future customers away from you.
Maintaining relationships should not just be about preventing bad reviews - it should also be about personal and professional achievement.
When you are faced with an angry customer, introduce them to your alter ego, the LAURA process, and refocus them by moving the conversation towards a productive solution.
Listen to the customer, Acknowledge their issue, Understand why they are angry, Relate to their pain, and Act by providing a solution.
By being a good LAURA, and refocusing the situation, you de-escalate the customer's anger and end the interaction on a positive note.
Once the issue has been partially or completely resolved, complete an After Action Review. Replay the scene in your head or reread the correspondence and focus on your behavior.
View your actions through the customer's eyes and try to see where you might have escalated their anger. Then choose how you would act differently if you could redo the whole thing.
By reviewing yourself and taking note of how you could improve past situations you can improve your customer service for future situations.
Improving your customer service can also have other benefits such as promotions and training opportunities.
Now you need to implement change to avoid future problems.
Draw up a list of customer complaints and group them into: 1) Unexpected errors or surprises; 2) Waiting time; 3) Confusion; 4) Effort required by the product or service; and 5) Repeat follow ups).
Come up with solutions tailored to each problem.
For Waiting, alter the customer's perception of time with offers like free breadsticks at restaurants; for Confusion, have step by step tutorials available.
Some problems require a lot of effort to solve, but the end result is always worth it.

insights.title: Improve your service to prevent future incidents

actions.title: Say their name.
actions.markdown: Use their name in conversation; this shows the customer that you consider them to be special, and care about them and their needs.

paragraphCards.markdown: It is difficult to be angry with someone who is utterly reasonable.
Building connections with customers is the key to a friendlier and more relaxed environment that is not conducive towards anger.
Introduce yourself by name and ask for theirs. Greet them and offer your help. Repeat this with every customer like they are your first of the day.
A waiter who is helpful and shows genuine interest in their customer's experience is not going to suffer for the kitchen's mistake.
"If you say 'I'll get right back to you', customers will think you'll get back to them in minutes, even if you really meant a few hours." \[Jeff Toister\]
The easiest way for a customer to get angry is for them to think they have not received the level of service that they think they have paid for.
The best way to negate this issue is to avoid getting their hopes up.
If your company has a 5-7 day delivery, then tell the customer their package will arrive within seven days. If it arrives on day seven, they're happy; if it arrives on day five, they're ecstatic.

Words like 'no', 'you should have...', 'it's policy', or using the word 'you' in an accusatorial manner are triggers. They put the blame on the customer which makes them feel attacked, and react angrily.
Always try to de-escalate the situation. Practice vocabulary that does not include trigger words.
Try out statements like 'I'm afraid not' instead of 'no', 'let's look at alternatives…', 'unfortunately the company works in such a way that…'
Explain the issue instead of blaming policy, the company, or the customer. This shows the customer that you are on their side, and prevents them from getting angry.
"What matters most is three things. Did you do your best? Did you learn from your experience? And did you give your next customer the best service possible?" \[Jeff Toister\]
Customers can be difficult to work with. They get angry, upset, embarrassed, and take it out on who they think should be responsible: you.
Working with Upset Customers is the perfect course for anyone who operates within a business that has deals directly with customers.

Whether you're a consultant at Sephora, a waiter at the local diner, a doctor improving his bedside manner, or an HR manager at a big corporation looking to improve staff training, there's lots to be learned from this course.
