Toister designed this course to help people deal with real-world upset and angry customers. l Working with Upset Customers will help you upskill your customer service abilities with practical tips that can be easily and immediately implemented.
This course unpacks ways that will make customer service more enjoyable for the customer and for you.
You'll learn how to deal with angry customers, grow from those experiences, and work proactively to prevent future problems.

In Working with Upset Customers, customer service extraordinaire Jeff Toister teaches you the best methods for dealing with angry customers, growing from the experience, and improving your future service.
We get why You Are A Badass is such a massive hit. It's 90% motivation with 10% tactics and calls to action, thrown in at the very end.
You'll get really revved up and ready to go – and then you're let off your leash. [giphy.com/fusemedia](https://media.giphy.com/media/3JUgWJVdDnqypTAmQC/giphy.mp4)
What a wonderful way of setting other people up for success.
Thumbs up from us, Mrs. Sincero! ![giphy.com/thegoodplace/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3M7pmsN2jp9lAV9QTG/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Decide you’ll stop caring what other people think, right now

actions.title: Prioritize your time.
actions.markdown: It’s easy to get caught up in others’ plans, but try not to let other people dictate your time. If you’ve planned to go running or have a writing deadline to hit, commit to your plans rather than getting distracted by others. Other people’s plans can wait, but your goals cannot.

paragraphCards.markdown: If people say they don't have time for you, it just means that other things are more important to them. ![giphy.com/davidmichaelchandler](https://media.giphy.com/media/JcZzoAcTjUZ2/giphy.gif)
We've never forgotten this lesson.

How you choose to spend your time is entirely up to you, so how you distribute it reflects your true priorities, no matter what you claim they might be. ![giphy.com/davidmichaelchandler](https://media.giphy.com/media/BpqVyj6K1UvoA/giphy.gif)

Naturally, chasing a distant dream of yours infers choosing yourself over others – and that always creates some fallout. ![giphy.com/davidmichaelchandler](https://media.giphy.com/media/g2WMZ96xTgfF6/giphy.gif)
If you're aspiring to be a writer, some of the comfort you usually get from hanging out with friends will have to come from appreciating the time you now spend writing.
Being serious means putting in days, months, years of work. ![giphy.com/Jesscoutureart/](https://media.giphy.com/media/jU8yHwHSAoHvepN65t/giphy.gif)
You'll lose some friends. You'll go to less happy hours and football games.
You'll be laughed at. Ridiculed. Made fun of.
But none of that matters if you're happy spending time chasing what others don't dare to.
To really go for your dream, you must put your inner badass in charge. ![giphy.com/daianaruiz/](https://media.giphy.com/media/l0HU5udGEkuf7w9nW/giphy.gif)

insights.title: Figure out what you want but don’t obsess about how you’ll get there

actions.title: Get comfortable talking about your goal.
actions.markdown: Most of us have a secret dream we aspire to. But we think it’s time you started talking about it. The more you talk about your dream, the more you’ll think about it - and soon you’ll be planning how to achieve it.

paragraphCards.markdown: Imagine you want to become a writer.
Here's how most people go about that particular dream:
Realize they want to be a writer.
Analyze every writer that inspires them in detail, learn about their paths to success and craft a master plan of which track they can follow.
Give up after six months of analysis paralysis and not writing a single word.
That's the kind of trap you should try to avoid at all costs. Jen Sincero suggests doing so by figuring out what you want, but not obsessing over how you'll get there.

Here's an updated plan for becoming a writer:

Realize you want to be a writer.

Start writing. ![giphy.com/pellyeah/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oz8xUJ4NQsJw9CjW8/giphy.gif)
There really isn't much more to it. Imagine making your way through a poorly trodden forest.
You'll find and shape your own path as you go along.

The most reassuring thing you can do to get the confidence to call yourself a writer is write, not seek comfort from other writers. ![giphy.com/universalafrica/](https://media.giphy.com/media/3gVFahaxjc8RJSKIrR/giphy.gif)
Over time, with more and more hours of writing practice put in, you'll get into a virtuous cycle that positively reinforces your attitude – and thus gets you to write even more.
This is what actually lets you make progress towards your goal. Not planning, or debating, or strategizing.

insights.title: If your habits, surroundings and friends don’t support you, it’s time to change them

paragraphCards.markdown: Having the thick skin to deal with the ridicule of friends or shooting down their tempting attempts to distract you is one thing.
Making a conscious decision to actually get rid of some of the weights that are dragging you down is another.
That's tough.
If your environment, your habits, your friends, even your family, don't lift you up in your journey towards a life you'll be glad to have lived when it's over, it's time to make some changes.
Those can be internal and external, as long as they shift the focus of your life towards making your dream the center piece.
For example, if playing Bubble Blast for 30 minutes every morning over breakfast is something you enjoy, but that cuts into your writing time.
So, maybe you can shave off the last ten minutes in exchange for recording a voice memo you'll transcribe later in your day.

Similarly, if an old friend you see once a month spends most of your conversation time mocking your writing attempts, maybe that's an hour a month you can save and, well, dedicate to writing instead. ![giphy.com/carlottanotaro/](https://media.giphy.com/media/pOZhmE42D1WrCWATLK/giphy.gif)
We're not saying these decisions are easy.

Yet, we have a hunch Jen Sincero's "You Are A Badass"  is onto something that'll absolutely minimize the number of regrets we have at the end of our lives – and that's a good thing. ![giphy.com/latewithlilly](https://media.giphy.com/media/f6bORR19YZJTDChwFX/giphy.gif)
"You are responsible for what you say and do. You are not responsible for whether or not people freak out about it." \[Jen Sincero\]
One thing we like about aging is that with each year, we care less about what people think.
We've always wondered why old people are so direct and unapologetic, but we believe that's why.

They've been around long enough that reality has reassured them countless times: opinions don't matter. Especially not those of haters. ![giphy.com/austinmahone/](https://media.giphy.com/media/hrj7zKa5WUTOixOl5j/giphy.gif)

The sad thing about learning this lesson only late in life is that you might not have the energy or time to still achieve your dream, whatever that may be. ![giphy.com/davidmichaelchandler/](https://media.giphy.com/media/zeaPZlJ241ecE/giphy.gif)
So the sooner you learn it, the better.
If you're young and worried about what other people think, this book is for you.
Enter Jen Sincero, who's seriously rebellious and rebelling seriously against humdrum life.
After working for a record label, starting a rock band, failing, and then writing a book about that, before ultimately coaching people to improve their sex lives and later their lives altogether.
You Are A Badass is the culmination of several years of helping people transform their lives from loser to happy-go-lucky and it comes packed with fun stories and valuable lessons.
Ready to discover your inner badass and put them in charge? Let's go!

You Are A Badass helps you become self-aware, figure out what you want in life and then summon the guts to not worry about the how, kick others' opinions to the curb and focus your life on the thing that will make you happy.

You'll See It When You Believe It is a powerful reminder of how real joy comes from within, not outside ourselves. The future is yours for the taking. With any luck, you'll now feel excited to start using the key insights from this book, and feel empowered to make every day more productive!

insights.title: Forget about changing your lifestyle or appearance; true self-improvement comes from expanding your mind

actions.title: Reconsider those New Year’s resolutions.
actions.markdown: Make self-improvement as much of a goal as shedding a few pounds. Instead of trying to change the number you see on the scale, work on improving your knowledge. You’ve found your way to Uptime, so you’ve made a good start.

paragraphCards.markdown: Most people get excited about changing themselves every year, and set the goals to do so.
Usually, "goal-setting" translates to trying to get healthier. Just consider how just mentioning the word "goals" makes you think of weight loss.
This leads to gyms full of people trying to lose weight or get fit, at least for a couple of weeks.
When we do this, we not only fail to reach our desired result, we also fail to focus on the most important part of improving ourselves-our mind.
If we only think of people as a group of bones and organs, everyone is exactly the same. The reality is, we're each far more than what we can see with the eye.
Your body is only 1% of who you are.
You can't see, touch, or smell the 99% of your personality that's made up of your thoughts and feelings. This is the only place where true, deep, and lasting personal development is possible.
Instead of trying to set goals to go to the gym more often, look for ways you can take your mind for a daily workout.
Trying to improve your thoughts will have a far greater impact on the growth you're looking for.
There will always be a limit to how fast you can run, or how much weight you can lose. But the potential progress within your higher consciousness has no bounds.

insights.title: To make your biggest dreams become reality, focus first on nourishing your thoughts

actions.title: Make self-belief a daily practice.
actions.markdown: Write out affirmations on a piece of paper, and stick them somewhere you’ll see often. Repeat these affirmations to yourself. You can even start a gratitude journal - remind yourself of how far you’ve come.

paragraphCards.markdown: Look around you. What do you see? Where do you live? What are you doing every day?
Take a close look. The objects you own, the actions you take, and the person you are - they're all the result of a thought you once had.
Your career, for example, is the result of a decision you made when picking a certain major in college. And you had the idea to apply for the job you're in, which is why you're there.
The root of all life experiences and changes is thoughts. If you want a different life, one where your wildest dreams are reality, you need to focus on improving your thinking.
Improving your thinking takes a few simple steps.
First, you must identify how everything you can do will first originate from a thought.
The vision you create in your brain is the beginning of getting what you want. So, focus on what you desire.
The next step is to start believing that everything you need to make your desired future happen already exists. It's all there; you only need to discover how to use it.
After that, you must will your thoughts to become reality. You need the resolve to move or quit your job, for instance.
Last comes letting go of the fear of failure. Realize that as long as you're willing to work for the future you want, you can never fail.

insights.title: Believe that your achievements have no limits, break through your invisible boundaries, and reach your full potential

actions.title: Adopt an abundance mentality.
actions.markdown: See the world for what it is: loaded with possibility. To harness these opportunities, you just have to take a little initiative. Don’t wait around for change to find you; you have to proactively seek it out yourself.

paragraphCards.markdown: Would you say that you're dedicating your life to what you love?
The sad truth is that your job probably isn't something you're crazy about. It only places limits on what you can do, wear, and become.
Your job restricts your freedom, and that's no fun. But how did you get here in the first place?
The problem is that you have a scarcity mindset. This means focusing only on what you lack in life instead of what you have.

One of the most common manifestations of this mentality is in phrases like: "I'll be happier when I have \[blank\]." You can probably already think of something you're filling in that blank with, whether it's money, time, or something else.

The job you're in might make you unhappy because you have a scarcity mindset around money, for example. You're simply afraid you won't have enough financial security without your awful job, so you keep it and limit yourself.
Stop limiting what you can achieve with a scarcity mindset. Instead, have an abundance mentality by focusing on the endless possibilities around you.
Recognize that the universe is infinite, and so is your mind. Nothing is impossible. All it takes is a little belief to make your dream life a reality.
Start by being grateful for everything you have. You'll soon realize that there isn't much scarcity in your life, so you might as well start focusing on abundance!
"We think as we choose, and we are what we think. Not what we eat, what we think."
Self-improvement is a popular topic these days. It makes sense, too. We'd all like to become happier, slimmer, and better all around.
Unfortunately, as you're well aware, even if you put in the work, it doesn't necessarily lead to fulfillment.
This isn't not your fault. It's simply a matter of focusing on changing the wrong things.
The truth is, you can't be significantly happier just by getting a toned body or a new job.
Trying to change your life with these external sources of happiness won't work. That's because real joy comes from within yourself.
The personal growth you seek really begins with changing your mind.
Wayne Dyer's book You'll See It When You Believe It teaches you every step you need to make this metamorphosis happen.
Learn how to let go of what's holding you back, and tap into the true source of change for the better.

You'll See It When You Believe It shows you how to discover your true, best self - revealing how the power of your mind can be used to find peace with yourself, the people around you, and the universe.
